Planting of spring wheat for this year's harvest was 75 percent completed, 10 points ahead of the normal pace, the report said. Seeding was complete in South Dakota and almost finished in Idaho. Planting was 62 percent completed in North Dakota, three percentage points ahead of normal. The weather facility is operated jointly by the Agriculture and Commerce departments. Weekly reports about weather and crop conditions do not include production estimates or forecasts.

The Agriculture Department has given the Soviet Union another go-ahead to buy more U.S. grain. Undersecretary Richard T. Crowder said Tuesday that Moscow now has permission to buy up to 22 million metric tons of U.S. grain without further consultations, an increase of 2 million tons. A long-term grain agreement between the two countries specified initially that Moscow could buy up to 12 million tons of grain a year without further U.S. approval. That limit was raised to 16 million tons last October and to 20 million tons in December. The new limit of 22 million tons applies to the 12-month period that began last Oct. 1. The agreement itself runs through Dec. 31. Officials said the increase in the ``consultation level'' of the agreement resulted from talks with the Soviets in recent days and also takes into consideration recent large purchases of corn by Moscow. In all, since Oct. 1, the Soviet Union has bought about 18.9 million tons of corn and wheat for delivery in 1989-90. Those orders include more than 15.6 million tons of corn and 3.3 million tons of wheat. Purchases also include 342,300 tons of soybeans, 1.2 million tons of soybean meal, and 7,300 tons of barley. In 1988-89, sales were a record of more than 21.7 million tons, including more than 16.3 million tons of corn and nearly 5.4 million tons of wheat. A metric ton is about 2,205 pounds and is equal to 39.4 bushels of corn or 36.7 bushels of wheat or soybeans.

Milk production dropped last year, but higher prices boosted sales receipts of dairy farmers to a record level, according to an Agriculture Department report. Overall, milk output in 1989 declined 1 percent to about 144.3 billion pounds from a record of 145.2 billion pounds in 1988, the report said Tuesday. But cash receipts from milk sales rose 10 percent to $19.4 billion, eclipsing the old record of $18.5 billion set in 1983. Milk production has been rising this year in response to higher prices and may edge up by 1 percent to 3 percent in 1990, possibly to another record level, according to USDA forecasters. The annual report showed that actual marketings of milk in 1989 totaled about 142.1 billion pounds, down from 142.9 billion in 1988. About 2.1 billion pounds were used on farms where produced, including milk fed to calves and used by dairy-producer families. About 141.1 billion pounds of the milk marketed was sold to plants and dealers for more than $19.1 billion, an average of $13.56 per 100 pounds, the report said. More than 497 million quarts (about two pounds each) were sold directly to consumers for an average of 53.9 cents per quart. Those receipts totaled $267.9 million. The average number of milk cows in 1989 was reported at 10,127,000 head, down from 10,262,000 the year before. But average milk production rose to 14,244 pounds per cow last year from 14,145 in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Calderon Inauguarated as President of Costa Rica
DOC.TEXT: Following in his father's footsteps, Rafael Angel Calderon donned the presidential sash doffed by Nobel laureate Oscar Arias, then promised his countrymen fiscal vigilance and austerity. ``Exactly 50 years ago my father was sworn in, before these same altars of God and the fatherland,'' he told a crowd of 50,000 attending Tuesday's ceremony at the national soccer stadium. Calderon outlined a government of national consensus in which private enterprise will be the motor of what he termed ``economic democracy.'' But he also lamented the large federal budget deficit _ 6 percent of the GNP _ and said austerity measures would have to be adopted during his first year in office to prevent a rise in inflation. First Lady Barbara Bush headed the U.S. delegation to the inauguration. Seven heads of state, including Calderon's four Central American colleagues, were on hand. Mrs. Bush thanked the people of Costa Rica for their warmth and hospitality before departing for Washington on Tuesday evening. ``I have fallen in love with the people of Costa Rica and the Calderon family,'' especially the four children, she said. Mrs. Bush had breakfast with the family before the inauguration ceremony. Calderon, a 41-year-old lawyer, has been in politics since the age of 16. He hailed Arias' work on behalf of peace in Central America. The outgoing president was awarded the 1987 Nobel Peace Prize for authoring a plan that has promoted, although not completely achieved, peace in the region. ``Halfway down the road toward peace, it is incumbent upon us, the presidents of the region, to go on to a new phase of the process in which the great goal will not be to silence the roar of the cannons but to finally lift ourselves toward economic development,'' Calderon said. He quoted Pope Paul VI in saying that in modern times, ``development is the new name for peace.'' Calderon said his government would encourage the creation of thousands of ``mini-enterprises,'' many of them linked to Costa Rica's burgeoning tourism industry. Calderon's Party of Social Christian Unity has accused Arias' social democratic National Liberation Party of fostering an oversized and inefficient state apparatus. He vowed to ``impose order on public finances.'' The Social Christians are slightly to the right of the Social Democrats. The similarly centrist ideology of the two parties has been a major factor in keeping the nation of 3 million stable and democratic during decades of turmoil and totalitarianism in Latin America. ``There are economic world powers and military world powers. We only aspire to consolidate ourselves as a world power of disarmament and human rights,'' said Calderon. Calderon, who lost presidential bids in 1982 and 1986, defeated Liberation candidate Manuel Castillo in a February election. The constitution forbade Arias, whom polls gave a 90 percent approval rate at the end of his presidency, from seeking another term. Calderon founded the Social Christian party in part to shed the legacy of his father, Rafael Angel Calderon Guardia, who was exiled in 1948 for trying to nullify the presidential vote that year. After a 40-day revolution, the army was abolished and the Calderon family sent into exile. Calderon calls his father, who served as president from 1940 to 1944, the greatest Costa Rican president of this century. The elder Calderon was a great social reformer, having founded Costa Rica's social security system. In his campaign, Calderon tried to take advantage of his father's image as a reformer without raising the events of 1948.

DOC.HEAD: White-Collar Sentencing Plan Not Abandoned, Attorney General Says
DOC.TEXT: Proposed tougher sentences for corporate criminals require more study before receiving Justice Department support, but have not been abandoned, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh says. ``The difference here was that there were not adequately reviewed _ they were not repudiated but were simply withdrawn for further study,'' Thornburgh told a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing. He promised to issue a tough-minded recommendation on sentences for white-collar criminals but said he had no deadline for doing so. Prosecution of ``crime in the suites'' has been a theme of Thornburgh's tenure at the Justice Department. His aides acknowledged last month that he withdrew support for the guidelines at the request of the White House. The request reportedly followed heavy lobbying by defense contractors, oil companies and others who saw the proposals as something very much like a ``corporate death penalty'' for several firms. The U.S. Sentencing Commission produced the guidelines last fall. They would require federal judges to impose stiff fines on companies convicted of polluting, fraud and other white-collar offenses. Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., said that when the Justice Department withdrew its support he was ``concerned that the Department of Justice has surrendered so easily to pressure from the White House and big business to go soft on white-collar crime.'' Thornburgh declared that he is adamantly opposed to soft treatment for white-collar criminals. ``I stand second to none in pressing for nothing less than the maximum penalties that we can accommodate under the law,'' he said. Sen. Howard M. Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, said, however, that criminals who are members of ``the country-club set'' frequently get off the hook. ``Your prosecutors are wheeling and dealing constantly without anyone going to the slammer,'' he told Thornburgh. ``I think you'd have a hard time explaining that to Woody Lemons,'' Thornburgh replied. Lemons, the former chairman of a Texas savings and loan, was recently sentenced to 30 years in prison, the stiffest sentence so far in the probe of massive fraud in the thrift industry. Thornburgh promised to get Metzenbaum a list of white-collar offenders who have been sentenced to prison. ``I will hope to disabuse you of what is obviously a mistaken view,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Finds Nothing Improper in Comics Switch
DOC.TEXT: A jury found The Dallas Morning News did not set out to wreck its rival in obtaining 26 comics and features that had been running in the Dallas Times Herald. The Harris County jury voted 10-2 on Tuesday to reject the Times Herald's claim for at least $33 million in damages. The Times Herald had contended The Morning News and its parent, the A.H. Belo Corp., violated antitrust laws by taking over the features in a move to drive the Times Herald out of business. The features, which ran in the Times Herald until last fall, included Doonesbury, The Far Side, Dear Abby and Erma Bombeck. Times Herald attorney Wayne Fisher said the newspaper will appeal. ``We disagree that the conduct of our competitor was legal or proper in any way,'' the paper said in a statement. ``In fact, it was wrong in many ways _ wrong morally, wrong ethically, wrong for the profession of journalism and wrong for Dallas and its people.'' Belo Chairman Robert Decherd said: ``The most important thing now is for our two companies to go about making the best newspapers we can and benefit the communities we serve. We feel strongly we've been vindicated.'' Decherd denied The Morning News intended to drive the Times Herald out of business. ``The Dallas market can support two vibrant, lively newspapers,'' he said. ``I still believe that.'' The Morning News said it obtained the comics and features as part of a joint venture with Universal Press Syndicate Inc. of Kansas City, the distributor of the features, to get into the TV programming business. Witnesses for Belo and the syndicate testified that Universal Press required all its features in the Times Herald be moved to The Morning News as part of the venture. The venture will use syndicate comics characters in TV programs and commercials to encourage newspaper readership. The Times Herald had asked for $33 million in actual damages and unspecified punitive damages. The $33 million would have been tripled had the Times Herald been successful in its lawsuit. The Times Herald had estimated the loss of the features cost it a permanent circulation drop of 10,800. In testimony, Morning News attorneys referred to circulation figures showing the Times Herald's circulation was slightly higher than before the features were moved. But Times Herald officials testified that to stop the circulation slide, they had begun a $1 million reader lottery promotion. When the promotion ends, their witnesses said, circulation could slide. As of March 31, The Morning News had a daily morning circulation of 355,633, according to figures filed with the Audit Bureau of Circulation. The Times Herald had a daily circulation of 222,416.

DOC.HEAD: Official Says Trust Funds Should be Included in Deficit Calculation
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subcommittee hearing 10 a.m. EDT; may be led
DOC.TEXT: The trust funds that are financed by taxes on gasoline and airplane tickets should be considered in calculating the federal deficit, a Transportation Department official says. ``If we can agree that we must not lose sight of the total federal deficit, I think we must then agree that we cannot ignore trust fund spending in setting the annual federal budget,'' Assistant Transportation Secretary Kate L. Moore told a House subcommittee Tuesday. She was scheduled to testify again today before a Senate public works panel. Members of Congress with jurisdiction over public works spending are being pressured by states, the aviation industry and contractors in particular to release money from those funds for much-needed building and repair. Moore was referring to the two funds _ paid for by taxes on fuel, tires, cargo and airline tickets _ which are supposed to be dedicated to spending on public works such as highways, bridges and air traffic control. Critics say the funds balances are kept artificially high to mask the size of the deficit. Some members of Congress want the funds removed from deficit calculations in order to stop that alleged abuse. Congress controls the flow of money from the two accounts: the Aviation Trust Fund and the Highway Trust Fund. The amount of money that is released in a given year typically falls short of the value of the projects. The highway money goes to states, which administer highway programs. The two separate funds have a combined cash balance of about $25 billion, but there is disagreement over how much is really an uncommitted surplus. There is also disagreement over how much of the Aviation Trust Fund should be spent on operations of the Federal Aviation Administration rather than on capital equipment. The Bush administration wants to raise the airline passenger ticket tax from 8 percent to 10 percent in order to finance modernization of the air traffic control system and increase the share of FAA operations financed by the fund. The National Aviation Safety Plan, as the modernization is known, is behind schedule and $4 billion more expensive than anticipated.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Says U.S. Opposition to Naval Arms Talks Could Harm Ties
DOC.TEXT: Continued U.S. opposition to naval arms talks could undermine U.S.-Soviet ties and derail future negotiations to cut strategic and conventional weapons, says the Soviet Union's chief arms control adviser. Marshal Sergei Akhromeyev issued his warning before a congressional panel Tuesday, and added a new wrinkle to Moscow's call for negotiations over a ban on short-range nuclear weapons in the superpower navies. Akrhomeyev, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's principal arms control adviser, said his country would be willing to include land-based aircraft used to protect its navy in naval arms talks. ``We think that nuclear weapons of all kinds of systems at sea should be the subject of negotiations,'' he said. ``In other words, the nuclear systems which are deployed on aircraft carriers, on submarines and on aviation.'' But the overriding issue is President Bush's rejection of the Soviet's plea for naval negotiations, Akhromeyev said. At the Malta summit last December, Gorbachev pressed Bush on such talks but the administration turned down the request, arguing that the United States must remain a naval power. Akhromeyev told a Senate Armed Services subcommittee that U.S. opposition to naval arms talks could jeopardize significant cuts in armed forces and weapons down the road. ``We consider that sooner or later if we do not want to stop the negotiations on reduction of nuclear and conventional arms, naval forces cuts negotiations are unavoidable,'' he said. Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., chairman of the projection forces and regional defense subcommittee, invited Akhromeyev to appear before the panel to discuss naval arms reductions. Members of the subcommittee expressed reservations about imposing limitations on U.S. naval forces. ``I am opposed to limiting the qualitative or quantitative naval forces,'' said Sen. John Warner of Virginia, ranking Republican on the Armed Services Committee and a former secretary of the Navy. Sen. William Cohen, R-Maine, said any reduction in the United States' access to sea lanes is ``tantamount to losing oxygen to our lungs,'' and added the arms control agenda is already overloaded. Akhromeyev also said the issue of whether the Soviets should give up their SS-24 nuclear missile if the United States scraps the rail-based, multiple-warhead MX missile should be addressed in talks once a treaty to reduce strategic weapons by 50 percent is signed. ``It would be good if experts of our countries in this issue ... really studied this prior to getting into those future negotiations. That issue is already on the agenda of the day,'' he said. On another issue, Akhromeyev said the Soviet Union did not violate the U.S.-Soviet agreement in December 1987 to eliminate short-range nuclear weapons even though some SS-23 missiles have been found in East Germany, Bulgaria and Czechoslovakia. Akhromeyev said the missiles, minus nuclear warheads, were sold to those nations before the treaty was signed and thus do not violate the pact.

DOC.HEAD: New Dumping Rules Set, Criticized
DOC.TEXT: Industry soon will have to comply with new federal requirements when disposing of toxic industrial wastes on land, but environmentalists contend the rules don't go far enough to curb pollution. ``It gives the green light to continue dumping billions of gallons of untreated hazardous waste down deep wells,'' said Jane Bloom, an attorney for the Natural Resources Defense Council. Other critics of the new regulations announced Tuesday by the Environmental Protection Agency said the requirements will only lead to new Superfund toxic wastes sites in the years to come. The EPA's long-awaited regulations, in development for six years, call on industry by 1992 to comply fully with new treatment requirements for more than 40 million tons of toxic waste that are dumped onto the ground surface or injected into deep wells. ``These rules will keep significant quantities of hazardous waste off the land, preventing the future groundwater contamination and assuring safe management of these wastes,'' said Donald Clay, the EPA's assistant administrator in charge of hazardous waste regulation and the Superfund cleanup program. But several environmental groups and an industry group representing waste-treatment companies strongly criticized the agency action, saying it was too weak to assure the environment will be protected. ``This action clearly shows the EPA's purported commitment to pollution prevention is merely lip service,'' said Ms. Bloom, of the Washington-based NRDC. Richard C. Fortuna, executive director of the Hazardous Waste Treatment Council, said the EPA action, designed to curb the land disposal of untreated toxic chemicals, instead ``ensures that the waste management practices of today will become the Superfund sites of tomorrow.'' The critics said that while the regulations impose new treatment requirements for some toxic wastes, they also will allow industry to dispose of acidic and solvent wastes through dilution rather than special treatment to reduce the toxicity. The environmentalists and other critics also said the EPA action: _Exempts toxic chemicals that go to wastewater treatment facilities or are injected into deep wells from special treatment requirements, requiring instead that the wastes be diluted. _Fails to establish technology-based treatment standards for eight toxic metals including lead, cadmium, chromium and mercury. _Allows toxic wastewater to continue to be placed in unlined and leaking lagoons and some residues from the treatment process to be placed in unlined landfills. ``This rule ... has every form of capitulation to every pollution interest imaginable,'' said Fortuna, whose Washington-based trade association represents high-technology firms that specialize in the disposal of toxic wastes. Karen Florini, an attorney for the Environmental Defense Fund, called the new standards ``extremely lax'' and said they fail ``to meaningfully control wastes containing toxic metals.'' Clay, the EPA assistant administrator, disagreed. ``The program ... will serve as a catalyst to prevent pollution by encouraging all hazardous waste producers to find ways to minimize their wastes,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bonn Promises to Fight Anti-Semitism
DOC.TEXT: The Bonn government, seeking to allay Jewish fears over reunification, promised a gathering of world Jewish leaders that it will maintain its vigilance in the fight against anti-Semitism. Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble addressed the final session of the World Jewish Congress in Berlin on Tuesday evening. During the three-day meeting, delegates expressed concern over a possible resurgence of anti-Semitism in Germany, which is still grappling with the legacy of the Holocaust in which 6 million Jews were killed by the Nazis. ``We will continue with all force the fight against right-wing extremism and anti-Semitism,'' Interior Minister Wolgang Schaeuble said in a speech. ``We do not hesitate to proceed with all means against those who refuse to learn,'' Schaeuble emphasized. ``This was always so in the 40 years of the Federal Republic of Germany (West Germany). And nothing will be changed in a united Germany.'' The West German Interior Ministry supervises police functions nationwide. There are about 35,000 Jews in West Germany, and about 2,000 in East Germany. Jewish leaders have been alarmed by last year's strong showings by the ultra-rightist Republicans in West Germany, although the party has been losing steam lately. In East Germany, last year's peaceful revolution also gave rise to some nationalistic sentiments. Young East German troublemakers known as ``skinheads'' have been chanting extreme-rightist slogans. The Congress' president, Edgar M. Bronfman, has expressed concerns over the growth of anti-Semitism in Eastern Europe, especially in the Soviet Union. He also addressed the situation in East Germany on Tuesday. ``In the Federal Republic (West Germany), there have been programs of de-Nazification, programs to teach, programs to ensure that what happened will not happen again,'' Bronfman said. ``For over 40 years they have practiced democracy based on education.'' Speaking to East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere, Bronfman added: ``East Germany has a lot to catch up with. Nevertheless, I know you will.'' For more than four decades, Communist East German leaders rejected any responsibility for the Nazi atrocities against the Jews. Last month, the newly elected democratic government accepted responsibility for the Holocaust. East Germany's first democratically elected Parliament on Tuesday eulogized the millions who died at the hands of the Nazis. Recalling the horrors of the time, Parliament President Sabine Bergmann-Pohl said ``the insane path of German history found its end on May 8, 1945,'' the day World War II ended in Europe. Referring to last fall's peaceful revolution that brought down East Germany's hard-line Communist leadership and opened the way for reunification, Mrs. Bergmann-Pohl said: ``Today we have the hope that May 8 does not remain as the last mutually binding date for German history.'' ``But it will always be closely tied to whatever happens along our way into the future,'' she added. Heinz Galinski, head of the West German Jewish communities, appealed especially to young people to resist the calls ``of the new demagogues.' ``No one must forget that anti-Semitism belonged to that ideology which pushed all of us to the brink of catastrophe and plunged many of us over the brink,'' Galinski told the evening session at the West Berlin Jewish Community center. Earlier Tuesday, Congress leaders went to the Wannsee Villa for a solemn ceremony recalling the 6 million Jews killed by the Nazis. Nazi leaders plotted the extermination of the Jews at the Berlin mansion. ``I will not pray here, because I personally believe that God turned his face away from this place, as he did from Auschwitz,'' said Bronfman. Bronfman proposed the erection of a memorial at the crumbling Berlin Wall to recall the importance of November 9: the day the barrier was opened last year and the night of the 1938 Kristallnacht Nazi attacks on Jews. In Washington, two surveys released to Congress on Tuesday by Jewish groups said anti-Semitism is on the rise in the Soviet Union in the age of glasnost.

DOC.HEAD: Cookie Sold With Health Claims is Pulled From Shelves
DOC.TEXT: The Phoenix Fiber Cookie that promises weight loss and protection from cancer and other diseases is being removed from store shelves under threat of court action by federal regulators. Lawyers for Phoenix International Marketing Corp. of Sparks, Nev., said after meeting with Food and Drug Administration officials Tuesday that the cookie would be recalled and distribution of related products halted. ``The company is cooperating fully with the FDA. It's pulling back all the objectionable (promotional) material and they hope to come out with a new product shortly,'' said David Weeda, a Washington-based lawyer for the company. The FDA last Friday told the company to take the products off the market because promotional materials for them made unsubstantiated medical claims. The agency threatened to go to court if the company did not comply. The material distributed about the Phoenix for Life Weight Control Program claimed the products were useful in weight control and in maintaining cardiovascular health, could prevent colon cancer and could help people with diabetes forgo medication, the agency said. The FDA also said the cookies contained twice the approximately 120 calories claimed on the label and disguised sugar content by saying on the label that the cookies contained ``100 percent natural cane juice.'' The company plans to change the recipe for the cookie and draft new labeling. If the new labeling is approved by the FDA, a new product could be on the market within a month, Weeda said. Phoenix also is discontinuing temporarily other products in its diet plan: Phoenix Fizzie, which dissolves in water to make a lemon-flavored drink; Phoenix Nutritious Beverage; and Phoenix Vitamins and Minerals Capsules. Whether these products will be reintroduced ``is up in the air,'' Weeda said. Referring to the FDA's charges, another company attorney, Dennis Johnson, said: ``We're not contesting FDA's conclusions.'' The Phoenix Fiber cookie represents more than 90 percent of the company's sales, which have soared this year _ from $2 million in January, to $4 million in February and $10 million in March, Johnson said. The cookie, introduced less than two years ago, contains large amounts of fiber and comes in chocolate chip, oatmeal raisin and vanilla. As part of the Phoenix weight-control program limiting calories to 1,200 to 1,500 per day, the company recommends eating a cookie and drinking two glasses of water in place of a meal. The company has hired a nutritionist to review its diet plan and suggest changes, Weeda said.

DOC.HEAD: Proposal to Create Environmental Fund Fails
LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: Finance ministers from 152 nations are heading home after stopping short of endorsing a $1.3 billion fund to help Eastern European and Third World countries protect the environment. France supported the establishment of the ``Green Fund,'' but the United States and other powerful members of the International Monetary Fund and its sister organization, the World Bank, balked. Britain and Japan also opposed the new program, which was backed by World Bank President Barber Conable. The World Bank already keeps environmental considerations in mind when lending for development projects and it supports some environmental projects in poor countries. But Conable argued that a new program was needed to address pollution problems that spill across borders. The proposal was debated into the evening Tuesday by the 22-member Development Committee, a joint body of the IMF and World Bank that sets policy for the agencies' development lending. In a statement, the committee said ``further work was necessary'' on the proposal and that, meantime, the World Bank should ``take steps to reinforce its existing environmental programs.'' French Finance Minister Pierre Beregovoy had pleaded with other countries to ``send a positive signal'' by approving the program now. ``Time is passing,'' he said. Among the projects that would be eligible are those aimed at protecting the ozone layer, promoting diversity of animal and plant species, reducing emission of gases thought to cause global warming, protecting multinational river systems and preventing deforestation and the spread of deserts. The idea is that no matter how zealous industrialized countries are in attacking those problems within their boundaries, the problems will not improve unless underdeveloped nations also participate. ``There is no doubt industrial countries are under the obligation ... to avoid deterioration of the environment,'' Beregovoy said. ``... Developing countries must also mobilize, and we must help them to do so.'' The Green Fund as envisioned by Conable would be a pilot project, lending $1.3 billion over for three years at low interest rates. Much of the money would go to Third World nations, but Eastern European countries that had neglected their environment under four decades of communist rule would also be eligible. However, the United States, concerned about its budget deficit, and other large contributors to the World Bank argued the agency should work to strengthen its existing environmental programs. It should, for instance, play a greater role in promoting debt-for-nature swaps in which a developing country agrees to preserve its rain forest, for instance, in exchange for a reduction in its debt burden, Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady said. Conable, a former Republican congressman from New York, had met with White House chief of staff John Sununu to seek U.S. backing for the Green Fund but was rebuffed. Brady, however, insisted that the environment ``is an issue of great importance to the United States.'' The finance officials did agree on a plan to increase the lending capacity of the IMF to $180 billion from $120 billion currently. The fund's policy-making board, the Interim Committee, announced its support of the record increase in contributions from IMF members Tuesday morning. It must now be ratified by members over the next nine to 18 months. At the insistence of the United States, the committee linked the increase to a program to crack down on 11 poor nations who owe the fund $4 billion. The countries will get loans from a special IMF account. If they default on their obligations, however, they could lose their voting rights and the gold they originally contributed to the IMF could be sold.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Chairman Atwater Again Hospitalized For Blood Clot In Leg
DOC.TEXT: Republican Chairman Lee Atwater, who is recovering from treatment for a brain tumor, has been hospitalized for a second time because of a blood clot in his leg, according to his spokeswoman. Atwater, who was released from George Washington University Medical Center on Saturday for treatment of a blood clot in his left leg, returned on Tuesday for physical therapy, said Republican National Committee spokeswoman Leslie Goodman. Examination indicated the problem may not have been cleared up, and doctors decided to re-admit him for more medication for the clot, she said. He probably will stay in the hospital about two days, she said. Atwater has taken radiation and chemotherapy for a dangerous tumor on the right side of his brain. Doctors have said it is common for patients in his condition to develop blood clots. ``No one is alarmed,'' Ms. Goodman said. ``It's not a big deal.''

DOC.HEAD: Artistic Director Quits, Citing Differences With New Chairman
DOC.TEXT: Marta Istomin cited ``a considerable philosophical difference'' with the new chairman of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in announcing her resignation as artistic director. In a letter Tuesday to James D. Wolfensohn, a New York investment banker who took command of the Kennedy Center on March 23, Mrs. Istomin, the widow of cellist Pablo Casals, expressed resentment at the chairman's recent criticism of the center's programming under her stewardship for the last 10 years. In turn, she attacked Wolfensohn's plans for a series of ambitious performing arts festivals as ``quickly expiring fireworks'' with little effect on expanding the Kennedy Center's audiences or raising the level of artistic taste. In a three-paragraph statement, Wolfensohn said ``I greatly regret'' Mrs. Istomin's decision to resign. ``She has been a fine artistic director and has done exemplary work for more than a decade,'' he said. Mrs. Istomin, a Puerto Rican-born musician, was appointed artistic director of the center in February 1980. ``My programs have been mainly focused on lasting values and substance rather than short-term glitter,'' she wrote Wolfensohn on April 13, when she first served notice she was resigning effective May 31. To attract an estimated $15 million annually in private funds to support the Kennedy Center's own programming, Wolfensohn has announced plans for a Texas state performing arts festival in 1991, a possible East European festival the same year and a ``Festival of the Americas'' in 1992, on the 500th anniversary of Columbus' discovery of America. In her letter Tuesday, Mrs. Istomin made clear she thought Wolfensohn's festival plans were an attempt to ``catch the public's fancy'' while trying to obtain new financial support for the center. Wolfensohn has asked Congress and the Bush administration to provide $45 million in federal funds to pay off the Kennedy Center's accumulated debts and to make long-neglected repairs.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 30,945.61, down 24.97 points, or 0.08 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Task Force Makes Pitch for Baseball Expansion
DOC.TEXT: Members of a Senate task force on baseball expansion made a pitch to Commissioner Fay Vincent to add a half-dozen teams by the year 2000, but he wasn't swinging. Vincent, instead, kept his heels dug in on the position that Major League baseball must first evaluate the success of two new National League franchises planned for no later than 1993 before committing to four more. Meetings between baseball's top executive and senators seeking to push new franchises for their states have become a semiannual event on Capitol Hill, and once more lawmakers questioned baseball's antitrust exemption. ``What I said, very precisely, was that the difference between us ... is that I am unwilling to commit baseball to expand beyond the two teams in the National League in the near term,'' Vincent told reporters after Tuesday's meeting with lawmakers. ``I don't say it will not happen. I think it is unlikely.'' National League club owners are scheduled to announce that circuit's long-awaited expansion plan during a meeting scheduled in Cleveland on June 13-14. Vincent emphasized Tuesday that no cities will be awarded franchises at that time, and that the owners will merely state guidelines for interested bidders. Denver and Tampa Bay-St. Petersburg, Fla., are believed to be major contenders for the two new National League franchises, although several others, including Washington D.C., Buffalo and Phoenix, have said they want franchises.
DOC.HEAD: Little Hope Seen For MOVE Charges Stemming From 1985 Tragedy
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department says it has insufficient evidence to reopen the case of the bloody 1985 confrontation between Philadelphia police and the radical group MOVE. Saturday is the last day that Philadelphia police officers or city officials could be charged with civil rights violations in connection with the tragedy. John Dunne, chief of the department's Civil Rights Division told reporters Tuesday, ``The case will have my full attention for the next 72 hours. I am hopeful that we will able to find any new information.'' Eleven people died, including five children, when police bombed a fortified row house occupied by MOVE on May 13, 1985. A fire that began when the bomb was dropped destroyed 61 homes. A Philadelphia grand jury and a federal investigation previously have concluded that the evidence would not support indictments. A group of Philadelphia ministers, lawyers and community activists is still hoping a federal grand jury could be presented with evidence and issue indictments before the weekend. But after meeting with the group for an hour, Dunne said he could offer no assurances. ``The federal statutes are very strict,'' Dunne said. ``There must be hard evidence to prove guilt beyond a reasonable doubt that a party or parties intended to deny people within our community their civil rights which are protected by the federal law.''
DOC.HEAD: Stamps by Phone, Anytime
DOC.TEXT: Americans can now order postage stamps by phone _ all day, every day. The U.S. Postal Service announced Tuesday that it has set up a nationwide stamps-by-phone system, operating 24 hours every day. Customers can buy stamps using major credit cards by calling 1-800-782-6724, (1-800-STAMP-24). The agency tested the concept between 1987 and 1989. It has now hired the Dallas-based firm, TMI Corp., to handle the operation. The system is expected to be most useful to small businesses, but can also be important to the elderly, the handicapped, and others for whom a trip to the post office can be difficult or time-consuming. Stamps will be sold at face value plus a $3 service charge, per order, and mailed to the buyer. They will be available in sheets of 50, rolls of 100 or 500 and booklets. The service also will sell postal cards and stamped envelopes.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Offers Documents to Prove Arms Not Destined for Colombia
DOC.TEXT: Israel has offered documents in an effort to prove that Israeli-made weapons that wound up in the hands of a Colombian drug lord were sent to Antigua at that Caribbean nation's request. The file of 14 documents was handed over Tuesday to a visiting Antiguan delegation, and some were shown to foreign reporters by Israeli officials. They included a certificate signed by Antigua's top defense official, Vere Bird Jr., assuring Israel that the arms were for the exclusive use of Antigua's security forces. In March 1989, Israel's Defense Ministry said 400 Galil assault rifles and 100 mini-Uzi submachine guns were shipped to Antigua and reached their destination. The Haaretz newspaper said the value of the arms deal was about $220,000. Israeli officials say they don't know how the weapons ended up on the ranch of Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, a leader of the Medellin drug cartel who was killed in a shootout with Colombian police in December. About 200 of the Galil assault rifles were confiscated in a police raid on the ranch. Antiguan officials have been quoted as saying they neither ordered nor received the arms. The Antiguan delegaton, headed by Patrick Lewis, an Antiguan diplomat at the United Nations, arrived Monday night to investigate the affair. He was accompanied by three U.S. lawyers. They met Tuesday with Foreign Ministry officials, including the head of the Latin American desk. ``Israel asked the Antiguan delegation how and why a promise made to Israel ... was broken and how items of an arms deal supplied to Antigua finally arrived in private hands in another country,'' said Moti Amichai, a Foreign Ministry spokesman. He said the Antiguan delegation would also meet with other Israelis involved in the deal, but did not give details. Lewis refused to comment on the documents. ``We were sent here to gather information and we really can't make any comments or statements. We have to report to our government,'' he said. At a briefing, reporters were shown three documents, each written in English on what appeared to be official Antiguan stationary bearing the nation's coat of arms. These included a letter dated May 16, 1985, and signed by Antiguan Cabinet Secretary Lionel Stevens. The letter appointed a Maurice Sarfati as special envoy of Antigua's Ministry of Foreign Affairs. The other two documents officials showed to reporters included an end-user certificate and authorization for Sarfati to broker the arms deal. The end-user certificate was attached to a invoice for the weapons and said: ``The below listed items ... will not be passed, sold or given to any third party.'' The two documents were signed Nov. 9, 1988, by Vere Bird Jr., who is security adviser to his father, Antiguan Prime Minister Vere C. Bird, 81. The New York Times on Sunday said Sarfati, who owned a debt-ridden produce business in Antigua, and Israeli army reserve Lt. Col. Yair Klein directed the diversion of weapons to Colombia. Amichai said he could not confirm if Sarfati was an Israeli citizen or had any links with Israel. The daily Maariv newspaper identified Sarfati as an Israeli businessman who had received special envoy status from Antigua to develop energy, tourism and commerce. Klein said he had been hired to run a training camp in Antigua for Panamanian rebels opposed to then-dictator Manuel Noriega. He said the weapons were apparently sent to the Panamanians after the plans for the camp fell through and some of them ``somehow got to Colombia.'' Klein repeatedly denied any involvement in the diversion. Last year, Klein was accused of training hit squads for the Medellin drug cartel in Colombia. Klein denied the allegations and said he was training farmers in self defense. In Antigua, Bird Jr. denied any wrongdoing but stepped down from his post until the matter is resolved. The three U.S. lawyers joining the Antiguan delegation are Lawrence Barcella Jr., Edgar Seibert and Conan Lewis, a Foreign Ministry official said.

DOC.HEAD: Kilauea Lava Meets the Pacific
DOC.TEXT: Poisonous vapor rose from the Pacific where lava from the Kilauea Volcano ended its fiery crawl after burying a town. The molten rock hit the sea near Harry K. Brown State Park on Tuesday after destroying 139 houses and forcing the abandonment of the town of Kalapana. The lava reaching the ocean had flowed slowly from the Kupaianaha vent on the eastern side of the volcano, a distance of about 8 miles. Officials were keeping watch on the steam clouds rising from the sea, known as laze. Laze contains hydrochloric acid and other hazardous chemicals, but so far trade winds are blowing the gas out to sea, the weather service said. No lava has flowed from the Kupaianaha vent since Monday, but geologists have said it could be just another in a series of pauses in the flow this year. Each pause has been followed by a larger and more devastating outpouring of molten rock. The vent has intermittently spewed lava since 1983. Gov. John Waihee and his Cabinet met with Hawaii County officials Tuesday to decide what kind of assistance to provide people who have lost their homes. He said the state had not heard yet whether federal disaster relief was forthcoming. ``Regardless of the federal government, we'll be stuck with this,'' said Waihee. ``We have to decide what we will do to mitigate these problems.'' Harry Kim, administrator of Hawaii County Civil Defense, said no amount of help would make the area habitable anytime soon. ``I don't see anyone having that kind of resources to make the land productive again,'' Kim said. ``Not in their lifetime or my lifetime or the next hundred years.''

DOC.HEAD: Emotionally Handicapped Poorly Served by Schools
DOC.TEXT: Public schools are failing to deal effectively with emotionally disabled children, and at least two-thirds of all such youngsters aren't getting any help at all, a soon-to-be-published study says. Schools tend to emphasize silence and obedience over learning and offer few opportunities for the emotionally handicapped to work with other children or learn social skills, according to the study by researchers at Bank Street College of Education in New York. Many other youngters are being mislabeled as emotionally disabled simply because they are ``mad, bad, sad and can't add'' and have thus gotten on the nerves of their teachers, the study found. Some 400,000 students, less than 1 percent of the school population, have been identified as having behavior disorders by school authorities. But studies estimate the true proportion is at least three to five times higher. ``This suggests that at best somewhere between 10 and 30 percent of children in need are identified,'' said the report. Youngsters with behavioral handicaps are entitled to special education under federal law. But whether or not emotionally handicapped children get special help from their schools depends as much on available resources and local attitudes toward difficult behavior as on students' needs, the report said. The report also found that only one out of three emotionally disabled students functions at or above grade level, and 42 percent drop out. The study, to be published later this month, was written by Jane Knitzer, Zina Steinberg and Brahm Fleisch. It was based on questionnaires sent to state directors of special education and mental health officials, visits to 26 programs in 13 states, a review of literature in the field and interviews with parents and educators from 1987 to 1989. ``The report leaves me optimistic simply because such a report finally exists,'' said William Schipper, executive director of the National Association of State Directors of Special Education. ``This is a very tough group to educate, a high-cost group. But the state of practice is well, well behind what the research tells us,'' he said. The report singled out a few exemplary programs. Golden Lake Elementary in Circle Pine, Minn., sends special educators into regular classrooms, allowing youngsters to stay with normal peers. Central Park East School in Harlem and elementary schools in New Haven, Conn., Benton Harbor, Mich., and Prince George's County, Md., have begun reforms that help all students. Such schools tend to shy from labeling youngsters ``handicapped.'' States, for their part, need to reexamine policies, the report said. In some states, for example, school districts are ``off the hook'' financially if a student is referred to a state facility.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Copies of the report can be obtained after May 15 for $15 through Bank Street College of Education, 610 West 112th Street, New York, N.Y. 10025; or through Citizens Committee for Children of New York, 105 East 22nd Street, N.Y., N.Y. 10010.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Experimenting With Drugs Can Be Just a Part of Growing Up
DOC.TEXT: Experimenting with drugs can be a sign of normal adolescent development, says a new study that calls into question the ``just say no'' appeal to shun drugs altogether. Adolescents who experiment with drugs tend to be better adjusted than abstainers or abusers, according to the findings by psychologists Jonathan Shedler and Jack Block of the University of California, Berkeley. The researchers' conclusion that self-control may be more critical than abstinence conflicts with the ``Just Say No'' anti-drug campaign. But some peers agreed Tuesday that casual drug use does not always lead to addiction. ``This may be hard for some people to take, but the real issue is knowing when to put the brakes on,'' said Dr. Shirley Feldman, deputy director of Stanford University's Center for Study of Family, Children and Youth. ``There's a whole big world out there and, psychologically speaking, experimentation is healthy in most youths.'' Shedler said the findings from the research, which tracked 101 San Francisco youths from age 3 to 18, ``absolutely do not mean drug experimentation is something that is beneficial.'' ``But it does mean that some limited drug experimentation may not be catastrophic,'' he said. ``It could be a sign of trouble to come or simply a sign of normal adolescent exploration.'' The study, published in the May issue of American Psychologists, found drug abuse is a symptom of deep-seated psychological problems originating in early childhood and is worsened by indifferent parenting. At age 18, those who used at least marijuana once a week were alienated, lacking in ability to control their impulses and distressed compared with experimenters, the study said. Abstainers at that age were anxious, emotionally constricted and lacking in social skills compared with experimenters, or teen-agers who used marijuana or another illegal drug no more than once a month. Those same psychological and behavioral traits were reported when the children were studied at ages 5, 7 and 11, according to the continuing research. The study group is now age 23. Brian Flay, director of drug prevention research in the public health department of the University of Illinois, said, ``The `Just Say No' campaign has always been off the mark.'' ``We can't stop kids from trying everything,'' Flay said. ``The `Just Say No' campaign is extremely simplistic. It should be, `Learn how to moderate your behavior. Learn how to resist the pressure to go overboard.''' Some psychologists, including Shedler, contend a more effective anti-drug effort would identify children who have traits that signal possible drug problems later in life, and then counsel those ``at risk'' youths. ``Nobody can predict absolutely who's going to abuse drugs, but we can talk about risk factors that are pretty good indicators,'' Shedler said. Among the factors identified by the study, the mothers of frequent drug users and abstainers were ``perceived to be cold, critical, pressuring and unresponsive to their children's needs,'' the researchers said. The study found no noteworthy findings involving fathers of frequent drug users. But fathers of abstainers were ``relatively unresponsive to their children's needs'' and were domineering. About two-thirds of the 18-year-olds in the study had tried marijuana, which is consistent with national figures. Few got involved with harder drugs, although those who did have ``great problems,'' according to Shedler. Some researchers have credited anti-drug education with a decline in illegal drug use among young people. A 1989 survey of college students found that 36.7 percent used an illicit drug at least once during the previous year, compared with 56.2 percent in 1980, when the survey began. Drug use among high school seniors dropped from 65.6 percent in 1981 to 50.9 percent last year. ``This reduced demand is attributable largely to the important changes occurring in the attitudes, beliefs and social norms among our young people,'' said Lloyd Johnston, a University of Michigan social scientist who helped conduct the survey.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Dip, Dollar Falls
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index slipped slightly today after a five-day climb, and the dollar declined against the Japanese yen. The dollar closed at 157.03 yen, down 1.02 yen from Tuesday's close. It opened at 157.24 yen and ranged between 156.95 yen and 157.40 yen. Currency dealers attributed the dollar's weakness to its overnight drop in New York, in part due to European currencies' strength against the dollar, as well as results of the three-year U.S. Treasury bond auction Tuesday in Washington. ``The predominant sentiment of the market today was watching from the sidelines,'' said a trader with Daiichi Kangyo Bank, speaking on condition of anonymity. Another trader, at the Bank of Tokyo, said higher-than-expected bidding in the U.S. Treasury bond auction made the dollar less attractive to currency investors because it suggested U.S. interest rates would not rise significantly. The Daiichi Kangyo Bank trader noted, however, that 10- and 30-year Treasury bonds were to be auctioned today and Thursday, and ``until we see the results, we can't really say where it (dollar) is going, but I don't think the yen will get much stronger than it is now.'' On the stock market, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, a 14.31-point gainer the previous day, fell 24.97 points, or 0.08 percent, closing at 30,945.61. It was the index's first decline since April 26. In the five trading days before today, the index rose 1,546 points, or 5.25 percent. Securities dealer attributed today's decline mainly to profit-taking. ``After the Nikkei index surpassed the 31,000-point mark in early morning trading, many investors turned to profit-taking,'' said a dealer with Nikko Securities, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``The index rose for five consecutive days until yesterday, and many thought it was about time to take a break,'' said another dealer with a major Japanese brokerage, also requesting anonymity. ``But as far as the market environment is concerned, such as the stronger yen and the performance of foreign stock exchanges overnight, it looks like a bullish market is ahead of us. It seems to have managed the heavy profit-taking today,'' he added. A dealer with Nomura Securities said the yen's rise triggered sales of export-oriented issues, such as electricity and automobile shares. The stronger yen generally depresses the profits of export-dependent industries. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds was quoted at 86.72 points at 4 p.m., up from Tuesday's close at 86.46. The yield fell to 7.220 percent from 7.275 percent the previous day.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: Some people never throw anything away, according to Scott Bruce, who came to this breakfast food mecca looking for old cereal boxes to add to his collection. Sound flaky? ``Cereal boxes represent heroes of popular culture _ the grain gods, I call them,'' said Bruce, a Cambridge, Mass., collector who once started a lunch-box collecting craze. ``When a kid sits down with a bowl of his favorite cereal, he becomes one with his hero. It's like a secular communion rite.'' Bruce, 34, is talking this week with cereal company executives as well as ordinary people who hoard cereal boxes, if there is such a thing. Rare boxes can fetch up to $1,000, said Bruce, who began his collection in 1988 and recently published a collector's magazine called Flake. Battle Creek is the home of Kellogg Co., the world's largest cereal maker, as well as Post and Ralston-Purina plants. ``The people here have cereal in their bloodstream,'' said Bruce. Old cereal boxes are all the more valuable because of the scarcity of people who allow them to hang around. ``The militant mom was the death to many collections,'' he said mournfully. ``But maybe I'll find that that odd citizen who has a Corn Flakes box with Vanessa Williams.'' Miss Williams, Miss America 1984, lost the crown when it was disclosed she had posed nude for Playboy. Bruce said he generally hunts for vintage boxes in good condition from the 1930s through 1970s. But he's even squirreling away some of today's boxes. ``The 1990 Batman cereal box from Ralston is an instant classic,'' he said. ``Just you wait.''

A marina owner has discovered a use for the pesky zebra mussels clogging water intake lines along Lake Erie. Kent Floro makes the mussels into jewelry. ``Business has been going quite well,'' said Floro, owner of Floro's Marina and a convenience store. ``It's kind of like your pet rock from a few years ago. Everyone's got to have one.'' Floro said he collects the basic raw material from the shore by his marina. Completed mussel earrings, necklaces, tie clips and hat pins cost between $3 and $4. ``We aren't going to run out of stock,'' Floro said, pointing out that a mussel can produce 30,000 larvae a year. The tiny shellfish, less than an inch long, have been clogging water intake lines from the lake since 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``Never argue with the voters.'' _ Rep. Donald ``Buz'' Lukens, R-Ohio, after finishing a distant third in Tuesday's GOP primary, his long career shattered after his conviction on a sex offense.

``I think we should hear straight from the president where he stands on taxes.'' _ Rep. Richard Durbin, D-Ill., as the Bush administration outlined the need for up to $100 million to lower the federal deficit.

``The `Just Say No' campaign is extremely simplistic. It should be, `Learn how to moderate your behavior. Learn how to resist the pressure to go overboard.''' _ Brian Flay, director of drug prevention research in the public health department of the University of Illinois, on findings self-control may be more important than abstinence when it comes to drugs.

DOC.HEAD: Army Won't Seek Repayment of Scholarship Money From Gay Cadets
DOC.TEXT: The Navy is dropping its bid to force repayment of tuition from two cadets expelled from ROTC for homosexuality. A Navy spokesman Tuesday said the cases were ``reviewed on their merits, and the decision was made not to seek recoupment,'' The New York Times reported today. However, the unidentified spokesman said there had been no change in the Pentagon's ban on homosexuals in military. Robert L. Bettiker, 22, a chemistry major at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and David Carney, a 23-year-old Harvard graduate studying in Britain, had been dismissed after informing their commanders they are gay. The Navy had said it would seek reimbursement of their scholarship money: $38,612 from Bettiker and $50,687 from Carney. Bettiker on Tuesday called the turnaround great and said he hoped it would have implications for other ROTC cadets in similar circumstances. ``The way it's worded, they tried to make it as particular to me as possible _ but I feel its a precedent,'' said Bettiker, who was discharged Jan. 31. The Ohio native had planned to enter the Navy's prestigious Nuclear Propulsion Program after graduation next month but will now work in a cancer research laboratory at the University of California at Berkeley. ``I always felt I did what was right,'' said Carney. ``I never thought in the end they would sue for the money. The Navy is not as mean-spirited as that.'' In a third case, involving the expulsion of James Holobaugh, a gay Army ROTC cadet at Washington University in St. Louis, an Army officer has made a preliminary recommendation that the Army try to recover it scholarship money. Holobaugh's case attracted the support of 24 members of Congress for the ROTC cadets. ``We believe that to compel these men to repay this money would not only be fundamentally unfair; it would also reflect an appalling mean-spiritedness which has no place in the Navy,'' the lawmakers said in a letter written by Rep. Gerry Studds, D-Mass.

DOC.HEAD: Showers Over North-Central Plains; East Coast Cloudy
DOC.TEXT: The Plains received scattered showers early today, and clouds covered the Eastern Seaboard from Georgia to Maine. It was mostly fair in the West and windy in the Plains cities of Oklahoma City, Forth Worth, Texas and Grand Rapids, S.D. Snow fell at Great Falls, Mont., and snow was forecast for the Colorado mountains. A severe thunderstorm watch was posted in western Kansas. Heavy rains were expected from Mississippi to the mountains of the Carolinas. Showers and thunderstorms were forecast along the Gulf Coast from Louisiana to western Florida. Showers also were expected to spread into the Ohio and Tennessee valleys. On Tuesday, from three to six inches of snow fell in the higher elevations of Wyoming and Colorado. Rain extended from eastern Texas and Arkansas to northwestern Florida, and rain also fell from Iowa to Michigan. Heavy rainfall totals for the six-hour period ending at 8 p.m. EDT Tuesday included about 1{ inches at Fort Polk and Lake Charles, La. Strong winds lashed the Southwest. At Saint Johns, Ariz., gusts were clocked at up to 55 mph and up to 67 mph at Vernal, Utah. The nation's high Tuesday was 102 degrees at Laughlin, Nev. DOC.HEAD: Hospital Reprimanded For Not Seeking Parental Consent
DOC.TEXT: The National Institutes of Health has reprimanded Children's Hospital for failing to seek parents' consent for a comparison study of two treatments for infants with damaged lungs. The hospital ``made a serious error'' in not asking for consent from the parents of babies chosen randomly to receive conventional treatment, the federal agency said in a recent letter quoted in today's The Boston Globe. Nineteen of the 20 babies who received the experimental treatment survived, against six of 10 treated conventionally. The tests were part of a study that was published in December and confirmed the value of the experimental treatment, extracorporeal membrane oxygenation, or ECMO, which ``breathes'' for the infants until their lungs can take over. Charles R. McCarthy, director of the NIH Office for Protection from Research Risks, said the committee at Children's Hospital that approves all human studies ``made decisions that rightfully belong to the parents. ... They really blew it.'' The action is believed to be the only time the federal office has reprimanded a hospital for failing to ask consent of all subjects in a study. Dr. Peter H. Wolff of Children's Hospital told the agency in a letter that he would seek consent in all future human studies. But Wolff, chairman of the committee that approves human studies at the hospital, defended the failure to seek consent, saying that asking all parents for permission ``would impose unacceptable psychological burdens on the parents of children not included in the ECMO arm of the study.'' Dr. Michael Epstein, who led the study, said that parents of conventionally treated infants were not informed to spare them anguish. He said that even if they decided not to allow their child to participate, there was no way they could have obtained the experimental treatment for their child _ at least not at Children's. ``I continue to be troubled by all of this discussion,'' he said. ``But I still feel that we acted in a morally appropriate way, given the conditions at the time.'' At the time, the experimental treatment was available at many other U.S. hospitals and some studies indicated it offered better chances of survival to infants with severely damaged lungs. However, no random, controlled study had proven its advantage or documented its safety. Wolff's committee decided not to seek consent of all participants to avoid difficulty recruiting subjects for the conventional treatment, according to a letter from McCarthy's office sent to the hospital in November. The hospital researchers have acknowledged in scientific reports that a random study would probably show ``large differences in survival'' between EMCO and the standard therapy.

DOC.HEAD: Rocket Launch with German Satellite On Schedule
DOC.TEXT: A German observatory known as Rosat will be carried into orbit aboard a Delta rocket May 31 to study the heavens for sources of cosmic X-rays. The $170 million satellite will perform the first full sky survey of celestial bodies that emit X-rays, said Volker Kaltenbach, Rosat spacecraft manager for the German Aerospace Research Establishment of West Germany. It will use the largest imaging X-ray telescope ever built. ``Rosat is up to now the most ambitious project in the young history of X-ray astronomy,'' Kaltenbach said Tuesday. About 1,000 sources of cosmic X-rays, which do not penetrate the atmosphere and therefore are invisible from the ground, are known to exist. Astronomers hope Rosat will identify 100,000 sources, said Alan Bunner, Rosat program scientist for NASA. It will observe stars, black holes and supernova remnants, hot clouds produced by exploding stars at the end of their lives. The observatory originally was scheduled to be carried into orbit by a space shuttle. But the 1986 Challenger explosion delayed the mission along with everything else, and neither the German Aerospace Research Establishment nor NASA wanted to wait until the mid-1990s, Bunner said. Rosat was redesigned somewhat to be launched aboard McDonnell Douglas' unmanned Delta 2 rocket from Cape Canaveral Air Force Station, Bunner said. The $170 million cost of the satellite excludes rocket and launch expenses, which are being covered by NASA. The United States has contributed about $106 million to the project. Great Britain also has paid part of the costs. Rosat is short for Roentgen Satellite, named after German scientist Wilhelm Conrad Rontgen, who discovered X-rays in 1895.

DOC.HEAD: San Francisco Begins Water Rationing
DOC.TEXT: Drought is forcing part of the San Francisco Bay area to ration water for the second time in three years. Under the plan approved Tuesday by the city Public Utilities Commission, the cost of water will jump, beginning in July, by about 9 percent, increasing the average household bill to $6.28 a month. Water customers will be given allotments based on the number of people in a household. Those who use 10 percent above the allotment will have their base rate doubled, while big water wasters may face a tenfold rate increase. In addition, hosing down sidewalks is forbidden, decorative water fountains will be shut off and restaurant customers will not be given water unless they ask for it. ``There is a real emergency,'' said Rodel Rodis, commission president. Officials aim to cut consumption to 25 percent of 1987 levels for a total of 2.2 million people _ about a third of the Bay area population _ in San Francisco, San Mateo and Santa Clara counties and Alameda County across the San Francisco Bay. It is the fourth straight year of drought in Northern California; rationing also was ordered in 1988. Before that it was last rationed in 1977. In March the Santa Clara Valley Water District, in the southern part of the San Francisco Bay Area, ordered mandatory cuts of 20 percent to 25 percent. Some parched Southern California communities also are rationing water.

DOC.HEAD: Columnist Suspended Two Weeks By Newsday
DOC.TEXT: Newsday suspended columnist Jimmy Breslin after he obscenely insulted an Asian-American reporter and phoned a radio personality to joke about it on the air. The 61-year-old Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist was suspended for two weeks without pay, Don Forst, editor of New York Newsday, said early today. Breslin launched into a tirade in the newsroom Friday after reporter Ji-Yeon Mary Yuh, 25, criticized his May 3 column as sexist in an internal computer message. In an expletive-laced outburst, Breslin referred to her as ``a yellow cur'' and ``slant-eyed.'' Breslin was later reprimanded by his editors and apologized to the staff in a computer message. Forst said the paper had believed the reprimand and apology were sufficient until hearing Breslin's on-air conversation, which indicated ``a lack of sensitivity to what what has been and continues to be a painful episode.'' The conversation took place Tuesday with Howard Stern, a WXRK-FM personality who is known for racial and ethnic jokes and who tangled with the Federal Communications Commission over his sexually frank language. ``I have one social problem coming out of all of this,'' Breslin said on the air, explaining that his nephew is to marry a Korean woman in September. ``Now does this mean I can't go to the wedding?'' he said. Calls to Breslin at Newsday and at home were not immediately returned. On Tuesday, a group of Newsday reporters, including Yuh, had asked for Breslin's suspension or for the paper to print a column about bias against Asian women. They had also threatened to withhold their bylines on stories. After the meeting, Newsday editors listened to a tape of the radio show and decided to discipline Breslin, New York Newsday reported today. The suspension was applauded by a representative of one Asian-American group. ``Basically, we are glad that management had decided to do the right thing,'' said Jeannie Park, a board member of the Asian American Journalists Association.

DOC.HEAD: Is New York Melting Pot a Bubbling Cauldron?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 12-14, `The city...' with 6 grafs to CORRECT date of murder to August, sted November, to show trials are separate, and UPDATE with new remarks by Sharpton warning of violence; PICKS UP 15th graf pvs, `Violence broke...
DOC.TEXT: At his inauguration as New York's first black mayor, David Dinkins hailed the city as a ``gorgeous mosaic'' of races, nationalities and sexual orientations. Five months later, cracks in the mosaic are showing. A flurry of events threatens to turn the melting pot into a bubbling cauldron. At City College, two professors preach racial supremacy: One for whites, one for blacks. In Brooklyn, a black group boycotts Korean grocers. A white newspaper columnist slurs a Korean-American co-worker. A Columbia University soccer player gives a speech attacking homosexuals and Jews. Voices of caution are being heard. After a black student reported to police that she had been sexually assaulted by white St. John's University students, black leaders came to the school to say there appeared to be no racial dimension to the case. ``Racist fires are alight,'' The New York Times warned in an editorial this week about the Brooklyn boycott of two Korean-run grocery stores by blacks. The paper urged Dinkins to follow through on his campaign promise of bringing people together. Dinkins on Tuesday defended his low-key approach to the racial conflicts and said he was using ``tremendously delicate diplomacy'' to resolve the dispute over the groceries. Racial tension is a constant presence in varying degrees in New York, where millions of people from around the world live and work. In 1986, for example, young men in the largely white Howard Beach neighborhood hounded a black man to his death, and blacks protested for months. But the recent rash of high-profile incidents has raised questions about whether racial and ethnic harmony has been strained beyond normal limits. In the anti-Korean boycott, blacks led by self-proclaimed ``anti-white'' activist Sonny Carson berated and spat on those who tried to shop at the stores, whose business has plummeted. Leaflets encouraged consumers to avoid patronizing ``people who do not look like us.'' Carson, a convicted kidnapper, was dismissed from the Dinkins campaign last year for inflammatory remarks about Jews. ``There are people out there who want to foment race riots,'' said Richard Izzo, a lawyer representing the Koreans in a civil rights suit against the protesters. The city has been more active in battling racial violence like the August attack on Yusuf Hawkins, a black 16-year-old shot to death while shopping for a used car in a mostly white Brooklyn neighborhood. Two juries today were considering separately the fate of two white men charged in the killing. The Rev. Al Sharpton, a black activist who has been pressing the prosecution of the case, last week urged blacks to remain calm regardless of the verdict. ``We do not want Yusuf Hawkins' name tainted with senseless violence,'' he said. But in today's New York Post, Sharpton warned that anything less than murder convictions would lead to violence. ``You are lighting a match to the end of a powder keg and telling us to burn the town down,'' he said. ``We are not calling for mindless violence,'' Sharpton added. ``Don't blame me. As a social weatherman, I'm telling you that the clouds of violence are over New York City.'' Violence broke out last week when philosophy Professor Michael Levin offered a talk in Brooklyn titled ``White Fear of Black Crime is Morally and Epistemically Correct.'' Nine people were arrested and six police officers injured in a scuffle prompted by the lecture. Levin and Professor Leonard Jeffries Jr., who believes whites are inferior to blacks, teach at City College, which is 39 percent black, 28 percent Hispanic, 17 percent white and 16 percent Asian. At Columbia University, soccer player Chris Ziadie stunned an athletic awards banquet by charging the administration there catered to Jews and homosexuals at the expense of other students. Newsday announced today that it is suspending Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist Jimmy Breslin for two weeks without pay for a newsroom outburst in which he used racial and sexual slurs against a Korean-American reporter. Breslin has apologized to the reporter and the staff. As these incidents hang heavy over the city, the world of fiction provides little relief. A movie crew has been in town making the film version of Tom Wolfe's novel ``Bonfire of the Vanities,'' sparking protests that the blacks and Hispanics of the Bronx are being unfairly portrayed as criminals. In the newly released ``Q&A,'' featuring Nick Nolte as a corrupt Irish-American cop, the soundtrack is thick with racial epithets as Nolte goes about wiping out blacks, Hispanics and homosexuals.

DOC.HEAD: Abuses Continue in Turkey, Amnesty International Says
DOC.TEXT: Six months after the government proposed new human rights safeguards, widespread torture and other abuses continue unabated in Turkey, according to a report released today by Amnesty International. ``In early 1990, thousands of people remained imprisoned for political reasons, including hundreds of prisoners of conscience convicted for their non-violent political or religious activities,'' the international human rights organization said. ``Among them are members of political organizations, trade unions and Kurdish groups as well as journalists and religious activists. The use of torture continues to be widespread and systematic, in some cases resulting in death.'' Turkey ratified the United Nations Convention against Torture in 1988, the report said. In September and November, the government announced proposals governing length of detention, access to lawyers and protection for prisoners of conscience. None of those proposals has been enacted. Under the government proposal, the maximum detention period under police custody would be reduced from 15 days to 4-to-10 days, though longer detention would be permitted under emergency legislation. The government also proposed abolishing the death penalty for 13 categories of offenses, but not for murder and political offenses that produce the most death sentences, the report said. ``While these draft amendments, if passed, would represent a step in the right direction, they nevertheless would fall short of international standards in important respects,'' Amnesty said. The report included testimony from several prisoners who said they were tortured with beatings on the soles of their feet, electric shocks, showers of ice cold water and hanging by their arms. ``Torture is still routine even among those detained for only a few days,'' Amnesty reported. The testimony of prisoners shows ``anyone is at risk from torture in Turkey, particularly if held on political grounds,'' the report said. ``Many prisoners sign confessions under torture which are then used as evidence against them, in violation of international standards,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: Martinez Blames Sponge, Still Supports Electric Chair
DOC.TEXT: A botched execution that caused flames to shoot from the head of an inmate in an electric chair was caused by a synthetic sponge, Gov. Bob Martinez said. The malfunction occurred because two maintenance workers had substituted a synthetic sponge for the natural sponge that serves as a conduit for electrical current applied to the prisoner's head, Martinez said Tuesday. The synthetic sponge didn't work properly, he said. Flames, smoke and sparks shot 3 to 6 inches above the head of Jessie Tafero as authorities administered three 2,000-volt shocks to the convicted cop-killer on Friday. The governor said the maintenance workers ``took it upon themselves to replace what they thought to be a worn-out sponge, and didn't realize there is a different chemical reaction by virtue of substituting a synthetic sponge for a natural sponge.'' A report from Corrections Secretary Richard Dugger said Tafero died immediately. The attending physician's report indicated that at the least, the condemned man was knocked unconscious by the jolt. ``There is no way to apply 2,000 volts directly to someone's brain without killing them instantly,'' said Dugger, who has witnessed 16 executions. ``They are never conscious of what happens.'' Dugger, in a report requested by the governor, said prison officials had conducted a test using a household toaster that confirmed the synthetic sponge caused the problem. ``Although the sponge was only in the toaster for ten seconds it produced a large amount of smoke and reduced in size by approximately two-thirds,'' the report said. Tafero's attorney, Mark Olive of Atlanta, and the Florida Clearinghouse on Criminal Justice called the execution ``torture.'' Tom Horkan, executive director of the Florida Catholic Conference, referred to it as a ``barbarous experience.'' Martinez, whose support of the death penalty has been highlighted in his re-election ads, said he opposed legislative attempts to introduce lethal injection as another means of execution in Florida. ``There have been injections where they've missed the vein,'' he said. ``I'm not sure from time to time there isn't going to be debate about some procedure ... but I think in carrying out a difficult mission, it's been carried out appropriately.'' Tafero was executed for the 1976 shooting deaths of Florida Highway Patrol Trooper Phillip Black and visiting Canadian constable Donald Irwin of Kitchener, Ontario. He was the 22nd person put to death in Florida since the 1976 U.S. Supreme Court ruling allowing states to resume use of the death penalty.

DOC.HEAD: Two Killed, 30 Injured in Bombings Blamed On Sikh Separatists
DOC.TEXT: Suspected militant Sikh separatists blew up two buses at a terminal in this Sikh holy city today with bombs concealed in plastic baskets, killing at least four people and injuring 41, police said. Senior police superintendent Sanjeev Gupta said the first blast occurred on a Punjab state transport company bus that was about to leave for the state capital of Chandigarh. Police said a man and a woman were killed instantly and two more people died after being taken to the hospital. They said 26 people were hurt. The bomb exploded as passengers were rushing out of the packed bus, alerted by a police search party that noticed the bomb, Gupta said. Five minutes later, the second bomb exploded in a bus a few yards away, injuring 15 passengers, he said. Both buses caught fire and were gutted. Gupta said the casualties were lower in the second blast because most passengers were evacuated from buses at the terminal after the first explosion. ``If the alarm had not been raised before the blast, the casualties would have been much higher,'' he said. Bus station superviser Dilip Singh said the police, acting on intelligence reports, began searching for a bomb an hour before the blasts. Ranjit Singh, the driver of another bus, said he was parking his vehicle alongside the first bus when ``I heard a loud explosion and saw metal pieces flying in the air.'' Gupta said Sikh extremists were suspected to have planted the bombs. He refused to elaborate. Thirteen of the injured were in critical condition, he said. The second bus was on its way to a Hindu shrine, 220 miles north of Amritsar in Jammu-Kashmir state, and was packed with Hindu pilgrims, he said. Amritsar, the site of Sikhdom's holiest shrine, the Golden Temple, is also the stronghold of Sikh militants who have been fighting since 1982 for a separate nation they propose to carve out of Punjab.
