Elsewhere in Punjab, Sikh extremists killed six persons since Tuesday night, United News of India news agency said. The killings brought to 777, the number of people Sikh militants are alleged to have killed this year alone. The northern state, India's only region where Sikhs are in a slight majority, is a rich farming area bordering Pakistan. Sikhs who form 2 percent of India's 880 million people allege cultural, political and economic discrimination by the Hindu majority and the Hindu-dominated government. In their bloody quest for independence, Sikh militants are alleged to have killed 767 people this year alone.

DOC.HEAD: Police Halt Protest By Hundreds Of Islamic Fundamentalists
DOC.TEXT: About 500 Islamic fundamentalists were detained briefly after police broke up a sit-down protest in a street outside a courthouse, police and witnesses said today. The demonstration occurred Tuesday in front of Morocco's Appeals Court to protest the conviction earlier this year of six fundamentalists. Traffic was blocked for about two hours. Police intervened and took away most of the protesters in vans for an identity check, but officials said all were released shortly afterwards. The court is hearing the appeal of six members of Al Adel Wal Ihsane (Justice and Charity), an outlawed fundamentalist group, who have been sentenced to varying prison terms for involvement in an illegal organization, publishing illegal newspapers, and disturbing the public order. The court adjourned the hearing of the appeal to May 15. Arriving outside the court building, the protesters sat in the street, began reciting verses from the Koran and demanded to be admitted to the hearing. About 40 were allowed in, but officials then said there was no more room.

DOC.HEAD: Reformers Welcome Court Ruling To Make Coalition Pacts Public
DOC.TEXT: Champions of electoral reform claimed their first victory today after Israel's Supreme court ordered political parties to make full disclosure of any political deals they make to form government coalitions. In a unanimous 25-page decision, a three-member panel of judges ruled in favor of suits filed by four Israeli citizens against the center-left Labor Party led by Shimon Peres and the rival right-wing Likud bloc of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, as well as other individual politicians. Chief Justice Meir Shamgar wrote that the disclosure should be made in the Knesset, or Parliament, no later than the day the prime minister-designate presents his new government for a vote of confidence. ``Free opinion and public knowledge of what is occuring in the system of government are an integral part of the democratic system,'' he wrote. ``Public confidence cannot possibly be maintained on the basis of things which are concealed.'' The court said that hiding information is justified only when state security, relations with foreign countries or vital public interests are endangered. Uriel Reichman, a law professor who has been a reform leader, hailed the ruling as step toward overhauling what he called the ``corrupt system'' of political horse-trading. ``A coalition agreement can't be signed any longer in sealed rooms without the public knowing how national interests are decided and taxpayers money is distributed,'' he said. Reichman said it would give new impetus to the reform campaign, which started six weeks ago with an outburst of public anger over secret deals that were made to lure politicians to cross party lines and to win over small religious factions. ``This is a victory for the protest movement,'' said Shraga Eliad, one of the four citizens who petitioned the court. The movement began with a small group of hunger strikers shortly after the national unity government collapsed March 15. Tens of thousands later joined public demonstrations and a half-million signatures, about 10 percent of Israel's 4.7 million people, were gathered. Shamir has been given a presidential mandate to try to form a government coalition after Peres failed to put together a coalition that would have excluded Likud. Amnon Rubenstein, head of the liberal Shinui (Change) party, said disclosure of coalition agreements would ``heighten public disgust'' with the existing system and put pressure on the large parties. He said the test will come when Parliament takes up reform proposals in the next few weeks, including bills for direct election of the prime minister and for the election of 80 of the 120 members of Parliament by districts. Parliament candidates are currently selected by the parties and run on a nationwide list. Rubenstein said ultra-Orthodox religious parties which hold the balance of power between Labor and Likud were to blame for the lack of change until now. ``The Orthodox parties exercise a stranglehold ... They veto reform whenever it threatens their interests,'' he said. Both major political parties welcomed the decision even though they were targets of the lawsuit. Yossi Brun, a spokesman for Likud, said the party had disclosed its agreements with small parties, including the Torah Flag and Torah Guardians religious factions. The Jerusalem Post said the agreement with Torah Flag pledged to give the party an extra $48 million for education, aborption of new immigrants and religious activities. ``It is inconceivable that we would go against the Supreme Court decision. We are for the decision,'' he said. But he said the decision did not apply to intra-party agreements and would not force Likud to make public its pact with Avraham Sharir, a former tourism minister who was lured back after crossing over to Labor briefly. Labor Party Secretary Micha Harish was quoted by the Jerusalem Post as saying ``we will keep our promise'' to disclose details of coalition pacts.

DOC.HEAD: Rockefeller Breezes to Nomination
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Recasts reference to Ms. Caperton in 1st graf. SUBS 5th graf to CORRECT to Burger sted Berger.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Primary Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Sen. John D. Rockefeller IV breezed to a primary victory, while the governor's former wife, Dee Caperton, lost a chance to become state treasurer. ``I've won folks, how about that!'' Rockefeller told about 50 supporters at his campaign headquarters Tuesday night. Rockefeller, heir to one of America's largest fortunes, had 198,759 votes, or 84 percent, with all precincts reporting. He was followed by inventor Ken Thompson, with 21,961 votes, or 9 percent, and conceptual artist Paul Nuchims, with 14,508 votes, or 6 percent, in a race that was never expected to be competitive. ``I don't think that people know that much about what I've been doing,'' said Rockefeller, a Democrat seeking a second term. ``I look at the campaign as a creative way to show what I've accomplished.'' The Republican Senate nominee is John Yoder, 39, a former aide to retired Chief Justice Warren Burger. Yoder had no opposition. In the treasurer's race, former Treasurer Larrie Bailey defeated Ms. Caperton, 47, a former legislator and the former wife of Gov. Gaston Caperton. With all precincts reporting, Bailey had 89,627 votes, or 38 percent, to 74,950 votes, or 32 percent, for Ms. Caperton. The rest of the votes in the Democratic primary were divided among Marie Prezioso, a Charleston investment banker, and Eugene Knotts, a county assessor. Ms. Caperton, a former Miss West Virginia and runner-up in the Miss America pageant, spent more than $240,000 on her primary campaign, nearly 40 times the $6,169 spent by Bailey. The lone GOP candidate for treasurer was Elvin F. Martin, a certified public accountant.

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk Arrives in Paris to Start Major European Tour
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk of South Africa arrived here today on the first stop of an 18-day European tour viewed by his government as a major step toward ending decades of international isolation. Buoyed by a breakthrough in black-white negotiations at home, de Klerk plans to meet with presidents and prime ministers in nine West European countries _ the most extensive trip by a South African leader since the governing National Party took power in 1948. In his talks with European leaders, de Klerk is likely to urge an easing of economic sanctions imposed on his country and to seek support for his initiative to negotiate a political settlement with the black majority. He is to confer Thursday with President Francois Mitterrand, who shunned P.W. Botha _ de Klerk's predecessor _ when Botha came to France to visit the graves of South African soldiers killed in the two world wars. No senior French official was at Orly Airport to greet de Klerk, who was met by a Foreign Ministry representative and a military honor guard. De Klerk had no public events scheduled today but planned a news conference Thursday evening after meetings with Mitterrand and Premier Michel Rocard. De Klerk reportedly was to have lunch Thursday with prominent business leaders from across France, South Africa's sixth largest trading partner despite its observance of limited European Community economic sanctions. Mitterrand decided to invite de Klerk after the South African leader made moves toward reform in February, including the release of jailed South African black leader Nelson Mandela and the legalization of anti-apartheid groups. Last week, de Klerk and a delegation of African National Congress officials led by Mandela agreed to work together to end political violence and clear the way for formal negotiations on a new, post-apartheid constitution that would end the 5 million white minority's monopoly on power. ``It is wonderful to go to Europe with the knowledge that South Africa is busy taking its rightful place in the international community,'' de Klerk told reporters before his departure from Johannesburg late Tuesday. En route, he conferred briefly with President Felix Houphouet-Boigny of the Ivory Coast during a refueling stop in Abidjan, the capital of the West African country. No details were available on their meeting. South Africa's state-run television quoted a senior government source as saying the European trip represented ``a concerted effort to pull South Africa from the morass the country has found itself in.'' The report said, ``The visit is ... of the utmost importance to South Africa.'' After France, de Klerk will visit Belgium, Italy, West Germany, Britain, Spain, Switzerland, Greece and Portugal. Among his hosts will be British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, King Juan Carlos of Spain and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. France's relations with South Africa have been marked by several peculiarities. In the 1970s, French authorities incurred international criticism for nurturing a major arms trade with South Africa, including the sale of the Mirage fighter planes, the backbone of South Africa's air force. Since Mitterrand became president in 1981, France has stayed in step with other European Community members in imposing selective sanctions but has never been a vocal advocate of escalating such embargoes. In some Parisian liquor stores, South African wines are displayed in windows alongside local vintages. Johnny Clegg, the white leader of a multiracial, anti-apartheid South African rock 'n' roll group, is more of a superstar in France than anywhere outside his home country. Yet the anti-apartheid movement in France is less of a force than its counterparts in Britain, the Netherlands and Scandinavia.

DOC.HEAD: Iran-Contra Figure Channell Dies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs graf 2, Channell died, to change ``recovering from'' to ``being treated for.''
DOC.TEXT: Carl R. ``Spitz'' Channell, convicted in the Iran-Contra affair for illegally raising money for the Nicaraguan rebels, has died at the age of 44. Channell died Monday in a Washington hospital while being treated for injuries suffered when he was hit March 15 by a car, according to authorities. Associates said he suffered from cancer and pneumonia. The conservative fund-raiser who also operated a public relations firm became the first person to be convicted in the Iran-Contra affair, when he pleaded guilty in April 1987 to a charge of conspiring to defraud the government. Channell's agreement to cooperate with the investigation of independent counsel Lawrence E. Walsh was the first break for Iran-Contra prosecutors. Channell admitted that he illegally used his tax-exempt National Endowment for the Preservation of Liberty to raise millions of dollars in private donations to buy weapons for the Contras. He implicated Oliver L. North in the fund-raising effort and testified at the former White House aide's trial last year. North was convicted of unrelated Iran-Contra crimes but was acquitted of charges arising from his involvement in the fund-raising effort. Channell also assisted prosecutors in the investigation of the sale of U.S. arms to Iran and the diversion of profits to the Nicaraguan rebels. Former Rep. Dan Kuykendall, a friend of Channell, said the he was struck by an automobile on March 15 near his Capitol Hill office. Channell was thrown over the top of a parked car and landed on the curb, according to his aunt, Eleanor McManus, who witnessed the accident. District of Columbia police spokeswoman Shannon Cockett said the driver of the car that hit Channell had lost control of his vehicle. The driver, Donald Parker Jr., was cited for failure to pay full and close attention, Cockett said. The accident will be referred to the U.S. attorney for further investigation because it resulted in a fatality, she said. After the accident, police said Channell was taken to D.C. General Hospital and later was transferred to George Washington University Hospital. Terry Abdoo, a spokeswoman for the hospital, said Channell died on Monday. Both Kuykendall and Mrs. McManus said Channell was suffering from lung cancer and pneumonia at the time of his death. Channell ``struggled and struggled'' to recover from massive injuries that included several broken bones and a crushed pelvis, said Kuykendall, now a lobbyist. Fighting cancer, from which his brother had died two years ago, Channell ``was in tough shape,'' Kuykendall said. ``But until he got hit, his spirit was remarkable.'' Services for Channell will be held Saturday in Elkins, W.Va., followed by burial in Huttonsville, W.Va., said Mrs. McManus.

DOC.HEAD: World War II Anniversary Turns into Anti-Independence March
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout with anti-independence rally in Latvia. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Five thousand people who oppose secessionist movements in the Baltics turned a parade celebrating Soviet victory in World War II into an anti-independence rally in Latvia today. The rally was held in the shadow of Riga's towering monument to the victory over Nazi Germany, and speakers addressing the crowd denounced the Latvian parliament's declaration of independence on Friday. ``We consider the declaration of independence a defeat for everyone,'' said Lt. Gen. Oleg Zinchenko, head of the political directorate of the Baltic Military Region, which includes Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia. Zinchenko said the military was calling on the Kremlin to intervene more forcefully in the three Baltics republics. Many of his listeners waved bright red banners and Latvian flags emblazoned with the Soviet hammer and sickle. A similar military parade took place in the neighoring republic of Lithuania, Radio Vilnius reported. It said there were no confrontations between backers and opponents of Lithuania's March 11 declaration of independence. One resident of Vilnius, however, said that 200 young people shouted, ``Occupiers Go Home!'' at war veterans as they marched along Gediminas Avenue near a monument to Gen. Ivan Chernyakhovsky, a Soviet hero of World War II. The young people tried to block the path of the marchers, who were apparently Russians, but a cordon of paratroopers prevented them, said Pranas Karlonas, a Lithuanian radio editor. Soviet Defense Minister Dmitri T. Yazov, appearing on state-run TV in Moscow, complained about the attitude of the Baltic republics, which were annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940, overrun by German forces, then retaken by the Soviets. ``We were greeted with flowers'' when the Red Army drove the Nazis from the Baltic republics, said Yazov. When Latvia declared itself independence, it did not ask for an immediate break with Moscow or suspend the Soviet Constitution. Like Estonia, it has set an unspecified transition period for secession. Latvians are waiting to see if the Kremlin will impose economic sanctions and send troops to occupy some government buildings, as it did to Lithuania after that republic's independence decree. Unlike in Lithuania, where the population is 80 percent ethnic Lithuanian, ethnic Latvians are in a bare majority in the republic of 2.6 million people. Ethnic Estonians make of 64 percent of the 1.5 million people in their state. In Riga, the Victory Day celebration began at midmorning with a military parade overseen by the commander of the entire Baltic Military District, Maj. Gen. Fyodor Kuzmin. In brief remarks to hand-picked guests on the banks of the River Daugava, Kuzmin denounced Baltic independence, saying: ``We must overcome nationalist, separatist and anti-Soviet tendencies.'' Ceremonial cannon fire boomed through the warm spring air, signaling the beginning of a parade of troops, artillery and armored vehicles on the 45th anniversary of the defeat of Nazi Germany. Marchers included several hundred paratroopers in blue berets, whose presence in Riga over the past several days has caused some concern. Pavel Pedanov, a 76-year-old veteran watching the parade, said recent political events in Latvia spoiled the holiday. He said he opposed independence because ``the people should be all together.'' He lamented the denunciation by some Balts of the Soviet occupation in 1940 because ``they don't appreciate what we did.'' Veterans and officers marched toward the downtown victory monument, and were met on the way by about 5,000 residents who formed a separate civilian demonstration celebrating Victory Day and protesting secession. Most were speaking Russian, apparently members of the non-Latvian minority. One protester held a sign that said: ``Secession is profitable only for nationalist careerists and political adventurers.'' Another read: ``We'll support any leader who will impose order on the country and defend the ideals of socialism.'' Latvian lawmaker Viktors Alksnins, urged the crowd to support a signature drive demanding a republic-wide referendum on independence.

DOC.HEAD: Two NY Premieres and Fracci at Ballet Theater
DOC.TEXT: American Ballet Theater dancers looked wonderful on the second night of the company's season at the Metropolitan Opera. The program was two New York premieres, a dazzling ``Black Swan'' pas de deux and ``Lilac Garden'' starring Carla Fracci. The Italian ballerina returned to American Ballet Theater as a guest to perform in an excerpt from ``Lilac Garden'' at Monday's gala opening and the entire Antony Tudor ballet on Tuesday night. The entire ballet, to Chausson's ``Poeme,'' was as achingly romantic as it is meant to be. The young bride-to-be, danced by Miss Fracci with subtlety and gentle beauty, is stoical but suffering because in love with a younger man. He was danced with romantic yearning by Kevin McKenzie. Ross Stretton as the Man She Must Marry was stiff with his bride-to-be but softer when he met An Episode in His Past in the lilac garden. She, danced by Martine Van Hamel, seemed a strong survivor but she was hurting, too. The evening began with ``Birthday Offering,'' which Frederick Ashton choreographed for the 25th anniversary of the British Royal Ballet. It gives important solos to seven ballerinas, showing each one's strength. Ballet Theater added it to its repertory last October in Houston. On Tuesday, the star ballerina was Susan Jaffe, partnered by Stretton. The others were Cheryl Yeager, Amanda McKerrow, Julie Kent, Leslie Browne, Alessandra Ferri and Christine Dunham. All looked good. Fernando Bujones, back this season as a guest, having been greatly missed, and Cynthia Harvey danced the ``Black Swan'' pas de deux. Both were in the highest, exciting form. Toward the end of the duet, Miss Harvey danced only 16 of the famous 32 fouettes, whipped-leg turns. The audience murmured, fearing she had felt a muscle tear, but she finished the duet flawlessly. The evening ended with the half-hour ``Brief Fling'' which Twyla Tharp choreographed for the company. This eclectic, quite enjoyable ballet had its premiere in February in San Francisco. In it, Cheryl Yeager and Julio Bocca, in Navy, do formal ballet dancing to ``I'm a Little Teapot'' played on amplified piano. Shelley Washington, loose-limbed as Miss Tharp was as a dancer, looked like an urchin being tossed around by Jamie Bishton, Kevin O'Day and Keith Roberts in mini-kilts. Claudia Alfieri, Isabella Padovani, Gil Boggs and Robert Wallace wore red plaid. During the 10 sections of ``Brief Fling'' there also was a jig and music which sounded like minimalism meeting a cement mixer. The music was by Michel Colombier. Clever costumes were by Isaac Mizrahi. Dennis Cleveland played the violin solo in ``Lilac Garden.'' The orchestra sounded thin, as though too small for the requirements of the music.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Says No Prisoner-Hostage Swap Without Release of Israelis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to UPDATE with Shamir's remarks. Pickup 4th, ``When there...'' Deletes grafs 12-13, ``Deputy Foreign...praise it.'' to tighten. ^By ARIEH O'SULLIVAN
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today that Israel would not release any Arab prisoners in return for Western hostages unless Israeli soldiers held in Lebanon were also freed. Speaking for the first time about a possible prisoner-hostage swap, Shamir said no progress had been made in efforts to secure the release of three Israeli soldiers captured in Lebanon in 1986. Asked about U.S. hints that Israel might free its Shiite prisoners to facilitate the release of Western hostages, Shamir said: ``I don't think that anybody will ask Israel to participate in such an endeavor without having a possibility to release our own prisoners and missing soldiers.'' The three missing Israeli soldiers are believed held by Hezbollah, or the Party of God, a pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem group. Hezbollah is also believed to have links to the Shiite extremists holding most of the 16 remaining Western hostages, including six Americans. When asked whether any progress had been made concerning the release of the Israeli soldiers, Shamir said: ``Unfortunately, not yet.'' He spoke to reporters during a tour of a high-tech factory in Jerusalem. Israel's military chief of staff, Lt. Gen. Dan Shomron, said no contacts were under way concerning a three-way swap involving Israel, the United States and the captors in Lebanon. Shomron said in an interview broadcast today on Israel radio that there have been no practical proposals for a prisoner swap. He also said any deal that might materialize would have to include the release of the the three Israeli soldiers held in Lebanon. ``When there is a readiness on the other side to return (Israeli) prisoners, we are prepared for an exchange. This (policy) has not changed,'' Shomron said. ``Today, there is nothing concrete, where someone is talking to us about exchanges.'' Shomron was interviewed Tuesday night at a reunion of hostages and soldiers from the 1976 Entebbe rescue mission. He noted that Israel had the option of rescuing hostages with a military mission. At the Entebbe Airport in Uganda, more than 100 passengers aboard an Air France plane hijacked by Palestinians were saved by a daring Israeli commando operation. ``In my opinion, the Israel Defense Forces can do it again even today. The IDF has units today that can do it, maybe even better, because they have better tools.'' President Bush has indirectly appealed to Israel to free Shiites as a goodwill gesture to encourage further releases of Western hostages, including six Americans. Last month, thanks in part to Iran and Syria, Shiite militant kidnappers in Lebanon released Americans Frank Herbert Reed and Robert Polhill. Iranian officials have said the release of any more American hostages likely hinges on Israel's willingness to free Moslem prisoners, including Sheik Obeid, a Shiite cleric taken from his home in southern Lebanon in 1989. About 30 Lebanese prisoners, including Shiite clergyman Sheik Abul Karim Obeid, are held in Israel. The South Lebanon Army, the Lebanese militia trained and supplied by Israel, has more than 300 mostly Shiite prisoners in a south Lebanon jail. In addition to the Shiites, Israel holds 9,986 Palestinians who were detained during the Palestinian uprising against Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Former Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin, also interviewed at the reunion Tuesday night, said Israel was prepared to use all its ``bargaining chips'' to win the release of its captives. He said Israel's abduction of Obeid from south Lebanon in July was necessary to provide Israel with a bargaining chip for a hostage swap. ``My policy has been that when you have a hostage situation, soldiers or civilians, if there's a military option, you use it. If not, then enter an exchange deal. For that you have to have the cards,'' Rabin said.

DOC.HEAD: 31 Killed in Fighting, Aoun Threatens Shipping
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with higher death toll, details of fighting; pickup 8th graf pvs, Geagea controls...'
DOC.TEXT: Fierce shelling today by the forces of rival Christian leaders Gen. Michel Aoun and Samir Geagea killed 20 people and wounded 41, police said. The barrages came after Aoun threatened to attack ships using ports controlled by Geagea. On Tuesday night, 11 people died and 21 were wounded in fighting. The casualties raised the overall toll to 972 killed and 2,564 wounded since the showdown for dominance of the Christian enclave north of Beirut broke out Jan. 30. Tuesday's deaths included Brig. Gen. Francois Zein, commander of the military academy in the Aoun-held Fayadiyeh suburb east of Beirut. Zein, 47, was killed when his office at the academy was hit in a barrage fired by Geagea's Lebanese Forces militiamen. Aoun's threat to attack ports controlled by Geagea was aimed at cutting off supplies for Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia. A communique issued by Aoun's headquarters warned ``local and international maritime agencies'' against serving any port along the 28-mile stretch of Mediterranean coast in the enclave. Geagea's headquarters said in a communique the warning was ``illegal because it was issued by an illegitimate side that usurped power.'' The communique pledged ``severe response to any attack on a civilian ship.'' Smoke billowed from east Beirut's district of Ashrafiyeh, Geagea's main stronghold, and the pinewoods of the Metn mountains, where Aoun's troops are entrenched. The thuds of exploding shells echoed across Beirut as radio stations interrupted regular programming to report on the developments and blare appeals from hospitals for blood donations to cope with the influx of casualties. Geagea controls Beirut harbor and the ports of Jounieh and Byblos north of the capital. Jounieh, 12{ miles from Beirut, is the terminal for a ferry and a hydrofoil from Cyprus. These vessels are the Christians' only outlet from their enclave, which is ringed on its land sides by hostile Syrian troops and their Moslem militia allies. Aoun's 19,000-man army controls only a three-mile strip of the Christian coast and he is not believed to have any working gunboats left from the heavy fighting with Geagea's militia of 6,000 fighters and thousands of reservists. He has heavy artillery in the mountains overlooking Beirut and the coast and has used it to fire on Geagea's flotilla of gunboats and armed speedboats. But the guns are not radar-controlled and the police spokesman noted: ``It will be extremely difficult for Aoun's gunners to hit mobile targets, especially speedboats.'' The communique said Aoun declared the coast between Christian east Beirut and the Madfoun bridge in north Lebanon a military operations zone. ``Sailing across it is banned to any vessel irrespective of its type or cargo,'' the communique said. Geagea ordered his flotilla to blockade Aoun's only sea outlet at Dbaye, north of Beirut, on April 23 in an effort to prevent the general shipping in weapons and ammunition. President Elias Hrawi and Prime Minister Salim Hoss drove to the Syrian capital, Damascus, for talks with President Hafez Assad on ways of implementing a peace plan to end Lebanon's 15-year-old Christian-Moslem civil war. Aoun has rejected the Arab League-brokered peace plan, endorsed by Lebanon's Parliament in the Saudi Arabian resort of Taif in October, because it does not guarantee the withdrawal of Syrian forces from Lebanon. Syria, the main power broker in Lebanon, maintains 40,000 troops in predominantly Moslem regions under a 1976 Arab League peacekeeping mandate. Aoun calls them an occupying army. He also refuses to recognize Hrawi's election to implement the peace plan. But Geagea has recognized Hrawi and cautiously accepted the peace plan, which calls for an equal distribution of power between Moslems and Christians.

DOC.HEAD: Problem With Cooling System Could Delay Shuttle Launch
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT time element.
DOC.TEXT: Next week's launch of Columbia with a $100 million observatory could be delayed days or even weeks because of a problem with the shuttle cooling system. ``We're trying to understand it and understand where we go from here,'' William Lenoir, head of NASA's space flight program, said Tuesday. ``We'll probably fool with it another day or so before we make that decision.'' Columbia had been due to lift off May 16 or May 17, but a valve that controls the flow of coolant does not appear to be working properly, NASA said. If the valve has to be changed, NASA would prefer replacing it at the launch pad, where it's never been done before, said NASA administrator Richard Truly. Bascom Murrah, a NASA official in charge of prelaunch operations, estimated it would be a ``10-day to two-week hit'' to make the repairs on the pad because the system would have to be drained of coolant and cleaned. Rolling the shuttle back to its hangar to change the valve or another part could take even longer, Truly said. During Columbia's nine- to 10-day flight, the four astronomers in the seven-member crew will operate the Astro observatory, which will probe sources of ultraviolet and X-ray radiation.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Snubbed by Some American Vets
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle hailed America's World War II soldiers today as heroes who laid the groundwork for European unity, but some veterans boycotted a ceremony because of Quayle's military record. In remarks to about two dozen members of the American Legion of Paris, the vice president praised Dwight D. Eisenhower's vision of world peace. ``Eisenhower foresaw that the Europe that existed in his time must change to reflect the fundamental principles that these heroes fought for, principles that the United States and France have shared for some 200 years,'' he said. But one of the legionnaires present said that several people in his 750-member organization declined to attend the ceremony at the American Embassy because they believed Quayle avoided combat duty during the Vietnam War by joining the Indiana National Guard. ``That bothers some of the members,'' said a Vietnam veteran who asked not to be identified. ``But he could have gone to Vietnam. The Massachusetts National Guard was called up and they took heavy casualties.'' Roger Lamtgne, a decorated member of the 101st Army division that parachuted into Normandy on D-Day, called his views on Quayle's military record ``personal.'' ``But I will say that I think a man owes at least one time in his life to his country,'' said Lamtgne of Lewiston, Maine, who wore an ``I Like Ike'' button above his Bronze Star and Purple Heart earned during the D-Day landing. Quayle later met President Francois Mitterrand for talks to follow up the April 19 summit in Key Largo, Fla., with President Bush. ``Things are changing in Europe,'' Quayle said after the 45-minute meeting. ``They're changing on the positive side of the ledger. President Mitterrand has a vision of where Europe should be going. His views are not only listened to, but solicited.'' The pair did not discuss the situation in Lithuania, but Quayle praised a proposal by Mitterrand and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany that the breakaway Soviet republic suspend its declaration of independence and negotiate terms of secession with Moscow. ``It was very positive contribution to a very delicate situation,'' Quayle said. ``We hope and anticipate this matter will be resolved without violence.'' Mitterrand supports a new European framework for security focusing on the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. Foreign ministers from the conference meet in September to prepare a summit in late 1990. The conference includes the United States, Canada and all European nations except Albania. Quayle's swing through Rome, London and Paris marks his first official trip to Europe since being elected in 1988. Its purpose was to celebrate the 100th anniversary of Eisenhower's birth and strengthen the Atlantic alliance as the Cold War barriers between East and West break down.

DOC.HEAD: Lukens Loses After Sex Scandal; Runoff to Decide Helms Opponent
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 13-19, ``The top...' with 5 grafs to UPDATE with Easley calling for runoff in North Carolina Senate race. Picks up 20th graf pvs, `There was...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CN6
DOC.TEXT: Ohio voters cast out Rep. Donald ``Buz'' Lukens, his long career shattered by his conviction on a sex offense, while North Carolinians boosted a black Democrat's bid to challenge conservative Republican Sen. Jesse Helms. ``Never argue with the voters,'' Lukens said finishing a distant third in Tuesday's GOP primary, which he entered over the objections of his party's leaders. The loss, following his conviction on charges of having sex with a 16-year-old girl, apparently ended a congressional career that spanned nearly 25 years. On the busiest day of primary elections so far this year, both Helms and Democratic Sen. Jay Rockefeller of West Virginia coasted to easy victories and turned their attention to the general elections in November. In other races: _Ohio Attorney General Anthony J. Celebrezze Jr. picked up more than 80 percent of his party's vote to claim the Democratic nomination for governor. That sets up a November race against the Republican nominee, former Cleveland Mayor George Voinovich. _West Virginia's former first lady, Dee Caperton, lost her shot at joining the administration of her ex-husband, Gov. Gaston Caperton, when she was beaten in the Democratic primary for state treasurer. _The indicted mayor of Atlantic City, N.J., James Usry, clinched a spot in a June 12 runoff by finishing second to a city councilman in a seven-way non-partisan race. _Former Democratic Reps. Katie Hall of Indiana and Ken Hechler of West Virginia lost comeback bids in their old districts. Ms. Hall was beaten by Rep. Pete Visclosky, and Hechler lost to Rep. Nick Joe Rahall Jr. _A 100-year-old eye doctor lost his race for Congress in North Carolina but wouldn't admit it. ``I don't concede a damn thing,'' Harry Merritt Stenhouse said after being trounced by businessman Don Davis. The big race in North Carolina was the contest to select a Democratic opponent for Helms, the flamboyant conservative who sets Democrats' nerves on edge. Helms had little trouble knocking off two GOP challengers, businessman George Wimbish and salvage dealer L.C. Nixon, who could manage only 8 percent of the vote each. With 99 percent of the precincts in, Helms had 84 percent, or 155,101 votes. The top finisher in the Democratic primary was former Charlotte Mayor Harvey Gantt, who is hoping to become the first black Senate nominee in North Carolina in this century. But Gantt failed to win the 40 percent needed to avoid a June 5 runoff, which second-place finisher Michael Easley, the Brunswick County district attorney, called for this morning. Thad Beyle, a political science professor at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, said a runoff would be bad news for Gantt. ``I think if you go on the basis of the political history of the state, if a liberal or a minority doesn't win it in the first primary, they'll lose it in the second primary,'' Beyle said. With 99 percent of the precincts reporting, Gantt had 257,485 votes, or 38 percent, to Easley's 205,972 votes, or 30 percent. They were trailed by John Ingram, a former state insurance commissioner, with 118,018, or 17 percent, and R.P. ``Bo'' Thomas, a former state senator, with 80,875 votes or 12 percent. Two other candidates ran far behind. There was less suspense in Tuesday's other Senate contest, in West Virginia, where Republican attorney John Yoder had no opposition and Democrat Rockefeller had little more. With 89 percent of precincts reporting, Rockefeller had 176,341 votes, or 84 percent, to a combined 32,551 votes for his opponents, inventor Ken Thompson and conceptual artist Paul Nuchims. ``I've won folks, how about that!'' Rockefeller told about 50 supporters at his campaign headquarters. There was no celebration for Lukens, who has served in Congress or the Ohio state Senate since 1967. His career began to unravel last year, when he was convicted of a misdemeanor for having sex with a teen-ager. And although he refused Republican leaders' advice to retire, voters decided it was time. According to final unofficial returns in western Ohio's 8th District, state Rep. John Boehner won with 25,068 votes, or 49 percent, followed by former Rep. Thomas Kindness with 16,330 votes, or 32 percent, and Lukens with 8,681 votes, or 17 percent. Mort Meier, a bond underwriter, had 716 votes or 1 percent. Lukens said afterward that he has no immediate plans. ``I really haven't thought beyond tomorrow,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Conyngham Returns to Port After Fire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to raise reference to second death, and SUBS 21st graf, `In another...' with ID of second fatality.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: The guided-missile destroyer USS Conyngham, damaged by a fire so hot its decks were ``bubbling,'' docked today at the Norfolk Naval Station as the Navy began investigating the blaze that killed a crewman. Eighteen other sailors, including the No. 2 officer, were injured in the worst shipboard fire since a string of accidents prompted the Navy to suspend operations for a two-day safety check in November. A second Navy man was killed in a separate accident on Chesapeake Bay. Six of the sailors with less serious injuries accompanied the ship back to port before going to the hospital, said Capt. Paul Hanley, Atlantic Fleet spokesman. Twelve others had been flown from the ship to hospitals. The Conyngham, with a large scorch mark on its right side just above the water line, docked at 2:30 a.m., 21 hours after the fire erupted during routine operations about 100 miles southeast of Norfolk, said Lt. j.g. Karl Johnson, an Atlantic Fleet spokesman. The commander of a ship that helped the Conyngham fight the blaze said today it was ``a major league fire'' that could have destroyed the warship. Capt. Joseph W. Perrotta Jr., skipper of the USS Normandy, said when he approached the Conyngham, smoke was pouring out of the ship's forward stack area and bridge. The Normandy provided additional firefighting equipment and personnel to help the Conyngham crew control the blaze. The Conyngham crew ``did a super job of putting out that fire,'' Perrotta said. The ship could have been lost if not for the gallant effort of the crew.'' About 200 family members and friends met the 383-member crew, which disembarked as work crews from other vessels boarded the Conyngham to clear the vessel's decks of water, Hanley said. Naval Investigative Service agents earlier were flown to the ship to help preserve evidence, said Cmdr. Deborah Burnette, an Atlantic Fleet spokeswoman. The fire aboard the 27-year-old ship started in the No. 1 boiler room as the boiler was being fired up, and spread to the ship's nerve center, said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. ``The fire spread to the combat information center spaces, which caused the captain to evacuate the combat information center and the bridge, temporarily leaving the ship without communications and dead in the water,'' Fitzwater said. One of the injured was seaman James Choss, of Hammond Lake, Ind., an electrician getting ready for bed after working most of the night in the combat information center, his mother said. ``One of the other guys in the room was hit by a fireball that singed his hair,'' said Elizabeth Choss. Her son described hallways filled with smoke, holes burned in the floor, masks on firefighting gear that melted onto the faces of his shipmates and ``decks that were bubbling' in the intense heat, she said. ``It was just trashed _ those were his words,'' Mrs. Choss said. ``He said a fuel pump blew down in one of the boilers'' and that's what started the fire, Mrs. Choss said. Choss and his companions were unable to get out of their berth area right away because they couldn't get the hatch open, she said. The main fire was put out about 8 a.m., about 2{ hours after it started, but the crew continued to fight smaller fires until shortly before noon, the Navy said. The extent of damage was not immediately known. Killed was Lt. Algernon Pope Gordon Jr., 34, of Montgomery, Ala. He was the ship's operations officer, in charge of collecting, evaluating and disseminating tactical information. Three of the 12 sailors airlifted to hospitals were reported in guarded condition, the rest in satisfactory condition, including Lt. Cmdr. Martin Moody of Indian Head, Md., the ship's executive officer. The ship started for home under its own power, but its captain, Cmdr. William R. Williams, ordered the engines shut down as a precaution after a fuel leak was discovered, Ms. Burnette said. Shortly after noon, the salvage ship USS Opportune took the Conyngham under tow. In another accident Tuesday, a propeller broke apart and threw debris onto the deck of a Navy hovercraft involved in a towing exercise at the mouth of Chesapeake Bay, killing a crewman. The Navy identified the victim as Petty Officer 3rd Class Norbert Thomas Hanke of Louisville, Ky. No age was immediately available. Last fall, the Navy ordered a two-day ``stand-down'' during which ships and installations reviewed safety procedures. More than 100 Navy personnel were killed on duty during 1989, including 47 who died in a gun turret explosion aboard the battleship Iowa. From Oct. 11 to Nov. 22, 13 serious accidents occurred, four on Nov. 14 alone. Since the stand-down fewer accidents have been reported, Navy officials said, although no statistics immediately were available. The 437-foot ship was commissioned in 1963. A conventionally powered warship, the Conyngham is armed with Harpoon anti-ship missiles and Standard anti-aircraft missiles, torpedoes, depth charges and two 5-inch guns. Pentagon spokesman Bob Hall said he ship was scheduled to be decommissioned in 1991. He declined to say if it might be decommissioned sooner because of the damage. In May 1987, the Conyngham helped put out the fire on the USS Stark and tow it to port after it was hit by missiles from an Iraqi jet in the Persian Gulf. Sixty Conyngham crew members were decorated for valor for their actions.

DOC.HEAD: Voters Reject Lukens Bid For Nomination
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 9th, `I think...' to add passage of stadium proposal in Cleveland, which moved as a separate story on sports wires.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Primary Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Voters sent U.S. Rep. Donald ``Buz'' Lukens into retirement one year after he was convicted of having sex with a teen-age girl. Lukens, 59, who had served western Ohio nearly 25 years in the Legislature and in Congress, finished a distant third Tuesday in the four-way Republican primary after the party disowned him and invited the voters to remove him. The GOP nominated state Rep. John Boehner, 40, of West Chester, to run in November. He faces Democrat Gregory Jolivette, 38, former mayor of Hamilton. ``Never argue with the voters,'' Lukens said as he walked along Main Street after his loss. ``You always believe you can win, but without money, you just can't make enough things happen. Name is just not enough.'' In Lukens' case, his name may have hurt him after his conviction last May on a misdemeanor charge of contributing to the unruliness of a minor. A Columbus girl alleged the divorced congressman had sex with her in 1988 when she was 16. Lukens was sentenced to 30 days in jail and fined $500 but is free on bail while he appeals. ``I feel he deserved to lose after the kind of stunts he pulled. He kind of set himself up to lose,'' one constituent, Eric Hayes, said Tuesday night. ``His character and the vote kind of went hand-in-hand,'' said Tim Jones. ``I think you get what you deserve,'' said Donna Craft. Elsewhere in Ohio, Cuyahoga County voters agreed to pay up to half the $344 million cost of a new downtown sports complex where the Cleveland Indians and Cleveland Cavaliers plan on moving in 1994. The ``Gateway'' proposal passed by 52 percent to 48 percent Tuesday, putting an extra tax on cigarettes and alcohol to help pay for an open-air baseball stadium and a basketball arena. Lukens was seeking his third consecutive two-year term and fifth overall. He first was elected to Congress in 1966 and served two terms before stepping aside to run unsuccessfully for governor in 1970. He was elected to the state Senate in 1971 and served there until 1986, when he again won election to Congress. With all precincts reporting, Boehner had 25,068 votes, or 49 percent, to 16,330 votes, or 32 percent, for former U.S. Rep. Thomas Kindness, who represented the district for 12 years until 1986. Lukens had 8,681 votes, or 17 percent, and Mort Meier, a bond underwriter, had 716 votes, or 1 percent. Among the Democrats, Jolivette had 13,122 votes, or 52 percent. Lawyer Harry Wilks had 9,012 votes, or 36 percent, and Ricky Lee Mattox was third with 3,166 votes, or 13 percent. ``We can be proud to be Democrats today,'' Jolivette said. ``I'm not sure if John Boehner can (hold) his head up high with the distortions and negative campaigning he's made against Tom Kindness during their campaign.'' Boehner dismissed Jolivette's comment. ``He's just starting his November campaign today,'' the GOP candidate said.

DOC.HEAD: Man Sentenced to Six Months for Using Hummingbird as Necklace
DOC.TEXT: It wasn't an albatross but a pet hummingbird that landed a man in jail after police caught him wearing the bird as a necklace. Ramon A. Ruiz, 26, of suburban North Hollywood, was sentenced to six months in jail after pleading no contest Tuesday to cruelty to animals and an unrelated probation violation in San Fernando Municipal Court. In exchange for the plea, prosecutors dropped a charge of willful injury to an animal. Ruiz was arrested April 6 after police officers saw him walking in North Hollywood with the bird tied to an 18-inch pink string around his neck. The bird died a few hours after Ruiz was taken into custody. Ruiz's public defender, Dean Masserman, said Ruiz had clipped the bird's wings so he could keep it as a pet. ``Sometimes he tied it around his neck. That was poor judgment,'' Masserman said. Deputy City Attorney Norm Wegener said animal control officers never determined what killed the hummingbird. It had lost circulation in its legs where the string was tied, police reports said. At the time of his arrest, Ruiz was on violation for spousal battery and tampering with a vehicle.

DOC.HEAD: Highlights of Tuesday's Voting in 5 States
DOC.TEXT:
Here, at a glance, are highlights of primary voting in five states Tuesday:
WEST VIRGINIA= SENATE: Sen. Jay Rockefeller defeated two Democratic primary opponents in his bid for a second six-year term. John Yoder was unopposed for the GOP nomination. CONGRESS: In 4th congressional district, World War II historian Ken Hechler failed to wrest his old congressional seat from seven-term incumbent Nick Joe Rahall Jr. in their third scrap in West Virginia's coal fields since 1976. STATE TREASURER: Dee Caperton, ex-wife of Gov. Gaston Caperton, finished second to Larrie Bailey in a four-way Democratic primary for state treasurer. Elvin F. Martin was unopposed on GOP side.
NORTH CAROLINA= SENATE: Sen. Jesse Helms, seeking a 4th term, won the Republican primary challenge over two virtual unknowns. Former Charlotte Mayor Harvey Gantt topped a six-man field running for the Democratic nomination but faces a June 5 runoff with second place finisher Southport District Attorney Mike Easley. CONGRESS: In the 3rd congressional district, 100-year-old Henry Merritt Stenhouse lost the Republican nomination and the chance to challenge incumbent Democrat Martin Lancaster to businessman Don Davis.
OHIO= GOVERNOR: On the Democratic side, Attorney General Anthony J. Celebrezze Jr. defeated one token opponent. George Voinovich, the former Cleveland mayor, ran unopposed for the GOP nomination. CONGRESS: In the 8th District, Republican Rep. Donald Lukens lost his seat as state Rep. John Boehner won the Republican primary. Former Hamilton Mayor Gregory Jolivette won the Democratic primary. REFERENDUM: Voters in the Cleveland area agreed to raise taxes on liquor and cigarettes to finance new baseball stadium complex.
INDIANA= SENATE: Sen. Dan Coats unopposed in Republican primary; state Rep. Baron Hill unopposed on Democratic side. CONGRESS: In the 1st District, incumbent Democrat Peter Visclosky won his primary, defeating three challengers including the woman he ousted from the seat in 1984, Katie Hall.
NEW JERSEY= MAYOR: None of the seven candidates in the non-partisan mayoral election received 50 percent of the vote so the two top vote-getters, Mayor James Usry and City Councilman Jim Whelan, will vie for office in a June 12 runoff. Usry ran for re-election despite his indictment for bribery.

DOC.HEAD: About 10,000 Gallons of Gasoline Leaks into Waterway
DOC.TEXT: About 10,000 gallons of gasoline leaked from a punctured barge early today into a heavily industrialized waterway between New York's Staten Island and New Jersey, the Coast Guard said. The spill at the GATX terminal on the Arthur Kill, site of about a half-dozen spills this year, was reported by workers on the barge, which is owned by Victoria Transportation of Elizabeth, said Coast Guard Petty Officer Jodi Hoffmaster. Workers had been pumping unleaded gasoline onto the barge for several hours before realizing there was a hole beneath the water line, said George Lowman, a spokesman for Chicago-based GATX. Fire Chief Richard Greenberg said the hole was about 8 feet long. Hoffmaster said 10,000 gallons spilled. Lowman said company officials believed between 5,000 and 10,000 gallons of fuel leaked into the Arthur Kill, which connects to New York Harbor. The waterway was reopened after about five hours when most of the gasoline had either evaporated or dispersed, said Coast Guard Petty Officer Howard Holmes. The barge was to remain at the GATX terminal until officials could inspect it, Lowman said.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Battle Police in Anti-Government Protests
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE with details of fire at U.S. office, CORRECTS name to U.S. Information Service Center and that protests were the largest in the capital since 1987. Edits thruout to tighten. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos SEL1,5
DOC.TEXT: About 15,000 students hurling rocks and firebombs fought with riot police and set a U.S. government building on fire today in the largest anti-government protests in the capital since 1987. Violent protests demanding the overthrow of President Roh Tae-woo also were staged in other cities. Police, who fired tear gas canisters in Seoul, said dozens of officers and protesters were injured but gave no numbers. It appeared no one was hurt in the fire at the U.S. building. The demonstrations came as the newly created Democratic Liberal Party held its inaugural convention. The students claim the party, created by merging three political groups, will lead to dictatorship. Fierce street battles broke out in central Seoul as groups of 300 to 2,000 students dashed from sidewalks to occupy main streets around the fashionable Shinsegye Department Store just before sunset. About 2,000 riot police in the area were outnumbered by columns of protesters surging down main boulevards leading to city hall and other government offices. Angry demonstrators overpowered at least two groups of 200 to 300 riot police and seized their helmets, clubs and shields. Some police were beaten up by protesters. About 3,000 students fought pitched battles with riot police near the U.S. Information Service Center in downtown Seoul. During the two hours of fighting, students broke windows at the center and threw firebombs inside the first floor, touching off a fire that burned out of control for more than an hour. Firefighters extinguished the blaze after police regained control of the street. ``Yankee go home!'' students shouted as they hurled rocks at the four-story building, which houses a library and trade offices. ``No U.S. personnel were known to be inside the building,'' said Jack Sears, spokesman for the U.S. Embassy. He said a Korean cleaning crew might have been inside. No damage estimate was available. Street battles also broke out in other parts of the capital as students tried to break through lines of police blocking their march into the city center. ``Down with Roh Tae-woo!'' students shouted as they raced down the streets, raising their clenched fists in the air. By nightfall, the demonstrators, many armed with wooden sticks and rocks, took control of several commercial streets in the heart of the capital. A huge plaza in front of City Hall was filled with tear gas and covered with rocks and broken bottles. Observers said the protests were the largest and most serious since nationwide anti-government demonstrations in 1987 forced former President Chun Doo-hwan to carry out major democratic political reforms. At that time, hundreds of thousands of Koreans took to the streets daily for three weeks. Earlier in the day, police arrested nine students who tried to march on the U.S. Embassy in central Seoul, shouting anti-government and anti-U.S. slogans. Radicals claim U.S. Ambassador Donald Gregg, a former CIA Seoul station chief, was behind a plot by government conservatives to prolong their power beyond 1993, when Roh's term ends. Roh took office in early 1988 after winning the country's first direct presidential elections in 16 years. In the central city of Chongju, about 100 students set fire to a police station, and in nearby Taejon students burned a police bus with firebombs, the Yonhap news agency reported. In the southern city of Kwangju, an opposition stronghold, about 200 students wrote ``Let's destroy the DLP dictatorship'' in blood on a huge placard during a campus rally, the agency said. Violent protests also were reported in Suwon, Taegu, Pusan, Chunju, Cheju, Kongju and Mokpo. Radicals had said they would stage violent anti-government protests in 17 cities, and the nation's 130,000 police were put on increased alert. Radical students and dissidents oppose Roh's new governing political party, which they say is ``dictatorial and undemocratic.'' ``We can achieve nothing without national unity and harmony,'' Roh told about 8,000 cheering supporters who filled an Olympic gymnasium in southern Seoul for the inauguration of the party. It was formed in a merger of Roh's old party with two moderate opposition groups early this year. Roh was chosen as party president during the convention. Roh said the three-party merger, an unprecedented alliance between governing and opposition parties, will help stabilize the country's politics, which he said had been marked by ``confusion and confrontation.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Gets Lengthy Term for Racial Attack on Youth
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Terrence in 4th graf is correct.
DOC.TEXT: A man convicted in the racially motivated shooting of a black youth has been sentenced to the maximum of 14 years and eight months in state prison. Mark Shane Lashley, 29, was sentenced Tuesday by Superior Court Judge John Shook, who convicted Shook in a non-jury trial last month of second-degree attempted murder, a felony civil rights charge and a misdemeanor civil rights count. Shook called the 1988 shooting in Playa del Rey an ``egregious offense against society for which (Lashley) will be punished severely with a maximum sentence, which is so justly and richly deserved.'' According to trial testimony, 14-year-old Terrence Goudeau and three young cousins were fishing on June 26, 1988, when Lashley and two friends shouted racial slurs at them. The boys yelled back and the argument escalated, ending when Lashley aimed a .22-caliber rifle at Goudeau, who ran, shielding a 12-year-old cousin. Goudeau was shot in the back, and a bullet nicked a lung. Bullet fragments remain embedded near his spine. Lashley's attorney, Lloyd Riley, who is black, called the prison term unreasonably harsh and said there was ``too much emphasis on the factor of race.''

DOC.HEAD: American Legion Band Helps Celebrate Soviet Victory Day
DOC.TEXT: An American Legion band didn't get to march through Red Square as planned, but the musicians did strut down Marx Prospect today, drawing hugs, kisses and cheers from Muscovites celebrating Victory Day. Bandleader Dorothy Hill, 74, brought the 70-member, all-male band from American Legion Post 156 in Waltham, Mass., to the Soviet Union on a mission of peace. Mrs. Hill said band members had originally been led to believe from Soviet officials that they would be the first U.S. band to play in the main Victory Day military parade through Red Square celebrating the defeat of Nazi Germany. But after the band arrived in Moscow, the Soviet Peace Committee, which is organizing their visit, kept changing the Americans' schedule and finally they were informed that they wouldn't be able to march in the Red Square parade. No explanation was immediately available for the change in schedule. Instead, the band had to settle for taking part in another Victory Day parade in downtown Moscow of marching musical units from various Soviet republics. And the Americans proved to be a crowd favorite. As the band marched down Gorky Street and turned onto cordoned-off Marx Prospect playing ``God Bless America,'' traffic police gave up trying to control the crowds thronging after the Americans. During ``The Battle Hymn of the Republic,'' one woman in the crowd running beside the band shouted back ``Slava! Slava!'' (``Glory! Glory!''). Others gave the ``V'' for victory sign and waved their fists in a salute. The band settled into seats in an open space next to the Bolshoi Theater for a concert, and a crowd of about 1,000 pressed around it so tightly that it had to be warned repeatedly to move back. Soviet war veterans wearing medals repeatedly hugged the American Legion members wearing their military decorations. During a one-hour concert, the band played ``When the Saints Go Marching In,'' ``Yankee Doodle Dandy'' and ``Old Gray Mare,'' during which Mrs. Hill twirled around jauntily to the music. As they played ``Hail Massachusetts,'' the band members put down their instruments and sang the chorus: ``Swinging down the avenue, with colors on high; We'll tell the whole creation that Massachusetts passes by.'' The crowd responded by improvising a chorus of ``Moscow Nights.'' ``You see there is friendship and everybody is watching with pleasure. That's why so many people are gathered here, thanks to them,'' said Nikolai Sidorenko, a World War II paratrooper. After the concert, the band members laid a wreath at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier who fell in World War II. Summing up the trip, Mrs. Hill, a World War II Coast Guard veteran, said it was ``far more than I ever expected to accomplish on a first visit.'' Richard Giovangelo, a band member from Newtonville, Mass., expressed some regret in not being able to march through Red Square. ``I wanted to. It was my impression that we were going to. Now that we didn't, I'm somewhat disappointed,'' he said. ``But overall, I'm satisfied.'' The Joseph P. Hill American Legion Band, named after Mrs. Hill's late husband, arrived in Moscow on Saturday on a 10-day trip. Its members range in age from 17 to 82, and include veterans of World War II, Korea and Vietnam.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Offers to Halt Chemical Weapons Production
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, looking for an agreement to highlight his upcoming summit, is offering to halt production of chemical weapons if the Soviets set a schedule for destroying their poison gas stockpiles, administration officials said today. With the visit of Mikhail S. Gorbachev less than two weeks away, and other arms control negotiations running into snags, Bush would like to conclude a chemical weapons agreement. However, the officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the Soviets had to meet two conditions before the United States would agree to stop turning out chemical weapons. The first, they said, is to agree to a schedule to destroy the Soviet stockpiles. The other is to allow the United States to keep a small arsenal until all nations capable of production agree to a global accord. Initially, Bush last year offered to end production over eight years. But now, the officials said, he is willing to set a date far short of that if the Soviets meet the conditions. Secretary of State James A. Baker III will explore prospects when he meets in Moscow next week with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. They are also to go over problems in other arms control fields. The most difficult concern a proposed treaty to cut long-range nuclear missiles, bombers and submarines by up to 50 percent on each side. Bush and Gorbachev had hoped to sign such a treaty at their May 30-June 3 summit here. But as the date draws close, many differences remain. These include a Soviet demand to restrict multi-warhead missiles carried on warships. The administration is resisting this, and also insisting on retaining more air-launched cruise missiles than the Soviets have proposed. A chemical weapons agreement at the summit would be historic and serve the political purpse of distracting attention from slow progress in other areas. The United States now has about 32,000 tons of poison gas. U.S. officials consider the Soviet stockpile to be somewhat larger, even though Moscow announced in 1987 that it had stopped production while the Reagan administration declined to end the U.S. program to produce binary weapons. This is a process of manufacturing two ingredients which are deadly when mixed. Even if the Soviets agree to terms before or during the Washington summit, officials said the accord would begin to take effect some months later. The first accounts of Bush's chemical weapons initiative appeared in Tuesday editions of The Washington Times.

DOC.HEAD: North Carolina Democrats Gantt, Easley Facing Runoff in Senate Race
With PM-Primary Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Former Charlotte Mayor Harvey Gantt will face a runoff with a district attorney in his bid to become the first black nominated for the Senate from North Carolina this century. With 99 percent of precincts reporting, unofficial returns showed Gantt leading Brunswick County District Attorney Mike Easley by 38 percent to 30 percent. Gantt was just shy of the 40 percent threshold needed for an outright nomination to face Republican incumbent Jesse Helms in November. ``It's like kissing your sister at the last minute,'' Gantt said as the final precincts were counted. ``We want to get the brass ring and it's pretty close.'' Four other candidates on the Democratic ballot split the remaining 32 percent of the vote. In the Republican primary, Helms easily defeated two opponents, drawing 84 percent of the vote. Gantt, who campaigned on the premise that a runoff would divide the party, urged Easley late Tuesday not to let ``1 or 2 percent divide us.'' But Easley called for a runoff in a news conference this morning at state Democratic Party Headquarters. ``We don't want to send our candidate into the fall armed with less than 40 percent of the vote,'' Easley said. Easley said he informed Gantt this morning that he wanted a runoff, which otherwise would not occur automatically under state law. ``I don't think he expressed disappointment and I don't think he expressed any surprise,'' he said. Gantt had no immediate comment on Easley's announcement. Thad Beyle, a political science professor at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, said a runoff would be bad news for Gantt, despite his first-place finish. ``I think if you go on the basis of the political history of the state, if a liberal or a minority doesn't win it in the first primary, they'll lose it in the second primary,'' Beyle said. In congressional races, 100-year-old Henry Merritt Stenhouse finished last in a three-way race for the Republican nomination in the 3rd District, but refused to concede before going to bed for the night. Dunn businessman Don Davis took the nomination to face incumbent Democrat Martin Lancaster in November. Other incumbent congressmen who won renomination were Democrats David Price and Bill Hefner and Republican Cass Ballenger.

DOC.HEAD: Source: North Korea, U.S. Exchange Letters
With PM-South Korea
DOC.TEXT: The United States, which is trying to persuade North Korea to negotiate with South Korea, has exchanged letters with officials in North Korea's government, sources said today. The sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the North sent a letter to Washington via the Soviet Union and Washington responded. The United States does not have diplomatic relations with North Korea. The contents were not made public, but Washington and Moscow have been encouraging the reclusive, totalitarian North to work toward detente with capitalist South Korea to ease tensions on the divided peninsula. It was unclear whether this was the first such written correspondence between Washington and North Korea's government in Pyongyang. Despite the collapse of Communist regimes in Eastern Europe, North Korea remains closed and is one of the last hard-line Communist states. Word of the correspondence coincided with a three-day trip to Seoul by the U.S. assistant secretary of state for Asian and Pacific affairs, Richard Solomon. He met today with South Korean Foreign Minister Choi Ho-joong. Korean news reports said they discussed efforts to arrange talks between the Koreas, divided since 1945. It was not known if the exchange of letters was discussed, but one source close to the talks said, ``It would not be wrong to assume it was.'' American diplomats have met North Korean officials in Beijing seven times over the past year, but U.S. officials have said there has been little change in the North's attitude toward the South. North Korea invaded the South in 1950 to begin the Korean War, which ended three years later with an armistice, not a peace treaty. The two nations remain technically at war, and the border between them is the most heavily fortified in the world. The United States has 43,000 troops in South Korea under a mutual defense pact. The Soviet Union is a long-time ally and arms provider of the Communist North but in December established limited consular relations with South Korea.

DOC.HEAD: Maryland County Passes Mandatory Bicycle Helmet Law
DOC.TEXT: Bicyclists would be required to wear helmets under legislation passed by a Maryland county council, a law one safety expert said would be watched nationwide. The legislation, which goes into effect 150 days after it is signed by Howard County Executive Elizabeth Bobo, would be the nation's toughest helmet law. Howard County, lies between Baltimore and Washington, D.C., and has a population of 180,000. The County Council approved the legislation 3-2 Monday night. Bobo has indicated she will sign the legislation within the next 10 days. New York and California have limited helmet laws for children under 5. The legislation should create ``a ripple effect nationally,'' said Dr. Andrew Dannenberg of the Johns Hopkins Injury Prevention Center. Andy Clarke of the Bicycle Federation of America, who had expressed concerns about the legislation at a public hearing, agreed that passage of the bill ``will have a national impact for sure. Many jurisdictions will be watching to see if it works.'' First-time violators would be subjected to fines of up to $50. A second violation would carry a $100 fine if it occurred within 12 months of the first, but a judge could waive the fine if a cyclist showed proof of having purchased a helmet. Dannenberg said he will lobby for similar legislation on a state or national level. ``I will also try to get support for having helmets included in the price of bicycles, to increase the accessibility of helmets,'' said Dannenberg, whose center will be monitoring the use of helmets in the county under the legislation. The deaths of three youths in bicycle accidents in western Howard County during the past three years prompted County Councilman Charles C. Feaga to introduce the bill. Clarke's organization had expressed doubt about whether the law would be accepted by the public. He had said a major bike-safety education effort should be tried first. About 600 children die each year nationwide in bicycle accidents, and head injuries are the most common cause of death, said Fred Rivara, director of the Harbor View Injury Prevention Center in Seattle. Rivara said a study by the Seattle center showed that helmets would prevent 88 percent of the brain injuries suffered by cyclists. Helmets usually cost about $50, but Rivara said some jurisdictions have gotten discounts from manufacturers that brought the cost down to as low as $20.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Celebrate World War II Victory In Time of Change
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to MOVE UP graf on May Day, UPDATE with Latvian, Lithuanian parades, American legion band performing in other parade. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union proudly paraded its military might through Red Square today, marking the 45th anniversary of the defeat of Nazi Germany as Kremlin leaders grapple with the reunification of their former foe. World War II veterans with red ribbons on their suits accompanied some of the tanks and artillery they fought with from Moscow to Berlin during the 30-minute march past President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and the rest of the Soviet leadership standing atop Lenin's Mausoleum. The atmosphere was very different from the May 1 May Day parade, when thousands of loudly critical protesters poured through Red Square in front of Gorbachev, who walked off the tribunal with other Soviet leaders. Defense Minister Dmitri T. Yazov, who commanded a World War II rifle regiment, today credited Gorbachev's ``new thinking'' with lowering the tension in Europe, divided between East and West after the war. ``At the same time, positive changes have not yet become irreversible,'' he said in his orders for the parade. ``Military danger still exists in the world.'' The celebration of Victory Day comes as Eastern European countries, freed by Gorbachev's reforms, are struggling to re-establish democratic rule and rebuild their economies after four decades of subservience to Moscow. Soviet leaders are also facing secessionist movements in different republics, and these tensions were reflected during Victory Day parades in the Baltic republics of Latvia and Lithuania. In Riga, the Latvian capital, 5,000 people who oppose the secessionist movements in the Baltics turned the Victory Day parade into rally against Latvia's declaration of independence on Friday. Lt. Gen Oleg Zinchenko, head of the political directorate of the Baltic Military Region, which includes Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia, told the rally that the military wanted the Kremlin to intervene in the three republics. Radio Vilnius reported there were no confrontations between backers and opponents of Lithuania's March 11 declaration of independence during a military parade through the Lithuanian capital. But a Lithuanian radio editor said 200 young people shouted, ``Occupiers Go Home!'' at war veterans as they marched down a Vilnius street, and paratroopers prevented the demonstrators from blocking the path of the marchers. In the Moscow parade, the Soviets drove five new pieces of military hardware through Red Square, including their latest tank, a T-80 variant known to the West as the Soviet Medium Tank 1989, for the year it entered service, said a NATO military officer who attended the parade. Two new infantry vehicles were in the show, a BMD-2 airborne combat vehicle equipped with an anti-tank missile, and a BMP-3 armored infantry vehicle with a double-barreled cannon, said the NATO officer. One ominous-looking weapon was the new SAM-10 surface-to-air missile, mounted on a long truck that carries four missile canisters. The Soviets also displayed their BM-22 multiple rocket launcher, a truck mounted with a brace of 220mm rockets with a range of about 24 miles, said the Western officer. The Soviet Union and World War II allies Britain, France and the United States are negotiating with East and West Germany about reunification. Moscow seeks a neutral Germany, but the United States and its allies want a reunited Germany to be part of the Western NATO alliance. In a speech Tuesday evening, Gorbachev reiterated that the Soviet Union supports German reunification and wants to cooperate with a new Germany. But the Soviet Union must be sure ``that in the future, only peace will come from German soil,'' he said. Gorbachev also used the speech to sharply criticize Josef Stalin's conduct of the war, and expressed hope that his summit meeting in Washington with President Bush at month's end will lead to further disarmament and an easing of world tensions. The Soviet leader smiled, waved and raised his clasped hands as he led the leadership onto the reviewing stand for the second time in eight days. Leaving the stand at the end of the parade, he raised a bouquet of red and white flowers to the applause of the diplomatic corps that gathered to watch. War veterans bedecked with rows of glistening medals marched in columns between military bands, soldiers, sailors, paratroopers, and KGB border guards. The motorized portion of the parade opened with the rumble and smoke of two-dozen vintage T-34 tanks. The tank was first produced in 1943 and helped push back the Nazis from deep inside Soviet territory. Overall, the Soviets showed 18 pieces of modern equipment, driving them through Red Square in formations ranging from six to 47 vehicles. An American Legion band from Waltham, Mass., had planned to become the first U.S. band to take part in the parade through Red Square. But the Soviet Peace Committee, which is organizing the band's visit, kept changing their schedule after their arrival in Moscow and finally informed the musicians that they would not be able to march in the main Victory Day parade. Instead, the legionaires' band marched in another Victory Day parade in downtown Moscow with marching units from Soviet republics and gave a concert outside the Bolshoi Theater. No explanation was immediately available for the change in schedule.

DOC.HEAD: Coast Guard Spots 4 On Raft Southwest Of Bermuda
DOC.TEXT: Four people believed to be from a Rhode Island sailing vessel were spotted in a life raft 150 miles southwest of Bermuda early today, the Coast Guard reported. A search was begun late Tuesday after the Coast Guard station at Woods Hole, Mass., received a report that the Misconduct, en route to Bermuda, was sinking 150 miles north of Bermuda. A Navy plane failed to find the distressed vessel in that area, the Coast Guard said. But a report from another vessel that had been with the Misconduct several days earlier prompted the Coast Guard to send a C-130 to search south of the island. The plane remained in the area awaiting arrival of a merchant vessel, the Baron Trader, to pick up the four survivors.

DOC.HEAD: Race Attack Defendant a Jerk, Not a Murderer, Lawyer Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 2-3, `After receiving ..., with 3 grafs to UPDATE with deliberations resuming; picks up 4th graf pvs: `According to ...
DOC.BYLINE: With PM-Racial Unrest, Bjt ^By RONALD POWERS
DOC.TEXT: An attorney in the Bensonhurst attack trial said his client was merely a ``jerk,'' not a murderer, but the prosecutor said the man showed a ``depraved indifference to human life'' by organizing an armed posse. A jury resumed deliberations about 10 a.m. today on whether Keith Mondello, 19, a white, was responsible for the shooting death of Yusuf Hawkins, a black 16-year-old on a Brooklyn street Aug. 23. At about the same time, a second jury resumed deliberations on the case of Joseph Fama, 19, the alleged gunman in the Hawkins killing. Judge Thaddeus Owens, who instructed the Mondello jury Tuesday afternoon, has sequestered both panels. According to testimony, Mondello organized the mob to attack the black and Hispanic friends that he had heard a neighborhood girl planned to invite into the mostly white Bensonhurst neighborhood. Hawkins and three friends happened to wander into the neighborhood to buy a used car. The mob surrounded them and someone, allegedly Fama, shot Hawkins. Mondello and Fama would face 25 years to life in prison if convicted of murder. Defense attorney Stephen Murphy said the incident was not motivated by race and sought to deflect the blame to Gina Feliciano, 18, who he said invited her ``drug-dealer'' friends to a party in the neighborhood. Murphy argued that Mondello, who admitted to being on the scene with a baseball bat, had nothing to do with the murder. ``As they were walking away, some lunatic comes out and shoots him,'' Murphy said. ``You might convict him of being a jerk,'' Murphy said. ``He is a jerk. He let her make a jerk out of him. He let the cops make a jerk out of him. But it's no crime to be a jerk.'' Assistant District Attorney Paul Burns countered that it was preposterous for Mondello and the other young white men he had assembled ``to believe they had the right to arm themselves and go out on a public street'' to protect their neighborhood. After one of the whites pulled an automatic pistol and fired four shots, the mob of about 30 young men scattered without pausing to help their fatally wounded victim, Burns said. He charged that Mondello armed and set in motion the actions of the mob. ``That's depraved indifference to human life,'' Burns said. ``He's responsible under the law.''

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Backs Emergency Plan for Soviet Immigrants
DOC.NOTE: Eds: 2 new grafs at end to ADD background on Arab opposition to immigration of Soviet Jews, Kremlin policy on flights from Moscow. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today he supports an emergency plan under which the government would spend an additional $1 billion to absorb 150,000 Jews expected in the coming year. The extra spending is necessary because the numbers of Soviets arriving has outgrown the estimates of Israel's budget planners.
