The 1990 budget only earmarked enough funds to absorb 40,000 Soviet Jews during the fiscal year ending in March 1991. Updated figures suggest 150,000 may arrive in this period. More than 30,000 Soviet Jews have come to Israel since Jan. 1. The plan to be presented to the Cabinet on Sunday estimates that Israel needs $1.9 billion in fiscal 1990 to absorb the immigrants, said Finance Ministry Spokesman Eli Yosef. He refused to give the number of immigrants on which the ministry's calculations were based. But former Deputy Finance Minister Yossi Beilin, who worked on the emergency spending plan, said it was based on 150,000 Soviet immigrants. Beilin left office, along with other ministers of the center-left Labor Party, when the party's coalition with the right-wing Likud bloc collapsed March 15. Asked whether his caretaker Cabinet would approve the plan Sunday, Shamir said: ``I hope so. If we are convinced that this is the program that is needed today in the period of big immigration, we will approve it and make an effort to implement it.'' He was speaking to reporters during a tour of a high-tech factory in Jerusalem that specializes in employing Soviet scientists. The influx of Soviet Jews has stirred alarm in the Arab world, where fears have been raised that the immigrants will be settled in the occupied territories and displace Palestinians living there. Arab states have put pressure on the Soviet Union to restrict the emigration, and as a result the Kremlin has not allowed direct flights from Moscow to Israel. Instead, most Soviet Jews fly to Israel via East European countries such as a Romania and Hungary.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Balloon Crash-Lands While Trying to Cross Everest
DOC.TEXT: Three Japanese balloonists trying to fly over Mount Everest from Tibet to Nepal crash-landed today after hitting a cliff in Tibet, and one was injured, expedition officials said. The balloon and the basket holding the three men also caught fire. It was the first attempt to cross the world's tallest mountain by balloon. The balloon took off from Nyalam, situated at 14,432 feet on the edge of the Tibetan plateau in southwestern China, said officials at the Everest Japanese Balloon Expedition Committee headquarters in Katmandu. Committee Secretary General Masashi Kakuda said that when the balloon had traveled about six miles and reached an altitude of about 32,000 feet, the balloonists decided to land as soon as possible because the winds were not favorable for crossing the 29,028-foot Mount Everest. ``Then they went down. ... Unfortunately, their balloon hit a tall rock and the balloon's envelope was torn. Later on, the basket fell down several meters from the middle of the rock to the bottom,'' Kakuda added. ``We didn't know what happened at that time. There was fire on the basket and the balloon was half burned,'' he said. One of the pilots, Saburo Ichiyoshi, 43, of Tokyo, suffered leg injuries in the crash-landing, Kakuda said. He said pilot Michio Kanda, 41, and photographer Atsushi Saito, 27, escaped uninjured. Kanda walked about six miles from the crash-landing site to Nyalam, Kakuda said. ``We have sent four rescue teams from Nyalam to help the balloonists. One of the rescue teams met Kanda midway. As of this evening, two of the rescue teams already had reached the crash-landing site.'' The expedition committee asked Chinese authorities for permission to send two Nepalese helicopters to pick up the balloonists on Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Olive Oil No Better Than Corn Oil In Maintaining `Good' Cholesterol
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 4th graf to add explanation that earlier study involved rich diet, latest study applies directly to low-fat diets.
DOC.TEXT: Olive oil may be no better for the heart than corn oil for people on low-fat diets a new study suggests. ``When someone is eating a reduced fat diet that's low in saturated fats, it doesn't matter what kind of unsaturated fat they choose,'' said Darlene M. Dreon, a research scientist at Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory in Berkeley, Calif. Previous research indicated that monounsaturated fats, found in olive oil and peanut oil, beneficially lower LDL cholesterol, so-called ``bad'' cholesterol, without lowering HDL, so-called ``good'' cholesterol. Polyunsaturates, such as in corn oil and safflower oil, also lower ``bad'' cholesterol, but they tend to lower ``good'' cholesterol as an unwanted additional effect, previous research has indicated. A 1985 study that prompted some consumers to switch from corn oil to olive oil involved a highly enriched diet because the experimenters hiked levels of unsaturated fats to measure them more easily. In the new study, Dreon and colleagues found that neither polyunsaturated nor monounsaturated fats offered an advantage in maintaining levels of good cholesterol in the blood for people on low-fat diets. HDL cholesterol is called good cholesterol because it is believed to protect against heart disease; LDL cholesterol is called bad cholesterol because it is believed to contribute to fatty deposits in the arteries that promote heart disease. Excess total cholesterol in the blood is one of the three main modifiable traits that scientists have linked to an increased risk of developing heart disease. The other two are high blood pressure and smoking. Researchers in the new study analyzed data on 20 women and 19 men who were all put on a standard diet for two weeks, then divided into groups for 12-week diets alternately rich in monounsaturates and in polyunsaturates. The standard diet was one recommended by the American Heart Association, which calls for 30 percent of total calories from fats, in contrast to the 40 percent of calories from fat that the average American eats. The test diets provided the same proportion of calories from fats overall, but restricted saturated fats _ the kind found in meat and dairy products _ to 10 percent. The other 20 percent were polyunsaturates or monounsaturates, depending on which test diet was being used. Blood levels of LDL cholesterol and HDL cholesterol did not change significantly with changing fat types, the researchers reported in today's Journal of the American Medical Association. Dr. Linda Cashin-Hemphill, an assistant professor at the University of Southern California School of Medicine's Atherosclerosis Institute in Los Angeles, said Americans should aim for overall fat reduction. ``There is no one magic bullet'' for fatty substances, including cholesterol, in the body, she said in a telephone interview. ``You have to control total fat.''

DOC.HEAD: NASA Puts Off First Hubble Photograph
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs with delay in first photos till at least Friday; Picks up 3rd graf pvs bng ``The plan would be.'' ^By HARRY F. ROSENTHAL
DOC.TEXT: NASA engineers delayed until at least Friday an attempt to snap the first photograph of stars using the main camera of the Hubble Space Telescope, the space agency said today. NASA had said Tuesday that they would try to get the first picture today, even if engineers had to interrupt the telescope's shakedown tests, now entering the third week. But NASA spokesman Dave Garrett said today, ``The first light picture will not be until at least Friday.'' Garrett said he had no information about the reason for the delay. Other public affairs officers more closely connected to the Hubble program were not available. The first light picture is the traditional first photograph of the stars taken by a new telescope. The plan would be to photograph a 3 billion-year-old star field called Theta Carina, or ``The Ship's Keel,'' visible in the southern sky. The star cluster, 1,260 light years away, can be seen with the naked eye from parts of Africa, South America and Australia. On Tuesday, ground controllers tried unsuccessfully to teach the telescope exactly what in the heavens it is looking at. The instrument was told to look for stars of a certain brightness in what scientists thought was a rich field. It found none. ``It was somewhat of a surprise,'' said Michael Harrington, the NASA manager in charge of the checkout. ``We had expected that this field has a plenitude of that size stars and that we had no problem getting plenty. It didn't turn out quite like that.'' Once the telescope locks on to the bright stars, it will remember where it was pointing and that, in turn, will enable it later to find any other target ordered by the ground. The sequence is like looking at a map to determine your location and then being able to go to any point from there. Harrington said there probably were gaps in the star field without any stars of the brightness being sought. ``We thought we had hit the field that was rich enough. It's not a problem with the instrument.'' The 12.5-ton telescope, which cost $1.5 billion, was released from the space shuttle Discovery on April 25. Before Tuesday's failed effort, engineers estimated they were one week behind schedule in their checkout because of earlier problems. The telescope's mission is to collect the light generated by galaxies and other heavenly bodies billions of years ago. It will enable astronomers to look far deeper into the universe than possible with ground-based telescopes. Teams of engineers are concentrating on two persistent problems on the telescope. One is a jittery action when the instrument is instructed to roll. The other is a shaking motion when the telescope passes from shadow into sunlight as it orbits the Earth.

DOC.HEAD: Copenhagen Landmark Doing Fine After Surgery
DOC.TEXT: City welders have repaired the Little Mermaid, the 74-year-old landmark in Copenhagen harbor which was slashed by a vandal's hacksaw, police said Wednesday. The attempt to decapitate the girl-sized bronze statue may have occurred several weeks ago, inspector Ole Wagner said. Police were alerted Monday by an engineering student who found a deep gash in the neck when he was studying earlier repairs. The municipality works department Tuesday welded the 7-inch wound and covered the scar with patina, leaving a barely noticeable discoloration. ``The old lady is doing fine,'' Wagner said in a telephone interview. ``The crime probably occurred around Easter. Some witnesses reported they saw someone on the statue on Good Friday,'' Wagner said. Police were investigating but had no suspects. The original head was severed and disappeared in 1964. It was replaced by a new one cast from the original mold. In 1984 vandals amputated an arm, but it was found and rewelded. Built in tribute to Danish storyteller Hans Christian Andersen, the statue depicts a girl with a fish tail looking wistfully to the sea. It is taken from one of Andersen's best-loved tales.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Department Refers Fauntroy Allegations to House Ethics Committee.
DOC.NOTE: EDS: New throughout with Justice confirming referral to House ethics panel.
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department said today it has referred to the House ethics committee allegations that Walter Fauntroy, Washington's non-voting congressional delegate, hired a colleague's son for a no-show job. The department, which decided recently not to bring criminal charges against Fauntroy following a lengthy investigation, referred the matter for review by the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct. Although there was no evidence of criminal wrongdoing by Fauntroy, ``there was information that the House ethics committee might want to look at,'' said spokesman David Runkel, who declined to give further details. Fauntroy, D-D.C., was the subject of a 15-month investigation by the department into allegations that he had hired the son of Rep. Gus Savage, D-Ill., for a no-show job. Thomas Savage was on Fauntroy's payroll from September 1987 through June 1988, except for an unpaid leave of absence, a period when he said he went to Illinois to run for the legislature. Under House rules, congressional employees must work in Washington or in the district the member represents. Runkel said a parallel investigation of Gus Savage had also been closed for lack of evidence to warrant any prosecution, but the matter also was referred to the House ethics committee. The Justice Department examined whether the elder Savage was aware of any possible wrongdoing in Fauntroy's hiring of his son, said sources who spoke on condition of anonymity. The Washington Post today quoted unidentified sources as saying the Justice Department's Public Integrity Section believed there ``were some things the ethics committee might want to look at'' in the case of Savage's son. A spokesman for Fauntroy, Abbe Lowell, told the Post that referral to the committee was routine in such cases, saying the department ``has done no more and no less than follow their normal practices.'' Jan Keyes, a spokeswoman for the ethics panel, declined to comment on whether it would open an investigation. Fauntroy is a candidate for mayor in this fall's election and may not seek re-election to his House seat.

DOC.HEAD: Pioneer Announces Satellite Navigation System for Vehicles
DOC.TEXT: A new car navigation system that uses satellites to plot a vehicle's location and displays it to the driver on a computer map will go on sale next month in Japan, a company said Wednesday. The device is the first such system available on the retail market, said Toru Yokomizo, spokesman for Pioneer Electronic Corp. The system, which goes on sale June 21, connects to a car's audio system and uses special compact discs to display color maps of any part of Japan, Yokomizo said. The AVIC-1 device uses signals from satellites to automatically calculate the vehicle's location. It indicates the location with a red dot on the maps, which are displayed on a four-inch flat color screen, he said. The driver can choose from five levels of detail in the maps, which also include names of thousands of restaurants, hotels, and entertainment facilities and the services they provide, he said. The navigation system has an accuracy of 65 to 100 feet and can be used by cars, trucks or even helicopters, Yokomizo said. The vehicles can be moving or standing still. The complete system, including navigation device, display, antenna and audio system, will cost about $3,160, he said. ``In the future, we hope to develop a navigation device that will allow drivers to input where they want to go, and then will display on a map the best way to get there,'' Yokomizo said. ``By monitoring traffic reports, it will automatically advise the driver to take an alternate route to avoid congested areas.'' Such ``smart cars,'' which give drivers the latest traffic information, also are to be tested in Florida and California. Pioneer has no plans to market the device outside Japan. It estimates initial sales at 2,000 units per month, Yokomizo said.

DOC.HEAD: Police Seize Tons of Hashish Destined for Greece
DOC.TEXT: Police seized 6{ tons of hashish hidden aboard a Lebanese trawler and arrested six people, the semi-official Anatolia news agency reported Wednesday. The shipment, one of the biggest ever seized in Turkey, was destined for Greece and had a street value of $120 million, according to police in this Mediterranean coastal province. The agency quoted Antalya Gov. Erol Tezcan as saying police also seized 22 pounds of heroin and an unspecified number of weapons and ammunition aboard the trawler, identified as the Ceta-M. The statement identified the six arrested as a Greek, two Syrians, two Lebanese and a Palestinian.

DOC.HEAD: Italy Agrees to Give Malta 200 Million Dollars in Aid
DOC.TEXT: Italy agreed Wednesday to give Malta more than $200 million in aid and to provide helicopters and patrol boats to help combat drug trafficking through the island nation. Foreign Minister Guido De Marco and Claudio Vitalone, Italy's undersecretary for foreign affairs, signed the protocol that will provide $207 million in aid. The agreement makes up the third financial protocol to a 1981 treaty in which Italy pledged to guarantee Malta's neutrality. Under terms of the agreement, the Maltese government said more than half of the funds would go to make up for the island's heavy trade deficit with Italy. It said the rest will be in the form of loans and grants for infastructural projects and technical assistance.

DOC.HEAD: Blasts Shatter Windows at Courthouse and Bank Office
DOC.TEXT: Explosives hurled by unidentified people shattered the windows of a courthouse and a bank office, but caused no casualties, the semi-official Anatolia news agency reported Wednesday. The blasts at the state security court building in the district of Cagaloglu and the Fatih district office of the state-run Ziraat Bankasi occurred simultaneously around 9 p.m. Tuesday, the agency said. Devrimci Savas Hucreleri, or Revolutionary War Cells, a previously unheard of group, claimed responsibility for the explosion at the bank with telephone calls to several newspapers, Anatolia said.

DOC.HEAD: Former Hostage Frank Reed's Hospital Stay Extended
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 3-4, Another former, with Polhill undergoing biopsy.
DOC.TEXT: Former hostage Frank Reed is expected to remain hospitalized for another week but he is in good spirits, sleeping well and starting to regain some of about 50 pounds he lost, according to a medical report. The Air Force said Tuesday a battery of medical tests has tired the 57-year-old educator so his examination schedule is being spread out over more days. He went into the hospital at Andrews Air Force Base in Maryland on Friday, four days after his Middle East kidnappers released him April 30. Another former hostage and fellow educator, Robert Polhill, underwent a biopsy Tuesday at Walter Reed Army Medical Center for a growth on his left vocal cord. Jim Stueve, a hospital spokesman, said the findings were expected in several days. Polhill, 55, was freed April 22. Reed's doctors had said he probably would be able to return to his native Massachusetts by the end of this week, but that has been revised to next week. The Air Force gave no further details on Reed's physical or mental condition, citing his request for privacy. Spokesmen referred reporters to a family friend, Carroll Lowenstein, who they said was helping him deal with media requests for interviews. Lowenstein did not answer his telephone Tuesday night. Reed told a news conference Sunday that his Islamic kidnappers savagely beat him, breaking his nose, jaw, ribs and feet and bloodying his kidneys during his 44 months in captivity. ``Thank God they didn't kill me,'' he said. ``I was one of their pet whackers.'' In the Middle East, Hussein Musawi, a Shiite Moslem fundamentalist, said in an interview with the communist-run Voice of the People radio that he did not expect the hostage issue to be resolved this year. He said the United States has not responded with a goodwill gesture of its own for the release of Reed and another former hostage, Robert Polhill, within eight days of each other last month. Peggy Say, the sister of hostage Terry Anderson, has urged Israel to release Shiite detainees to help win the freedom of the remaining six American and 10 other Western hostages. Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, is the longest held of the hostages. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985. Mrs. Say made her request on behalf of the hostages at a meeting with Ambassador Moshe Arad at his residence on April 27. ``We also have soldiers of ours that are in the hands of the Hezbollah and we have other soldiers who are still missing in action,'' Ruth Yaron, a spokeswoman for the Israeli embassy, said Tuesday. ``Israel is willing to release those detainees that are held by us for terrorist actions if this could bring about the release of all Israeli prisoners as well as the release of the Western hostages,'' she said. The embassy said the detainees held by Israel are terrorists, not hostages. ``There is no room for any comparison between them and the hostages who are innocent citizens kidnapped by the Hezbollah organization and Lebanese organizations affiliated with it,'' the embassy said. Syrian and Iranian officials have said the release of any more American hostages likely hinges on Israel's willingness to free Moslem prisoners, including Sheik Obeid, a Shiite cleric taken from his home in southern Lebanon in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Collor de Mello Says Up to 400,000 Public Employees Could be Fired
DOC.TEXT: President Fernando Collor de Mello said today up to 400,000 public employees could be fired as part of his economic reform program. ``The economic modernization of the country cannot proceed without deep government reform,'' the president said after a Cabinet meeting. He estimated that 1.6 million people work for the federal government or for government-controlled firms. ``From now on, we will proceed with a reduction of 20 to 25 percent of this number, through firings and by placing excess workers ``in availability,'' Collor said in Brasilia, the capital. ``In availability'' is a Brazilian legal term that means civil servants stay at home and draw only partial salaries. The premise is that eventually they will become disgusted and quit. Collor did not give further details of the layoffs. Previous presidents threatened deep cuts in the government payroll, but never really followed through. It appears that Collor was more determined than previous leaders, however. The 40-year-old leader also said today he will move ahead with promises to privatize many of Brazil's 188 state-run firms, many of which lose money and together have a debt of $62 billion. Many also serve as job havens for friends and relatives of politicians and appointees. ``The public sector will continue operating only in areas considered to be of strategic importance for the economy,'' Collor said. Collor was inaugurated March 15 for a four-year term after becoming Brazil's first popularly elected president since 1960. He campaigned on a pledge to reduce government waste. In his first day in office, he announced that 23 federal companies, foundations, and institutes would be shut down, and that more than 11,000 federal employees holding more than one government job would have to quit their extra employment. He also froze $115 billion in savings accounts and money market deposits for 18 months. Collor has said those measures and spending cuts are necessary to bring down record inflation of 4,854 percent during the past year and eliminate a federal deficit of $31 billion. The actions have drastically cut the cost of living, but the economy still appears headed for a recession.

DOC.HEAD: Studies: Experimental Drug Relieves AIDS Symptoms
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6 p.m. EDT, time set by source
DOC.TEXT: Two new reports conclude that the experimental drug DDI is a promising weapon against AIDS, but a top government researcher cautions doctors and patients to ``suspend judgment'' until much larger studies are finished. The latest work found that the medicine improved AIDS patients' blood counts, increased their energy and helped them put on weight. But it also shows that the treatment can cause severe, even life-threatening side effects. ``There is some evidence that it inhibits the AIDS virus,'' said Dr. Howard A. Liebman of Boston City Hospital. ``The important question is: Will the spectrum of toxicity prove to be the limiting factor of the drug? Will that make it not any better than AZT and perhaps worse?'' Doctors hope that and other questions about DDI will be answered by a major new study under way at hospitals across the United States. The two newly published studies were conducted on small numbers of patients by doctors at Boston City Hospital and the University of Rochester. The results, published in Thursday's New England Journal of Medicine, were similar to those of a National Cancer Institute preliminary study published last July in the journal Science. All three studies were so-called Phase I trials. They were intended to determine the maximum safe dose that patients can tolerate, not whether the medicine had an effect on their illness. Nevertheless, the researchers found that many of the patients clearly improved while taking DDI for a few weeks. In an editorial in the New England Journal, the director of AIDS work at the National Institutes of Health wrote that ``there certainly is a suggestion of short-term benefit from DDI.'' Currently, about 800 patients are enrolled in a study that compares DDI to AZT, or zidovudine, the only AIDS medicine approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration for routine use. An additional 8,600 people who cannot take AZT because of side effects or worsening symptoms are using DDI in an unusual program that makes the drug available before its formal approval. In the editorial, Dr. Anthony S. Fauci predicted that the two latest reports will stir up ``inevitable enthusiasm'' about the treatment. But he added, ``Physicians and patients should suspend judgment about DDI until the multi-center Phase II-III clinical trials currently in progress are completed.'' The New England Journal studies were directed by Drs. John S. Lambert of Rochester and Timothy P. Cooley of Boston City and involved 71 patients. Many of the patients felt better or put on weight while taking DDI. Virus levels fell, while the blood cells attack by the AIDS virus increased. However, high doses of the drug also caused inflammation of the pancreas and severe foot pain. Liebman, who was senior author of the Boston City study, said the potentially fatal pancreatic ailment often occurred after three or four months of DDI treatment and frequently affected the sickest patients. ``Physicians have to be very alert to the toxicities,'' he said. ``A lot of physicians are not sensitive to this. They are just happy to be able to give something to their patients.'' Even if DDI turns out to be no better than AZT, it still may be an alternative drug for some patients. AZT often loses its effectiveness after a year or so of treatment. It also suppresses the body's ability to make new blood cells. Also in the journal, Dutch doctors reported an unsuccessful attempt to prevent an accidental AIDS infection by giving AZT. The victim, a patient in the hospital for an intestinal operation, was mistakenly given an injection with a syringe that contained a small amount of AIDS-tainted blood. Doctors quickly recognized their mistake and began giving him AZT within 45 minutes. However, the drug failed to stop the virus, and the man became infected. AZT is routinely recommended to prevent infections in hospital workers who accidentally jab themselves with needles that have been used on AIDS patients. The report, written by Dr. Joep M.A. Lange and others from the University of Amsterdam, shows that the strategy may not always work.

DOC.HEAD: Recording Industry Unveils Parental Warning Label
DOC.TEXT: The recording industry today unveiled a uniform, voluntary parental warning label for albums that might contain explicit lyrics. Jay Berman, president of the Recording Industry Association of America, told a news conference that the black-and-white label will appear on the lower right-hand corner of possibly-objectionable records, cassettes and compact discs reaching retail stores starting in July. ``We believe the uniform logo will enhance the existing voluntary system and better respond to the legitimate concerns of parents,'' Berman said. ``Now that we have agreed on this new logo, it will be up to parents to use it as they see fit,'' he said. The standard label, which reads ``Parental Advisory _ Explicit Lyrics,'' will appear on albums at the discretion of record companies and individual artists. Plans for the label were announced in late March at a convention of the National Association of Recording Merchandisers, which endorsed the idea at today's news conference. That association, representing record retailers and distributors across the country, said, ``Our members hope that this voluntary step by the recording industry will put the nightmare of governmental regulation behind us.'' Berman said that by his count, 16 of the 19 states considering legislation requiring warning labels on records have backed away from those efforts since the industry promised to institute a uniform label on a voluntary basis. The voluntary labeling plan had previously been endorsed by Tipper Gore, president of the Parents Music Resource Center, and Ann Lynch, president of the National PTA, as a better answer to parents' concerns about explicit lyrics than mandatory labeling. The new system is intended to alert consumers to recordings that could be deemed objectionable because of explicit lyrics dealing with sex, violence, suicide and substance abuse. The voluntary labels also were endorsed at the news conference by Daddy O of the rap group Stetsasonic, who said he was the father of five children. ``We don't think the government should determine what our children listen to,'' Daddy O said. ``We all think the label is cute.'' Berman said he anticipated that virtually all of the recording industry association's members would subscribe to the labeling plan. Record distributors which committed themselves to the new labeling last month were Warner Bros., MCA, CBS, Capitol-EMI, RCA and Polygram, the six largest recording industry companies. Companies belonging to Berman's trade association produce more than 90 percent of the records sold in the United States. Many of the records deemed objectionable by critics are released by small, independent companies that are not association members. The uniform label replaces a system under a 1985 agreement that involves individual record company warning labels. Erratic compliance under that agreement created confusion among parents' groups.

DOC.HEAD: Brother Beats Sister For School Board Race
DOC.TEXT: An accountant beat out his sister by 100 votes for a seat on the Roane County school board. ``It was a close race from start to finish,'' C. DeVaughn Moore said Tuesday night after edging his sister, Judith Shafer, on a vote of 1,253 to 1,153. Shafer, 46, a Walton postmaster, wasn't around to congratulate her brother. ``She wasn't there. I haven't seen her today,'' Moore said. Moore, 42, an accountant, said he just wanted to serve on the board, not challenge his sister. ``I was the first one to file from this district and that was my goal,'' he said. ``It wasn't to beat an opponent no matter who the opponent was. I thought that was a job I could contribute to.'' Moore will begin his term on July 1. Both candidates were Republicans and making their first bid for elected office.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Selection Continues in Traders' Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to UPDATE with jury selection resuming. A longer version moved on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers for three futures traders accused of fraud will be allowed to introduce at their trial evidence suggesting that the difference between legal and illegal trading is ``blurry.'' The ruling by U.S. District Judge Ann C. Williams was a victory for defendants Robert D. Mosky, Danny L. Scheck and David Zatz. Jury selection, which began Tuesday, resumed today for the trial, which is expected to last six weeks. Mosky, Scheck and Zatz traded Swiss franc futures on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. They were indicted last year, along with 44 other Chicago futures traders and a clerk, on charges of defrauding customers. Sixteen of those indicted have pleaded guilty to reduced charges in return for their cooperation. Mosky, Scheck and Zatz face more than a dozen counts each of fraud and violations of the Commodity Exchange Act. Each count carries up to five years in prison and a $150,000 fine. Mosky also is charged with racketeering conspiracy, for which he could be sent to prison for 20 years and be forced to forfeit assets, including his exchange membership. The judge, ruling on several motions Monday and Tuesday, said that if the evidence shows the line between legal and illegal trades is ``sufficiently blurry,'' it can be introduced. Defense lawyers have indicated they will challenge the ability of the prosecution witnesses to discern legal and illegal trading. The government's case hinges on the testimony of two traders and on the observations and tape-recordings of an FBI agent who posed as a corrupt trader. Swiss franc futures are contracts to buy or sell specified amounts of the currency on future dates at prices agreed upon in advance.

DOC.HEAD: Postmaster General Says Mail Changes Inevitable
DOC.TEXT: It may make some people uncomfortable, but change is necessary and is coming at the post office, Postmaster General Anthony Frank said Wednesday. ``We have to have the foresight and the courage to take responsibility for our future,'' Frank told a Senate post office and governmental affairs subcommittee. ``It is not going to be placid waters, smooth sailing, and huzzahs all around,'' said Frank, who was not specific about changes. The postal waters have been decidedly choppy in recent weeks, following reports of some planned reductions in service standards at the same time the agency is seeking a rate increase. Higher postal prices _ including a 30-cent first class stamp _ are expected to take effect next year. Frank told the subcommittee, however, that postal costs have been held below inflation for the first half of the current fiscal year and work efficiency in the organization has increased for three consecutive quarters. Mail volume and delivery points have increased slightly over the last year, but the postal service now has 19,000 fewer career employees than a year ago, said Frank. At the same time, he said, the agency is $361 million in the black for this fiscal year, although it is expected to fall into the red as the normal summer and fall decline in mail volume occurs. Frank noted the Postal Service will begin negotiating new contracts this summer with its major unions and said changes in the way workers are used may be discussed. He did not get into specifics, however. Increased automation will also have a great impact on the future, especially the use of bar codes on virtually all mail. Bar codes resemble the rows of lines used for computerized supermarket pricing and will allow mail to be handled more easily by machines.

DOC.HEAD: Trial Resumes After Imelda Marcos Returns to Court
DOC.TEXT: Imelda Marcos, whose fraud trial was abruptly recessed when she fell ill for a second time during emotion-charged testimony, returned to court today wearing a blood-pressure monitor. ``She's feeling better today,'' her attorney, Gerry Spence, said after the morning testimony. The federal court proceeding was halted in mid-afternoon Tuesday when the former Philippine first lady, evidently upset by references to her children, suffered an attack of high blood pressure. Mrs. Marcos faltered and began to sob at the defense table and was comforted by a niece. She was treated by a courthouse nurse and, still sobbing, walked from the nurse's office to her black van with the help of a courthouse marshal. Friends quoted Mrs. Marcos' personal physician, Dr. Rafael Zagala, as saying her blood pressure had soared to 200 over 110, a dangerous level. It was the second time in less than two weeks that Judge John F. Keenan called a hasty recess after Mrs. Marcos, 60, became ill in court. The first time, on April 26, the jury was not in the courtroom, but this time jurors saw the incident. Her earlier illness prompted doctors to fit her with an electronic device to constantly monitor her blood pressure. She has worn it some days but did not have it on Tuesday. Mrs. Marcos is accused of helping her husband, the late President Ferdinand E. Marcos, loot their nation's treasury of more than $220 million dollars, using the money to support lavish living and to secretly buy four New York office buildings. Her co-defendant, Saudi Arabian financier Adnan Khashoggi, is charged with having helped the Marcoses conceal their ownership of the buildings and some artworks. Mrs. Marcos became upset as Spence cross-examined FBI agent James Trimbach on whether he saw anything wrong with the Marcoses' financing of the education of their daughters, Imee and Irene, and son Ferdinand Jr., known as ``Bong Bong.'' Before the witness could reply, Mrs. Marcos began to cry. Friends said later she was upset by the reference to Imee, whom she has not seen in four years. Imee, who has three children of her own, lives in Morocco and is not permitted to travel on a Philippine passport, they said.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Comedians Robin Williams and Whoopi Goldberg appeared before a Senate panel Wednesday to urge passage of a bill providing long-term help for homeless families. ``It's a very sad state of affairs when we cannot take care of our own,'' Goldberg said. Both appeared before the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee and are working with the Comic Relief group, which has raised money for the homeless. ``George, read my lips: Help us,'' Williams said, referring to President Bush, at a news conference before addressing the committee. The celebrities support a bill sponsored by committee chairman Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., and others that would authorize $265 million next year for services for homeless people. Appearing with Williams and Goldberg was a formerly homeless woman, Connie Perez of Oxnard, Calif., now a case worker helping other homeless people. She described the hardship of trying to keep her seven children together during three years of homelessness. ``My children suffered the most,'' she said. ``I am still trying to correct the damage that was done.''

Mary Martin and Celeste Holm are among nearly two dozen stars marking the Shubert theater's 75th birthday Saturday by reprising or reminiscing about its Broadway shows that ``opened out of town.'' Miss Martin is expected to sing Cole Porter's ``My Heart Belongs to Daddy,'' from ``Leave It To Me,'' which premiered at the Shubert in 1938. Her tryout for the show was her first time on stage. Miss Martin also appeared at the Shubert in the pre-Broadway tryouts of ``South Pacific,'' in 1949, and ``The Sound of Music,'' in 1959. John Raitt will sing ``Bill's Soliloquy'' from ``Carousel,'' which opened here in 1945. Miss Holm will sing ``I'm Just a Girl Who Can't Say No,'' from ``Oklahoma!'' which opened in 1943. Others stars featured include Yvonne DeCarlo, Robert Goulet, Connie Stevens, Maureen Stapleton, Vincent Gardenia and the Rockettes in the 90-minute show directed by Joe Layton, creative director of Radio City Music Hall. From the 1930s to the 1960s, the Shubert was known as the ``birthplace of the nation's greatest hits.'' Slides and film will be used to help retrace the theater's history, starting with its opening in 1914 with the musical, ``Belle of Bond Street.''

Lady Bird Johnson sank city officials' plans to rename Town Lake in the former first lady's honor only hours before the City Council was to make it official in a special meeting. Mayor Lee Cooke proposed the idea during a 25th anniversary celebration of President Johnson's inauguration, and a majority of the council agreed. Cooke said he hadn't expected Lady Bird's veto Tuesday. Mrs. Johnson, who helped develop and beautify the popular recreation spot 20 years ago, wrote the officials that Town Lake ``will always be a special place for me, but I will feel very self-conscious if it is named for me.'' Mrs. Johnson noted that she had turned down previous proposals and asked that the council ``follow my long-held wish.'' Cooke said he accepts Mrs. Johnson's decision ``reluctantly and disappointedly.''

Architect Maya Ying Lin, who designed the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Washington, D.C., when she was a Yale student has returned to her alma mater to mark the arrival of women undergraduates 20 years ago. Yale has commissioned Lin to design a sculpture to celebrate new generations of Yale women on campus, culminating a yearlong observance of the 20th anniversary. The monument ``is more about the future than commemorating the past,'' Lin said Tuesday, and likely will include places where ``people can sit and enjoy themselves.'' She would not discuss possible designs. In 1981 as a senior, Lin's design was chosen from 1,420 entries for the Vietnam memorial, a black granite work inscribed with the names of 58,000 Americans killed or missing. It is the most visited monument in Washington. Lin also designed a monument to those slain during the civil rights movement. The work was dedicated in Montgomery, Ala., in November.

Longtime civil rights figure and former Fayette Mayor Charles Evers has filed for bankruptcy, records show. Evers, 67, who once owned several businesses in the small southwest Mississippi town he led as mayor for 16 years, declined to say why he filed for personal bankruptcy under Chapter 7 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code. ``I think it speaks for itself,'' said Evers, who serves as unpaid general manager of WMPR-FM, a Jackson public radio station. Evers was an unsuccessful candidate for governor in 1971 and in 1983, for the U.S. Senate in 1978 and for central district highway commissioner in 1989. According to Tuesday's filing, Evers has less than $50,000 in assets, less than $50,000 in debt and none of his assets will be available for distribution to creditors.

DOC.NOTE: For release at 6:30 p.m. EDT; time set by source
DOC.HEAD: More Americans Eligible to Vote
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS penultimate graf, The voting-age, to CORRECT number of blacks to 21.1
DOC.TEXT: The number of Americans old enough to vote this fall is up more than 3.6 million from two years ago, but the odds are fewer will actually turn out. The nation's voting-age population will climb to 186,382,000 by November's election, the Census Bureau projected on Wednesday. That's up from about 182.7 million two years ago, the bureau said. But the absence of a presidential contest this year means there will probably be less public interest and so a lower turnout. An estimated 50.1 percent of voting-age Americans voted for president in the 1988 general election. In 1986, the last congressional election year without a presidential vote, only 33.4 percent voted. The new Census report shows the aging of the giant post-World War II Baby Boom generation is continuing to place the bulk of voters in the 25-to-44 age group. That segment of Americans will make up 43.9 percent of eligible voters, up from 43.5 percent two years ago and 38.5 percent in 1980. The smaller generation that followed the Baby Boom means the younger age group is losing potential political influence. Voters aged 18-to-24 will be only 13.8 percent of those eligible this fall, down from 14.5 percent in 1988 and 18.4 percent in 1980. The middle aged, those 45 to 64, will be 25.2 percent of voters, down from 25.3 percent in 1988 and 27.3 percent in 1980. But voters aged 65 and over will be 17 percent, an increase from 16.7 percent two years ago and 15.7 percent in 1980. Women will outnumber men in the voting age population by 97.1 million to 89.2 million, the report shows. Men have a slight edge in the 18-to-24 group, but women outnumber them at older ages. As women tend to live longer than men, the biggest margin is at age 65 and over, with 18.8 million women and 12.9 million men. The voting-age population will include 21.1 million blacks and 6.1 million persons of other races, such as Asians, Pacific islanders and American Indians. Although the report lists all Americans aged 18 and over as part of the voting-age population, the bureau noted not all are eligible to vote. Included are about 6.6 million legal aliens, 2.8 million illegal aliens and 850,000 persons in prisons or mental hospitals who are not eligible to vote.

DOC.HEAD: NATO Defense Ministers Discuss Slashing Nuclear Arsenal
DOC.TEXT: NATO defense ministers met today to discuss slashing their arsenal of battlefield nuclear weapons now that political changes in Eastern Europe have dramatically reduced East-West tensions. The officials of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization gathered in the majestic Rocky Mountains of western Canada for their first nuclear strategy talks since pro-democratic revolutions swept through Eastern Europe last year. Upon arrival Tuesday, the alliance's secretary-general, Manfred Woerner, described the discussions as ``very important'' in laying the groundwork for ``a more peaceful, more secure future.'' ``We will start adjusting our nuclear posture to the future ... to make sure that we continue to prevent (war) with less weapons and hopefully also with less soldiers,'' he said. Just days before the meeting, President Bush announced the cancellation of plans to build a more powerful short-range nuclear missile and a modernized 155mm nuclear-tipped artillery shell. Even before the American decision, there was a growing feeling among NATO diplomats that the West could safely reduce, if not eliminate entirely, its arsenal of land-based tactical missiles and artillery in Europe. Those weapons, most deployed in West Germany, were designed to hit targets in countries of Eastern Europe that have now improved ties with the West. German Defense Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg, on his arrival late Monday, said it was possible that all land-based nuclear systems in Europe would be withdrawn. ``Of course,'' he told reporters, ``the requirement is the readiness of the Soviet Union to withdraw their own systems.'' ``It cannot be unilateral,'' he said. ``It must be on both sides.'' It was unclear if the defense ministers, meeting as the Nuclear Planning Group, would announce changes in their nuclear arsenal at this meeting. Some officials thought it more likely NATO would delay any announcements until the end of a series of high-level meetings this month and next on the alliance's future and its need for nuclear and conventional forces. The discussions will wind up with a summer summit of Bush and other leaders of the 16 nations.

DOC.HEAD: Flooding in Texas, Arkansas Sweeps Away Cattle Along With Homes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 4th graf, `In Texas...' to UPDATE with volunteer patrols today, river expected to crest.
DOC.TEXT: Floodwaters swept away homes, cattle and crops as the rain-swollen Arkansas River reached a record level, and the National Guard was called in to shore up a levee weakened by the worst flooding in northern Texas in 80 years. In Arkansas, farmers hogtied calves for transport and residents sandbagged their homes as the Arkansas River on Tuesday hit a record 27.6 feet _ four feet above flood stage _ at Little Rock. More than 300 families were forced from their homes. ``People are just devastated. All you can see from here is rooftops and water,'' said Donna Booth Johnson, local Red Cross executive director. ``One guy left his refrigerator, thinking that since the motor was sealed, it would be OK. It floated off, along with the microwave he had put on top of it.'' In Texas, more than 1,600 people have sought shelter from flooding along the Trinity River. Gov. Bill Clements authorized the National Guard to send 50 soldiers to shore up a weakening levee on the Red River near Texarkana. Hundreds of volunteers patrolled the river today, anxiously scanning levees for breaches a day after water broke through the top of a 60-foot-long section of levee, swamping several two-story homes. Authorities said the river was expected to crest today and maintain its swollen level for two days. The water level at Lake Texoma on the Oklahoma line continued to fall after cresting at a record 644.76 feet above sea level, 27 feet above normal. Thirteen deaths have been blamed on the weather in the past two weeks, one in Oklahoma and the rest in Texas. In Arkansas, a threat of rain raised fears of more flooding in Little Rock even as the crest of floodwaters moved downstream today toward Pine Bluff, 40 miles to the southeast. The National Weather Service forecast a 30 percent chance of thunderstorms today and a good chance of rain and thunderstorms on Friday. ``Lord, we don't need this and neither do any of these other people,'' said Gary Stone, standing outside his parents' house in North Little Rock. ``If the water comes over those sandbags, it's all over. It's going to be a shame for all of us to have fought this thing so long and then lose because it starts raining.'' At least 400 homes have been heavily damaged or submerged by the Arkansas River, state officials said. The river also has swept away cattle, including all but 67 of a herd of 250 in Conway County, upstream from Little Rock. ``A few of them floated down river and walked out and a few of them floated down river and didn't walk out,'' said Conway County extension agent William Nelson. Felix Brown and his sons and grandsons saved a herd of 170 attle stranded on an island near Pine Bluff. Brown said they hogtied 40 calves Saturday and took them out by fishing boats, and found a barge big enough to ferry out the rest. In Texas, the Trinity and Red rivers have engulfed farmland along with hundreds of businesses and homes. In Ellis County south of Dallas, an estimated 20,000 acres planted in wheat, corn, sorghum and cotton were inundated after levees on the Trinity failed. ``I think it's going to pretty well put me out of business unless we get some government help,'' said Charlie James, who said all but 100 of his 1,800 acres of crops were washed out. ``I don't really know what the alternatives are.'' Upstream on the Trinity, between Dallas and Fort Worth, International Wildlife Park, where floods killed 10 animals this year and 20 animals last year, will be moved to a flood-free location, owner Micky Hunt announced. Seven deer, two antelope and one ostrich died in last week's flooding. Some animals had been moved to area zoos or Hunt's second wildlife park, in Ohio, but many were forced to scramble for high ground. ``It's very devastating to have an outside factor that you have no control over rob you of a major tourist attraction,'' Grand Prairie Mayor Jerry Debo said. Hunt said he would find a new location in the Dallas-Forth Worth area.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Begins Probe of `Major League' Fire Aboard Conyngham
LaserPhotos XNK1-2, LaserColor XNK101
DOC.TEXT: The fire that killed one sailor and injured 18 on a guided-missile destroyer was so hot it made the decks bubble and melted firefighters' breathing masks on their faces. It was a ``major league fire'' that could have destroyed the 27-year-old USS Conyngham, said Capt. Joseph W. Perrotta Jr., skipper of a rescue vessel. The Navy declined to comment on a possible cause of the fire, one of two fatal incidents on Navy ships Tuesday. Navy officials said the fire started early Tuesday in the forward boiler room when the boiler was being lit. Fire and smoke spread quickly upward, filling berthing areas, the Command Information Center and the bridge. The Command Information Center is the ship's nerve center with communications, radar and sonar. The Conyngham docked early Wednesday, 21 hours after the fire erupted about 100 miles southeast of Norfolk, said Lt. j.g. Karl Johnson, an Atlantic Fleet spokesman. Portholes were broken out along the right side of the vessel and a 12-foot-long scorch mark was visible just above the waterline at mid-ship. Perrotta, skipper of the USS Normandy, said that when his ship approached the Conyngham, smoke was pouring out of the ship's forward stack area and bridge. The Normandy provided additional firefighting equipment and personnel to help the Conyngham crew control the blaze. Cmdr. William R. Williams, the Conyngham's skipper, had ordered the affected spaces evacuated, leaving the ship dead in the water and without communications, and formed firefighting crews, Perrotta said. The main fire was extinguished in about 2{ hours by the ship's 383-man crew, but sailors continued to monitor conditions because of the intense heat held by the aluminum decks and bulkheads, Perrotta said. ``The ship could have been lost if not for the gallant effort of the crew,'' he said. Seaman James Choss, an electrician aboard the ship and one of the injured, told his mother he was getting ready for bed after working most of the night in the Combat Information Center when the fire broke out. ``He said a fuel pump blew down in one of the boilers'' and that's what started the fire, Elizabeth Choss said from her home in Hammond, Ind. ``One of the other guys in the room was hit by a fireball that singed his hair,'' said Mrs. Choss. She said her son described hallways filled with smoke, holes burned in the floor, masks on firefighting gear that melted onto the faces of his shipmates and ``decks that were bubbling' in the intense heat. After the main fire was put out, the Conyngham was able to get under way on its own, but Williams shut down the boilers when a fuel leak was discovered. The ship was towed back to port, where it was met by about 200 crewmembers' family and friends when it docked. While the ship was in tow, a team of Naval Investigative Service agents was flown to the vessel to begin looking for the cause of the fire, said Lt. Cmdr. Deborah Burnette, a U.S. Atlantic Fleet spokeswoman. The commander of Destroyer Squadron 10, Capt. Raymond Sharpe Jr., will head the investigation of the accident. Killed in the fire was Lt. Algernon Pope Gordon Jr., 34, of Montgomery, Ala. Gordon was the Conyngham's operation's officer, in charge of collecting, evaluating and disseminating tactical information. Twelve of the 18 injured where flown to the Portsmouth Naval Hospital and to a hospital trauma center. Six others walked off the ship when it docked. Navy officials said none of the injuries were serious, and five crewmembers were released from the naval hospital Wednesday. At the mouth of Chesapeake Bay on Tuesday, Petty Officer 3rd Class Norbert Thomas Hanke of Lousiville, Ky., died after being struck by debris when the propeller of a hovercraft disintegrated. The accident occurred during small boat manuevers.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-, AM-Ship Fire
DOC.TEXT: Here is a list of the 12 sailors evacuated from the USS Conyngham following a fire Tuesday off the Virginia-North Carolina coast: _Lt. Cmdr. Martin Moody of Indian Head, Md., the ship's executive officer _Lt. j.g. Oscar Dansby of Atlanta _Lt. j.g. John Beaver of Falls Church, Va. _Petty Officer 1st Class Joseph Sanchez of Seguin, Texas _Petty Officer 1st Class Timothy McCauley of Thomasville, N.C. _Petty Officer 3rd Class Joseph Hoff of Kingsport, Tenn. _Petty Officer 3rd Class Randal Valentine of Lapeer, Mich. _Petty Officer 3rd Class Paulo Acedera of San Pedro Laguna, Republic of the Philippines _Petty Officer 3rd Class John Repik of Albuquerque, N.M. _Seaman Daniel Bartolo of New York, N.Y. _Seaman James Choss of Hammond Lake, Ind. _Seaman Edward Gardner of Scott City, Mo. Choss, Bartolo, Gardner, McCauley, and Sanchez were released Wednesday. Navy officials said the remaining sailors were in satisfactory condition. Six other sailors with minor injuries were taken to the Portsmouth Naval Hospital on Wednesday after the ship docked.

DOC.HEAD: Bugs Traverse Tiny Treadmills as Science Marches On
DOC.TEXT: Cockroaches, centipedes and crabs are skittering on teensy-weensy treadmills to help scientists learn more about how the little critters get from here to there. So far, biologist Robert Full's research team has found that insects run rather than walk, and that cockroaches, beetles, dogs and humans all use the same basic gait when they run. Crabs, however, gallop. Full's laboratory at the University of California, Berkeley, contains a series of miniature treadmills in airtight plastic boxes. Air tubes connected to the boxes allow Full and his students to measure itty-bitty amounts of oxygen consumed by jogging cockroaches. The scientists also can measure the force exerted by insects' individual footfalls. Each insect or crab is put through its paces for 10 to 15 minutes at a time in a series of tests lasting a couple of weeks. Full found the amount of energy a creature uses getting from one place to another has nothing to do with how many legs it has, or even how smoothly it runs or walks. Instead, energy expenditure depends on the amount of force produced by leg muscles and the amount of time it takes each leg to go through a whole cycle of movement. ``This seems to be true all the way from an awkward marathon winner to a centipede weaving over the ground,'' Full said. Researchers also learned that the energy required to walk or run depends largely on the force needed to hold the body up against gravity, and not so much on mechanical power needed to swing the legs and propel the body forward.

DOC.SECOND: PM-Missouri River Lawsuit, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0553,0516
DOC.HEAD: States Win Battle With Federal Agency Over Control of Missouri River
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 2nd to UPDATE with notice of appeal. Edits throughout to makes subseqent references to corps lower-case.
DOC.TEXT: A judge today ordered the Army Corps of Engineers to bow to the wishes of three states and limit releases of water from Lake Oahe until June 1 in order to protect fishing. U.S. District Judge Patrick Conmy granted a request by North Dakota, South Dakota and Montana to stop the corps from lowering the reservoir by 3 feet until the end of the month. The states contend the May release of water from Lake Oahe wipes out the lake's walleye spawn. The corps filed a notice today that it will appeal, U.S. attorney Steve Easton said. Officials of the three states said the legal dispute reflects growing anger at the corps' management of the entire Missouri system during a drought now entering its third year in the upper Great Plains. ``The fish spawn are symptomatic of a much bigger problem,'' said former South Dakota Gov. William Janklow, attorney for the three states. ``That's the neglect, the abuse and the disregard that ofttimes comes from people within the bureaucracy that make decisions.'' The lake is in North and South Dakota. Montana joined in contending the corps is managing the system in favor of navigation in lower basin states to the detriment of recreation and wildlife in upper basin states. Charles Findlay, a Justice Department attorney representing the corps, argued Tuesday that Conmy had no authority to dictate how the agency should manage its system of six Missouri River dams. But Conmy said today he was ``unwilling to accept an interpretation that would place any governmental agency beyond the scope of judicial review of actions having a direct economic effect upon thousands of citizens.'' The corps has many complex considerations to make in deciding how to handle the system, Findlay said, arguing that Conmy's order would not be in the public interest. If the lake falls dramatically, walleye eggs laid in shallow water will be exposed and destroyed, Janklow argued Tuesday before Conmy. That would deal a $20 million blow to Dakota tourism, said Janklow. ``We don't live in wealthy states ... We have very limited economic opportunities available to us,'' he told Conmy. The three states' request would effectively end shipping in the Missouri's navigation channel, which stretches from Sioux City, Iowa, to St. Louis, the corps' attorney said. Shipping contributes only $14 million in benefits to the system, compared with $67 million in benefits from fishing and recreation, Janklow said. The states' request also could harm the nesting of two federally protected rare birds, the piping plover and interior least tern, he said. Janklow countered the birds would not be affected. Governors of North Dakota and South Dakota attended Tuesday's hearing as did top attorneys from the Dakotas, Montana, Nebraska, Iowa, Kansas and Missouri.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Opposes New Fund to Fight CFCs
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration opposes setting up an international fund to help poor countries decrease their production of ozone-depleting chemicals known as chlorofluorocarbons, the White House said today. While the administration wants so-called CFCs eliminated and believes ``financial assistance should be made available'' to help developing countries do that, President Bush feels that resources in existing international agencies are sufficient to handle it, said White House spokesman Roman Popadiuk. The idea of a $100 million special fund to help developing nations was to be raised at an international conference on CFCs, which U.S. representatives are attending in Geneva, according to The Washington Post. The newspaper said the proposal seeks money to help the Third World countries convert to alternative chemicals and identify ways to replace CFCs. CFCs are used widely for refrigeration and some aerosol products, and their emission is depleting the ozone layer that protects the Earth from harmful ultraviolet rays. ``The United States believes that the health of the global environment is everyone's responsibility and must be addressed. We support a worldwide phaseout of CFCs,'' Popadiuk said in a prepared statement. ``The United States agrees that financial assistance should be made available to help developing countries phase out production of CFCs. However we believe it is more sensible to use existing institutions and existing financial mechanisms already established by the World Bank.'' It would not be sensible, he said, to set up a new fund that would create ``new rules, regulations and procedures that will have to be negotiated for every new protocol.'' ``The World Bank should use existing resources,'' he said. He did not elaborate on how the World Bank might reroute existing resources for the effort. The administration has come under criticism by environmentalists previously for what they say is foot-dragging on the question of eliminating CFCs and failing to keep up with the leadership of more aggressive European nations. The administration endorsed the idea of phasing out CFCs last year, after it was proposed by Europeans.

DOC.HEAD: German Reunification Casts Shadow on Soviet Victory Day Celebrations
DOC.TEXT: Soviet World War II veterans Wednesday celebrated their defeat of the Nazis 45 years ago, but worried that a reunited Germany could once again threaten their homeland. A senior naval officer thought a reunified Germany so repulsive he responded angrily when asked about the issue: ``I killed Germans then, and if I have to, I'll kill them again!'' He refused to give his name and stormed off. Thousands of gray-haired veterans took advantage of bright spring weather to don their uniforms, pin on their medals and gather in parks to recall the conflict they call The Great War for the Fatherland. It was their first Victory Day celebration since East Germany's hard-line Communist leader Erich Honecker was swept from power, the Berlin Wall was opened and negotiations began on reuniting East and West Germany. Most of the half-dozen veterans interviewed in Sverdlov Square outside the Bolshoi Theater after an official military parade in nearby Red Square said they would tolerate a reunited Germany only if it were neutral, belonging neither to the NATO nor Warsaw Pact military alliances. ``I'm not against the reunification of Germany but I am against war with Germany, making sure it is not repeated,'' said retired Air Force Lt. Ivan D. Morozov, who said he met U.S. soldiers on the Elbe River in Germany at the close of the war. Asked which alliance Germany should join, he said: ``It shouldn't be in any bloc. There just should be peace on earth so people don't know war.'' Morozov held red tulips and wore a brown jacket with four rows of silver and gold medals. Nearby, a group of women accompanied by an accordion sang of the heroism of Soviet soldiers. Gen. Ivan Petrov, who served on the Ukrainian front, said he also believed Germany should be neutral if its citizens choose that course. ``Let the German people decide themselves,'' said Petrov, who was interrupted by children giving him flowers. He echoed the Kremlin compromise suggestion that if a reunited Germany could not avoid joining one military alliance, it should remain in both. Soviet officials have suggested that a united Germany belong to both the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact until undefined European ``security structures'' are created to maintain stability. Bonn and Washington reject this, saying Germany should belong only to NATO. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze has said his people should have a special say in discussions on German reunification because they suffered so much in World War II. Twenty million Soviets were killed. Fears abounded among the veterans that a reunited Germany could become an aggressor. ``Unification is good but there must be a guarantee of the security of all people, especially those who suffered the most from Hitler. It's in the center of Europe, so it must be a peaceful country,'' said Col. Vasily Kovalev, 63. An artillery regiment commander, Kovalev wore a dark green dress uniform and held orange and red tulips. Nearby, Lt. Konstantin Trepakov said in broken English that the wartime allies, the Soviets, French, British and Americans, would join again to fight Germany if it became a threat. A wartime buddy, Lt. Col. Konstantin Palkin, interrupted: ``I'm skeptical. I don't exclude the possibility of (German) revenge. Our World War II allies won't allow that.'' Another veteran standing in the group, wearing a blue paratrooper's beret, said he did not believe a neutral Germany would be safe. ``It could develop strongly on its own and could not be controlled by the Americans or anyone else,'' said the veteran, who did not give his name.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Congressional Leaders Agree to Budget Talks Next Week
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new grafs 12-15, bgng, Foley said ... with names of negotiators; deletes pvs graf 16, The budget-summit ... and bottom 4 grafs to tighten
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and congressional leaders agreed today to open negotiations on a deficit-reduction package that may include tax increases as well as deep spending cuts. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater announced the talks after Senate and House leaders met with Bush for more than an hour in the Oval Office to discuss the widening 1991 budget gap. Fitzwater said the negotiatations would begin next Tuesday. He said whether taxes are included in any compromise was ``a matter for the negotiators to consider.'' Although Bush won the White House pledging ``no new taxes,'' he abandoned that pronouncement this week in face of the spiraling federal deficit. ``Severe action needs to be taken,'' Fitzwater said today, blaming the nation's worsening deficit situation on rising interest rates, reduced revenues to the Treasury and a previous underestimate of the costs of the savings and loan bailout. ``The table is clean,'' Fitzwater said, suggesting that tax increases could be part of the eventual compromise. ``We are setting the stage for open and fruitful discussions.'' Congressional leaders, speaking with reporters outside the White House after the meeting, generally steered away from questions about tax increases. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said: ``I think there is an understanding we'd like to avoid'' the automatic spending cuts that would be triggered in the absence of a budget agreement. ``No decisions have been made other than to begin discussions next week,'' said Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine. And House Minority Leader Bob Michel, R-Ill., said that there were limits to what negotiators can do faced with the need to make up to $100 billion in cuts. Budget slashes of such magnitude run the risk of being ``injurious'' to the economy, Michel said. Foley said he has appointed Rep. Richard Gephardt of Missouri, the Democratic majority leader and an outspoken critic of the administration, to chair his delegation to the talks. The speaker's other negotiators are: Rep. William H. Gray III, D-Pa., the majority whip; and Reps. Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, Jamie Whitten of Mississippi and Leon Panetta of California, the Democratic chairmen of the Ways and Means, Appropriations and Budget committees, respectively. Michel said the House Republicans would be Reps. Newt Gingrich of Georgia and the ranking Republicans on those same three tax-writing and finance committees, Reps. Bill Archer of Texas, Silvio O. Conte of Massachusetts, and Bill Frenzel of Minnesota. Mitchell said Sen. Wyche Fowler, D-Ga., would be his ``personal representative'' to the talks, along with Sens. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, and James Sasser, D-Tenn., the chairmen of Appropriations, Finance and Budget respectively. Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., was expected to name his representatives later today. Budget Director Richard Darman told Congress on Tuesday that $50 billion to $100 billion might be needed in deficit-fighting steps this year _ between two and three times more than the savings Bush said would be needed when he submitted his budget last January. Fitzwater said Bush would not participate directly in the meetings but would monitor them closely and ``will be involved as necessary.'' He said the three-way negotiations will be conducted by teams from the House, Senate and White House. Earlier, Michel urged GOP lawmakers to ``hold their fire'' and stop criticizing the budget efforts by the White House and congressional leaders. ``Nobody wants to make a tough choice,'' Michel said after meeting with House Republicans this morning. Fitzwater said that, from the president's vantage point, the special budget negotiations have four basic objectives: _Reducing the deficit ``substantially on a multi-year basis.'' _Allowing the economy ``to grow at a continued strong pace.'' _Overhaul the congressional budget process. _To ``avoid the adverse economic and programmatic effects of a stalemate that might otherwise ensue.'' Fitzwater said there was no specific timetable for forging an agreement. But, he added, ``all parties feel that it's in the best interests to try to move this process forward immediately.'' Although until recently Fitzwater and other administration officials have issued optimistic assessments of the economy, Fitzwater declared that economic ``growth is low at this point'' and the nation's economy is weakening. ``There is no hiding from that,'' Fitzwater said. ``We do have an economic problem that we need to deal with.'' Some Republicans have vowed to oppose any tax increases that might emerge from the talks. Michel, asked what he told GOP colleagues after meeting with them this morning, replied: ``Hold their fire, keep their powder dry. Don't be quick to criticize when they're not a party to whatever is being negotiated.'' On Tuesday, Iowa Gov. Terry Branstad, a Republican who heads the National Governors Association, warned Bush to expect an uprising from the states over proposals for a national sales tax. ``States are going to dig in very strongly against a national sales tax,'' Branstad said. ``I think that would be a big mistake.''

DOC.HEAD: Women's Advocacy Group Calls For Revisions In Pension Policies
DOC.TEXT: An advocacy group recommended Wednesday that person who stay home to care for children or disabled family members be given Social Security credit. The Older Women's League said current law penalizes women, who are more likely than men to leave the work force for family duties that give them no credit in the Social Security system. The group released a report that executive director Joan Kuriansky said ``shows in brutal detail what is in store for America's mid-life and younger women.'' The report said that federal pension policies mean unmarried and widowed women who retire 30 years from now are much more likely to live in poverty than either married women or men. At fault, the report said, are Social Security and private pension systems that favor the ``traditional family'' and so benefit men. OWL said fewer than 10 percent of American families fit the traditional profile of a working father, homemaker mother and two children. ``There are system-wide inequities ... that will continue to penalize women,'' OWL President Lou Glasse said at a news conference, where release of the report was timed to precede Mother's Day this Sunday. ``Pension eligibility has generally required long-term, continuous full-time service with one employer _ a bad fit for women,'' she said. Glasse said Congress should at least allow debate on the idea of Social Security credit for non-working ``caregivers.'' ``Policy makers should realize that women do move in and out of the workforce,'' Kuriansky said. OWL also called on Congress to: _Mandate portable pension plans, so that people who change jobs may take with them all retirement contributions. _Reduce from five the maximum number of years employers may require for vesting. OWL claimed that for most women, ``decades of Social Security contributions will translate into virtually the same retirement benefits as those paid to their mothers, who may never have earned wages or paid Social Security taxes.'' The league said that 20 years into the next century, Social Security and private pension plans will have practically ended poverty among older men and couples, but financial problems will remain widespread for single women. Glasse said women 30 years away from retirement are ``already in jeopardy.'' The report said the 55-year-old Social Security system and private pension plans penalize women, who typically live longer than men but earn less money. The OWL said 70 percent of Baby Boom women will outlive their husbands by about 15 years but, on average, will earn about two-thirds the pay for men their age. ``If our nation's Social Security and pension programs remain fundamentally unchanged, the retirement income future is unlikely to get any brighter for women,'' the league said.

DOC.HEAD: Still Reading After All These Years: Literary Clubs Head Into 2nd Century
DOC.TEXT: It is 2 o'clock on a Thursday somewhere in the lush and leafy suburbs. A bell rings. A woman opens a book and reads aloud the treasured words of Herman Melville's ``Moby Dick'' while 21 women listen in rapture. Welcome to The Thursday Club, where great books have been read aloud every week for 100 years. And while most of its members are elderly, the club and others like it are thriving. No one knows how many Americans belong to such clubs, which can trace their origins to before the Civil War when housewives found a way to awaken sleeping intellects. But according to Bowdoin College Professor Theodora Penny Martin, the impulse persists. Ms. Martin gets a glimpse of this whenever she gives a talk about her 1987 book on the early days of women's reading clubs: ``The Sound of Our Own Voices.'' ``Women of middle age and even younger ... the minute they hear about the clubs want to tell me about a book club they are in,'' Ms. Martin said in a telephone interview from Brunswick, Maine. ``There still is that sense of wanting to be intellectually alive outside their jobs, and also a sense of wanting to be part of a circle of women,'' she said. The Thursday Club, with two members in their 90s and most in their 60s and 70s, is still the exclusive, invitation-only group it was in 1890. Members still take turns being hostesses of readings every Thursday from 2 p.m. to 4 p.m., October to May. The routine, strictly kept, is one hour of reading from a book of lasting value, such as works by James Joyce, Charles Dickens, Homer, Goethe and Confucius. They also read more contemporary writers such as James Baldwin, Gabriel Garcia Marquez, Alice Walker and Thomas Mann. A brief break follows, with water the sole refreshment. Then comes an hour of lighter fare, such as poetry or plays. ``I feel as though I am witnessing the last members of a very special generation ... raised by Victorian grandmothers. I don't think there are women who are like this anywhere. (It's) a rarefied little group,'' said Deborah Youngman. At 39, Ms. Youngman is ``the baby,'' as one member described the doctoral candidate in human development. ``I imagined it would be the quintessential bluestocking affair. It was not. I also assumed it would be a marvelous opportunity to observe local High Quaint,'' said the native Californian now living in Belmont. ``I couldn't have been more naive ... they are rather more than middle-aged, rather more than middle-class, white, clad in good old wool and sensible shoes. They're very, very serious. ``They are rich and evocative but not in cakes and tea,'' Ms. Youngman said. Such reading clubs began in the Midwest in 1860 and reached their heyday around 1900, when membership was estimated at nearly 1 million, typically comprising well-off housewives with children in school and servants at home. For a long time, the literary gatherings provided women unable to attend college a place to use their minds. But early in this century, women were finally getting into many schools and reading clubs began to fall by the way. The clubs also felt the drain and distraction of women during the two world wars. Further decimation occurred after the 1960s, as the women who might have joined reading clubs poured into universities and out again into professions. Group's like The Thursday Club may one day vanish. Ms. Youngman said she fears that one day she will be its last member and the one to take its archives to their final rest at the Belmont Public Library. She should talk to Alfreda L. Irwin. Mrs. Irwin, 77, an author and journalist, is now in Chautauqua, N.Y. But she still belongs to The Wednesday Club she joined as a housewife in 1938 in Franklin, Pa. ``I go back and it's just marvelous because they have all these wonderful, educated women who are just very anxious to participate in this interesting club,'' she said in a telephone interview.

DOC.HEAD: Michigan Fires Destroy at Least 80 Homes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with color, two smaller fires, rainfall; picks up 6th graf pvs bgng: One firefighter ...
DOC.TEXT: A fire destroyed at least 60 homes and blackened about 16 square miles in Michigan's parched Lower Peninsula before being brought under control, and firefighters welcomed midmorning rain. Three smaller fires covering a total of about one square mile destroyed at least 20 homes in rural northern Roscommon and southern Crawford counties, officials said. The larger fire broke out in a forested area in eastern Crawford County Tuesday afternoon, forcing the evacuation of about 300 people, Grayling sheriff's officials said. One resident along the Au Sable River, Norbert Szkotnicki, said he snuck past police barricades Tuesday evening to check on his home. He found part of it burning. ``I got a chainsaw and cut off a (burning) corner of the cabin,'' he said. Firefighters then arrived and doused the house, saving it. ``My family has been here 110 years. My grandfather built that house,'' he said. ``I wasn't going to lose it.'' Another resident, William Witt, piled three elderly neighbors and their five dogs into his car and fled as the fire reached his driveway. ``When I saw the fire come through, I didn't worry about nothing but dogs and people,'' he said today. The blaze was brought under control late Tuesday. Fire officials worried about forecast winds of 10-20 mph today, but light rain started falling at midmorning as four National Guard helicopters dumped 185-gallon drums of water on areas that continued burning. ``Thank God for the rain,'' Crawford County sheriff's Deputy Heide Miller said. Deputy Sheriff Mike Shearer said today that about 100 structures had burned, including at least 60 homes.
