One firefighter was hospitalized for smoke inhalation. ``All you see are burned spots on the ground that used to be homes,'' said firefighter Jed Blaauw. ``There will be a lot of broken hearts,'' said Bill Mahalak, acting regional forest manager for the Department of Natural Resources, as he drove past the burned homes along the Au Sable River, known for its trout fishing. About 150 firefighters battled the blaze, officials said. A 14-square-mile area was evacuated Tuesday as gusts of more than 20 mph pushed the fire at nearly 4 mph, said forest manager Jim McMillan. But an unexpected change in the weather caused winds to shift, blowing the fire back onto itself, firefighter Scott Heather said. That and a brief rain gave firefighters enough of a break to plow fire lines, officials said. ``We've had about a dozen saves,'' Dean Goss said late Tuesday as he looked at the only house still standing in one section of wood along the river. Around him, the flames on one house crackled and another behind it smoldered in the dark, a stone chimney the only thing left standing. Officials said the spring fire season is at its worst as warm winds dried out last year's leaves before this year's growth had a chance to get started. Much of the northern Lower Peninsula is 1 to 2 inches behind in rainfall this spring, said state fire specialist Art Sutton. ``I've been terribly nervous,'' said Harry Selleck, manager of the Muskegon State Park. ``The forest floor is not greening up so far. It's become a real tinderbox.''

DOC.HEAD: Coast Guard Rescues Four on Raft in Atlantic
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with rescue. Deletes BRF-designation from keyword.
DOC.TEXT: Four survivors of a sunken Rhode Island sailing vessel were rescued this morning from a raft 150 miles southwest of Bermuda, the Coast Guard said. The survivors were picked up at 9 a.m. by the merchant vessel Baron Trader, Coast Guard officials reported. They did not know if there were others on the the 57-foot Misconduct, which hit a submerged object and sank en route to Bermuda. The survivors' names were not released. The Baron Trader was expected to arrive at Baton Rouge, La., around midnight May 13. A search for Misconduct began 11 p.m. Tuesday after the Coast Guard station in Woods Hole, Mass., picked up a report that the boat owned by Paul Harron of Newport, R.I., was sinking. A Navy patrol plane couldn't find it. But a report from another vessel that had been with Misconduct several days earlier prompted the Coast Guard to send a C-130 from Elizabeth City, N.C., to search south of Bermuda. The raft was located by the plane at 4:37 a.m. The plane remained over the site to await arrival of the Baron Trader.

DOC.HEAD: MIT Admissions Director Gives Credit Where It's Due
DOC.TEXT: The letters Michael Behnke gets brim with such gratitude they can be heartbreaking. ``I just had to write and thank you for making my day, week and year!'' wrote one correspondent from Westlake, Ohio. ``This letter changed me, it made me realize what I do is terribly important,'' wrote another from Troy, Mich. Used-car salesmen in need of a hug? Worn-out parents feeling neglected by their children? No. These letters came from high school teachers. They were replying to an annual form letter from Behnke, admissions director at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. If teaching teen-agers is a thankless task, MIT doesn't think it should be. Several years ago Behnke initiated the custom of dispatching letters of praise to the educators who loomed large in the lives of students newly admitted to the school as undergraduates. The form letter goes like this: ``Each year, we ask students admitted to MIT to share with us the name of a teacher who has been especially influential in that student's development. ``We congratulate you on being named this year by _ '' and the student's name is filled in. ``More importantly, we thank you for the time, patience, expertise, love, discipline and all the other qualities which have had such an important impact on your students. You do the work from which we all benefit. ``Congratulations again on the respect you have earned from your students.'' Among the 1,800 questionnaires returned from incoming freshman admitted for fall 1989, 1,265 teachers were cited. Behnke said every year about 20 teachers thank him in turn for the letters. He feels he has tapped a deep need for recognition among purveyors of the three R's. The MIT letter even reached that citadel of public expression, Dear Abby. One teacher ecstatic about getting a thank you letter from MIT sent a copy to the columnist and signed off: ``My Name is Legion, My Address is Cloud Nine.'' Behnke said he finds the teachers' responses moving _ and a bit disturbing. ``You are both happy and sad that not more is done, that so little can mean so much. It is troublesome.'' Not that the subject doesn't have its lighter side. One New York educator with a sense of humor and a smart son wrote along with his thank you this year that he had been cited four times by former students. So, he said, Behnke recalled, `I hope you pay attention when I write a letter of recommendation for my own son.''' The son was admitted. The idea of giving due credit occurred to Behnke when he arrived at MIT five years ago. The school was already collecting names of teachers from incoming students. But MIT was only using the names as contacts when recruiters went around the country seeking top-notch young minds. Behnke, 46, a former high school teacher and the husband of one, decided to lift those teachers' names out of the anonymity of the databank. ``I know how much teachers appreciate hearing from students,'' he said, noting that high school teachers have the hardest time of any getting audience feedback. ``It's hard for adolescents,'' Behnke said. ``If they show too much excitement, they're accused of brown-nosing. It's not cool.'' But youngsters take their cues from adults, he said. ``In society, people get accustomed to not thanking people, in general. ``This is a very small gesture.''

DOC.HEAD: Gantt Appeals to Foe to Forgo Senate Runoff in North Carolina
DOC.TEXT: Harvey Gantt, the leader in North Carolina's Democratic primary for Senate, appealed to his nearest rival Wednesday to forgo a runoff in the spirit of party unity against arch-conservative Republican Sen. Jesse Helms. In Ohio, the man who ousted scandal-tainted Rep. Donald ``Buz'' Lukens said his campaign was ``a mission to do what's right for the district.'' In other results of Tuesday's primaries, West Virginia Democrats nominated Sen. Jay Rockefeller for a second term, but dashed former first lady Dee Caperton's hopes of becoming state treasurer. Rockefeller will face Republican John Yoder in November. Ohio Democrats pinned their gubernatorial hopes on Attorney General Anthony J. Celebrezze Jr., setting up a November contest with former Cleveland Mayor George Voinovich. Voters in Ohio's Cuyahoga County approved a higher ``sin tax'' on liquor and cigarettes to finance a new $344 million downtown sports complex for baseball's Cleveland Indians. Former Democratic Reps. Ken Hechler of West Virginia and Katie Hall of Indiana lost comeback bids, and 100-year-old Henry Stenhouse finished last in a GOP congressional primary in North Carolina. Atlantic City, N.J., Mayor James L. Usry came in second in a seven-way race and will compete in a June 12 runoff against Councilman Jim Whelan. Gantt, the black former mayor of Charlotte who was running in a six-man field, fell short of the 40 percent mark that would have guaranteed him the nomination. Under state law, the second-place finisher can order a June 5 runoff, and Michael Easley, the Brunswick County district attorney, did just that. ``We don't want to send our candidate into the fall armed with less than 40 percent of the vote,'' Easley told reporters. ``There appears to be no real consensus. It appears the voters ought to hear more from Mike Easely and Harvey Gantt.'' But Gantt urged Easley to reconsider. ``Before Mike Easley takes that walk to the Board of Elections, he should consider unity over divisiveness,'' Gantt said. ``We should not divert attention from the real challenge of defeating Jesse Helms.'' Thad Beyle, a political science professor at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, said a runoff would be bad news for Gantt. ``I think if you go on the basis of the political history of the state, if a liberal or a minority doesn't win it in the first primary, they'll lose it in the second primary,'' Beyle said. With 99 percent of precincts reporting, Gantt led with 258,501 votes or 38 percent; Easley had 207,929 votes or 30 percent; former insurance commissioner John Ingram had 119,363 votes or 17 percent; ex-state Sen. Bo Thomas had 81,608 votes or 12 percent, and two other candidates divided the remainder. Helms, seeking his fourth term, easily dispatched two token opponents in the GOP primary, piling up 84 percent of the vote. In western Ohio's 8th District, Lukens finished third in a four-way GOP primary. He had rejected calls for by party leaders for his resignation following his misdemeanor conviction last year for having sex with a 16-year-old girl. ``Never argue with the voters,'' said Lukens, who returned to Washington on Wednesday, saying he planned to return ``to a normal life.'' State Rep. John Boehner, who won the primary, denied Lukens was the issue. ``This race was never focused on Lukens,'' Boehner told supporters. ``When I started last June, it was a mission to do what was right for this district. ``... Buz was black and white. People were either with him or against him. This race wasn't a popularity contest. It was about who was the best candidate.'' Boehner will face the Democratic nominee, Gregory Jolivette, former mayor of Hamilton. The district is a GOP stronghold that has consistently elected Republicans to Congress since the 1950s. With all precincts reporting, Boehner had 25,068 votes or 49 percent; former Rep. Thomas Kindness had 16,330 votes or 32 percent; Lukens had 8,681 votes or 17 percent, and Mort Meier, a Hamilton bond underwriter, had 716 votes, or 1 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Academy Test Apparently Stolen; Navy Gives It Anyway
DOC.TEXT: Burglars may have stolen copies of an engineering exam during a break-in at two Naval Academy offices during the weekend, but the exam was given as scheduled anyway, a newspaper reported Wednesday. The (Annapolis) Capital quoted unidentified faculty members as saying copies of the test had been stolen, but academy spokeswoman Carol Feldmann said no one was sure if copies had been stolen. ``We couldn't be sure that the test was compromised and we couldn't be sure that it wasn't,'' Feldmann said. ``So we went ahead and gave the test as is.'' Midshipmen took the test Monday. The exams were for a required electrical engineering course that is usually taken by midshipmen in their junior year. The break-in was discovered about midday Sunday by engineering faculty members, Feldmann said. The offices are in Maury Hall, which is left open on weekends for studying.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Dispenses With Security in Tour of Prison Yard
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs, pope plunges into crowd of convicts. Pickup 10th graf pvs, ``John Paul met...''
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II stepped off a raised, fenced-off platform and plunged into a jammed prison yard today in an unscheduled display of compassion as a convict chorus sang Beethoven's ``Ode to Joy.'' The pontiff then told about a thousand prisoners that ``the worst prison is a closed heart,'' and urged them to keep up their hope for a better life because ``Christ never loses hope in his creatures.'' The pope had been scheduled to greet only one prisoner _ a man who had killed his wife _ before his brief speech, but John Paul conferred with several assistants when he reached a platform that had been set up in the prison yard. The prisoners were confined behind a high Cyclone fence, but the pope descended from the platform, ordered that a gate be opened, and strolled into the yard, greeting and blessing prisoners for 20 minutes. One prisoner showed off an injured foot, and others appeared to be shaking with nervousness or joy as the pope approached. A prison band played Mexican tunes, then broke into the ``Ode to Joy'' in Spanish as the pope toured the yard. The ``Ode'' is the choral finale to Beethoven's Ninth Symphony. The state prison in Durango holds about 1,200 prisoners, authorities said, including convicted murderers and drug traffickers. The pontiff was scheduled to address a crowd of businessmen on their social responsibility during the afternoon. On Tuesday night, in a speech to diplomats in Mexico City, 450 miles to the southeast, the pope called for a moral as well as an economic approach to the ``imprisoning'' foreign debt crisis. ``Technical measures are not enough to resolve the great problems that menace international equilibrium,'' the pope told the diplomats. ``I feel the obligation to underline ... the ethical dimension of this imprisoning crisis,'' which, the pontiff said, was hindering development in many poor nations of the world. John Paul met the diplomats after celebrating a Mass for young people near a shrine at San Juan de los Lagos, 250 miles northwest of Mexico City. There, he encouraged Mexico's young people not to be disheartened by injustice and inequality and to use Christ as a defense against despair. He said loss of hope in today's world was symbolized by ``evasion, abandon, hedonism, discotheques, drugs, indifference, pessimism, the artificial paradises in which so many find refuge.'' ``Young people, don't lose hope! You are the pilgrims of hope,'' the pontiff cried. More than 200,000 people packed the slopes of a hill outside San Juan for the Mass on Tuesday. Many waved flags in papal white and yellow or in green, the town's colors, and interrupted the pope frequently with cheers and chants. Priests wore white robes and yellow baseball caps to ward off the harsh sun. The town was one of the centers of a guerrilla war waged in the 1920s by Catholic conservatives opposed to the government's tight religious restrictions, and memories of the conflict are still strong. A large banner on a building facing the altar read ``Viva Cristo Rey'' _ Long Live Christ the King _ the battle cry of the Cristero rebels. In a morning address to teachers, the pope issued a veiled call for a lifting of constitutional prohibitions on religious schools, a prohibition that is ignored by many schools and even universities. ``Open the world of teaching to Christ!'' the pope said in a speech at the airport in Aguascalientes, about 50 miles north of San Juan de Los Lagos. Church-state relations are now at their best in 50 years, and President Carlos Salinas de Gortari recently sent a personal representative to the pope. The move was seen as a step toward possible re-establishment of the diplomatic ties severed in 1926. ``I have observed with great satisfaction the significant and important gesture of the president,'' the pope told the diplomats on Tuesday evening. John Paul's eight-day trip is his 47th outside Italy since becoming pope. He first visited Mexico in 1979.

DOC.HEAD: Fighting Escalates In Battle Between Christian Militias for Ports
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian forces escalated their battle Wednesday for control of a strategic stretch of coastline, killing 20 people and wounding 41 in fierce shelling duels, police said. The barrages came after rebel Gen. Michel Aoun threatened to attack ships using ports controlled by his rival Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia. Aoun backed up his threat by using howitzer batteries deployed in mountains northeast of Beirut to shell almost the entire length of the Christian enclave's 28-mile Mediterranean coastline in an effort to block Geagea's supply lines, a police spokesman said. Police said Aoun's gunners were shelling ports controlled by the Lebanese Forces at Jounieh, Amsheet, Byblos and Beirut harbor. Geagea's fighters responded by firing salvoes from multi-barrelled rocket launchers at territory controlled by Aoun's 19,000-man army, including a three-mile coastal strip around Dbaye, where the rebel general has a makeshift port. ``Its the war of ports. They are shelling each other's sea outlets,'' said the spokesman, who cannot be named in line with regulations. ``The whole (Christian) enclave is on fire. It is a war of destruction. No ground offensives are underway.'' Police said the casualties included a family of three who were killed when a 122mm rocket blasted their single-story house in the Aoun-held mountain resort of Baskinta, northeast of Beirut. Casualties from the latest round of fighting raised the overall toll to 972 killed and 2,564 wounded since Geagea and Aoun began their battle for control of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave on Jan. 30. The coastal battle has intensified since April 23 when Geagea ordered his flotilla of 20 speedboats and one gunboat to blockade Aoun's sea outlet at Dbaye to prevent the rebel forces from receiving weapons and ammunition. Aoun, who has only two crippled gunboats trapped at Dbaye, has relied on his howitzer batteries to shell his rival's ports. Jounieh, 12{ miles north of Beirut, is the terminal for a ferry and hydrofoil from Cyprus. These vessels are the Christians' only outlet from their enclave, which is ringed on its land sides by Syrian troops and their Moslem militia allies. Aoun's headquarters issued a communique early Wednesday warning local and international maritime agencies against serving any port along the coast of the Christian enclave. The communique said Aoun had declared the Christian coast a military operations zone. ``Sailing across it is banned to any vessel irrespective of its type or cargo,'' it said. Geagea, in a defiant response, told the Christian Voice of Lebanon radio that Aoun ``will not be able to squeeze us even if he maintains his shelling for 10 years.'' Smoke billowed from east Beirut's Ashrafiyeh district, a Geagea stronghold, and the pinewoods of the Metn mountains, northeast of Beirut, where Aoun's troops are entrenched. The thuds of exploding shells echoed across Beirut, as radio stations interrupted regular programming to blare appeals from hospitals for blood donations to cope with the influx of casualties. Beirut's Moslem sector has not been involved in the Christian fighting. About 400,000 of the Christian enclave's 1 million population have fled the fighting, mainly to safer areas in predominantly Moslem sectors of the nation. In another development, Lebanese President Elias Hrawi and Prime Minister Salim Hoss drove to the Syrian capital of Damascus for talks with President Hafez Assad on ways of implementing a peace plan to end Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war. Aoun has rejected the Arab League-brokered peace accord, endorsed by Lebanon's parliament in the Saudi Arabian resort of Taif in October, because it does not guarantee the withdrawal of the 40,000 Syrian troops in Lebanon. He also refuses to recognize Hrawi's election to implement the peace plan. Geagea has recognized Hrawi and cautiously accepted the peace plan, which calls for an equal distribution of power between Moslems and Christians.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: If you ask, ``Is there a doctor in the house?'' and get three yeses, don't be surprised. And don't think you need to see an eye doctor. Perry, Philip and Paul Johnson, of Omaha, will graduate together from the University of Kansas Medical School. They also were born together. They're triplets. The 25-year-old brothers will graduate May 20 in ceremonies at Lawrence, Kan. Each has a grade point of at least 3.97. The brothers are the sons of Robert Johnson of Omaha and Karen Cline of St. Charles, Ill. Perry and Paul attended the school's Kansas City campus and Philip went to the Wichita branch. Perry Johnson said he and his brothers received scholarships in undergraduate school and medical school. The Johnsons won't be practicing medicine together. Perry and his wife, Ann, will move to Omaha after graduation to begin serving his internship at the University of Nebraska Medical Center. Philip Johnson will begin an internship at Baptist Hospital in Oklahoma City. Paul Johnson will remain at the University of Kansas in Kansas City.

A prisoner assigned to pick up litter along a state highway has lived up to the name trustee. Hampton County Jail spokesman Richard McCarthy said Tuesday that when the inmate discovered a bag discarded along the road containing more than $1,100 in cash and checks, he gave it to a corrections officer. The money and checks had been stolen in a Jan. 12 break-in from the Office for the Aging in nearby Westfield. ``We never expected to see any of the money again,'' said Sophia Bousquet, executive director. ``That young man should be commended for his honesty.'' She said no one has been arrested for the break-in, ``but we recovered all but one of the checks that were taken and $470 of the $750 in cash. And needless to say we are very happy.'' McCarthy said state confidentiality laws prevented him from releasing the name of the inmate or the nature of his offense without the man's permission. He said the prisoner had been one of a group of six trustees working to clean up roadways under the guard of a corrections officer May 3.

How long can 500 students and teachers do the hokey-pokey? You remember how to do it: You put your right hand in. Take your right hand out. Put it in again and shake it all about. You do the hokey-pokey and you turn yourself around _ that's what it's all about. On Friday, Bob Luckadoo intends to set the world's record for doing just that. But he can't explain what exactly inspired him. ``I don't know if my defenses were down or if my creative was up,'' said Luckadoo, a guidance counselor at G.E. Massey Elementary School. ``But one day the idea all of a sudden sort of popped into my head.'' Luckadoo isn't the only one. The hokey-pokey muse has clobbered otherwise normal folks in Indiana, Illinois and Texas this spring. Like Luckadoo, they have told Mark Young, editor of the Guinness Book of World Records, that they intend to establish a record for doing the dance step. Guinness has no hokey-pokey record. It does have records for the longest conga line (119,986 people) and largest dance (25,000 in a 1984 Buffalo tribute to Glenn Miller). ``I just can't figure out why everyboody wants to do the hokey-pokey now,'' Young said. ``Maybe they can't do the lambada.''

DOC.HEAD: Unemployment Surges in East Germany as Country Braces for More
DOC.TEXT: In a prelude to the massive unemployment expected during the unification of the Germanys, the number of jobless East Germans nearly doubled last month compared with March, officials said Wednesday. Economic experts in both countries say the union of their countries' economies will put tens of thousands of East Germans out of work because dozens of dated and inefficient East German companies will fold. The West German mark will replace the nearly valueless East German mark on July 2, increasing pressure on East German businesses unable to pay off massive debts in the hard currency. Also Wednesday, the 20 unions belonging to the East German labor federation, Freie Deutsche Gewerkschaftsbund, voted to disband the organization and form a new one. For four decades the federation was the Communist-run labor organization. Despite attempts to break away from government control, it has been criticized for failing to adapt to change following the fall of the hard-line Communist government last year and plans for unification and a free market economy. The prospect of massive unemployment at the outset of unification was one of the major issues in East Germany's March 18 elections, the first free balloting in the nation's history. Workers protested what they accurately predicted would be widespread layoffs from once-guaranteed jobs. The Ministry for Labor and Social Affairs said Wednesday the number of unemployed rose from 38,313 in March to 64,948 last month. They included 36,000 skilled workers and 16,000 unskilled workers, according to the figures, distributed by the government-run news agency ADN. ADN did not provide a figure for April unemployment as a percentage of the total labor force. East Germany only recently began releasing unemployment data, and its current figures are considered incomplete. Officials said the number of job openings had ``slumped considerably'' to 73,558 in April, but did not provide figures for comparison. East Germany once had one of the strongest economies in the Soviet bloc, but it has been plagued by inefficiency since the beginning of the 1980s. Western experts say cumbersome central planning made East German businesses slow to adapt to changes and trends. The same held true for other countries in Eastern Europe that are now moving toward market economies following the democratic reforms that have swept the region. East Germany's economy suffered another serious blow in September, when tens of thousands of skilled workers began fleeing the country for West Germany. Even after the East Germans were allowed full freedom of travel last November, workers continued leaving in droves to West Germany. In all, more than 500,000 East Germans left the country from January 1989 through March of this year. West German officials and business leaders are counting on massive investment from the West to rebuild the East German economy.

Here are excerpts from recent editorials in newspapers throughout the country. May 5 Grants Pass (Ore.) Daily Courier on the hostage situation: Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani is miffed that the United States isn't falling over itself trying to thank him for helping with the release of two American hostages in the past two weeks. The releases, though, are a little like a man agreeing to quit beating two of his neighbor's 19 children: He's still whipping the remainder. In this case, Rafsanjani and the terrorists in Beirut supported by his government are inflicting the damage, while Western countries wait for the release of 17 more hostages. Why should the United States or any of these other countries make a goodwill gesture to terrorists who have robbed innocent people of years of their lives and continue to hold them for no apparent reason? Rewarding countries or terrorists for the release of the hostages would be like paying ransom, which would only encourage the seizing of more Westerners. ... At first, the captors, members of Islamic Jihad or ``Islamic Holy War,'' wanted to trade their hostages for 17 comrades imprisoned in Kuwait for bombing the U.S. and French embassies there. That deal was rejected by former President Reagan long ago, though. Since then, the kidnappers have turned the hostages into representatives of their governments, protesting the presence and policies of the United States and the other Western countries by continuing to hold and threaten their captives. But during the last five years, the United States has reduced to low levels its armed forces in the Middle East and put pressure on Israel to begin talks with the Palestinians on a solution in the occupied territories. What's more, U.S. officials have repeatedly stated they won't deal with the kidnappers. These conditions have made the hostages more of a liability than an asset for the kidnappers and those associated with them.

May 7 Concord (N.H.) Monitor on the hostage situation: As freed hostage Frank Reed said this weekend, the taking of hostages is a tactic as old as civilization. Captives can be traded for arms, exchanged for prisoners or held by the enemy as insurance against attack. But even in the United States, where reverence for the value of the individual life is perhaps greater than anywhere else in the world, the lives of hostages have never been more important than geopolitics. ... So as much as Americans may rejoice in the release of Reed and (Robert) Polhill, the president cannot rush to reward the hostage takers and those who influenced them. ``I want to see all hostages released,'' Bush said last week. What he meant was that Israel should free some of the hostages it has taken, including Sheik Obeid. But he could not afford to come out and say so.

May 5 The Herald-Dispatch, Huntington, W.Va., on defense spending: Reality is beginning to soak in at the Pentagon, if Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's proposals for cutting advanced aircraft spending is any indication. Still, it wouldn't be very difficult for someone such as, say, Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, to find far deeper cuts that could be made in the defense budget. Though Cheney has proposed cuts of about $35 billion between 1991 and 1997, that amounts to less than 2 percent of the original figure _ about $2 trillion _ that the armchair generals and admirals at the Pentagon had anticipated spending during that period. Congress could _ and should _ demand far larger cuts. The Cold War is over. The Berlin Wall is no more. Eastern Europe has rejected communism. The Warsaw Pact is falling apart. And the Soviet Union itself is undergoing unprecedented internal turmoil. Yet, the Soviet Union remains a nuclear superpower. And, yes, the United States must continue to maintain a strong defense, keeping our guard up against any eventuality. Nonetheless, the current course of events should make it clear that this country can make far deeper spending cuts at the Pentagon than Cheney proposes. Every unnecessary defense dollar that is cut can add to America's economic strength and, as the 1990s unfold, that strength will perhaps mean far more to our national security than more tanks, bombers and nuclear missiles.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: nuclear missiles.
DOC.TEXT: May 4 The Odessa (Texas) American on the United States and the Soviet Union: President Bush has been praised for his caution, but his actions make us wonder why. His administration announced an agreement to grant the Soviet Union Most Favored Nation status, probably to be signed at the summit between Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. This follows Bush's recent refusals to even murmur a single word of protest against the Soviet strangulation of Lithuania. Removing trade restriction between the free individuals of two nations is always to be praised; free trade would advance the freedom movement within the Soviet Union. But granting Most Favored Nation status also entails granting the Soviet loan credits backed by U.S. taxpayers. And Bush's timing, even as famished Lithuanians see their food and fuel supplies choked off, suggests an act of unprincipled groveling. Couldn't he have waited? Or recognized Lithuania's independence as a countermove? Would the summit have been endangered? Perhaps. But America's real strength in the world is not so much its ability to negotiate deals with other powers, but rather its adherence to principles of freedom and decency, which beg for recognition of the Lithuanian people's courage. For now, the more Bush trusts Gorbachev the less Americans will trust Bush.

May 4 The Press-Enterprise, Riverside County, Calif., on the S&L bailout: The S&L bailout will cost more than the bailouts of Lockheed, Chrysler, Penn Central and New York City combined. By conservative estimate. ... Chairman William Seidman of the Resolution Trust Corp., an agency created last August to merge and sell insolvent S&Ls and their assets, ... has displeased President Bush with his candid appraisals that the cost of all this was rising rapidly. The president originally estimated the cost of the project at $166 billion over 10 years. The fact that independent assessments support ... Seidman doesn't seem to matter (the GAO figures it could run up to $500 billion over 30 years). George Bush wants ... Seidman out. ... Seidman has tenure. He is in this job as an extension of his first title, head of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. _ an independent agency. Because the Senate confirmed him, the president can't fire him. He doesn't have to leave until his term is up, in October, 1991. ... If the truth about this bailout nettles George Bush, well, too bad. Keeping top people on the job is the percentage play here. And even a few percent of $500 billion makes it worthwhile.

May 4 The Providence (R.I.) Journal-Bulletin on going metric: By 1993, the European Community is scheduled to have a unified economy, larger than that of the United States, with all product standards based on the metric system. But some U.S. exporters may miss out on this vast market if they don't begin to adapt their products to metric _ the measurement system used by most of the world. Government agencies, as well as companies, have ... been slow to adapt to a world of tens. The comptroller general's office cites a study showing there has been little preparation for complying with a law that agencies use the metric system as much as possible by October 1991. The Commerce Department, which should be leading the way because of its foreign-trade responsibilities, was particularly faulted for not giving more leadership. It may be a great inconvenience for a while, but going metric is one of those chores we will have to perform to compete in the international marketplace, and the sooner the better. People may still usefully employ the historic English system in their private lives, but companies and government agencies should get to work on the transition.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: the transition.
DOC.TEXT: May 9 The Star-Ledger, Newark, N.J., on the deficit: Reading President Bush's lips today is likely to bring forth a different message than in the past, when he was adamantly against new taxes. The president has given assurance that the budget talks under way with Congress will be ``unfettered'' and will have no ``preconditions.'' Even new taxes, once a taboo subject, will be on the agenda. Congressional leaders make similar optimistic murmurs. But no official is predicting that the talks will really make a difference in reducing the nation's enormous deficit _ and such caution is more than warranted. ... There has been little or no progress in reducing the deficit since the huge shortfall that followed passage of the delusive Kemp-Roth tax cut legislation in 1981. There are several reasons for this failure to act by our elected officials other than sheer irresponsibility. For one thing, we have been spared the consequences of our huge deficit because foreigners have been willing to borrow such large amounts in our credit markets. ... The other is that there has been no political retribution wreaked by the electorate on our spendthrifts. ... And so once again, the responsibility remains on the president and Congress to agree on a plan that makes real deficit cuts. Fine words won't do it. There have to be real reductions in spending and, in all probability, tax increases as well.

May 7 The Daily Telegraph, London, on a united Germany: The goal of the series of talks which started in Bonn over the weekend must be not only the transfer of the wartime victors' residual powers to a united Germany but also the opening of the way to that ``common European home'' of which the Russians so often speak. The removal of land-based nuclear missiles from Europe, further cuts in conventional weapons, the strengthening of NATO's political functions, a higher profile for the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, a sympathetic response to the Soveit Union's wish for integration into the world economy _ all these are means of drawing Moscow out of its isolation on the eastern periphery of the continent. The division of Germany into two hostile states was at the core of post-war divisions. Transcending it should move Europe to the threshold of a new unity.
DOC.HEAD: End Editorial Rdp
Grant B. Cooper, Defense Attorney for Sirhan Sirhan, Dies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS next-to-last graf to include full reference to Sen. Robert Kennedy
DOC.TEXT: Grant B. Cooper, an attorney who defended Kennedy assassin Sirhan B. Sirhan, has died at age 87. Cooper died May 3 of an aortic aneurysm at the Hospital of the Good Samaritan in Los Angeles, his wife, Phyllis, said Tuesday. A trial lawyer for more than six decades, Cooper continued practicing law from his home until his death, Mrs. Cooper said. Born in New York, Cooper dropped out of high school and held several odd jobs before coming to California as a hired hand on an oil tanker. He accepted an offer from a lawyer uncle to go into that profession and enrolled at Southwestern University. He graduated in 1926 and passed the State Bar of California the next year. As a prosecutor, Cooper won death penalties in several murder cases. As a criminal defense attorney later in his career he opposed capital punishment, claiming it did not deter murder. Cooper's most notorious clients were Dr. R. Bernard Finch in 1959 and Sirhan a decade later. He obtained two hung juries for Finch, who was accused with his assistant, Carole Tregoff, of killing his wife, Barbara, in a case that attracted national attention. Finch and Tregoff were convicted when another attorney took over the defense in a third trial. Sirhan was convicted of the 1968 California primary election night slaying of Sen. Robert Kennedy at the Ambassador Hotel and remains in prison. In addition to his second wife, Cooper is survived by two daughters from a first marriage and one daughter and two sons from his second marriage.

DOC.HEAD: Record Industry Unveils New Warning Label for Explicit Lyrics
LaserPhoto WX18
DOC.TEXT: The recording industry on Wednesday unveiled a uniform warning label for albums with explicit lyrics and expressed hope that an improved voluntary system will halt campaigns in some states for mandatory labeling. The black-and-white stickers _ reading ``PARENTAL ADVISORY _ EXPLICIT LYRICS'' _ will appear on the lower right-hand corner of the front of albums that might be objectionable because of lyrics dealing with sex, violence, suicide, drug abuse, bigotry or satanic worship. The decision of whether to affix the labels will be left up to the record companies and their individual artists, said Jay Berman, president of the Recording Industry Association of America, whose members produce more than 90 percent of the records sold in the United States. Berman said the warning labels will begin appearing on the outer packaging, under the cellophane wrap, of potentially offensive records, cassettes and compact discs reaching retail music stores in July. The label size will range from 1{ inches by 1 inch for albums and CD long boxes to 1 inch by a half-inch for cassettes and CD cases. ``We believe the uniform logo will enhance the existing voluntary system and better respond to the legitimate concerns ofserve in that post, a U.S. official said Wednesday.
DOC.HEAD: The current, 2nd graf pvs
Deer Harvest to Be Split Equally Between Chippewa, non-Indians
DOC.TEXT: The number of deer to be hunted in northern Wisconsin each year should be equally divided between the Chippewa tribe and non-Indians, a federal judge ruled Wednesday. U.S. District Judge Barbara Crabb said equal division between the state's six Chippewa bands and non-Indian hunters should assure enough deer for both parties. Crabb's ruling came in a lawsuit filed by the Chippewa. Her decision to limit tribal deer hunting to 50 percent of the available resource contrasts sharply with her earlier ruling that the Chippewa should be entitled to 100 percent of the ``safe allowable'' catch of fish in northern Wisconsin. Crabb refused to discuss why her deer decision differed from the one on fish catch. Wisconsin's six Chippewa bands retain the right to spearfish, hunt and cut timber off-reservation on public lands in northern Wisconsin under 19th-century federal treaties. Since a court affirmed those rights in 1983, the Chippewa have exercised their spearfishing rights on northern lakes, encountering huge and sometimes violent protests by outdoorsmen. The opponents argue that the special treaty rights are unfair because they are denied to non-Indians. Since the court ruling affirming the rights, the Chippewa bands have filed a series of lawsuits asking the court to define how much of the resources of northern Wisconsin they are entitled to under the treaties and to what degree the state can regulate tribal activities. Crabb previously ruled the Indians are entitled to 100 percent of the ``safe'' harvest of walleye on northern lakes during spearfishing. Safe refers to the number of fish biologists say can be taken without harming fish populations. She has yet to rule on how much timber the tribe should be allowed to cut.

DOC.HEAD: `60 Minutes' Commentator Says Timidity Led to Suspension
DOC.TEXT: Andy Rooney's suspension from ``60 Minutes'' caused him to be more careful, but he says the entire episode ``was a better example of timidity than it was a violation of my First Amendment rights.'' ``Broadcasters are hardly the only people to blame, of course. The timidity with which the broadcast industry approaches seriously controversial ideas is reflected by society ... or perhaps the broadcast industry's timidity is a reflection of our society,'' the CBS commentator said. In February, CBS News president David Burke suspended Rooney for three months after an article published by the Los Angeles-based gay lifestyle magazine Advocate attributed racist and homophobic quotes to Rooney. Burke eventually shortened Rooney's suspension to three weeks. Burke decided ``between my right to say something and his obligation to keep the peace between CBS and several minorities, he'd better get rid of me,'' Rooney said Monday in a speech to 1,000 people gathered at a Constitutional Rights Foundation dinner. ``It's my personal opinion that my suspension was a better example of timidity than it was a violation of my First Amendment rights,'' he said. Rooney said we have become a nation ``that doesn't say what it thinks about so many things'' and he faulted special interest groups for squelching debate on television and in politics. ``There are organized minorities for almost every cause, and politicians, along with network executives, are scared to death of them,'' he said. ``Self-interest is what draws people to the voting booth. ``Most people have the feeling that what happens in an election won't matter much to them, so they don't vote. It's the people with some personal cause, not those with a general belief in democracy, who do the electing.''

DOC.HEAD: Sailors Abandon Ship During Storm, Are Picked Up By Dutch Cargo Ship
DOC.TEXT: Six Connecticut sailing students on a training trip abandoned ship during a storm and were picked up by a Dutch cargo ship en route to Belgium, the Coast Guard said. And four survivors of a sunken Rhode Island sailing vessel were rescued Wednesday from a raft 150 miles southwest of Bermuda, the Coast Guard said. Carol's Dream, a 42-foot sloop owned by Carol Horne of Ledyard, Conn., was three days out of Bermuda when it ran into a storm Saturday 200 miles east of Cape May, N.J., said Coast Guard Chief Brad Grueling in Boston. The boat's steering cable snapped, and its mast was in danger of falling because of the rough seas, he said. Early Sunday, the crew sent out a distress call that was picked up by Independent Accord, a 495-foot Dutch cargo ship carrying tobacco from Chester, Pa., to Antwerp, Belgium. The cargo ship reached Carol's Dream within an hour, said Edward Shea of Groton, the sloop's co-captain, in a ship-to-shore conversation with the newspaper The Day of New London. The two ships met in 30-foot seas, and Shea had to ram the bigger ship three times to get close enough to transfer the passengers. It took three attempts to get everyone safely off Carol's Dream. One person suffered broken ribs. The Independent Accord is due to arrive in Antwerp next Monday and the six Americans do not know yet how they will get home, Shea said. They have been in contact with the U.S. Embassy in the Netherlands to work out the problem. The trip was part of a sailing class conducted by Coastline Sailing School & Yacht Charters of Noank. The four students ``all said they got their money's worth,'' Shea said. The four survivors of the Rhode Island sailing vessel were picked up by the merchant vessel Baron Trader, Coast Guard officials reported. They did not know if there were others on the 57-foot Misconduct, which hit a submerged object and sank en route to Bermuda. The Baron Trader was expected to arrive at Baton Rouge, La., on May 13. A search for the Misconduct began late Tuesday after the Coast Guard station in Woods Hole, Mass., picked up a report that the boat owned by Paul Harron of Newport, R.I., was sinking. A Navy patrol plane couldn't find it. But a report from another vessel that had been with the Misconduct several days earlier prompted the Coast Guard to send a plane to search south of Bermuda.

DOC.HEAD: Hate Crime Victims Describe their Anguish
DOC.TEXT: Hate crime victims, some speaking through sobs and some with unvarnished anger, described at a hearing Wednesday the murders, stabbings, beatings and firebombings that have ravaged their lives. ``My brother Jimmy was a kind, loving, caring person,'' said Peggy Marlow. But because James Zappalorti was homosexual, she said, two men stabbed him, slit his throat and threw him into the water off his Staten Island home. ``They slaughtered him,'' Ms. Marlow said. ``All because he was gay.'' Others told of equally senseless attacks: A man who was called a ``faggot'' and viciously beaten, a black man whose home in a mainly white neighborhood was firebombed, a rabbi whose synagogue was daubed with pro-Nazi graffiti. ``I don't understand the hatred,'' said a woman, whose name was withheld. She suffered cornea damage when the leader of a gang of black youths jabbed her eye with a pin last year. Wilfred Phillips said he was ``so disappointed with the people'' of the neighborhood when saw his firebombed home in February. ``I'm not accusing nobody, any one person. But I think it's a big disgrace,'' he said. The hearing, called by City Council President Andrew Stein, comes at a time of a dispute between black residents and Korean grocers in Brooklyn, and jury deliberations are under way in last summer's slaying of a black youth by a white gang. The number of hate crimes reported to police has more than doubled since 1984, Stein said. And Inspector Paul M. Sanderson, head of the bias squad, said two-thirds of the crimes have gone unsolved. ``They are random, isolated and spontaneous,'' making arrests difficult, Sanderson said. Still, he noted that in 2,900 cases the squad has investigated since 1980, there have been 1,300 arrests. The problem is largely one of youth, Sanderson said: In 70 percent of the cases the perpetrators are younger than 19, and in 40 percent they are minors. The group that attacked Bruce Ellerin was made up of teen-agers. One called him a ``faggot,'' he recalled. Words were exchanged and they beat him so badly he suffered a broken cheekbone and a detached retina. What worsened the ordeal, Ellerin said, was the police insensitivity and indifference that followed. ``As soon as they heard the word `faggot' they made up their minds that this was not the most serious of incidents,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: 12-Year-Old Casts Deciding Vote in Florida House
DOC.TEXT: The 12-year-old son of a state representative unintentionally cast a vote that killed a House bill. Brian Langton, son of Rep. Mike Langton, was sitting at his father's desk last week while the Jacksonville Democrat left the chamber to make a phone call. A vote came up on a bill that would create a statewide register to document the number of children waiting for assistance from the Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services. During his weeklong stint as a House page, Brian had seen his father's green ``yes'' button light up many times. He decided to see what the red ``no'' button looked like. He didn't expect to kill an important piece of legislation. ``Once he did it, he suddenly had all these legislators hulking over him saying, `Did your dad tell you to do that?''' Langton said. ``When I came back, the poor kid was frightened to death.'' House members were scheduled to reconsider the bill Tuesday, but the vote was postponed. Langton said he would have voted for the bill had he been there. But Brian's ``no'' tied the vote at 53-53, effectively killing the proposal. Langton said he gave his son ``a stern talking to,'' but that Brian was embarrassed and felt bad enough without needing more punishment.

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Official Says Higher Gas Tax Could Go to General Spending
DOC.TEXT: The budget adviser to Congress said Wednesday the federal gasoline tax may be used for purposes other than building highways and bridges. ``There is no fundamental economic or governmental reason for earmarking tax revenues for specific purposes,'' W. David Montgomery of the Congressional Budget Office told a Senate transportation subcommittee. Montgomery also said the activities of the Highway Trust Fund should not be split off from the rest of the budget. ``Taking the fund off-budget would make the budget a less precise indicator of fiscal policy,'' he said. ``Finally, the existence of the fund and the presence of cash balances can lead to pressures for spending that impede deficit reduction and distort budget priorities.'' The Bush administration has also testified through the Transportation Department that the activities of the multi-billion dollar fund should not be set apart from the rest of the budget. Montgomery's testimony to the Senate Environment and Public Works subcommittee on water resources, transportation and infrastructure came in the second day of hearings on the use of the government's highway and aviation funds. A House Public Works and Transportation subcommittee heard testimony Tuesday. The two transportation funds are financed through fuel and ticket taxes and other user fees. The proceeds are supposed to be spent on highways, bridges, and air traffic improvements. A small share goes to mass transportation. The funds have accumulated a $25 billion cash balance over the years, but the real surplus is in dispute because large sums of the highway portion are committed to future spending by states. A custody battle has developed over those funds between the states, construction industry, rural lawmakers and congressional public works committees on one side, and the tax- and budget-writing committees of Congress and urban lawmakers on the other. Money that goes out of the funds to repair crumbling bridges and highways raises the overall deficit unless revenues increase correspondingly. Wednesday's hearing was prompted by legislation by Sen. Richard Bryan, D-Nev., that would force the government to release $9 billion in supposedly unspent trust fund dollars over the next three years. In the House, Rep. Bob McEwen, R-Ohio, has introduced legislation that would take the highway fund off budget. The hearing Wednesday came against the backdrop of budget discussions between congressional leaders and the White House. An increased fuel tax, advocated by House Ways and Means Chairman Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., could emerge. Currently, each 11 gallons of gasoline purchased produces $1 in federal tax revenue. Each 10-gallon purchase of diesel fuel other than for passenger cars provides $1.50. Sen. John H. Chafee, R-R.I., said any increase in the gasoline tax ``should not be earmarked.'' ``I think this committee had better be thinking how those revenues will be used,'' said Sen. Daniel P. Moynihan, D-N.Y., subcommittee chairman. The CBO's Montgomery said there was another impact of higher fuel taxes: fighting pollution. ``Raising fuel taxes is a way of charging users for polluting the air,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Cyclone Batters South India Coast, Kills at Least 11
DOC.TEXT: A cyclone battered the southern India coast Wednesday with wind up to 155 mph, killing at least 11 people and cutting off thousands of others from the rest of the country. The center of the storm struck the Indian mainland from the Bay of Bengal at 6:30 p.m., 160 miles north of the city of Madras, United News of India reported. Strong wind and towering 33-foot waves lashed the low-lying, heavily populated coastline of Andhra Pradesh state, knocking down hundreds of thatched huts, uprooting trees and downing power lines. Naval boats were battling rough seas in an effort to reach more than 6,000 people in the coastal town of Yedurumudi who were cut off by the storm from the rest of the country, rescue officials said. Rescue workers evacuated more than 150,000 people during the day from coastal districts in Andhra Pradesh and Tamil Nadu states before the storm struck, which kept the death toll down, said Arjuna Rao, a top relief official in Andhra Pradesh's capital, Hyderabad. He was reached by telephone from Madras. Indian news reports said the cyclone appeared to be stronger than a 1977 storm that killed more than 10,000 people in southern India, but few people were evacuated then. Andhra Pradesh's chief minister, Channa Reddy, said telecommunications, power and transportation had ``completely broken down'' in nine coastal towns. ``There is heavy devastation to property,'' he said, speaking to reporters in Hyderabad. High wind knocked out telephone service and power in much of the coastal area and the state government was relying on ham radio operators to convey information. Army and navy helicopters and boats assisted in the rescue and relief operations. The bulk of the damage was concentrated on a small peninsula jutting out into the Bay of Bengal, where the center of the storm hit. Six of the dead were killed when a wall collapsed in the East Godivari district on the peninsula, United News said. Three others were electrocuted when wind knocked down live electrical wires. Another person died in a building collapse, and a 60-year-old laborer died from exposure, the report said. In Madras, capital of neighboring Tamil Nadu state, electrical wires knocked down by rain and wind preceding the storm killed three people Tuesday. An Indian cargo ship carrying 60 passengers was initially trapped in the storm, but escaped harm, Indian media reported. The government barred fishermen and sailors from putting out to sea as the storm headed toward land. Cyclones are the Indian Ocean's equivalent of hurricanes. They usually come in the spring just before the monsoon season begins.

DOC.HEAD: American Released By Liberian Rebels
DOC.TEXT: Liberian rebels have freed an American Peace Corps worker and two Western relief officials who were kidnapped along the Liberian-Guinean border last week, a French volunteer agency said Wednesday. The agency, Doctors without Borders, said the three were released unharmed. It said the hostages were forced to march for seven hours to the rebels' main camp where they were questioned and held captive for eight days. The three _ David Kelley of Illinois, Werner Will of West Germany, and Ludov Pichrist of Belgium _ were released Tuesday night, according to the Belgian chapter of Doctors without Borders, a medical aid group. The captives were turned over to Ivory Coast officials and taken to the Doctors without Borders office in Danane, Ivory Coast, the statement said. Kelley, Will, Pichrist and a Guinean relief worker were kidnapped on May 1 along the Liberian-Guinean border as they inspected refugee facilities. The kidnappers later released the Guinean, but held the other three. Doctors without Borders said the kidnappers accused the volunteers of being on ``the territory of Liberian rebels.'' The three Westerners were checking water sanitation at border villages where more than 100,000 people have sought refuge from fighting between the rebels and troops loyal to President Samuel K. Doe of Liberia. The French and Belgian chapters of Doctors Without Borders had sent 16 people to the region to vaccinate refugees and assure the quality of their water supplies to prevent epidemics. The rebels have previously captured other Westerners and held them for several days before releasing them. Fighting between the rebels and Liberian troops broke out Dec. 24, and hundreds of rebels and scores of soldiers have been reported killed. The State Department said last week that 380 American officials and their dependents had left Liberia as rebel forces moved within striking distance of the capital, Monrovia.

DOC.HEAD: Bensonhurst Juries Deliberate
DOC.TEXT: Several hours into their first full day of deliberations, jurors deciding the fate of Bensonhurst murder defendant Keith Mondello asked Wednesday to review Mondello's signed statement about his admitted involvement in the shooting of Yusuf Hawkins. The jury also asked the trial judge, Justice Thaddeus Owens of state Supreme Court in brooklyn, to again explain the elements of the four homicide charges against Mondello. Mondello is on trial on two counts of second-degree murder, first- and second-degree manslaughter and several lesser charges. In the three-page statement taken by the police and signed by Mondello on the day after the shooting, he admits organizing the mob, knowing that at least one person had a gun and carrying a baseball bat when Hawkins was shot. Defense lawyer Stephen Murphy said the police tricked his client into putting his name on the statement. A second jury for the accused shooter, Joseph Fama, began its second full day of deliberations listening to lengthy readbacks of the testimony of two prosecution witnesses, Gina Feliciano and Cindy Hamburger. The panel wanted to hear again what the two young women said Fama was wearing and where he was about the time of the Aug. 23 shooting. The two defendants, both white 19-year-olds, would face 25 years to life in jail if convicted of murdering the black teen-ager. Moses Stewart, the father of the slain teen, has asked the black community to react with restraint if the two are acquitted. Stewart said Tuesday he personally would be disappointed with anything short of two murder convictions. The Mondello case went to the jury late Tuesday while the Fama panel began its deliberations Monday evening. Testimony lasted nearly three weeks.

DOC.HEAD: NEA Says Federal Education Spending $12 Billion Short
DOC.TEXT: The nation's largest teachers union said Wednesday that the federal government needs to raise education spending by $12 billion to fully fund key programs. In releasing the National Education Association's annual report on federal education expenditures, the union's president, Keith Geiger, said he was ``tempted to characterize our national commitment to education as killing our children with kindness. ``We have plenty of kind words for education in our new kinder and gentler America, but little action to back up these words.'' The report tracked the decline in the share of the federal budget going to education since 1980. That year, 2.5 percent of the budget went to education. This year, only 1.7 percent of federal expenditures will go to education, the report said. Geiger urged President Bush and the Congress to ``rethink the budget priorities of the United States _ and to make education a top priority in action as well as in rhetoric.'' Three specific areas lacking in federal support are handicapped, bilingual and higher education, the report said. When the Handicapped Education Act was passed in 1975, the government promised to provide 40 percent of the excess costs for educating disabled students. The report said the amount would be $3,520 of the current $8,800 for each child. Yet the federal contribution, the NEA said, is $352. Bilingual education programs reach only 5.6 percent of those identified in the 1980s, the report said. As for student aid, the NEA said 80 percent of high-ability but low-income high school graduates went on to college in 1980. Today that figure has dropped below 70 percent. Part of the reason for the drop is that the maximum federal student aid package now pays less than 40 percent of college costs, compared with as much as 80 percent of the costs in 1980. The report also said that Head Start programs for low-income families will serve about 450,000 3-, 4-, and 5-year-olds in 1990-91, less than 20 percent of the 2.5 million eligible children. Chapter One reading and math programs for disadvantaged students will serve about 5.3 million children in 1990-91 _ half of the elementary and secondary students living in poverty.

DOC.HEAD: Biden Says NATO's Nuclear Weapons Strategy ``Obselete''
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of a Senate Foreign Relations panel said Wednesday that nuclear weapons are useless as part of a NATO strategy because of the collapse of the Warsaw Pact and expected cuts in U.S.-Soviet forces. Sen. Joseph Biden, D-Del., told a top Defense Department official that the mid-summer review by the 16-nation alliance of NATO strategy should begin with the theory of defending Western Europe with only conventional forces. ``I believe the military mission nuclear weapons previously served in NATO strategy has become obsolete,'' Biden said. There has been a growing belief among NATO diplomats that the West could safely reduce, if not eliminate entirely, its arsenal of land-based tactical missiles and artillery in Europe. Germany's Gerhard Stoltenberg, arriving in Canada Monday for a meeting of NATO defense ministers, said it was possible that all land-based nuclear systems in Europe would be withdrawn. ``Of course the requirement is the readiness of the Soviet Union to withdraw their own systems,'' Stoltenberg told reporters. Biden, chairman of the Foreign Relations subcommittee on European affairs, said he feared that U.S. steps that fail to reflect the general feeling in Western Europe would force the United States out. ``We must lead in order to remain,'' Biden said. ``What I'm planning for is the worst-case scenario ... because of our actions or inactions we lose the support of Western Europe publics for what you and I both believe is sorely needed for our peace, security and prosperity.'' Paul Wolfowitz, undersecretary of defense for policy, said the Bush administration has shown a willingness to change. President Bush announced last week that his administration had abandoned plans to build a more powerful short-range nuclear missile and modernize its 155mm nuclear-tipped artillery shell. But the president stopped short of proposing elimination of the nuclear arsenal, saying the ``United States is not going to allow Europe to become `safe for conventional war.''' Wolfowitz said the expected withdrawal of Soviet forces from Eastern Europe could result in a reduction in the nuclear arsenal. ``But our theater nuclear forces will remain critically important for deterring all forms of aggression, conventional as well as nuclear,'' the undersecretary said. Elsewhere on Capitol Hill, two House members issued a draft report that contends the United States has focused on the Soviet threat for 40 years at the expense of preparing for a low-intensity conflict or mid-intensity battle. ``The armed forces of the United States are ill-prepared for the realities of conventional combat that are likely to confront them over the next 12 years,'' Reps. Dave McCurdy, D-Okla., and John Rowland, R-Conn., said in a statement. The Center for Strategic and International Studies prepared the report that urges the Defense Department to reexamine its current strategy.

DOC.HEAD: NATO Defense Ministers Open Talks on Nuclear Strategy
DOC.TEXT: NATO defense ministers Wednesday opened their first nuclear strategy session since upheavals in Eastern Europe caused the unraveling of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. The officials of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization gathered for two days of talks in the rugged Kananaskis region of the Canadian Rocky Mountains, site of the 1988 winter Olympic Games. The ministers are under pressure to redo their nuclear policy in response to greatly reduced East-West tensions. West German officials said Defense Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg intended to press his counterparts to withdraw quickly all of NATO's nuclear artillery shells, most of which are deployed in West Germany. Stoltenberg told reporters earlier this week that it was possible for all land-based nuclear systems to be removed from Europe. But he linked the withdrawals to a Soviet willingness to do the same. ``It cannot be unilateral,'' he said. ``It must be on both sides.'' Any push for a quick, one-sided pullout of nuclear weapons from Europe would likely be opposed by both the United States and Britain. British officials said they do not favor the so-called ``third zero,'' military jargon for the elimination of land-based, short-range nuclear missiles in Europe. Discussions about scaling back the West's arsenal of battlefield nuclear weapons were given fresh impetus last week by President Bush. He announced the cancellation of plans to build a more powerful version of the Lance short-range missile and a modernized 155mm nuclear-tipped artillery shell. Tactical weapons, most deployed in West Germany, can only hit targets in the now friendly countries of Eastern Europe. As NATO reduces its land-based forces, analysts expect it to put more emphasis on air-launched nuclear systems. The United States is developing a tactical air-to-surface missile, known as the TASM, which would replace gravity bombs. American and British officials, though, seem intent on avoiding any debate on deployment of the new, longer-range missile. There is ``a certain feeling not to have the meeting dominated by TASM,'' said an official, who demanded anonymity. West Germany is thought to be reluctant to get into any discussions about stationing the TASM missile on aircraft on its soil. The Bonn government, holding sensitive negotiations on its merger with East Germany, is mindful of Soviet security concerns. The West contends it needs nuclear weapons to offset the Warsaw Pact's overwhelming superiority in tanks and other conventional arms. The United States and the Soviet Union are expected to enter into negotiations, possibly early next year, on cutting short-range systems. A Dutch newspaper, Het Parool, reported Wednesday that the United States plans to site 389 new TASM missiles in seven European NATO nations starting in 1995 if the alliance approves the program. The plan provides for TASM sites in West Germany, Britain, Italy, Turkey, the Netherlands, Belgium and Greece. The newspaper did not say how it had obtained the information. At a summit last May, Bush and other alliance leaders agreed that bargaining on the tactical weapons could not occur until implementation of an accord reducing tanks, artillery, troops and other conventional arms in Europe. But Bush announced last week an acceleration of the timetable, saying bargaining could start once agreement was reached. Negotiators of NATO and the Warsaw Pact are pressing for a deal by fall. The meeting of the Nuclear Planning Group is one of a series of high-level NATO talks this month and next on the alliance's future and its need for nuclear and conventional forces. The discussions will wind up with a summer summit of Bush and other alliance leaders. All 16 NATO nations, except France, attend the nuclear meetings, held twice a year. France is a NATO member but does not belong to the alliance's integrated military structure. Iceland, which has no armed forces, has observer status.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Urge Administration to Forgive East European Debts
DOC.TEXT: Members of Congress urged the Bush administration Wednesday to drop its opposition to forgiving debts owed by Poland and other Eastern European countries. The United States and other Western nations should write off at least a portion of the debt to help the ailing economies of countries emerging from four decades of communist rule, lawmakers said. Reps. John LaFalce, D-N.Y., and Jim Leach, R-Iowa, are sponsoring bills that would provide for some type of reduction of debt, including proposals to exchange the debt for projects in the countries that would protect the global environment. Treasury Undersecretary David Mulford, appearing before a Banking subcommitee chaired by LaFalce, said the administration was unwilling to forgive the $3 billion Polish debt, in part because of the precedent it would set for the $63 billion in foreign debt held by the United States. LaFalce told Mulford that the dramatic changes in Eastern Europe had to be supported economically by the United States. Leach warned that a ``certain degree of chaos'' could result if the United States didn't take the lead in fostering the movement to free-market economies. Similar warnings came from Polish Finance Minister Leszek Balcerowicz, who called on commercial banks and governments holding Poland's $41 billion in debt to make concessions that would slash Poland's debt payments by 80 percent. ``We have to show the Polish people that further sacrifices will bear fruit,'' he told reporters at a briefing Tuesday. ``This is why we have been requesting very substantial debt reduction.'' Mulford said foreign governments already had granted Poland a moratorium that suspended payments on most of its official debt until March 1991, allowing the country to get its new economic program under way. Foreign governments hold about 80 percent of Poland's debt, with the other 20 percent owed to commercial banks. ``The issue is important, but how to approach it country by country is extremely complicated,'' Mulford said of the call for debt forgiveness. ``It is just not practical at this moment.'' Mulford did say the United States had been lobbying commercial banks to reach an agreement to reduce Poland's commercial bank debt, using the guidelines established last year under Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady's debt-reduction plan for Third World countries. Horst Schulman, managing director of the Institute of International Finance, a bank lobbying group, said commercial banks were looking for official agencies, such as the new European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, to play a greater role in supporting Eastern Europe. ``Further (commercial) bank lending at this point will have to be based on confidence that the reform process will be successful and that countries will again become credit worthy,'' he told the subcommittee. Mulford said the new European bank is expected to have an American as its No. 2 official, reflecting the fact that the United States will have 10 percent voting power in the organization, the largest of any single country. Published reports have said that London will be the site for the new bank, and Jacques Attali, an adviser to French President Francois Mitterrand, will head it. Mulford said those decisions will be made at a May 19 meeting. Mulford told members of Congress that the United States will have a commitment of $1.2 billion, but only $350 million will have to be paid into the bank. The rest will be available if needed, Mulford said. The Soviet Union will be a member of the new bank, raising questions in Congress over whether U.S. tax dollars would go to support the Soviet economy. Mulford said restrictions written into the bank's charter at the insistence of the United States will limit the Soviet Union's borrowing authority for the first three years to the amount it contributes to the institution.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmits a0653 to fix cycle designation and edits throughout to CLARIFY that Jews do NOT fall under dealer's restrictions
DOC.HEAD: Auto Dealer's Pitch: Jesus Saves
DOC.TEXT: Looking for a good deal on a new car? Freddye ``Action'' Jackson is ready to give you a discount on a Lincoln or Mercury _ as long as you can prove you're Christian or Jewish. Under Jackson's Christian Members Buyers Plan, Brown Lincoln-Mercury in Fairfax City offers cars at a discount to practicing Christians. Jews qualify, Jackson said, but Moslems, Hindus, Sikhs and most other non-Christians would not. ``We're a Christian dealership. We sell the Christians cars at just a little above invoice,'' said Jackson. Under the program, Jackson sells Lincolns for $600 over cost and Mercurys at $250 over cost to those who qualify. Jackson said pastors can buy Lincolns at $400 over what he pays the factory, and Mercurys at $150 over cost. The dealership also will donate $100 for a Lincoln and $50 for a Mercury to the church of the qualifying customer's choice, Jackson said. ``Realizing that the church is the most vital unit and organizaton in society today, it is important that we as Christians continue to work for the Lord and support the uplifting of his kingdom,'' Jackson wrote area churches. The plan has upset attorney Victor Glasberg, who says the discounts may violate the federal Equal Credit Opportunity Act, which forbids religious discrimination in credit transactions. ``It is not clear to me that one of the benefits which Jesus had in mind for those who accepted him as a savior was to provide them with discounted Lincoln or Mercury automobiles,'' Glasberg said in a letter to the dealership. State and local officials said Jackson's buying program does not appear to violate civil rights laws. The laws apply to housing, employment and places of public accommodation, such as restaurants and movie theaters, but not to car dealerships, said Bert Rohrer, a spokesman for Virginia Attorney General Mary Sue Terry. Jackson compared the program to the United Buyers Service, which offers deals to employees of certain companies, and United States Automobile Association, which is open to military families. A spokesman for Lincoln-Mercury, a division of Ford Motor Co. in Detroit, said the company is aware of the program. ``Ford Motor Co. would not structure a program in this manner, but Freddye Jackson is an independent businessman,'' spokesman John Spelich said. ``Quite frankly, we don't address this in our sales agreements with our dealers.'' Jackson won't discuss his profits or say how many customers have used the program he created shortly after taking over the dealership in July 1989. He says Ford pegged the dealership among the lowest-ranked Lincoln-Mercury dealers for customer service in the Washington area, but since he took over and it became a ``Christian dealership,'' it has risen to third place. Sales people are not allowed to smoke, drink or use profanity in the showroom and are encouraged to attend church, Jackson said. ``Christ being here made the difference,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Brazil's President Wants to Fire 400,000 Federal Employees
DOC.TEXT: President Fernando Collor de Mello said Wednesday he wants to fire up to 400,000 public employees to speed his drastic economic reform program. ``We're about to complete two months in office. In a short amount of time we've done a lot, but now we need to do more, and faster,'' Collor, 40, said during a morning meeting with his Cabinet ministers. He also said he wanted to move more quickly on his program to privatize state companies and slash federal spending to wipe out a $31 billion deficit. Collor announced a package of austerity measures on March 16, his first full day in office as the country's first freely elected president in 29 years. They included closing 23 federal companies, foundations and institutes, and an 18-month freeze on $115 billion in individual and corporate bank accounts. But Collor said Wednesday there was still much to be done to spur growth in the economy, the largest in Latin America. The president, who estimated 1.6 million people work for the government or for government-controlled firms, ordered his ministers to reduce personnel by 20 percent to 25 percent. The cuts would be made by firings, and by placing excess workers on what is called ``in availability,'' a Brazilian legal term that means that civil servants stay at home and draw only partial salaries. The premise is that eventually they will become disgusted and quit. But Collor did not give a deadline for the layoffs or explain how he would skirt a constitutional clause that prevents the firing of any federal employee who has been on the job more than five years. He also said public employee salaries should be ``adequate for the reality of the national economy, with special attention paid to intermediate and upper-level pay.'' This was interpreted as a sign that salaries will be reduced. In assessing the initial results of his austerity program, the president said ``available indicaors show inflation near zero, with the real value of salaries increased.'' Before his reforms were put into effect, inflation was racing along at a rate of 84 percent per month and totaled 4,854 percent the past 12 months. Collor said the long-term success of the plan depended on reducing Brazil's large state sector. His critics have complained his measures, especially the bank freeze, had a severe impact on the private sector. Meanwhile, they say, he has barely acted on his promise to reduce the size of the federal government by cutting spending, privatizing firms and firing public workers. Collor's announcement that he intended to fire 320,000 to 400,000 government employees was seen partly as a response to the critics. The economic slowdown caused by Collor's measures has led to the firing of an estimated 300,000 people in the private sector. Economist Julian Chacel of the prestigious Getulio Vargas Foundation said recently that firing public employees ``would be like lighting a match in a gunpowder depot.'' But on Wednesday he repeated his promise to privatize many of Brazil's 188 state-run companies, many of which lose money and together have a debt of $62 billion. Many also serve as job havens for friends and relatives of politicians and appointees. Brazil's Congress has authorized the privatization of almost all state companies, with the exception of the oil monopoly Petrobras, the postal service, the telecommunication giant Embratel and some banks. Foreign capital will be allowed to buy 49 percent of capital shares in the privatized firms but hold only 33 percent of voting shares.

DOC.HEAD: Aspin Doubts Cheney's Assessment of Soviet Military Intentions
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the House Armed Services Committee said Wednesday he doubts that the Soviet Union, faced with a faltering economy, can upgrade its strategic weapons, as Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has predicted. ``Bad news for the Soviet economy is good news for American security,'' said Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., as he called for delaying the Pentagon's plans to move full speed ahead in modernizing U.S. strategic weapons. Cheney acknowledges the major changes in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, but contends that Moscow is upgrading its strategic forces at a rate that has not been affected by the rapid developments overseas. The Pentagon chief, responding to budgetary pressures, has revised the Pentagon's plans for buying the B-2 stealth bomber and other sophisticated aircraft. Cheney has said, however, that this is not the time to abandon U.S. development of strategic weapons. In a speech to the Overseas Education Fund, Aspin said Cheney is the most pessimistic of President Bush's advisers on the issue of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's chances for survival. Aspin noted the public dispute between Cheney, who believes a Soviet hard liner opposed to U.S. overtures could succeed Gorbachev, and CIA Director William Webster, who has told Congress that the real threat to the Soviet president is from reformers.
