The Wisconsin Democrat said the Central Intelligence Agency's report on the Soviet economy said its performance in 1989 was abysmal. Soviet economists said the CIA was too optimistic. ``I listen to what the intelligence services say about the state of the Soviet economy and don't see how Moscow can spend the billions of rubles on defense that Cheney says they will,'' Aspin said. In addition, Soviet engineers, scientists and other technical people are in short supply, Aspin said. ``I think it is possible we will see cutbacks in areas _ such as air defenses, aircraft carriers and even strategic forces _ that will be significant and add another element of irreversibility to the declining Soviet threat,'' Aspin said.

DOC.HEAD: Military Charges Filed Against Bisexual Colonel
DOC.TEXT: An Army colonel who dressed as a drag queen to perform at a gay bar has been charged with conduct unbecoming an officer. Three other officers face similar charges for homosexual activities. Col. Edward L. Modesto, 42, a dental surgeon at Fort Carson, was accused of engaging in homosexual acts and indecent exposure for dressing in a wig and women's clothes and exposing himself to customers at a laundromat. A hearing will be held May 31 to determine if Modesto should be court-martialed, said Fort Carson spokesman Mike Howard. Modesto, a self-professed bisexual, denied the indecency charges Tuesday. ``I think they're trying to make an example of me and I don't know why. I know that I'm an excellent oral surgeon. My military career is excellent,'' Modesto said. Court documents filed last month show that Modesto performed as ``Carmen'' at benefit shows at the Hide N' Seek Club in Colorado Springs, where he dressed in wigs and sequined gowns and lip-synched Bette Midler songs. But Modesto said that he performed as part of a benefit for AIDS patients and that he felt it was not unbecoming behavior. Homosexual acts are prohibited by military regulations, and some groups are working to get that regulation changed. ``We feel that the regulation common to all of the services that homosexuality is incompatible with military service is inane and without a rational foundation,'' said Charles Bumer, attorney with the Military Law Task Force of the National Lawyers Guild. ``This is plain, old-fashioned homophobia and in our society should not be tolerated,'' said task force co-chairwoman Kathy Gilberd. ``Thousands of lesbians and gays serve honorably in the military with considerable bravery.'' The Modesto investigation began in March, after another officer was arrested for homosexual activity and identified other homosexuals at Fort Carson, including Modesto. Three other soldiers have been charged and others are being investigated, Howard said. Modesto said investigators took the informant to gay bars in Colorado Springs. They used him to point out other military officers, with whom the investigators would strike up a conversation, he said. ``I feel it's a type of entrapment, to try to engage you in a conversation just to find out if you are gay,'' he said. ``I feel that's wrong. ``I don't think it was done for any other reason except to humiliate me,'' he said. Modesto has been removed from patient care but still is working at the army hospital, Howard said. If convicted of all charges, Modesto could face 74 years in prison, fines, dishonorable discharge and lose pay and benefits. After nearly 18 years in the military, Modesto was just over two years from retirement when he was arrested. ``There's a big inequity here. Most of the (gay) enlisted people are being allowed to resign,'' he said. He added that all he wants now is a discharge ``because that would allow me to continue my profession and go on with my life.''

DOC.HEAD: Hungarian Party Asks for Nation's Removal from Warsaw Pact
DOC.TEXT: In an effort to loosen ties to the East bloc, Hungary's second-largest political party on Wednesday asked the government to declare its intention to leave the Warsaw Pact and become a militarily neutral nation. The League of Free Democrats, in making its proposal to Parliament, cited a 1956 government statement that annulled Hungary's membership in the Soviet-led bloc. The statement prompted a Soviet invasion that crushed the rebellion. Deputy Parliament Speaker Matyas Szueroes said the proposal would be discussed at the lawmaking body's next session. Until now, Hungary's leadership has pledged that it would remain in the Soviet-led alliance, although individual leaders have repeatedly suggested the country could one day become neutral. The Free Democrats' proposal said Hungary should make clear that it does not wish to belong to either the Warsaw Pact or the Western military alliance NATO. The party, which won the second-largest number of seats in Parliament in April elections, proposed the new declaration on the basis of the 1956 statement. The proposal was presented by Miklos Vasarhelyi, an associate of Imre Nagy, the leader of the 1956 uprising. Vasarhelyi, who was imprisoned following the uprising, helped draft the declaration. Three days after Hungary declared its withdrawal from the alliance, Soviet troops and tanks rolled into Budapest to crush the revolt. Nagy was executed following a show trial. Kremlin troops have remained in Hungary since then. Now, with the country's transition to democracy, Hungary has negotiated the complete withdrawal of Soviet troops from her territory by the middle of next year. The new Parliament would like to see the accord, negotiated by the outgoing Socialist government, re-negotiated to speed the pullout. A special subcommittee of the foreign relations committee in Parliament is to deal specifically with this issue. Vasarhelyi made clear the proposal does not call for Hungary's immediate withdrawal from the Warsaw Pact but opens negotiations on the topic with Moscow. He said if the proposal is adopted, however, Hungary should suspend all activity in the East bloc alliance and forbid Warsaw Pact exercises on Hungarian soil. The new Parliament is no longer dominated by Communists or their successors, the Socialists. In free balloting in March and April, the Socialist Party gained only 33 of the 394 parliamentary seats. Jozsef Antall, the leader of the center-right Hungarian Democratic Forum, which has the most seats in Parliament, is trying to form a new government with the like-minded Independent Smallholders and the Christian Democrats. Antall told Parliament he expected to present his new government and its program May 22. The Free Democrats campaigned on a platform of swift transfer to a free market economy, while the Hungarian Democratic Forum emphasized the need to avoid social disruption and generally emphasizes conservative, traditional values.

DOC.HEAD: Banker Testifies About Khashoggi's Ownership Claim of Building
DOC.TEXT: Billionaire Adnan Khashoggi claimed ownership of a Wall Street building, allegedly bought by Ferdinand and Imelda Marcos, several months after a court order froze the Marcoses' assets, a banker said Wednesday. John Sanderson, a Citibank vice president, testified that the representation was made by a Khashoggi associate during a discussion in the summer of 1986 about a $39 million Citibank loan that had been secured by the building. Sanderson's testimony addressed the prosecution's allegations that Khashoggi assumed ownership of four New York buildings held by the Marcoses after a March 1986 injunction prohibited any transfer of their properties. Khashoggi, a Saudi financier who is charged with mail fraud and obstruction of justice, is on trial in federal court with Mrs. Marcos. She is accused of helping her husband, the late Philippines president, loot their nation's treasury of more than $220 million, using the money to support lavish living and to secretly buy the four buildings. Mrs. Marcos, 60, also is charged with defrauding banks of more than $165 million in loans, including the Citibank loan, to finance the real estate. She has pleaded innocent to charges of racketeering, racketeering conspiracy, mail fraud and obstruction of justice. Sanderson said his initial dealings concerning the loan were with Gliceria Tantoco, a close friend of Mrs. Marcos. Mrs. Tantoco, owner of a department store in Manila, also was charged in the indictment but is a fugitive. Sanderson testified that he had at least two meetings with Mrs. Tantoco in 1984 and 1985 about problems with the Wall Street building's management. In July 1986, he learned that the management company was $2 million behind in city real estate taxes and became concerned because any city claim would come before Citibank's, Sanderson said. A short time later, he got a call from a Karl Peterson, who told him he was working for Khashoggi and said Khashoggi was the building's owner. Sanderson said the loan agreement had prohibited any transfer of the property without the bank's written consent. The bank started foreclosure on the loan in the fall of 1986 because a substantial amount of interest and real estate taxes were not paid and required rehabilitation of the building was not undertaken, Sanderson said. He left the account in the summer of 1988, but said he believed Citibank did win a judgment and recover its money. Mrs. Marcos, who fell ill Tuesday with high blood pressure for a second time, returned to court Wednesday wearing a monitor. ``She's feeling better today,'' her attorney, Gerry Spence, said after the morning testimony.

DOC.HEAD: Radical Students Often Children of South Korea's Elite
With AM-Korea, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: At the height of violence that rocked South Korea's capital Wednesday, a young woman with a ponytail ducked into a doorway with a makeshift medical bag to aid a student bleeding from the head. The thunder of volleys of police tear gas shells shook the ground. Clouds of acrid gas billowed along the street in front of her like great balls of fog. Nearby students gagged or vomited. The girl carefully wrapped the young man's head with bandages and gave him a hug. Moments before, the young man had been hurling firebombs at a U.S. diplomatic building and yelling ``Yankee go home!'' His friends later forced riot policemen to kneel, and then they beat them. The two, both radical students, are among the elite of South Korea's young, those able to gain admittance to universities. They are the pride of a country that equates education with prosperity. Yet they are a deep embarrassment in a society that values harmony. Most of the radical students claim they are serving their country. The country's government says most of them are naive leftists who have been brainwashed by Communist North Korean teachings. Some of them, the government has said, may be Communist agents. Who are these students and what do they want? Radicals wear American jeans and sneakers, carry their books in a backpack and look like college students everywhere. They go to some of the best schools in South Korea. Radical students number only about 5 percent of the roughly 1 million students in college. Other students listen to their rallies, read their newspapers or may agree with some of their views, but they do not usually participate. Radicals are demanding more democratic reforms from a government they claim has been too slow to do so. They view the January merger of the governing party with two opposition parties as a political coup intended to prolong a hold on power without an election. ``Down with (President) Roh Tae-woo!'' they shout. Many feel an overthrow of the government could solve the country's problems but offer few details on how a new leader could do better. Radicals claim Washington makes decisions for a Seoul puppet government. They demand the withdrawal of 43,000 U.S. troops based in South Korea because they say their presence hinders unification talks with North Korea. None of them are old enough to remember the bloody 1950-53 Korean War, launched by North Korea, the war in which 5 million Americans served. Some of them say they have never talked to an American. At protests, women collect rocks, wave banners, tend to injuries and sing support songs. Men deployed in platoon fashion hurl firebombs and rocks. The radical student movement lost momentum after Roh took office in February 1988 promising broad democratic reforms. The smaller numbers forced radicals to become more violent to be noticed. Some began to use homemade explosives. The government privately worries the violent protests could breed discontent among older South Koreans, especially laborers who often feel underprivileged and underpaid. With escalating prices and double-digit inflation, Roh's government has declined in popularity and it's mindful of student-worker alliances that have wrought change in the past. In 1960, hundreds of thousands of students took to the streets to demand the fall of President Syngman Rhee regime. In 1987, hundreds of thousands of students spurred an authoritarian former president, Chun Doo-hwan, to make reforms. Discontented workers joined those protests. ``In Korea, protests are a statement,'' the president of a Seoul university said on condition of anonymity. ``Eventually the country may mature enough not to have to make the statement with violence. It's embarrassing.''

DOC.HEAD: Columbia Launch Delayed, Repairs Needed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with delay estimated at 2 to 3 weeks, NASA statements, other details. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `Engineers noticed...' ^By MARCIA DUNN
DOC.TEXT: A puzzling breakdown in Columbia's cooling system has forced NASA to delay next week's scheduled shuttle launch by an estimated two to three weeks, the space agency said Wednesday. Columbia had been scheduled to lift off May 16 or May 17 with seven astronauts and the $100 million Astro observatory, capable of probing ultraviolet and X-ray radiation. But engineers this week spotted a problem with a valve that controls the flow of coolant in the shuttle. ``We are obviously disappointed that we are not ready to fly,'' said William Lenoir, head of NASA's space flight program. ``However, this particular system is absolutely critical to the safety of the crew and overall mission success, so we have decided to change the component.'' NASA had hoped to confirm a launch date at the end of the two-day Flight Readiness Review meeting on Wednesday afternoon, but that did not occur. Mission managers agreed an apparently faulty valve would have to be replaced and that the work could be done at the launch pad. ``They don't understand the problem enough to feel comfortable flying with it, so they've got to go in and fix it,'' said Bascom Murrah, a NASA official in charge of prelaunch operations for Columbia. ``We feel we can do that at the pad, but how long that will take I really would only be guessing.'' Launch teams expect to have a better idea by early next week as to how long the job will take, NASA said in a statement. The agency has never replaced a cooling valve at the launch pad. Returning Columbia to its hangar for the valve to be replaced would have resulted in a considerably longer delay. NASA said mission managers ``decided that completing the replacement and checkout on the pad is as safe and effective'' as performing the work in the shuttle's hangar. Engineers noticed the problem Sunday when there was an unexplained change in the flow of coolant. The valve is in one of Columbia's two Freon cooling loops beneath the payload bay liners. It controls the proportion and rate of Freon distributed between the crew cabin heat exchanger and the cooling system for payloads. Columbia's nine- to 10-day flight will be the 36th shuttle mission, provided it goes before an Atlantis mission in July. It also will be the first Spacelab mission since 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Name New Council Members
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will nominate four new members of the National Council on the Humanities, the White House said Wednesday. They are: _Bruce D. Benson, president of Benson Mineral Group Inc., of Golden, Colo., who would succeed Kathleen S. Kilpatrick. _Billie Davis Gaines, president of Horizon Productions of Atlanta, who would succeed Jeffrey Hart. _Gary L. McDowell, vice president of the National Legal Center for the Public Interest in Washington, D.C., who would succeed Rita Ricardo-Campbell. _Jeanne J. Smoot, an English professor at North Carolina State University in Raleigh, who would suceed Ellis Sandoz.

DOC.HEAD: Michigan Fires Destroy 75 Homes
LaserPhoto XGRL3
DOC.TEXT: Firefighters aided by cool, damp weather gained the upper hand Wednesday over two forest fires that blackened more than 12 square miles of dry woods and grasslands and destroyed 75 homes. Up to 300 people were evacuated from their homes, most of them along the Au Sable River, after the fires broke out Tuesday in a sparsely populated section of the northern Lower Peninsula, authorities said. The only known casualty was a firefighter treated for smoke inhalation, said Scott Heather, assistant regional forest manager with the state Department of Natural Resources. The larger fire began five miles east of Grayling. Fanned by 20-mph gusts, it burned an 8-by-1{-mile swath of woods and grassland and destroyed 66 houses and more than 30 other structures such as shacks and garages, Heather said. ``We feel at this point we've got the fire 75 percent controlled,'' he said. ``The weather conditions are with us; it's cool and damp. We don't anticipate any further problem.'' Flames persisted in a mainly marshy area, where it was difficult to bring in firefighting equipment, Heather said. The second fire broke out 10 miles to the south, in southern Crawford and northern Roscommon counties. It consumed 450 acres and nine homes and five other structures before being brought under control early Wednesday with help from a quarter-inch of rain that fell overnight, Heather said. Light rain continued Wednesday as four National Guard helicopters dumped 185-gallon buckets of water on flames. About 30 evacuees spent Tuesday night at nearby Camp Grayling, a Michigan National Guard base. About 100 turned up at a Red Cross center Wednesday to obtain warm clothing and instructions for seeking financial help. ``This one little old lady in particular struck me,'' said Crawford County Sheriff's Deputy Heide Miller, who was meeting evacuees at the door. ``She had apparently got word her house was gone. She was in shock.'' The cause of the fires remained under investigation, Heather said. Other Department of Natural Resources officials said they suspected a trash fire had gotten out of hand. Most of the northern Lower Peninsula went 13 days without any rain and longer than that without a heavy downpour, said meteorologist Chuck Defever of the National Weather Service's Ann Arbor office. In addition, snow melted early this year, allowing undergrowth to become very dry. Gov. James Blanchard and department Director David Hales arrived to survey the damage. Up to 150 department and local firefighters battled the blazes at their peak late Tuesday, but only about 75 remained Wednesday afternoon, Heather said. Miller said most residents would find out Wednesday evening whether their homes were among the few saved, when firefighters expected to remove road barricades. ``There will be a lot of broken hearts,'' said Bill Mahalak, acting regional forest manager with the Department of Natural Resources. The area's year-round population is relatively sparse, but grows when cabin owners visit for the summer and fall, drawn by deer or bear hunting and trout fishing along the Au Sable River. Norbert Szkotnicki said he snuck past police barricades to check on his home along the river. He found part of it burning. ``I got a chain saw and cut off a (burning) corner of the cabin,'' he said. Firefighters then arrived and doused the house, saving it. ``My family has been here 110 years. My grandfather built that house,'' he said. ``I wasn't going to lose it.''

DOC.HEAD: Few Who Need Flood Insurance Have It, Official Says
LaserPhotos LR4,XPB2,XPB4,TRK2, LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Record floods that are saturating hundreds of houses are striking at people who often don't have flood insurance, a state official says. Some can't get it, some can't afford it, and some don't bother. Flood insurance is a hot topic while the Arkansas River is slopped over its banks. The river crested Tuesday to a record level at Little Rock and was expected reach 48 feet Wednesday at Pine Bluff _ a foot above flood stage. F.A. Crockett wishes he hadn't let his flood insurance policies lapse a few years ago. He says he can't recall getting a renewal notice for his flood insurance and assumed he no longer needed it. ``I went along for years and didn't think nothing about it,'' said the 72-year-old Crockett, who owns a used car dealership. ``I don't know much about insurance except that I pay the premium.'' Now water is waist deep or higher in five houses he owns. Statewide, about 500 homes are under water, between 250 and 300 of them in Jefferson County, official said. Corps of Engineers spokesman P.J. Spaul put early estimates of flood damage at $15 million to $20 million statewide. The damage to agriculture is not yet tallied. Cattlemen say hundreds of cattle have drowned or are trapped by flood waters; the spring wheat crop is lost in some counties, and flooded fields further delay spring rice planting. Jefferson County probably will lose one-sixth of its $60 million annual agricultural sales, said Frank Plafcan of the county extension office. A federal disaster declaration for Arkansas' flooded counties could come later this week, civil defense officials said. In Texas, where flooding and heavy rains have claimed 12 lives in the last two weeks and President Bush declared disaster areas in 16 counties, the Red Cross estimates that 4,000 homes have been damaged or destroyed by flooding. Officials in Texas say the first federal disaster relief checks are being handed out in 1,383 requests for help the Federal Emergency Management Agency has received since May 2. Arkansas officials say they don't know how many flood victims have no flood insurance, only how many Arkansans have it. ``It is low, I know that,'' said Alison McCollum of the state Soil and Water Conservation Commission. As of March 31, there were 7,628 flood insurance policies in Arkansas, paying premiums that totaled $1,687,926, said FEMA official Greg Solovey. Solovey said 337 areas in Arkansas participate in the federal insurance program. But some areas along the Arkansas River aren't in the program, and property owners in those areas must absorb any losses due to flood damage. Ms. McCollum said people ignore the need for flood insurance because they think it's expensive. But it's not as expensive as people think, she added. ``Flood insurance costs are not astronomical,'' she said. ``People should check, because I know it gets out that you just can't afford it. If people don't live in a designated flood plain they can get very good rates.'' Wanda Irving, who was forced by rising water to leave her home here, said she had to get flood insurance to finance her house. She pays $119 a year to insure the house and its contents, she said. Tina Mullins, a sales representative, said flood insurance rates vary but generally are inexpensive. In North Little Rock, a premium of $100 a year will buy $40,500 worth of coverage on a house and $1,000 on contents. The federal government underwrites all flood insurance programs, and only those who live in cities, towns or counties that participate in the government's National Flood Insurance Program can obtain flood insurance. To join a flood program, a city or community must agree to certain land management goals. ``In other words, stop the shopping centers from building in a flood zone area, stop the developers from putting in a residential area where it's going to flood,'' said Bill Starkey of the Independent Insurance Agents of Arkansas. The federal government subsidizes flood insurance to restrict building in flood plains and because flood insurance never can pay for itself, he said. ``The people on the mountain top don't buy it. Only the ones next to the river,'' Starkey said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Nominates Canal Official
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Wednesday he will nominate Raymond Philip Laverty as deputy administrator of the Panama Canal. Laverty, a longtime canal official who is acting deputy administrator for operations, would succeed Fernando Manfredo. A native of Brocton, Mass., the 59-year-old Laverty is a graduate of the University of Notre Dame. Bush announced last week during the White House visit of Panamanian President Guillermo Endara that he was nominating Gilberto Guardia Fabrega as administrator. The 60-year-old Panamanian is president of an architectural and engineering company in Panama City. Educated at Santa Clara University in California, Guardia was a civil engineer with the Panama Canal Co. in the 1950s. The canal treaties call for a Panamanian _ selected by Panama, nominated by the U.S. president and confirmed by the U.S. Senate _ to be put in charge of the canal in the final decade of U.S. jurisdiction. The canal will be turned over to Panama in 2000. Last year, Bush balked at Gen. Manuel Antonio Noreiga's choice for canal administrator and refused to send a name to the Senate.

DOC.HEAD: Attacked Colleague Gratified By Jimmy Breslin's Two-Week Suspension
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 3 grafs with commen from Breslin's wife
DOC.TEXT: Newsday turned a reprimand into a suspension for Jimmy Breslin after the Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist went on a radio show and spoke flippantly about his racial and sexual tirade against another reporter. Don Forst, the editor of New York Newsday, announced the two-week suspension without pay late Tuesday. Ji-Yeon Yuh, a Korean-American reporter who was the target of the columnist's epithets, said Wednesday the punishment was appropriate. ``I think Newsday did the right thing,'' Yuh said from her desk at the newspaper's office in Queens. ``I think when these kinds of things happen you really need to send a strong message that it is completely unacceptable.'' Asian-American staffers who had told management that the reprimand and Breslin's apology were not enough called off a planned byline strike. Calls to Breslin's apartment Wednesday for comment were met with busy signals. Forst's announcement of the suspension said the newspaper had believed Breslin's apology in response to its reprimand of his conduct had been genuine and sincere. ``But his radio conversation Tuesday morning with Howard Stern indicates a lack of sensitivity to what has been and continues to be a painful episode for all of us,'' he said. Stern is a talk-show host who has tangled with the Federal Communications Commission over his sexual and ethnic jokes. Breslin, 61, telephoned Stern while he was on the air and bantered about what may occur when he attends the approaching wedding of his nephew to a Korean woman. Breslin said he called the program at the urging of his children because Stern was devoting much of his show to the controversy. ``I think that even without the Howard Stern show, he should have been suspended,'' Yuh said. The brouhaha was touched off when Yuh criticized as sexist a column Breslin wrote last week complaining that women officials _ especially his wife, a member of the New York City Council _ didn't spend enough time at home. Yuh delivered her comments to Breslin the following day via interoffice computer memo. Breslin roared his response to other Newsday staffers in the Manhattan office, describing Yuh, who was not present, with an obscenity and calling her ``yellow cur'' and ``slant-eyed.'' Later Friday afternoon, Breslin submitted an apology to Newsday's staff in an internal computer message in which he said: ``I am no good and once again I can prove it. ... I am sorry. I said things I shouldn't have said. The racial and sexual insults I spewed are never appropriate.'' He apologized again in his column on Monday. After meeting with protesting staffers Tuesday evening and saying they did not intend to go beyond rebuking Breslin, the newspaper's editors listened to a tape of the columnist on Stern's program and decided to suspend him. Breslin's wife, Ronnie M. Eldridge, issued a statement Wednesday defending him and saying he is neither racist nor sexist. ``He is an artist. He has written fine books and memorable columns. His view of the world is special and consistent and wonderful,'' she said. ``But he is also outrageous. And he has a quick and miserable temper. He lost it the other day. And said terrible and regrettable things. Sadly, for him, he found no compassion or forgiveness.'' His comments on the radio show, she said, were ``a poor attempt at humor.''

DOC.HEAD: Low Temperatures, Snow And Thunderstorms
DOC.TEXT: Record cold and snow spread along the northern Rockies, western Plains and Great Lakes on Wednesday and rain extended across the Plains and the Southeast. The calendar reads May, but Great Falls, Mont., hit a record low of 24; Helena, Mont., had a record low of 25, and Laramie, Wyo., hit a record low of 16. Grand Junction, Colo., tied its record of 33. The low of 13 at Rawlins, Wyo., was the city's lowest May temperature since 1951, and was also Wednesday's low for the Lower 48 states, the National Weather Service said. Higher elevations of Colorado had snow showers and snow was mixed with rain over western Kansas during the morning. Snow also fell at higher elevations of Wyoming, and over sections of Upper Michigan. Rain was mixed with snow over northern Wisconsin. Yellowstone National Park in northwestern Wyoming got 14 inches of snow from the storm late Monday and through Tuesday. The Big Horn Mountains got 10 inches. Early Wednesday, fog, heavy snow and blustery wind cut visibility in Cheyenne and Laramie, Wyo., to one-half mile, the weather service said. Northwesterly wind of 15 to 30 mph created biting wind chills near zero, the agency reported. Showers and thunderstorms extended from central and north-central Kansas across eastern Nebraska, Iowa, southern Minnesota, Wisconsin, northern Lower Michigan, northern Illinois, and from northeastern through west-central Missouri. Strong thunderstorms during the morning produced locally heavy rain, including 1.53 inches at La Crosse, Wis. Intense thunderstorms swept through Iowa, dumping more than an inch of rain in the northwest and in a 70- to 80-mile wide band stretching from Council Bluffs in the southwest to Dubuque in the northeast. A school bus carrying 25 children tipped over on a wet, muddy road in southeastern Iowa but no serious injuries were reported, police said. Showers and storms also reached from Tennessee across western and central North Carolina, western South Carolina, Georgia, Florida, Alabama and eastern Mississippi. Light rain was scattered over southwestern Arkansas and east-central North Dakota. Heavier rainfall during the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT included 1.79 inches at Mobile, Ala.; 1.38 inches at Mary Esther, Fla.; 1.24 inches at Rochester, Minn.; 1.12 inches at Eau Clair, Wis.; and 1.06 inches at Milton, Fla. Early morning thunderstorms in Kansas produced three-quarter-inch diameter hail in Kansas near Scandia and Washington, and golfball-size hail with wind gusting to near 60 mph at Concordia. Flooding continued in parts of Texas, Oklahoma and Arkansas. The Arkansas River had begun to recede slowly at Little Rock and was cresting at Pine Bluff. Extensive flooding continued along the river, and other streams in eastern Arkansas also were out of their banks. In Texas, the flood crest on the Trinity River was near Crockett, almost halfway across Texas on its way from the Dallas area to the Gulf of Mexico. Urban flooding was a threat in Puerto Rico after locally heavy rain fell during the morning on an area around San Juan that was well soaked by rain on Tuesday. The Rio Culebrinas was out of its banks by late morning. Port Arthur, Texas, got 2.42 inches of rain Tuesday, bringing the city's total for May to 6.89 inches and for the year to date to 33.83 inches. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 32 at Marquette, Mich., to 94 at Laredo, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: White House Says NATO Summit Likely in Early July
DOC.TEXT: The White House indicated Wednesday that a NATO summit meeting, called by President Bush, probably will be held in the first week of July. The meeting, expected to be in London, apparently will be squeezed in between a six-day Bush vacation in Kennebunkport, Maine, and a summit session in Houston of leaders of the world's seven largest economic powers. White House deputy press secretary Roman Popadiuk said that dates for the NATO summit had not been set but that a number of allies had expressed a preference for early July. Popadiuk said NATO Secretary General Manfred Woerner has been quoted as mentioning July 5-6 or July 6-7 as likely dates. Bush said last week that leaders of the 16 NATO nations should meet to develop new military and political strategies ``for the transformed Europe of the 1990s.'' The only timing he mentioned was late June or early July. In the first of three summer summits, Bush will meet in Washington with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev from May 30 to June 3. On June 29, Bush is expected to travel to his seaside home at Kennebunkport. If the July 5 opening of the NATO summit holds, Bush would fly to London from Kennebunkport on Independence Day. Tentative plans call for Bush to return to Washington on the evening of July 6 and then leave the next day for Houston, where he will host the seven-nation economic summit July 9-11.

DOC.HEAD: French, British Aerospace Firms to Study New Supersonic Plane
DOC.TEXT: Aerospace companies from Britain and France said Wednesday they have begun a $34 million study to determine whether to develop a new supersonic airliner to replace their jointly produced Concorde. The decision on whether to proceed with a $10 billion production program would be made in 1995, said Aerospatiale President Henri Martre, whose company is working with British Aerospace. Martre told a news conference that the companies would welcome U.S., Soviet West German or Japanese cooperation. British Airways and Air France operate 13 Concordes on trans-Atlantic routes. The jetliners are due for retirement in 15 to 20 years, and the new planes _ if developed _ would be ready by about 2005. The new generation of supersonic transport could carry about 225 passengers over distances of up to 7,500 miles at 2{ times the speed of sound, aviation experts say. The present Concorde carries 128 passengers on flights of up to 3,720 miles at twice the speed of sound. The projected aircraft would be capable of nonstop flights across the Pacific.

DOC.HEAD: Luxembourg Envoy to NATO Quits after Security Breach
DOC.TEXT: Luxembourg's envoy to NATO has quit after he committed a minor security infraction, Foreign Minister Jacques Poos said Wednesday. He told Parliament that Guy de Muyser, 64, resigned on April 25 after the government learned he ``had breached security rules'' at the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Indicating the infraction was minor, Poos said de Muyser will remain envoy to Belgium. Luxembourg traditionally combines the two Brussels ambassadorships. Sources said the security breach stemmed from trips de Muyser made to the Soviet Union where he gave out NATO documents whose contents had already been publicly reported. On April 25, the government, citing ``preventive reasons,'' withdrew de Muyser's security clearance denying him access to secret NATO papers and effectively forcing his resignation that same day. The sources spoke on the condition of not being identified. Officials at NATO headquarters declined to comment on the case. De Muyser became NATO ambassador in 1986. He was envoy to the Soviet Union from 1981 to 1983. During the 1970s, he held senior positions at the Palace of Grand Duke Jean, Luxembourg's monarch. De Muyser was not available for comment Wednesday. A man answering the phone at his Brussels residence said the envoy was vacationing in France. Last month, a staff member at NATO's West German mission was arrested on charges of spying for East Germany and the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: FCC Head Says Panel Could Regulated Bell Companies
DOC.TEXT: The government's top telephone regulator said Wednesday he can still control the huge regional Bell telephone companies if they are allowed to design and manufacture telephone equipment. But Bell rivals and consumer representatives told a Senate hearing they were concerned that unfettered Bell companies could use their enormous earnings power to drive out competition and subsidize new business ventures with their monopoly local telephone earnings. A bill by the committee chairman, Sen. Ernest F. Hollings, D-S.C., would lift manufacturing restrictions imposed on the seven regional Bell companies by the so-called Modification of Final Judgment, which ended the AT&T antitrust suit in 1984. The Hollings bill would allow the Bell companies to design, develop and fabricate telecommunications equipment, including network and customer premises equipment. It also would require that such activities take place in the United States. The FCC's admitted inability to fully moy-Probe 05-09 0342
DOC.HEAD: AM-Fauntroy-Probe,340
Justice Department Refers Fauntroy Allegations to Congress
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department has referred to the House ethics committee allegations that Del. Walter Fauntroy, D-D.C., hired a colleague's son for a no-show job, officials said Wednesday. The department decided recently not to bring criminal charges against Fauntroy following a 15-month investigation. Spokesman David Runkel said ``there was information that the House ethics committee might want to look at.'' He declined to give further details. Fauntroy, the district's non-voting delegate in Congress, was investigated for his employment of the son of Rep. Gus Savage, D-Ill. Runkel said a parallel Justice Department investigation of Savage had also been closed for lack of evidence to warrant prosecution, and that matter also was referred to the House ethics committee. The department examined whether the elder Savage was aware of any possible wrongdoing in Fauntroy's hiring of his son, said sources who spoke on condition of anonymity. Fauntroy, who has denied any wrongdoing throughout the investigation, said in a statement Tuesday, ``There are no new facts for the ethics committee to find.'' Abbe Lowell, Fauntroy's attorney, said the lawmaker had cooperated fully with the probe. Savage did not return phone calls to his office on Wednesday. Jan Keyes, a spokeswoman for the House Committee on Standards of Official Committee _ the formal name of the ethics panel _ had no comment on whether it would open an investigation. The Justice Department investigation began in December 1988, after The Associated Press reported that Thomas Savage was living in Chicago and running for election to the Illinois House while on Fauntroy's payroll in the nation's capital. Thomas Savage was on Fauntroy's payroll from September 1987 through June 1988, except for a 10-week unpaid leave, a period when he said he went to Illinois to run for the legislature. House rules require that congressional employees must perform their duties either in Washington or the member's district. Fauntroy is giving up his House seat to run for the Democratic mayoral nomination.

DOC.HEAD: Poisoning Guide, Bondage Equipment Among Evidence Seized in Tampering Case
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Investigators seized a homemade poisoning guide, boxloads of chemicals and bondage gear from a man charged with the 1988 poisonings of his neighbors, according to court records unsealed Wednesday. The property of George James Trepal, 41, who was arrested and charged last month with first-degree murder, attempted murder and product tampering, was listed in an item-by-item inventory. ``If you believe everything you've heard so far, sure it looks bad. But when our side is finally heard you'll see the whole picture,'' said defense attorney Jonathan Stidham, who's called his client ``a bit of a different person.'' Prosecutors say Trepal, a computer programmer and Mensa member, used poison-spiked bottles of Coca-Cola to kill neighbor Peggy Carr of Alturas and poison her husband and children, leaving two of them partially paralyzed. In the six years before the poisonings, Trepal complained about the Carr's dogs chasing his cats, loud radios the Carr children played and the all-terrain vehicles they rode, police said. And in the months prior to the October 1988 poisonings, the Carrs were mailed a typed warning: ``You and all your so-called family have two weeks to move out of Florida forever or else you all die. This is no joke.'' Mrs. Carr lapsed into a coma and died in March 1989. An FBI analysis of the Coca-Cola showed it was laced with highly toxic thallium nitrate. When questioned in 1988, Trepal said his only knowledge of thallium came from TV news, according to authorities. But Trepal was convicted in 1975 and served three years in prison for running a drug lab in North Carolina that produced $7 million in illegal methamphetamines. Thallium is used in amphetamine manufacture. Bottles of the poison found in the garage of Trepal's Alturas home late last year led to his arrest and further searches, according to court documents. Among the things seized from Trepal's home in Sebring, where he moved late last year, were boxloads of labeled and unlabeled chemicals, laboratory equipment and a neat, green ledger on poisoning, according to authorities. ``It looked to be a homemade journal with different pages from different books placed in it. ... It's a very extensive book,'' Polk County Detective Ernie Mincey said during a court hearing last month. Detectives seized hundreds of books in Trepal's home, but listed one in particular, ``Pale Horse,'' an Agathie Christie murder mystery in which a chemist kills many people by putting thallium in makeup, medicine and foods. Trepal and his wife, orthopedic surgeon Diana Carr, were members of Mensa, an organization for people of high intelligence. Diana Carr is not related to the victims' family and has not been charged. In April 1989, Trepal and his wife organized the group's ``Murder Mystery Weekend,'' investigators said. A booklet of background material Trepal prepared for the event detailed a staged voodoo poisoning death. One passage of that seized book reads: ``When a death threat appears on the doorstep, prudent people throw out all their food and watch what they eat,'' according to court documents. More than 60 books and six videotapes on bondage were also found in the Sebring home, along with leather bondage tools, the search warrants showed. Detectives testified in detail last month about finding a soundproof ``torture-type room'' in the basement, complete with a flat wooden bed and stirrups. ``We believe it was probably used in bondage,'' Mincey said. In addition to the search of the Sebring and Alturas homes, detectives also searched a mini-warehouse Trepal rented, Diana Carr's medical office and her airplane, warrants showed. ``The prosecution has come out with a lot of evidence,'' defense lawer Jonathan Stidham said Wednesday. ``It's all very interesting, but none of it shows my client put thallium in Coke bottles and put it in these peoples' home.''

DOC.HEAD: Contemporary Art Prices Soften
DOC.TEXT: Two auctions of contemporary art featured lower prices this week, suggesting that the market has stopped its frenzied climb upward and buyers are becoming more selective, art experts said Wednesday. The experts said the contemporary art market is still healthy and they did not fear a bust, even though many paintings didn't sell or sold well below their estimated prices. ``People are more than willing to pay top sums for excellent pieces of art but are not willing to pay inflated prices for second-rate works of art,'' said Larry Gagosian, a Madison Avenue art dealer. Roy Lichtenstein's ``Kiss II,'' from 1962, a cartoon image of a young couple kissing, sold at Christie's auction house in New York City on Monday for $6 million, the highest price ever paid for a work by the artist. Its presale estimate was $5 million to $7 million. At that same sale, 26 artworks out of 77 offered failed to find buyers because no bids reached the minimum set by the seller. The auction house sold $40.17 million worth of art, well below its presale estimate of $50 million to $71.8 million. At rival Sotheby's on Tuesday, 32 artworks out of 87 went unsold, and the sale brought in $55.9 million against house expectations of $86.6 million to $112.9 million. Still, Cy Twombly's 1971 untitled blackboard painting fetched $5.5 million, the most ever paid at auction for a work by the artist. ``I think a lot of the hysteria has gone out of the market,'' said Milton Esterow, editor and publisher of ARTnews. Allan Stone, a New York dealer, agreed. ``What's been going on the last couple years has been absolute insanity,'' he said. They said selective buying was replacing the buying sprees of the last several years, but the change doesn't indicate the art market had hit rocky times. ``I think the business will remain very good,'' said Gagosian. Some experts, particularly art dealers, have blamed Sotheby's and Christie's for creating unrealistic price expectations among consignors who place their art with the auction houses for sale. ``The problem, I think, is that too many collectors are too greedy and the auction houses have not put their feet down strongly enough in telling collectors that their reserves have no relation to reality,'' Esterow said. Auction houses and sellers agree to a reserve price below which an artwork cannot be sold. ``It is in our interest to give the consigner the most accurate estimate we can. It's also in our interest to make sure the painting sells,'' Nash said. David Nash, senior vice president in charge of fine arts at Sotheby's, said, ``There was something of a rather frenzied and heated atmosphere over the last several years which we knew could not be sustained.'' ``We sort of had the feeling you could sell almost anything regardless of price, and we knew this was not an ideal place for the market to be in.'' Nash said the turnover for the auction house's contemporary art department in 1984 was $13 million, compared to $250 million in 1989. During the last three years, prices of artworks were doubling every six months, he said. He called the change in the market ``a healthy development.'' Christopher Burge, president of Christie's, said contemporary art prices had been pushed to their limit in recent several years.

DOC.HEAD: Springfield Flips Flapjacks, Battle Creek Pours Cereal
DOC.TEXT: In the race to become the champions of big breakfasts, civic-minded chefs in western Massachusetts have stirred oceans of batter, flipped mountains of pancakes and brewed rivers of coffee. Rival Battle Creek, Mich., has served up cereal, Pop Tarts, doughnut holes and Tang _ cold. ``We're not talking apples and apples and oranges and oranges,'' says state Rep. Athan Catjakis, a co-chairman of this Saturday's breakfast in Springfield. Officials hope to dish up 35,000 pancake breakfasts to hang on to the biggest breakfast title, wrested from Battle Creek last year by a margin of about 1,000 breakfasts served. Battle Creek answers the challenge June 9. Springfield, Ore., which tried and failed to beat its Massachusetts namesake in 1989, will send Mayor William E. Morisette and his wife to pick up pointers, although no immediate challenge is planned. ``As far as a pancake breakfast, I don't think there's anybody in the United States that can touch us,'' Catjakis said. ``It's a lot easier to take a box of cereal and pour some milk.'' Officials in Battle Creek, home of three major cereal makers, defended their menu. ``Is it fair? You bet,'' said spokeswoman Helen Royal. She said Battle Creek, with a population of about 70,000, is at a disadvantage to Springfield, a city of about 150,000, so the Michigan city has to work harder to get the big numbers. Besides, cereal goes back a long way in Battle Creek, home of the Kellogg Co., the Post division of General Foods Corp. and Ralston Purina Co., she said. ``We are the cereal capital of the world. That's a title that we really honor and that we defend and we're the only city in the world that can claim that right,'' Royal said. Battle Creek held a free cereal breakfast in 1956 to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the founding of Kellogg. The event was repeated four times from 1958 to 1962. The tradition was resumed in 1976. A decade later, Springfield set up a table on Main Street and served 24,000 pancake breakfasts to celebrate its 350th anniversary. ``We were looking for something different to do,'' Catjakis said. The cities first competed for ``World's Longest Breakfast Table,'' but after that became logistically difficult, the race switched to feeding the most people. Battle Creek won in 1987 and 1988. But in 1989, Springfield won with 33,869 breakfasts served. Battle Creek officials blamed a cold, windy day for only attracting 32,856 people. In 1987, Springfield tried serving cereal, but it bombed with New England breakfast-eaters, Catjakis said. The Springfield pancakes, provided by a restaurant chain at $1.50 per adult, calls for 600 pounds of egg yolks, 220 pounds of butter, 3,000 pounds of flour and 400 gallons of water. Sixteen griddles are used and the flapjacks are served with 2,000 pounds of butter and 200 gallons of maple syrup. Six hundred gallons of coffee and orange juice complete the meal.

DOC.HEAD: GSA Chief Says Defense Department Should Pay To Fix Up Pentagon
DOC.TEXT: The acting head of the General Services Administration said Wednesday the Defense Department _ not the GSA _ should pay for the $1.1 billion renovation of the Pentagon. Richard G. Austin told a House Public Works and Transportation panel that he supports the transfer of the Pentagon from his agency's control to the Defense Department, a step expected later this year. Once the transfer takes place, the Defense Department should handle the expense of repairing the 48-year-old building. ``The renovation and modernization of the Pentagon building will create unique security problems, and the logistical difficulties inherent in any major renovation will be complicated by the extremely high sensitivity of the building tenants,'' Austin said. The acting GSA administrator also told the subcommittee on public buildings and grounds that the cost of $1.1 billion over seven years for the Pentagon repair ``would place a significant demand for resources on the federal building fund.'' Earlier this year, Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn., chairman of the Senate Appropriations subcommittee on military construction, said the Bush administration's request for $1.1 billion to renovate the Pentagon is ``out of the question.'' Sasser acknowledged that the building is in need of repair but said the administration's call for $1.1 billion over seven years would be difficult to heed in a time of shrinking budgets. ``The military construction bill is going to get smaller not larger,'' Sasser said. ``There's simply no room for such an undertaking.'' The Pentagon, the largest office building in the world, has 17.5 miles of corridors, 131 stairways, 19 escalators and 13 elevators, and covers 29 acres in northern Virginia.

DOC.HEAD: Government Targets Computer Hackers
DOC.TEXT: An interstate probe of computer hacking has uncovered losses that may reach millions of dollars and could be ``just the tip of the iceberg,'' federal law enforcement officials said Wednedsay. No computer-crime arrests resulted, however, when 27 search warrants served in a dozen cities were served by 150 Secret Service agents and police on Tuesday, officials said. Three people _ one each in Chicago, Los Angeles and Pittsburgh _ were arrested for unrelated offenses, officials said. Secret Service officials declined to release any specifics, including the number of people targeted, saying the two-year investigation, code-named ``Operation Sun Devil,'' was continuing. The probe is focused on illegal entry into computer systems and unauthorized use of credit-card numbers and long-distance codes, said Garry M. Jenkins, assistant Secret Service director for investigations. ``The losses that we estimate on this may run to the millions of dollars,'' said U.S. Attorney for Arizona Stephen McNamee, who joined Jenkins and Arizona Attorney General Bob Corbin at a news conference. ``Most of you have been taking this as a game,'' Corbin told reporters. ``It is not a game. ... They're not all kids. They're adults, too.'' Much of the alleged loss stems from unpaid telephone and computer access charges, the officials said. They said it was possible that hackers had gotten goods or cash through use of unauthorized credit cards, but could not cite any instance of it. In addition to misuse of credit cards and phone lines, the hackers are believed to have gotten into computers that store medical and financial histories, the officials said. The case ``appears to be the largest so far'' in the field, said assistant U.S. Attorney Tim Holtzen. However, it ``is probably only the tip of the iceberg'' when it comes to computer crime, he said. Statements from the Secret Service and the Justice Department gave conflicting information on the number and locations of the cities where searches were made. In addition to searches in or near Phoenix, there were searches conducted this week in or near Chicago; Cincinnati; Detroit; Los Angeles; Miami; Newark, N.J.; New York City; Pittsburgh; Richmond, Va.; Plano, Texas, and San Diego. Also listed in some of the statements were San Jose, Calif.; Saginaw, Mich.; San Francisco and Tucson. Officials said they were unable to explain the discrepancies. Documents on the search warrants will be sealed pending further investigation, assistant Attorney General Gail Thackery said. Under new computer crime laws, the Secret Service has jurisdiction to investigate allegations of electronic fraud through the use of access devices such as credit-card numbers and codes long-distance companies issue to individual callers. Defendants convicted of unauthorized use of such ``access devices'' can be sentenced up to 10 years in prison if they commit fraud of more than $1,000, according to the law. A similar investigation supervised by federal prosecutors in Chicago has resulted in several indictments.

DOC.HEAD: Grace Ford Salvatori, Philanthropist Behind L.A. Music Center, Dies
DOC.TEXT: Philanthropist Grace Ford Salvatori, wife of millionaire industrialist Henry Salvatori and a leading fund-raiser for the Los Angeles Music Center, has died. She was 80. She died Saturday at her Bel-Air home, the family said. A service was held Tuesday at Forest Lawn Memorial Park in Glendale. The Salvatoris gave many gifts to schools, hospitals and shelters, but helping raise funds to build the Music Center was Mrs. Salvatori's proudest accomplishment, said her daughter, Laurie Ann O'Connell. The $34 million center, with three auditoriums built between 1962 and 1967, gave the city a much-needed home for the performing arts. She also made major gifts to the University of Southern California, the Marlborough School and other educational institutions, as well as Childrens Hospital of Los Angeles, St. John's Hospital, the Hospital of the Good Samaritan and the Los Angeles Mission. A native of Oklahoma, Mrs. Salvatori came to Los Angeles as an aspiring actress. She was briefly under contract to MGM Studios. She and Salvatori, who was in the oil business, were married in 1937. Along with her husband and daughter, Mrs. Salvatori is survived by a son, Henry Ford Salvatori, and a grandson.

DOC.HEAD: Thornburgh Asks Stiffer Penalties for Cross Burnings
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said Wednesday he has asked Congress to stiffen criminal penalties for cross burnings and other forms of racial harassment that do not result in personal injuries. The proposed amendments to the landmark 1968 Civil Rights Act would make cross burnings a felony under federal law punishable by a five-year prison sentence and a fine up to $250,000. The offense is now a misdemeanor that carries a maximum one-year sentence and a $100,000 fine. Misdemeanor penalties would be retained to allow prosecutors to bring lesser charges in appropriate cases, the department said in a letter to Congress. The harsher penalties are proposed for what Thornburgh called ``particularly egregious cases _ those where firearms are used or fire or threats of fire, including cross burnings, are employed.'' Thornburgh's statement cited a case in which people who burned down a home rented by a black family were prosecuted for a misdemeanor because there were no injuries. The law would also apply to situations in which shots are fired into homes but there are no injuries. Prosecutors would have to prove racial or ethnic harassment motivated the incident. In another case, prosecutors could only bring misdemeanor charges against people accused of burning down a house trailer occupied by a biracial family, Thornburgh said. The proposed amendments deal with the use or the threat of force to interfere with a citizen's right to fair housing. ``The message of hatred and violence that cross burnings convey inflicts enormous psychological damage on victims, particularly children who live in a targeted house,'' the Justice Department said its letter to Congress last month that was released Wednesday. ``Frequently, lives are disrupted as families flee neighborhoods altogether or members alter schedules to protect their families and homes,'' said the letter by Bruce C. Navarro, the acting head of the department's legislative affairs office. State charges of arson may be filed by local prosecutors in many jurisdictions. These crimes carry heavier penalties. But cross burning is often treated as malicious mischief and shootings that do not result in injuries may be minor felonies, such as assault or attempted assault. Local authorities may not be willing to invest the time to investigate a crime that carries a light penalty, said Daniel Rinzel, head of the Justice Department unit that prosecutes hate crimes. ``Most cross burnings take some work to try to figure out who did it,'' Rinzel said. ``There are some incidents that you could consider to be serious simply because people were lucky they weren't injured'' but are nonetheless treated as misdemeanors by the law, Rinzel said.

DOC.HEAD: Saldana Attacker Agrees to Face Murder Charges in Britain
DOC.TEXT: A Scottish drifter who critically wounded actress Theresa Saldana in a 1982 stabbing has agreed to return to England to face charges in a homicide committed there nearly 23 years ago. Arthur Richard Jackson, 53, waived extradition proceedings during a Tuesday hearing before U.S. Magistrate Venetta S. Tassopulos. Jackson could be sentenced to life in prison if convicted in the shooting death of a passer-by during a June 1967 bank robbery in London, said Angus Mackay, Britain's vice consul in Los Angeles. Jackson still faces trial in Los Angeles Superior Court on charges he sent 16 threatening letters to Miss Saldana, 34, while serving a 12-year prison term for attacking her with a kitchen knife outside her West Hollywood apartment on March 15, 1982. The actress was hospitalized for 3{ months and underwent five major operations to repair wounds to her heart, lungs, legs and arms. ``It is our intention to try him on those charges and convict him here,'' said Sandi Gibbons, a district attorney's spokeswoman. ``But he can serve his sentence anywhere, in England as well as the United States. Once we've convicted him, England is welcome to have him.'' The charges filed last June were based on seven letters Jackson is accused of sending Miss Saldana and former water delivery man Jeff Fenn, who rescued Miss Saldana during the 1982 stabbing attack and held Jackson for police. Jackson allegedly wrote in one letter that he regretted using a knife because ``a gun would have given me a better chance of reunion with you in heaven,'' authorities say. Jackson had a history of mental problems when he entered the United States illegally in 1982. In Britain, Jackson is accused of killing a passer-by who chased him after the June 1967 bank robbery. He also is accused of wounding two bank employees in that robbery, as well as two other armed robberies in 1965 and 1967. Jackson was not identified as a suspect in those crimes until June 1987, when he sent Scotland Yard a letter admitting his involvement and saying he wanted ``to be extradited to England immediately,'' U.S. court documents say. Miss Saldana's agent, Morgan Paul, said he worried that Jackson would avoid a long prison term in England and return to the United States to stalk the actress again. ``He has been extradited three previous times and he's always gotten back here,'' Paul said. ``We want a sure thing. We want to know where he is at all times.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Dismisses Lawsuit Against FBI
DOC.TEXT: A lawsuit filed against the FBI after the agency's ill-fated investigation of an organization opposed to U.S. intervention in Central America was dismissed by a federal judge Wednesday. U.S. District Court Judge George Revercomb granted the FBI's motion to end the lawsuit filed by CISPES, the Committee in Solidarity with the People of El Salvador. The case is moot because the FBI agreed Feb. 24 to transfer all records pertaining to CISPES to the National Archives, Revercomb said. The FBI investigated CISPES for alleged terrorist activity based on a tip from a paid informant who was found to be untrustworthy. Earlier, the FBI conceded that its investigation was flawed, disciplined a number of agents and amended its guidelines for conducting investigations. The group said the Feb. 24 agreement does not cover copies of CISPES records provided to other agencies such as the Terrorist Information Center, the State Department or foreign police agencies. The FBI ``can only dispose of records over which they have custody or control,'' Revercomb said. ``Information and records ... already disseminated ... are beyond the disposal power'' of the bureau. CISPES sought an injunction directing the FBI to recover all copies of its files and computer data bases and to deposit them with the archives. ``People have to get more sophisticated about potential government abuse and understand it can occur with computers as well as paper,'' said Margaret Ratner, an attorney representing the committee. She said CISPES had not been allowed to see the agreement between the FBI and the archives and that she doubted computer files had been purged. Revercomb said that although CISPES records have been distributed to other agencies, ``the possibility that a federal employer is going to contact these other entities ... for security checks ... is too remote to be tenable.'' Members of a number of groups were placed under surveillance as a result of the FBI investigation and spinoff probes. CISPES alleged the FBI had violated the First Amendment and the Privacy Act of 1974.

DOC.HEAD: 27 Wounded in Occupied Territories, Arabs Mark 30th Month of Uprising
DOC.TEXT: Palestinians shut their stores to mark the 30th month of their uprising against Israeli rule and troops shot and wounded 27 Arab protesters, Arab hospital officials said. Throughout the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, transportation ground to a halt and businesses closed to mark the anniversary of the beginning of the revolt. Arab reports said a 14-year-old boy was shot in the head in clashes with soldiers in the West Bank town of Hebron. Hospital officials reported him to be in serious condition. In the West Bank's Askar refugee camp near Nablus, 22 Palestinians were wounded by gunfire in confrontations with soldiers, hospital officials said. In the occupied Gaza Strip, four Arabs were wounded in clashes, a military spokesman said. The army also confirmed three of the wounded in the West Bank and said they were investigating the other incidents. At least 683 Palestinians have been killed by Israelis in the revolt, and 43 Israelis have died in the violence. At least 212 Arabs have been killed by the fellow Palestinians on suspicion of collaborating with Israeli authorities or for moral offenses such as prostitution or drug dealing.

DOC.HEAD: Anniversary of Soviet World War II Victory Stirs Old and New Passions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf with one graf to fix spelling of word ``rifle.'' Pickup 4th pvs, `Gorbachev did...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MOSB2,5,7,10
DOC.TEXT: Tanks, missiles and troops paraded through Red Square on Wednesday to celebrate the World War II defeat of Nazi Germany, stirring emotions over the reunification of a former foe and the secession of three republics. ``Military danger still exists in the world,'' Defense Minister Marshal Dmitri T. Yazov said moments before he sent five new pieces of military hardware roaring past the assembled Kremlin leadership and Western spectators. Yazov, who led a rifle regiment in World War II, also praised in his speech the ``new thinking'' of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, which he said had lowered tensions in a Europe that was divided after the Nazi defeat in 1945. Gorbachev did not address the event, but smiled at participants as he led the leadership onto Lenin's Mausoleum to watch. Western diplomats applauded as he left the tribunal afterward, and in salute he raised a bouquet presented by military cadets during the ceremony. The celebration affected other Soviets differently. Some veterans interviewed after the parade expressed misgivings about German reunification. One senior naval officer thundered: ``I killed Germans then, and if I have to I'll kill them again!'' He refused to give his name to an American reporter. Emotions also ran high in the Baltic republics of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia, which the Soviet Union forcibly annexed during the war but which have moved toward independence this year. The Army staged Victory Day rallies in all three Baltic capitals, and in Latvia and Lithuania they turned into demonstrations for and against secession. In Latvia, which declared independence on May 4, a rally turned into a march by 5,000 protesters, supported by the Communist Party and military. ``We consider the declaration of independence a defeat for everyone,'' said Lt. Gen. Oleg Zinchenko, head of the political directorate of the Baltic Military Region, which encompasses the three republics. Zinchenko, saying he spoke for the Armed Forces, said appeals from the military to the Kremlin to intervene more forcefully in the Baltics were not signs of weakness. ``Nothing could be more dangerous than that misperception,'' he told the crowd, many of whom waved bright red banners as well as Latvian flags emblazoned with the Soviet hammer and sickle. In the Lithuanian capital of Vilnius, a witness said 200 people tried to block a Victory Day procession. They shouted, ``Occupiers go home!'' as the veterans marched along Gediminas Avenue near a monument to Soviet Gen. Ivan Chernyakhovsky, a World War II hero. The protesters tried to block the veterans, who were apparently Russians, but a cordon of paratroopers prevented them, said Pranas Karlonas, a Lithuanian radio editor. Lithuania declared independence on March 11, and Latvia followed suit on May 4. On Tuesday, Estonia took some steps toward independence, without formally declaring it. In the Estonian capital of Tallinn, the Soviet Army paraded, but there were no confrontations, said Neme Bruus, an editor at Estonian Radio. At the Red Square parade in Moscow, the Army took the unusual step of displaying five new pieces of hardware, some of which had never been seen by Western military observers. ``I think it's a very strong message that the army is still valued within Soviet society, that they're still a capable force, and that they're still valued by President Gorbachev,'' said Henry Dodds, editor of Jane's Soviet Intelligence Review, in an interview broadcast by Britain's Sky TV. The motorized portion of the parade began with an echelon of T-34 tanks, which were first produced in 1943 and were the workhorse of Soviet armor in the march to Berlin. Overall, the Soviets showed 18 modern weapons systems. ``For the military buffs there were some very interesting pieces of equipment. The first thing that we saw was a new armored personnel carrier,'' Dodds said, referring to a BMD-2 airborne combat vehicle, equipped with an anti-tank missile and designed to be dropped with paratroopers. ``This is absolutely brand new. There was only some suggestion of it having been in existence towards the end of last year. And it was absolutely remarkable to see it being displayed in Moscow today,'' Dodds said. A senior Western military attache said the centerpiece of the Soviet display was a new SAM-10 surface to air missile. Long, sleek trucks each carried four of the new missles, inside cannisters painted in camouflage. Another hot item in the Soviet parade was the latest tank, a T-80 variant known to the West as the Soviet Medium Tank 1989, for the year it entered service, said the NATO officer. One thing missing from the parade was an American Legion marching band that traveled to Moscow from Massachusetts. Soviet officials initially told the band it could march, but said Wednesday it would not be allowed onto Red Square. Instead, the 70-member band played outside the Bolshoi Theater, and band leader Dorothy ``Dot'' Hill said she was not disappointed. ``Victory Day was far more impressive to me than where it was,'' she said. ``Having it where they had it was perfect. It couldn't have been any better.''

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Students Battle Police; Demand Roh's Ouster
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 3rd graf to UPDATE with two U.S. guards injured; SUBS three grafs for 17th pvs, `An embassy...' with details of attack, background on anti-U.S. stand. Pickup 18th pvs, `In front...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos SEL1,5,7,8
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of students, dissidents and radicals battled riot police in more than a dozen cities Wednesday to demand the ouster of President Roh Tae-woo. Police arrested more than 900 people. In downtown Seoul, students hurled rocks and firebombs in the most violent anti-government protests in the capital since 1987. Dozens of police and protesters suffered injuries, some serious, but no figures were available. Protesters set fire to a U.S. diplomatic building, firebombed a police bus, truck and jeep, occupied the front of one of the capital's luxury hotels and took control of a fashionable downtown shopping area for more than three hours. Two U.S. guards were slightly injured by rock-throwing demonstrators, a State Department spokesman, Richard Boucher, said in Washington. Violence erupted as the newly created Democratic Liberal Party held its inaugural convention. Radicals and dissidents claim the gigantic party, a merger of three political groups, will lead to dictatorship. Roh's party is declining in popularity as inflation rises, but most South Koreans do not support radicals who espouse violence. ``Yankee go home!'' screamed thousands of students hurling firebombs and rocks. ``Down with Roh Tae-woo!'' At the height of the fighting, some 15,000 students rampaged through an area two or three miles wide from the Seoul railway station to Dondaemun market, the country's largest wholesale market. Protesters ripped up sidewalks and metal grating to make missiles. Street signs were taken apart to use as weapons against police armed with tear-gas masks, truncheons and shields. Clouds of choking tear gas billowed over the center of this capital city of 10 million people, sending office workers and shopkeepers racing for cover at the evening rush hour, holding their mouth and nose to keep out the acrid gas. Thousands of riot police in the city center appeared to be taken by surprise as throngs of 300 to 2,000 radical students dashed along sidewalks to occupy main downtown shopping streets. Screaming protesters overpowered at least two groups of 200 to 300 riot police and seized their helmets, clubs, shields and other items. Students forced dozens of police to kneel with their hands behind their backs and shouted insults, kicking and beating them with fists and clubs. ``Disband the DLP!'' students yelled repeatedly. After nightfall, about 3,000 students occupied a block around the U.S. Information Service center for two hours before being driven back by volleys of tear gas fired from black armored police vans. Students broke at least seven windows at the four-story center and threw firebombs into a first-floor window, touching off a fire that raged out of control for more than an hour with flames reaching up to the second story. Firefighters and U.S. Army fire trucks from the nearby American base extinguished the blaze after police regained control of the street. The front gate of the center was shuttered and it was unknown whether there were people inside the building, which includes a library and agriculture and trade offices. Boucher said the two injured U.S. guards were outside the building. He said no U.S. personnel were known to be in the building during the fighting. ``Early indications are that there was considerable smoke and water damage to the building,'' he told a news briefing in Washington. The radicals, who want unification with Communist North Korea, demand the withdrawal of 43,000 U.S. troops based in South Korea. In front of the luxury Hotel Lotte across the street from the American building, a torched police bus and a jeep burned several hours. The hotel was shuttered, its driveway littered with broken bottles, glass and rocks. The protests were the most violent in the capital since 1987, when nationwide demonstrations by hundreds of thousands of citizens forced former dictatorial President Chun Doo-hwan to carry out major democratic reforms. Roh was elected president in December 1987 and succeeded Chun in February 1988. The violent clashes spread to 16 other cities and involved an estimated 50,000 protesters nationwide, police and news reports said. Police said they arrested at least 912 people. Radicals attacked governing party offices in three provincial cities, destroying the office in the central city of Chongju, according to Yonhap, the national news agency. Yonhap said five police stations in the country were attacked. In the southern city of Taegu, about 100 riot police brandishing iron pipes attacked protesters during a street clash, injuring 20 protesters, Yonhap said.

DOC.HEAD: Birth of Test-Tube Tigers Buoys Hopes for Preservation of Species
DOC.TEXT: Zoo officials on Wednesday announced the birth of the world's first test-tube tigers and said in-vitro fertilization could help preserve the endangered tiger population as well as other species. Dr. Lee Simmons said two yellow tiger cubs and one white male were delivered by Caesarian section on April 27 at Omaha's Henry Doorly Zoo to the surrogate mother, a 9{-year-old Siberian tiger named Nicole. The parents of the three cubs were a white Bengal tiger and two Bengal tiger mothers, Simmons said. The white male cub died shortly after birth because of respiratory complications unrelated to the in-vitro fertilization. But the other two yellow-and-brown striped cubs, a male and a female, are strong and healthy and being hand-reared at the Omaha zoo, Simmons said. The births mean preserving an endangered species is possible and helps the cause of researchers and zoos, Simmons said. ``For some of the conservationists, research has been a four-letter word,'' Simmons said. Seeing the two ``cuddly little cubs can help show that maybe research isn't such a bad thing,'' he said. Three zoos _ Doorly, the National Zoological Park in Washington, D.C., and the Minnesota Zoological Gardens in Minneapolis _ have collaborated on the project for more than 10 years. The in-vitro techniques have been used successfully in humans and in farm animals, but progress has been slow in adapting the techniques to wild animals, Simmons said. Research has focused on tigers because at least three of the eight remaining tiger subspecies have become extinct in the past 20 years and only 50 tigers remain in the critically endangered South China subspecies, Simmons said. The program began with a National Zoo research program using the techniques on domestic cats. It is aimed at ultimately taking the technology and techniques into the wild, Simmons said. He outlined a scenario that begins with frozen embryos from tigers in captivity in Omaha or other zoos. ``We go into the wild in India and Nepal and capture a female for a short time,'' he said. During that time, scientists would induce ovulation and collect the tiger's eggs, he said. They also would transfer the frozen embryos to the wild tiger and turn her loose. ``About 110 days later, she would deliver cubs that she would raise in the wild,'' Simmons said. ``They (the cubs) would expand and enhance the gene pool.'' Expanding the gene pool is important as the populations of endangered animals decrease, Simmons said. As the habitats shrink and become more isolated, the wild populations ``fall prey to inbreeding,'' Simmons said. The dwindling habitat means that the tigers ``may still be running free in a forest, but they have unfortunately become just as captive as animals in the zoo,'' he said. ``The techniques can help enhance the survival of the zoo captives and the wild captives,'' Simmons said. The program in the wild still is years away as technology develops to make the mobile in-vitro lab really mobile, Simmons said. The in-vitro technique involves a veterinarian treating the donor female tigers with a hormone to stimulate growth of follicles in the ovaries. The eggs in the follicles then are stimulated to develop further with a second hormone injection. A day later, the tiger is anesthetized and examined. The eggs then are collected with a needle inserted through the abdominal wall. The eggs are placed with sperm collected from a male in a special medium in a warm incubator. In 12 hours, embryos are surgically transferred into the reproductive tract of the surrogate mother. The tigers involved in this first birth all came from the Omaha zoo, which has 40 tigers _ one of the largest tiger populations in the world, Simmons said.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Secretary: Talks With Iran Possible If Bring Results
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said Wednesday that direct talks with Iran to secure the release of British hostages were possible if they were likely to produce results. Iran broke diplomatic relations with Britain in Feburary 1989 after the country's spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, urged Moslems to kill Indian-born British author Salman Rushdie for blaspheming Islam in his novel, ``The Satanic Verses.'' Britain has come under increasing pressure to try to free four hostages missing in Lebanon following the release of American captives Robert Polhill and Frank Reed, who strongly criticized British inaction. ``I do not rule out the possibility of direct talks if we felt that they were likely to produce results.
