But the restoration of diplomatic relations ... is certainly not a matter for us alone,'' Hurd told the House of Commons. ``We shall do everything we can to bring about the release of all the hostages _ short of making concessions or striking bargains with those who hold them _ because we want a safer world not a more dangerous one,'' he said. Hurd acknowledged the Syrian role in Reed's release but added: ``We broke with Syria in 1986 on the issue of state-supported terrorism _ an issue that remains unresolved. ``We have had indirect talks with them since then on behalf of the hostages.'' Britain cut diplomatic ties with Damascus for allegedly using its embassy in London to help plot the unsuccessful destruction of an Israeli jetliner at Heathrow Airport. Opposition Labor Party lawmaker Gerald Kaufman, referring to Reed's charge of British inaction, asked Hurd to say ``the government is active day-in, day-out in efforts to secure the release of the British hostages.'' Hurd agreed people had every right to expect ``day-in, day-out'' efforts and these were continuing. ``I have every sympathy with Mr. Frank Reed ... but he is not in any position to know anything about the efforts we have made on behalf of the British hostages,'' Hurd said. The hostages are Church of England envoy Terry Waite, journalist John McCarthy, retired pilot Jack Mann and Brian Keenan, a teacher who has dual British and Irish nationality. The Foreign Office says it also seeks word on Alec Collett, a New York-based British journalist whose Palestinian abductors claim they killed him. His body was never found. Former Liberal leader Sir David Steel suggested there was a case for considering the reopening of diplomatic links with Libya and Syria. Hurd said there were three ``substantial'' problems with Iran: the hostages, the imprisonment of Briton Roger Cooper on spying charges and the threat to kill Rushdie. Labor's Harry Barnes urged ministers to stop taking an ``intransigent stance'' in developing links with Iran and Syria and ``take a lead'' from the United States. ``I have discussed policy with the U.S. Secretary of State Mr. (James) Baker in the last few days and it is entirely on on all-fours with that of the U.S.,'' Hurd said. Lawmakers also criticized claims by British Moslem leader Sayed Quddus that Waite would be released by his Beirut captors only if Rushdie was extradited to Iran. Quddus, a former secretary of the council of mosques in Bradford who was one of the first Moslems in Britain to publicly burn Rushdie's novel, said he was told this during a recent visit to Iran. He said he was also told Waite is alive and well. Conservative lawmaker Gary Waller said the idea of extraditing Rushdie was ``totally outrageous.'' The British hostages are among 16 Westerners, including six Americans, believed held in Lebanon. The longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, who was abducted March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Report Blames U.S. for Some Civilian Deaths in Panama
DOC.TEXT: Failure by the U.S. military to issue a warning before attacking Panamanian Defense Force headquarters may have led to the deaths of dozens of civilians living nearby, a report said Wednesday. ``Some 15,000 persons were left homeless in the attack, and a very rough estimate is that 50 (to) 70 civilians were killed,'' according to the Americas Watch study conducted after the December invasion of Panama. ``Many more were seriously wounded,'' the report said. The Pentagon had no immediate comment. Americas Watch, which promotes human rights in Latin America and the Caribbean, contends that both the U.S. and Panamanian military violated international humanitarian law governing armed conflict. It said the U.S. military failed to observe the laws of war in its attack on the PDF headquarters, located in the midst of a poor Panama City neighborhood called El Chorrillo. The report gave little credence to allegations by some observers that forces loyal to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega were responsible for fires that broke out in El Chorrillo and left numerous civilian casualties. Noriega was ousted by the invading force and later brought to the United States for trial on drug trafficking charges. The study said U.S. military leaders were unable to cite military necessity, such as the need for surprise, as a reason for not informing El Chorrillo residents that an attack was imminent. Roman Catholic priests said in January that about 20 people died in El Chorrillo, many in a fire set by retreating paramilitary supporters of Noriega. They said that nearly 10,000 people sought refuge in the church and the school and a home for the elderly next to it. The Rev. Javier Arteta said members of the Panamanian paramilitary Dignity Battalions bear much of the blame for the casualties. ``They came out of their homes shooting in every direction,'' Arteta said, adding that the U.S. military never fired in the direction of the church. The Americas Watch report also said the U.S. military failed to follow the laws of war in refusing to free prisoners after hostilities ceased. Noriega's forces violated international law by taking civilian hostages and by dressing as civilians during the fighting, thus attracting fire and exposing innocent people to combat, the report said. The study said the U.S. Southern Command in Panama undercounted the number of civilian deaths. The Pentagon total was 202, but the report said 300 was ``more likely the real figure.'' Former U.S. Attorney General Ramsey Clark has estimated the death toll at 4,000 to 7,000, but the report said there was no basis for such a finding.

DOC.HEAD: Supporters Of Family Leave Bill Say Bush Flip-Flopped
DOC.NOTE: Eds: House has scheduled only procedural votes Wednesday night; this version may stand for AMs.
DOC.TEXT: Supporters of a bill guaranteeing unpaid time off for workers in family emergencies cited President Bush's own 1988 campaign rhetoric Wednesday, saying he supported provisions in an election year that he now threatens to veto. The House began debating the family and medical leave bill, with a vote scheduled for Thursday. Rep. Bill Green, R-N.Y., a liberal Republican who supports the bill, quoted Bush from a September 1988 campaign appearance in which he said the presidential candidate seemed to be supporting just such a measure. Bush, Green said, told a Republican women's group: ``We need to assure that women don't have to worry about getting their jobs back after having a child or caring for a child during a serious illness. That is what I mean when I talk about a gentler nation.'' Bush's press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said a day earlier that Bush would veto the bill if passed, and that while Bush urged employers to offer guaranteed job-protected leave, he opposed any bill requiring periods of leave. ``Let me note he used the word `assure,''' Green said, referring to Bush's campaign speech. ``He didn't say we should urge employers to do it. ... The only way we can do that is by legislation.'' The bill would require businesses with 50 or more employees to offer unpaid time off for the care of newborn, newly adopted or seriously ill children, as well as to deal with personal health problems or ill spouses or parents. House opponents of the bill charged it would be too costly and burdensome for businesses. Rep. James Quillen, R-Tenn., said it would reduce employers' flexibility in offering benefits to employees. ``This bill will do serious damage to many small businesses and medium-sized businesses,'' Quillen said. Rep. Bob Carr, D-Mich., charged his own party's leaders were using ``unfair and heavy-handed'' tactics and trying to ram the bill through without permitting moderate amendments. The family leave bill is the second of two major social issues that the White House has threatened to veto this year. A conference committee has been named to work out House and Senate differences on a broader bill providing designed to help families find and afford child care, which also is under a veto threat. Under the bill sent to the House floor, employers would have to offer up to 18 weeks of unpaid family leave over a two-year period and up to 15 weeks a year for a sick worker. A proposed substitute backed by the bill's bipartisan supporters and expected to be adopted would change that to 12 weeks in both cases. Under the bill, an employee returning from leave must be restored to his or her previous job or an equivalent position. Employers would have to continue health insurance benefits for those on leave. Women's groups supporting the bill contend that workers, particularly women, suffer substantial earnings losses after the birth of a child or during illnesses because many can't return to their jobs at the same pay. Business groups, including the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, opposed the bill. They charged it would be a costly burden for employers, hurting productivity. Although the bill requires employers to offer only unpaid leave, some opponents were concerned it could lead to later legislation requiring paid leave or other benefits. The presidential veto threat was backed up in a formal ``statement of administration policy'' sent to Congress by the Office of Management and Budget, saying the administration ``strongly opposes'' the bill. ``If this or any other mandated leave legislation were presented to the president, his senior advisers would recommend that it be vetoed,'' the statement said. It said the bill would ``induce employers to reduce overall employee benefits'' because of the expense of the new requirement.

DOC.HEAD: Proposal: Let Romanian Parliament Name President, Scrub Elections
DOC.TEXT: The two opposition candidates said Wednesday they would withdraw from the presidential race if interim President Ion Iliescu also agreed to step down and let a newly elected Parliament choose the president. The offer came after violence and a prolonged anti-government demonstration marred the first weeks of campaigning for the May 20 elections. Presidential candidates Ion Ratiu of the National Peasants' Party and Radu Campeanu of the National Liberal Party both suffered violent attacks during campaign appearances. Campeanu canceled campaign appearances this week after suffering cuts to the face in an assault in Braila on Saturday. He said he hoped the withdrawal ``would restore a climate of peace and stability'' to the country. The two opposition parties say supporters of Iliescu's National Salvation Front have disrupted their campaigns and are harassing their candidates. Wednesday's offer drew no immediate reply from Iliescu, who was out of Bucharest at large campaign rallies. The development highlighted the uncertainty surrounding the political process in Romania almost five months after the December revolution that ousted Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, and less than two weeks before elections. In separate ballots, voters are to choose a new parliament and a new president. Opinion polls _ whose reliability has been questioned by foreign observers _ heavily favor the Front and Iliescu, who have dominated politics since the revolution. A downtown Bucharest demonstration against Iliescu and the Front entered its 18th day Wednesday. About 2,000 people gathered to demand Iliescu's resignation and to shout slogans denouncing the Front as ``neo-communists.'' Leading former dissident Doina Cornea said she was joining 56 hunger strikers in the protest. Some have taken nothing but tea for 10 days. The demonstrators want former Communist officials such as Iliescu barred by law from politics. Campeanu and Ratiu made their offer to withdraw at the request of an anti-government group that wants the elections postponed. Police said Wednesday they detained five people responsible for the attack on Campeanu, and filed charges against two of them. A third was sent to a psychiatric hospital for examination. All were from 28 and 39 years old. The state news agency Rompres said a man with six previous criminal convictions was jailed for 18 months for disturbing the peace during a campaign appearance by Ratiu in Buzau, northeast of Bucharest, April 24. Iliescu meanwhile continued his campaign. State-run radio said 100,000 people attended Iliescu's rally in the central city of Brasov. In Liberty Square in Ploiesti, 38 miles north of Bucharest, about 20,000 enthusiastic Front supporters heard Iliescu dismiss the demands of the Bucharest demonstrators as an electoral maneuver. ``We love him because he took us out of Ceausescu's hell'' said Ion Radu, a 66-year-old peasant who was in the audience.

DOC.HEAD: `Nameless' Abortion Protesters Released
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with protesters released. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Ninety-five anti-abortion protesters held 11 weeks in a Vermont jail for failing to identify themselves after their arrests finally did so and were promptly released Wednesday. ``For some reason, they all agreed to give their names, be fingerprinted and signed a waiver of right to trial,'' said Edward Sutton, deputy state's attorney. Under the agreement, District Judge Matthew Katz then found them guilty of unlawful trespass, a misdemeanor punishable by a maximum of 90 days in jail. They were sentenced and released for time served. The protesters agreed to give their names after being told they would not have to pay bail or a fine and that no probation would be set on them, said their lawyer, Daniel Lynch. In addition, Lynch said, under the agreement they did not plead guilty to unlawful trespass; instead they admitted to the facts of the case and were found guilty by the judge. The 95 had been held without bail even though they were charged with only a misdemeanor because they refused to identify themselves in court. ``Many of us will be back,'' said Joan Andrews, 41, a founder of the anti-abortion ``rescue'' movement in 1979 who was among those jailed. ``If the movement here is being threatened again, I will certainly try to make it back.'' The protesters had been arrested following a series of sit-ins at two Burlington abortion clinics between Feb. 21 and April 17. ``Frankly, these people are not acting as individuals, but as followers of a few leaders'' said Sutton. ``They take orders.'' The protesters were jailed for up to 78 days, about a week more than they most likely would have been held had they been tried and convicted. During their arraignments, they had identified themselves as ``Baby Jane Doe'' and ``Baby John Doe.'' The judge's decision to hold them without bail for refusing to give their names is under appeal to the Vermont Supreme Court. Only eight of the 95 protesters were from Vermont. The rest were from Canada, California, Iowa, Michigan, New Mexico, Ohio, Tennessee, Texas, Washington state and the Northeast. In addition to Ms. Andrews, several national leaders of the anti-abortion movement were among those jailed. They included the Rev. Norman Weslin, 59, head of the Victim Souls for the Unborn Christ Child, headquartered in Mountlake Terrace, Wash. The jailing cost the state of Vermont $6,000 a day.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuania Premier: Republic Will Exhaust Fuel Supplies in 2 Weeks
DOC.TEXT: Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene said Wednesday transportation and industry in the breakaway Baltic republic will halt within two weeks because of the Soviet economic blockade. ``By May 25 we will have a crisis. ... Our reserves of crude oil will run out by then,'' she said. ``Because of a lack of black (crude) oil and fuel, light industry, transport and, in general, different branches of our economy will close.'' Mrs. Prunskiene, addressing a news conference after talks with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, said her administration is saving emergency fuel supplies for hospitals and schools, and was self-sufficient in food. Medicine was coming from Poland, she said. ``And we have luck on our side because summer is coming up,'' Mrs. Prunskiene told reporters, speaking through an interpreter. She reiterated that Lithuania will not rescind its March 11 declaration of independence, but again offered to compromise with Moscow by suspending subsequent laws on citizenship and property. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has refused to negotiate with the Baltic republic and retaliated against its declaration of independence with an economic blockade. She said it appeared doubtful Moscow would use force if the crisis worsened. ``Those who wanted to punish Lithuania have actually been satisfied,'' she said. Mrs. Prunskiene spoke at the end of a two-day visit to Britain, part of a tour to drum up support in the West. She arrived after meeting with President Bush in Washington and will travel from London to Paris and Bonn. She said Mrs. Thatcher was sympathetic during their 75-minute meeting but Mrs. Prunskiene appeared to have gained little in substance. Mrs. Prunskiene saw similar results after he meeting with Bush. Thatcher aides said Britain's priority remained not to upset Gorbachev. ``We don't want the apple cart upset, but we do sympathize with them (Lithuanians),'' said one British official, speaking on condition of anonymity. Mrs. Prunskiene, at the news conference at a house in west London's Notting Hill district used as a Lithuanian center, acknowledged that the West ``is not rushing to help.'' But she said she was encouraged by moves toward independence by the neighboring Baltic republics of Latvia and Estonia. ``I cannot imagine that the West will simply look on while Latvia and Estonia have sanctions imposed against them, while they are being suffocated,'' she said. Also Wednesday, Finnish President Mauno Koivisto, in an address before the 354-member parliamentary assembly of the Council of Europe, urged the three Baltic republics to negotiate with Moscow for their independence. Citing Finland's history of accomodation with the Soviet Union, he suggested the Baltic states offer Moscow neutrality in return for independence. ``Our own experience tells us that with a great power neighbor one has to reach negotiated solutions that will stand the test of time,'' Koivisto said. In 1948, Moscow pressured Finland into a friendship treaty guaranteeing Finnish neutrality and precluding anti-Soviet policies in Helsinki.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Says No Reason Not to Release Bloch Court Paper
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department on Wednesday urged a court to make public the pleadings filed by suspected spy Felix Bloch in his fight against State Department efforts to fire him. The Justice Department said in a court filing that Bloch had ``failed to demonstrate any reason'' why the court document his attorneys filed May 2 should not be placed in the public court file. Bloch's attorneys are challenging the government's attempt to use information obtained from foreign counterintelligence surveillance as evidence against the suspended diplomat in State Department administrative proceedings. Bloch's lawyers contend that the surveillances were illegal. The Justice Department has asked U.S. District Judge Stanley S. Harris to declare that the information was legally obtained and therefore can be used against Bloch in the termination hearing. The Justice Department has not brought criminal charges against Bloch, whom law enforcement sources say is suspected of having passed secrets to the Soviet Union while he was posted in Europe as a diplomat. There have been reports that French agents videotaped him passing a briefcase to a KGB agent in Paris. The Justice Department disputed the argument by Bloch's lawyers that the May 2 pleadings should kept under seal because they contain sensitive information. Bloch's memorandum ``contains no classified information and filing it on the public record of this case would not harm the national security nor impede the underlying administrative proceeding'' being conducted by the State Department, the Justice petition argued. Bloch's hearing was scheduled to begin this week, but it has been postponed. In a separate pleading, the Justice Department reiterated its opposition to an attempt by Bloch's lawyers to obtain access to all the audio tapes and transcripts of the electronic surveillances. Bloch's attorneys have received copies of the tapes and transcripts of the material the State Department wants to use. But the lawyers have asked Harris to order the government to turn over all the surveillance information. The FBI has filed an affidavit stating that further disclosures to Bloch would endanger national security. The Justice Department also rejected a suggestion by Bloch's attorneys that they could receive the material because they already have security clearances. Bloch's lawyers had pledged not to disclose any of the material to their client, but the Justice Department said this would place them in an untenable position. Bloch's lawyers ``would have access to materials their client has not seen (and cannot see),'' the department said. ``This fact would make it difficult or impossible for them to give proper advice to their client as Mr. Bloch attempts to make informed decisions throughout the litigation,'' the department said, noting Bloch might be confronted with the choice of ``whether or not to seek a settlement.'' Bloch's lawyers ``then would have a conflict of interest in representing their client,'' the department said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules in Favor of Three States Battling for River Control
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Wednesday sided with three states and ordered the Army of Corps of Engineers to maintain water levels at a huge Missouri River reservoir in order to protect the states' fishing industry. U.S. District Judge Patrick Conmy's ruling regarding Lake Oahe prompted shippers to begin moving barges off the Missouri's 730-mile shipping channel to keep them from being marooned as the river falls. The order will virtually halt navigation along the channel, which runs from Sioux City, Iowa, to St. Louis, said Chet Worm, chief of the corps' reservoir regulation branch in Omaha, Neb. Officials warned that power shortages also could result. The ruling was in response to a request by North Dakota, South Dakota and Montana. Those states' governors said the order could help end disputes over management of the drought-hit Missouri, at 2,540 miles the longest river in the United States. But spokesmen for Govs. Terry Branstad of Iowa and Kay Orr of Nebraska, two states downstream, criticized it. ``The news is very alarming,'' said Orr's legal counsel, Bud Cuca. Downstream states rely on the river for water for drinking, cooling power plants and sustaining fish and wildlife populations of their own, officials said. Conmy ordered the Corps of Engineers to maintain the reservoir at its current level until June 1, when the lake's walleyed pike hatch will have ended. South Dakota officials contend the hatch would have been destroyed had the corps been allowed to proceed with plans to lower the level by 3 feet this month. Lake Oahe spans both Dakotas and has a storage capacity of 23.3 million acre-feet, or enough water to put 23.3 million acres under 1 foot of water. The governors of Montana and the Dakotas contend the corps is sacrificing millions of dollars' worth of recreation and fishing interests in their states to provide enough water for shipping. The corps filed notice it would appeal Conmy's order, U.S. Attorney Steve Easton said. But South Dakota Gov. George Mickelson said the three states have already won. Even an expedited appeal is likely to take a few weeks, Mickelson said. Before it is decided, ``we will have accomplished most of what we set out to do,'' he said. ``There is justice after all, and this running battle has come to a temporary halt, at least,'' North Dakota Gov. George Sinner added. ``The water will stop flowing away from us, and we will stop being washed down the river.'' Attorneys for the corps argued the agency had balanced a number of disparate needs in deciding how to manage the flow of water from six upper Missouri dams. Sinner, Mickelson and Montana Gov. Stan Stephens said they intended no long-term harm to states along the lower Missouri. ``My intention is to ... get them to sit down with us and recognize the contemporary needs of all the states,'' Mickelson said. Governors of the Missouri Basin states plan to discuss the dispute next Wednesday in Des Moines, Iowa, following a meeting by the executive committee of the National Governors Association, Branstad said. Charles Findlay, a Justice Department attorney representing the corps, said it may have to reduce the Missouri's flow through August due to Conmy's order, to avoid harming two rare birds that nest near the river, the piping plover and the interior least tern. If that happens, electricity shortages could crop up downstream, said Omaha Public Power District spokesman Mark Gautier. Barge owners worried Wednesday that they might not be able to get their vessels off the river in time. ``We've got five barges up above Omaha right now,'' said Roger Blaske, co-owner of Blaske Marine Inc. of Alton, Ill. Depending on how fast the river falls, the barges could be stranded, Blaske said. ``I guess we'd just hang them up on a stump somewhere and hope they're there next fall,'' he said. Missouri River marinas also could be put out of business as the river drops an expected three feet as a result of the decision, said John Ferrell, a corps spokesman in Omaha, Neb. But Sinner, Mickelson and other officials say upper basin states have suffered virtually all the impact of a lingering drought entering its third year in the upper Great Plains. ``It's the worst drought in this century, and there's going to be losers,'' said former South Dakota Gov. William Janklow, the lead attorney in the three states' lawsuit. ``The point we make is there shouldn't be any winners,'' Janklow said. ``We should all suffer together.''

DOC.HEAD: Senate Rejects Rebating Union Dues For Political Activity
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Tops with 9 grafs on agreement to vote Thursday and other developments, picks up 2nd graf pvs: ``On a,''
DOC.TEXT: Republicans, losing several votes on amendments, abandoned efforts Wednesday night to stall Senate action on a bill loosening restrictions on political activities by government workers. GOP Leader Bob Dole of Kansas agreed to allow a vote late Thursday on final passage of the wholesale revisions in the 1939 Hatch Act, which now forbids federal employees from participating actively in partisan politics. Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said the Senate would then proceed to consideration Friday of rival campaign finance bills in the hope of finding a bipartisan compromise by the end of next week. Mitchell, however, acknowledged tat a compromise will require some backroom negotiations with Dole and others. In the meatime, he said, Democrats will try next week to pass a bill authorizing $300 million a year in emergency aid for 13 cities whose public health systems face collapse because of local AIDS epidemics. The 13 cities are Atlanta, Boston, Chicago, Dallas, Houston, Los Angeles, Miami, New York, Newark, N.J., Philadelphia, San Francisco, Washington and San Juan, Puerto Rico. Under the agreement on the bill to revise the Hatch Act, Republicans may offer nine more amendments, including one by Dole to continue the current restrictions on employees in intelligence agencies, the Justice Department, the Internal Revenue Service and the Federal Election Commission. A similar amendment by Dole was defeated 51-46 Tuesday. Earlier Wednesday, Democrats overwhelmingly beat back a Republican effort to make federal employee unions refund part of the dues paid by members who disgree with the organization's political stands or endorsements. On a 63-35 vote, the Senate rejected an amendment by Sen. Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., to force the dues rebates as part of a bill loosening restrictions on political activities by 3 million government civil service and postal workers. McConnell said his amendment would remove for federal workers the ``Hobson's choice'' of having to pick between getting out of a union and losing their voice in collective bargaining or accepting the use of a portion of their dues for political causes they don't support. A similar measure is one of the main features of the GOP's version of a campaign finance reform bill introduced Wednesday in the Senate. Both seek to write into law and expand a 1988 Supreme Court decision that workers who pay fees to labor organizations under union shop agreements can demand a rebate of any portion of those fees not devoted to collective bargaining. The bill, already approved in a broader form by the House, would lift most of the current off-the-job restrictions on political activities by government workers under the 51-year-old Hatch Act. Also defeated, on a 62-36 vote, was an amendment by Dole to let workers in each federal agency decide by majority vote whether to accept a loosening of the rules on their outside political activites. The Senate spent more than a week on the legislation, with majority Democrats joined by about a dozen Republicans rejecting a series of amendments by the GOP leadership to maintain the restrictions. President Bush's senior advisers have said they would urge him to veto any change in the law as ``undermining the integrity and independence of the traditionally non-partisan civil service.'' George Gould, a lobbyist for the National Association of Letter Carriers, said Wednesday the stream of amendments is an attempt by GOP leaders to ``slow the process to give the White House time to try to peel away votes.'' Senate GOP Whip Alan Simpson admitted Republicans lack the 40 votes needed to maintain a filibuster against the bill. He said the real test will come later when the White House asks Republican leaders to scrape together the 34 votes needed to sustain a veto by Bush. The House passed the bill by a veto-proof 297-90 majority in April, 1989. With the support of 17 Senate Republicans, Democrats in a test vote last week mustered a 70-28 majority _ also sufficient for overriding a veto _ over the GOP leadership's opposition to bring the bill to the Senate floor. The union-sought legislation would lift current restrictions that prohibit federal workers from attending state and national political conventions as delegates or holding other party office. The House version also would allow them to run for public office and solicit campaign funds from the public, acts that would continue to be prohibited under the Senate bill. McConnell's amendment would have required federal employee unions to mail out notices annually to all 3 million government employees, whether members of a union or not. The notices would have to say that union members are entitled to a dues reduction equal to a pro-rata share of what the organization spends on political activities.

DOC.HEAD: KGB May Have Played Role In Revolution, Commission Says
DOC.TEXT: The KGB may have played a role in the peaceful revolution by influencing Czechoslovak security forces, the state news agency CTK said Wednesday. The agency cited the sketchy findings of a parliamentary commission investigating the Nov. 17 attack on protesting students, an event that sparked the swift popular revolt against more than four decades of Communist rule. According to CTK, the commission said it had been unable despite six months of work to form a clear picture of events. ``The key to understanding the events of November 17 ... is especially in the obviously illogical inactivity of the ministry of Interior in the days that followed November 17,'' the commission reported, according to CTK. ``State security did virtually nothing, although it had precise reports on what was happening,'' the report continued. As quoted by CTK, it hinted without specifics that some kind of a ``second center'' existed inside the security forces and directed events. The report said the commission was ``so far unable to to expose all culprits, identify the `second center,' those who directed the events, and give the public a satisfactory explanation.'' The report said Lt. Gen. Antonin Lorenz, considered a key figure in the Interior Ministry, had dinner Nov. 17 with a man it identified only as Groshko, a deputy chairman of the KGB and chief of its counterintelligence. A KGB official reached by telephone in Moscow said Wednesday the organization has a deputy chairman named Viktor Grushko. The report said Lorenz made some 20 phone calls during the 90-minute meal. It said Lorenz visited Moscow in August and September, where he held talks with KGB chairman Vladimir Kryuchkov and both his first deputies. But it stressed the content of the talks was not known. Months before the uprising, rumors circulated in Prague hinting that Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was dissatisfied with the rigid Prague regime and pressing for more democratic change. Two days after the Nov. 17 beatings, dissidents established the Civic Forum movement that eventually guided the revolution. Strikes and street protests spread around the country by Nov. 20, unhindered by police. Police allowed the dissidents, otherwise detained ``on every significant anniversary, to establish in peace and quiet the Civic Forum and overthrow the regime,'' the report said. By Nov. 24, the orthodox chief of the Communist Party, Milos Jakes, and his Politburo allies had been ousted. Lorenz is currently in custody pending investigation of charges that he abused the power of a public official. Miroslav Stepan, a former Prague Communist Party boss, is also in custody pending results of a similar investigation. Stepan and Jakes have denied they ordered the attack Nov. 17. If found guilty, Stepan and Lorenz could spend up to 10 years imprisonment.

DOC.HEAD: U.S.-Iran Small Claims Accord Opens Way for Resolving Big Claims
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS, ADDS material throughout to underscore way cleared for trying to settle major Iranian and U.S. claims. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Iran
DOC.TEXT: The small claims agreement announced Wednesday opens the way for settling about $16 billion in claims that have been a major financial irritant between Iran and the United States for 10 years, both nations agree. An American official and an Iranian official at the Iran-United States Claims Tribunal in The Hague told The Associated Press the settlement will speed resolution of the big cases. Settlement of the major cases could help re-establish economic relations between the two nations, the American official said. The Iranian official denied, however, that better U.S.-Iran economic ties would result. ``The economic relationship depends on the political relationship,'' he said. ``If you don't have a good relationship in the political sector, how can you have a good relationship in the economic sector?'' Both officials spoke on condition of anonymity. Government-to-government talks are expected to begin soon on settlement of the Foreign Military Sales, or FMS, claim by Iran, which the Tehran government has put at about $11 billion. The largest case before the tribunal, it deals with military supplies ordered by Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi before his overthrow in the 1979 Islamic revolution. Washington disputes Tehran's figure as exaggerated, claiming that while some of the materiel is under U.S. embargo, much of it was never paid for and is being held by U.S. contractors. The American official said once small claims are settled, the tribunal will have more time for military equipment and oil claims. The nine-judge arbitration panel was established as part of the 1980 Algiers Accords, which gained freedom for the 52 Americans held hostage at the U.S. Embassy in Tehran by Iranian militants. The tribunal has presided over the settlement of more than $2.2 billion in financial disputes stemming from the Iranian revolution, resulting expropriations and broken contracts. The oil expropriation claims, filed by the American oil giants Amoco, Arco and Sun, and by consortiums of smaller firms, total about $5 billion. ``A key to their (Iran's) economic recovery is settling all of them,'' the American official said. ``Settlement of these cases, particularly if they entailed a softening of U.S. import restrictions on Iranian oil, would reflect and accelerate a thawing.'' A reopening of the U.S. oil market to Iran is considered vital to the Iranians, who depend on oil exports for about 90 percent of their foreign exchange earnings. ``They're desperate for hard currency,'' said the American official. The small claims talks have been held almost monthly between the State Department's chief legal adviser, Judge Abraham Sofaer, and Iran's Jaromi Eftekhar. Sofaer is due to resign from his State Department position next month and the American tribunal official said Sofaer is expected to begin settlement talks before then with Iran on the FMS claim, known as B1. ``Without the small claims, the tribunal will have more resources to devote to B1 and the oil claims,'' said the American. A more speculative question is whether resolution of the military equipment and oil cases could provide the goodwill gesture sought by Tehran in response to the recent release of American hostages Robert Polhill and Frank Reed, who were held by pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem militants in Lebanon. The American official and Iran have denied any link between agreement on small claims and the release. Resolution of the FMS and oil cases would allow the Tribunal to shut down after almost a decade as the only official forum between Iran and the United States, which broke off diplomatic relations following the 1979 hostage-taking. ``If we do all the things necessary to close it down, doors will have been opened in the process,'' said the American tribunal official. ``It would result in improved good will.''

DOC.HEAD: Army Eases Curfew, Diplomats Fearful of Attacks by Communist Rebels
DOC.TEXT: U.S. officials allowed American troops to leave their bases Wednesday for the first time since the weekend slaying of a Marine, and U.S. diplomats began changing license plates to prevent identification by insurgents. Also Wednesday, prosecutors ordered police to release three suspects in the killing of Gunnery Sgt. John Fredette, 34, saying the arrests were flawed and evidence linking the men to the slaying was insufficient. Police have refused to obey the court order pending approval from the chief of police and the mayor, officials said. Assistant prosecutor Dorentino Floresca said his ruling does not absolve the three in the slaying of Fredette but added that evidence presented by the police against them is ``not convincing.'' He ordered police to submit additional evidence against the suspects within five working days. On Tuesday, police Lt. Col. Macarthur Torres said Renato Angeles, 38, a former Subic base worker, confessed to having accidentally killed Fredette in a robbery attempt. But on Wednesday Angeles denied he made such a confession. Police earlier speculated Fredette was shot by Communist rebels, who have threatened to kill American service members. Angeles and two other men were arrested earlier this week. Adm. Roger Rich, senior U.S. military commander in the Philippines, banned off-post leaves Saturday after Fredette was murdered near the Subic Bay naval base, 50 miles west of Manila. In a statement Wednesday, the U.S. military said the 40,000 U.S. troops, Defense Department civilians and military dependents would be allowed to leave the six American installations effective immediately but must return between midnight and 5:30 a.m. Americans who do not live on the bases must return to their homes during the curfew period, the statement said. ``In view of the current situation and continuing, potential threats against U.S. military and military-associated personnel, a curfew from midnight to 5:30 for all U.S. military personnel at all military installations in the Republic of the Philippines has been instituted,'' the statement said. The order applies to troops at Subic Base, Clark Air Base and the four smaller U.S.-run installations. Local communities near the bases depend heavily on spending by American service members. Despite the relaxation, U.S. officials said they remained concerned that the Marxist New People's Army may try to kill Americans before talks begin Monday on extending the lease on the bases. The lease expires in September 1991 and the Marxist rebels have demanded the expulsion of U.S. troops from the Philippines. On Wednesday, sources in the American community said the U.S. Embassy ordered diplomats to replace their distinctive, diplomatic license tags with regular car plates. American diplomats have already been varying their routes to work and staggering office hours to reduce the possibility of an ambush. The State Department also is considering increasing hazardous duty pay for embassy employees.

DOC.HEAD: Alaska Legislature Passes Several Oil-Spill Bills
DOC.TEXT: One legacy of the Exxon Valdez disaster has been several ``spill bills'' to strengthen Alaska's pollution laws, but two tough anti-spill measures have run aground on legislative shoals. Gov. Steve Cowper said Wednesday he was pleased with the bills that passed before Tuesday night's adjournment deadline, but he said the oil industry had played a major role in preventing stronger bills from passing. ``They weakened the legislation that passed and they probably were instrumental in stopping the bills that didn't get through,'' Cowper said. The Democratic-controlled House sent six oil-spill bills to the Republican-led Senate, which killed a major enforcement bill. House Republicans, meanwhile, stopped the only Senate-passed bill in their chamber. In addition, some provisions on bills that passed were weakened by the Legislature, Cowper said. Nonetheless, he said, state, industry and federal government measures since the spill will help prevent another disaster like the Exxon Valdez, the worst oil spill in the nation's history. The tanker struck a charted reef on March 24, 1989, and spilled nearly 11 million gallons of North Slope crude in the hitherto pristine waters of Prince William Sound. Walt Parker, chairman of the Alaska Oil Spill Commission which investigated the Exxon Valdez disaster, said the oil industry's ``massive lobbying presence'' against the bills was understandable. ``It is their No. 1 priority to have no state involvement in the oil transportation system,'' Parker said. A House bill that would set strict standards for oil-industry cleanup plans, including a 72-hour requirement for response to major spills, had to wait until the final hours of the session before winning Senate approval. ``It's not a performance standard, it's a planning standard,'' said Dennis Kelso, commissioner of the state Department of Environmental Conservation. The measure also requires companies either to prove they can pay spill cleanup costs or risk a state shutdown of their operations. Although revamped in Senate committee, ``The bill is still worth having,'' Kelso said. A tough enforcement and inspection bill died in the Senate Resources Committee when the session adjourned. The original bill would have let the Department of Environmental Conservation order companies to pay for independent audits of pollution problems. The Senate version said companies could refuse the state's request. The Senate Judiciary panel removed a provision allowing warrantless searches of suspected polluters, replacing it with a plan allowing such searches only if agreed on as part of the company's operating permit. The bill also was changed to give companies more time to obey state compliance orders for correcting violations of environmental laws. House Republicans blocked passage of a Senate bill that would have increased municipal access to the state's oil-spill fund, which is financed by a 5-cent-a-barrel tax on Alaska oil production. The new tax was instituted last year as an immediate response to the tanker accident, and the bill would have increased municipal access to the fund for cleanup and other emergency costs. Other bills that won legislative approval and were sent to the governor include measures that would: _ increase criminal penalties for negligent operation of oil tankers. _ establish a citizens' oversight council on oil and other hazardous substances. _ establish state management plans for oil-spill response efforts. _ increase corporate fines for negligence in oil spills and other crimes.

DOC.HEAD: At Least 8 Arrested at Pro-Democracy Meeting
DOC.TEXT: At least eight opposition figures have been arrested at a pro-democracy meeting, and the Interior Ministry said Wednesday that they have been detained for attending an illegal gathering. Former members of Kuwait's parliament, apparently stepping up their campaign for broader representation in the oil-rich Persian Gulf monarchy, claimed 20 arrests from a packed meeting house Tuesday. The fully elected Parliament was dissolved in 1986 and replaced by an transitional National Council, in which 25 of its 75 members are appointed. The opposition bloc, which includes 32 of the previous Parliament's 50 members, is pressing to cancel elections for the 4-year-old council and restore the fully elected house. The crown prince and prime minister, Sheik Saad Abdullah Sabah, had warned against using the meeting halls, known as diwaniyas, for political rallies ahead of the council elections set for June 10. ``Accordingly, security men were obliged to apply the law and disperse an illegal rally Tuesday night ... after the owner failed to respond to the security men's order to disperse the meeting,'' an Interior Ministry statement said. Eight people were arrested ``when they tried to impede security men carrying out their duty,'' it said. ``Those arrested are being interrogated as a prelude for referring them to the public prosecution to decide what measures should be taken against them.'' The arrests took place as registration of candidates running in the June election was drawing to a close. The official Kuwait news agency announced 567 candidates registered by the filing deadline on Wednesday. The opposition group of 32 had declared a boycott of the election campaign. The government insisted it needed a transitional period to find the means to limit the criticism the parliamentarians used to direct at government ministers. Government officials have said the elected Parliament, outlined in the constitution, will be restored eventually.

DOC.HEAD: Antiguans Quiz Israeli Colonel on Errant Arms Shipment
DOC.TEXT: An investigating team from Antigua questioned Israeli reserve Col. Yair Klein about a shipment of Israeli arms to the Caribbean island that instead was diverted to a Colombian drug lord, Klein's attorney said Wednesday. Attorney Yigal Shapiro said the four Antiguan investigators spent hours over inner talking with Klein, and added it was unlikely he would be questioned further. ``From our point of view, the answers given by the government of Israel clear us, and I don't think it is necessary (to meet again),'' he said The Antiguans, headed by the U.N. diplomat Patrick Lewis, were given a file of 53 documents by Foreign Ministry officials on Tuesday. The file included an end-user certificate bearing the signature of Vere Bird Jr., Antigua's top defense official, assuring Israel the arms would be used exclusively by the island's military and not sent on to a third country. A ministry official, demanding anonymity, said the Israelis asked the Antiguans ``some hard questions on how the end-use agreement was violated.'' The delegation is also expected to meet with the captain of the ship that carried the weapons to Antigua and a military officer who accompanied the arms. Shapiro said Klein had no information on how the arms got to Colombia and that the Antiguans gave no sign they planned to take legal steps against Klein. The New York Times identified Klein and Maurice Sarfati, an Israeli who was a businessman in Antigua, as the men responsible for the arms diversion. Colombian officials said Klein is wanted for organizing, training, and equipping paramilitary groups. Klein said earlier the weapons were paid for by Panamanian exiles and intended for a military training camp set up in Antigua for Panamanian rebels opposed to Manuel Noriega, the country's de facto leader now deposed and awaiting trial on drug charges in Florida. After plans for the camp fell through, Klein said the Panamanians wanted the arms shipped to Panama but they wound up in the hands of Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, a drug boss killed by Colombian police last December. Israel television said Sarfati, acting as special envoy for Antigua, came to Israel and arranged for a ship from Ashdod to carry a 10-ton container marked ``dangerous material'' which contained Israeli-made weapons and rockets. The vessel sailed for Antigua under a Panamanian flag. The cargo was supposed to be transferred to a ship named Sea Point which was bound for Panama, but instead continued on to Colombia, the TV said. The TV said the Antiguans planned to meet the captain. The Jerusalem Post identified the ship as the Else PH, owned by Svendbog Enterprises of Denmark, and said it sailed from Haifa on March 28, 1989, bound for Chile. It arrived in Antigua on April 24.

DOC.HEAD: Judge: Resources to Be Split Equally Between Indians, Non-Indians
DOC.TEXT: A judge who once granted Chippewa Indians 100 percent of the fish caught in northern Wisconsin ruled Wednesday that the region's ``harvestable natural resources'' should be divided 50-50 between Indians and non-Indians. U.S. District Judge Barbara Crabb's decision, which came in a case that set parameters for deer hunting, has sweeping implications that limit the tribe's right to half the available fish and timber in northern Wisconsin, lawyers said. Under treaties that ceded the northern third of the state to the United States in the 19th century, Wisconsin's six Chippewa bands retain the right to spearfish, hunt and cut timber off-reservation on public lands in the region. Since a court affirmed the treaties in 1983, the Chippewa have exercised their spearfishing rights on northern lakes, encountering huge and sometimes violent protests by opponents who claim the special treaty rights are unfair and threaten to deplete fish and timber resources. Wednesday's decision contrasts with Mrs. Crabb's previous ruling that the Chippewa are entitled to 100 percent of the ``safe allowable'' catch of fish in the 23,929 square miles of territory ceded in the 19th century. State lawyers said the new ruling essentially alters the previous decision. ``It's our understanding of this decision that it does not apply only to deer, but that it applies to all natural resources,'' Attorney General Donald Hanaway said. ``And I think that's extremely significant.'' Mrs. Crabb's office said the judge would not further interpret her intentions beyond what was stated in her 74-page decision. Since the 1983 court ruling, the Chippewa bands have filed a series of lawsuits asking the court to define how much of the resources of northern Wisconsin they are entitled to under the treaties and to what degree the state can regulate tribal activities. Tribal attorneys declined immediate comment on the ruling. But Tom Maulson, a Lac du Flambeau Chippewa spearfishing coordinator and a leader in the treaty rights group Wa-Swa-Gon Treaty Association, said the philosophy of sharing the resource has been supported by the tribe for years. Maulson said the split in allocation of resources did not unfairly deprive the Chippewa of their rights. ``I bet the tribe will never touch 50 percent,'' he said. ``We say the resource is for everybody. Maybe they'll start to realize that what we've wanted all along.'' Administration Secretary James Klauser, the top aide to Gov. Tommy G. Thompson, said Wednesday's ruling was significant because it recognizes ``the non-Indian right to the resources. ``The important findings are that the treaty provisions only apply to public lands and the state has regulatory authority for the hunting seasons,'' he added. The leader of an anti-treaty group said the latest ruling wouldn't anger non-Indians and could lead to a solution to tensions over tribal rights. ``I think she's beginning to open the door to cooperation, to open the door for settlement between all parties,'' said Larry Peterson of the Protect Americans' Rights and Resources. The judge said she was setting the deer limit for the Chippewa at 50 percent of the estimated population based on the tribe's ``needs for a moderate standard of living'' and to ``prevent the frustration of the non-Indian treaty right.''

DOC.HEAD: Socialist Government Survives No-Confidence Vote
DOC.TEXT: The Socialist government narrowly defeated a no-confidence motion introduced after a politician was granted amnesty under a widely unpopular law that had been sponsored by the governing party. Only 262 deputies voted for the motion, 27 short of the majority needed in the 577-seat National Assembly. If the motion had succeeded, Premier Michel Rocard's government would have been forced to resign, leaving President Francois Mitterrand to name a new prime minister or call legislative elections. It was the fifth failed no-confidence motion since Mitterrand was re-elected in 1988. The assembly passed the Socialist-proposed amnesty bill in December, with all Communist deputies and many rightists voting against it. The amnesty came as politicians and newspapers began reporting that kickbacks on public contracts had become a major source of funding for nearly all the established parties. The opposition says it understood the amnesty law would protect contributors but exclude members of the assembly. They claim the government misrepresented the bill and were especially angered when former Cooperation Minister Christian Nucci received amnesty in the financial scandal. The amnesty has contributed to Mitterrand's decline in public opinion polls. Only 39 percent of French citizens expressing approval with his performance in a recent newspaper survey.

DOC.HEAD: Discharged Navy Cadet Says He'll Help Other Gay ROTC Students
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 10th graf, `Smith said ...,' to UPDATE with Studds saying third Navy case reported; picks up 11th graf, `The Defense ...'
DOC.TEXT: The Navy's decision to let two gay ROTC cadets keep their scholarships could signal hope that a Pentagon policy barring homosexuals from the armed services might one day be abolished, activists said Wednesday. ``I think the military realizes that it needs to change and is fully working towards it,'' said discharged cadet Robert Bettiker, a chemistry major at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The Navy had ordered Bettiker and all other ROTC cadets who are homosexuals to reimburse the government for all tuition payments. But this week, Bettiker and another discharged cadet, Harvard University graduate David Carney, received letters from the Navy exempting them from the tuition demand. The Navy had been seeking $38,612 in tuition from Bettiker and $50,687 from Carney. ``I'm not exactly sure what it all means,'' Bettiker said. ``My lawyer and I will talk and see how this will help other people. I'm willing to do my part.'' Bettiker, 22, had wanted to enter the Navy's Nuclear Propulsion Program, but has instead decided to work at a cancer research laboratory at the University of California, Berkeley after graduation. Carney, 23, is working toward a masters degree in management at Templeton College in Oxford, England. While in the reserve corps, he was working toward a submarine assignment as a nuclear engineer. Navy Lt. Greg Smith said ``there was no real information provided'' about the Navy's about-face, but said the decision was related only to the Cambridge students' cases. The decision ``was handed down on a personal review of the cases that were involved and the Navy elected in these instances to not require them to repay the money,'' Smith said in a telephone interview from Washington, D.C. Smith said Bettiker and Carney were so far the only two former cadets to receive such a dispensation. He said the decision would not exempt them from the broader Pentagon policy barring homosexuals from ROTC and military service. Rep. Gerry Studds, D-Mass., who is gay, complained in a letter to Navy Secretary H. Lawrence Garrett III that he had learned of a third homosexual naval ROTC cadet from whom the Navy was seeking repayment. Studds released his letter but declined to identify the cadet. ``Must I look forward to hearing from midshipman after midshipman who has been ordered to repay funds which _ as the Navy acknowledged with regard to Carney and Bettiker _ he should not be required to pay?'' Studds wrote. The Defense Department issued a statement in March saying it views homosexuality as ``incompatible with military service'' for reasons of morale, discipline and security. Carney said that while he disagrees with the policy, he harbored no animosity about being rejected from the ROTC. ``I don't like the fact that an institution in our American society had this particular policy. But that policy does not make the Navy an institution filled with evil people,'' Carney said in a telephone interview from England. Mary Bonauto, Bettiker's lawyer, welcomed the Navy's decision but said she was ``looking at it as a crack in a very large wall.'' ``They haven't changed their policy, they simply made an exemption,'' she said. James Holobaugh, a former Army ROTC member at Washington University in St. Louis, was awaiting word on a similar appeal. Holobaugh, 24, was due to receive his Army commission last May. But after informing his superiors that he had come to the realization that he was gay, an Army professor recommended the cadet be denied commission and be ordered to pay back $25,000 in scholarship money. ``I think it's nice that the Navy admitted that it's wrong for going after the money,'' said Holobaugh, who is enrolled at the University of New Haven in Connecticut. ``But the money is not the issue here.'' Army spokesman Maj. Joseph L. Allred said the Army would consider appeals on a case-by-case basis and would not be swayed by the Navy's recent decisions regarding Bettiker and Carney.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Opens Higher in Hong Kong
DOC.TEXT: Gold rose 95 cents an ounce on Hong Kong markets Thursday, opening at $372.27. It closed at $371.32 Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Arkansas River Crests as Floods Keep More Than 500 Homes Under Water
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 3-4, `Flooding began ...,' with 5 grafs to ADD Texas, Oklahoma flooding, background; picks up 5th graf, `Officials say ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos LR4, XPB4, XPB6, TRK2, TRK4
DOC.TEXT: The rain-bloated Arkansas River reached its highest level in 37 years Wednesday in flooding that put more than 500 homes under water and has drowned or trapped hundreds of cattle, officials said. The river began slowly receding after cresting Wednesday morning at 47.5 feet at Pine Bluff about 40 miles southeast of Little Rock, the highest it's been since reaching 52.1 feet in 1943, the National Weather Service said. Floods that swamped Texas and Oklahoma as well as Arkansas began late last week following heavy rains. Rains and flooding have claimed 12 lives in Texas and one in Oklahoma, but none in Arkansas, officials said. In Texas, where 4,000 homes have been damaged or destroyed by flooding, up to 400 volunteers, National Guard soldiers and officials patrolled levees near the Arkansas line that threatened to give way on the swollen Red River. Residents of flooded sections of Dallas tried to save what they could from homes under several feet of water. Others began cleaning up. Several hundred homes were flooded in Oklahoma, but ``the waters are starting to go down,'' said Civil Defense spokesman Richard Hill. ``There's still a lot of places we can't physically reach.'' In Arkansas, about 300 homes in Jefferson County, which includes Pine Bluff, were flooded Wednesday, and more than 200 homes were underwater along the river from that county to Fort Smith on the Oklahoma line, authorities said. About 16,000 sandbags were sent to Jefferson County. Officials say it's difficult to estimate the number of people evacuated, because most are staying with friends or relatives rather than at emergency shelters. About 400 cattle were missing from herds along the river basin and were believed to have drowned, said Arkansas Cattlemen's Association President Walt Rowden. Officials continue to watch the weather, said Army Corps of Engineers spokesman Ron Helton. ``Our biggest concern now is ... rain,'' Helton said. ``Our lakes are full and they can't handle any more water, so it will have to come down river.'' The White House may declare Arkansas a federal disaster area later this week, state and federal officials said at a news conference at Little Rock's Riverfront Park as the river rolled by at 440,000 cubic feet per second. People could begin receiving federal assistance as early as Monday if the declaration is signed before the weekend, said Joe Brady, operations supervisor for the state Office of Emergency Services. No firm estimates on damage were available, officials said. Brady estimated damage to roads and bridges at about $10 million, but said that figure is expected to escalate. ``There's no way to get precise counts'' until the water recedes, he said. The floods have caused millions of dollars' worth of damage to farmers. In Jefferson County alone, the flooding is expected to cause an estimated $20 million in damages, including reduced rice and cotton crops, said Frank Plafcan of the county extension office. Direct losses to cattle ranchers across the river basin are expected to top $250,000, and expected higher feed costs due to hay and alfalfa crops now underwater will add to ranchers' woes, Rowden said. Bradley Harris, regional director for the Federal Emergency Management Agency, said he expects state emergency officials, assisted by FEMA personnel, to complete preliminary damage surveys by Thursday or Friday. That information will be forwarded to the White House. In another development, corps officials continued to discount complaints the flooding was worse because of mismanagement along the McClellan-Kerr Arkansas River Navigation System. Buddy Dyke of Swan Lake, where about 35 families have been forced to leave their homes, complained about misinformation from the corps. ``They said it was going to crest on Monday, then Tuesday, then Wednesday, then in Pine Bluff on Thursday,'' said Buddy Dyke of Swan Lake, where about 35 families have been forced to leave their homes. ``It'll probably be here on Friday.'' He said the river rose several feet higher than residents were told to expect. Cut off from land, they didn't have time to move out valuables. Col. Charles McCloskey with the Little Rock district of the Army Engineers said in Little Rock that water would have been higher in most places without the navigation system, and said the system worked like it was supposed to. P.J. Spaul, another corps spokesman, said earlier this week that flood damage would have been three to four times greater without the levee system. The reservoir system in Oklahoma prevented another $10.5 million in damages in Arkansas, he said. Among those with trapped cattle was state Rep. Lloyd George of Danville, who has about 150 head stranded on 40 dry acres on a 2,000-acre pasture. ``Obviously, that's not enough for them to feed on,'' said George, who's paying $100 a day to feed cattle that otherwise would graze. ``I'm concerned about these cattle,'' he said. ``If I have to keep feeding them it gets expensive.''

DOC.HEAD: Congressmen Say No Recollection Of Discussing Contra Aid With North
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS penultimate graf pvs with two grafs to detail North's hostage involvement
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Richard Lugar and Rep. Henry Hyde said Wednesday they have no recollection of discussions about assisting the Contras which turned up in newly released portions of Oliver North's notebooks. In a March 4, 1985 meeting about the Contras, Hyde, R-Ill., brought up ``private efforts, 3rd countries _ Taiwan, Saudi Arabia,'' according to an entry on one of 1,400 pages of North's notebooks. In 1985 during a U.S. military aid ban to the Contras, Saudi Arabia was providing them with $1 million a month. Taiwan contributed $1 million to the rebel force in mid-1985. Hyde says he didn't know anything about the Saudi contributions at the time. Assuming North's notes are correct, Hyde said he probably suggested Taiwan and Saudi Arabia as possible donors because they were anti-communist. North's notes say the comments came in a meeting about the Contras between national security adviser Robert McFarlane and four congressmen. McFarlane had arranged the Saudi contributions in 1984. Hyde, a staunch backer of the Reagan administration in the Iran-Contra affair, said ``I may have'' suggested third-country contributions on other occasions, but had ``no inkling'' that they were actually occurring until the congressional hearings into the Iran-Contra affair. Lugar, R-Ind., was told by Contra leader Adolfo Calero and national security adviser John Poindexter about Ilopango air base, a key link in the Contra resupply operation, according to North's notebook. ``Calero-JMP _ both told Lugar that Ilopango was active,'' says a Jan. 9, 1986 entry. Lugar has ``no recollection'' of being told such information, said his press secretary, David Shapiro. Lugar has said he was unaware in 1985 and 1986 of the arming of the Contras in contravention of the Boland Amendment restrictions. Meanwhile, the White House declined to make any substantive comment about a newly disclosed entry suggesting North met with President Bush on Aug. 6, 1986, the day the vice president returned from a trip to the Middle East. The apparent North-Bush meeting occurred a few hours after the White House aide lied to the House intelligence committee by denying he was offering military advice to the Contras. In connection with Iran, North received a call that day from Amiram Nir, the main Israeli contact regarding arms sales to Iran. Three days earlier, 240 spare parts for Hawk missiles had been delivered to Iran. Bush has said he didn't learn the full details of the Iran initiative until Dec. 20, 1986. But on July 29, 1986 during his Mideast trip, he met with Nir in Jerusalem and was briefed on it. Bush chief of staff Craig Fuller took notes saying that ``we are dealing with the most radical elements'' in Iran. ``The various committees, both congressional and independent counsel, have looked at all these matters and we don't have anything to add beyond that,'' said White House spokesman Roman Popadiuk. Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., suggested Tuesday that the page of North's notebooks pointing to a meeting with Bush apparently wasn't turned over to Congress. ``I don't know which parts were or were not made available to the Congress,'' said the White House spokesman. ``But I know that basically the independent counsel and the congressional investigating committees have been provided all kinds of material including North's materials, so ... we will not comment on it.'' North's other notebook entries for the morning of Aug. 6, 1986 referred to conversations with others in the U.S. government, including Elliott Abrams, then assistant secretary of state for inter-American affairs, and Col. James Steele, a U.S. military adviser in El Salvador, as well as then-Associated Press Washington bureau chief Charles J. Lewis. Terry Anderson, the AP's chief Middle East correspondent, is one of the U.S. hostages. North directed the Reagan administration's efforts to win release of hostages by selling arms to Iran and was the National Security Council staff member in charge of hostage matters. North also met about a month later with AP President Louis D. Boccardi to discuss Anderson's situation, according to notes supplied to a special presidential commission that investigated the Iran-Contra affair.

DOC.HEAD: Man Found Guilty of Trying to Poison Oak
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with details.
DOC.TEXT: A jury Wednesday found a man guilty of trying to poison the historic Treaty Oak, a centuries-old tree that was severely damaged by the powerful herbicide Velpar. Paul Stedman Cullen, 46, faces a possible life sentence because of a prior conviction. He has been jailed since his arrest in June 1989. State District Judge Bob Perkins scheduled the sentencing phase of the trial for Thursday. Cullen stood expressionless as the verdict was read after about three and one-half hours of deliberation. He refused to comment as he was led from the courtroom. Prosecutors contended that Cullen used the powerful herbicide Velpar to poison the centuries-old live oak tree in a ritual apparently designed to end his affection for his counselor at a methadone clinic. Legend has it that the giant live oak, estimated to be at least 500 years old, was the site of a treaty signing between Stephen F. Austin and Indians during the 1820s. Prosecutors during the 1{-week trial produced a tape recording in which Cullen told Cindy Blaco he had killed the tree, adding, ``The only evidence is my mouth.'' Cullen's defense lawyers said Cullen was lying to try to impress Ms. Blaco, who secretly taped the conversation for police. They contended that Ms. Blaco may have been testifying to collect more than $11,000 in rewards. The defense also called witnesses who said Cullen wasn't interested in the occult but was prone to telling outrageous lies. Ms. Blaco testified that during February 1989, when experts believe the tree was poisoned, Cullen had several books on witchcraft and the occult. She also testified that she saw two containers of Velpar in the back of Cullen's truck that month. Since the poisoning was discovered last Memorial Day, more than $100,000 has been donated as city foresters and outside experts have taken extraordinary measures to save the tree. Velpar-contaminated earth was removed from around its roots, the tree has been doused with spring water and shaded by elaborate sun screens. But foresters say at least half the oak is dead. News reports about the tree's plight have brought visitors and get-well messages from around the world.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Assails Mexican Rich, Criticizes Capitalism
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with pope ordaining 100 priests, details; CLARIFIES papal remarks regarding consumerism, births. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos XDUR1,3
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II, speaking to an audience of Mexico's wealthiest businessmen, assailed the idea that capitalism has beaten socialism and said Wednesday that Mexico is ``still very far from the ideal of justice.'' He said the poor had suffered the worst consequences of Mexico's economic crisis and accused the small, powerful upper-class of generating even more poverty. ``The events of recent history ... have been interpreted, sometimes in a superficial way ... as the triumph of the liberal capitalist system,'' John Paul said in a speech in Durango, a provincial capital 450 miles northwest of Mexico City. ``Some interests would like to take the analysis to the extreme of presenting the system they consider the `winner' as the only way for our world.'' But he said that conclusion avoids ``the necessary critical judgment about the effects that liberal capitalism has produced ... in the so-called Third World countries.'' On the fourth day of his trip here, the pope earlier Wednesday visited a state prison and spent 20 minutes greeting and blessing inmates, including murderers and drug traffickers. Wednesday evening, the pope ordained 100 new priests during a Mass in a local plaza attended by 200,000 people. The novices prostrated themselves as the pope prayed, then knelt before John Paul one by one as he placed his hands on their shoulders to indicate the transmission of the spirit of God. His message to Latin America's business people also appeared aimed at U.S. officials and intellectuals who have pushed the idea that Western capitalism beat communism with the upheaval in Eastern Europe. It was the Polish-born pontiff's strongest warning yet not to gloat over communism's decline and not to ignore the problems of materialism and poverty. John Paul used the economic situation in this nation of 85 million people as an example of the failings of capitalism. ``The last few years have seen the deterioration of buying power, and phenomena typical of the organization of the economy, such as inflation, have produced painful effects at all levels,'' he said. ``It is necessary to repeat once again: it is always the weakest who suffer the worst consequences, because they see themselves closed in a spiral of growing poverty.'' Mexico's economic crisis exploded in 1982 due to overborrowing and plunging prices for crude oil, the country's main export. The average Mexican's buying power was cut in half between 1982 and 1988. Mexico, ``despite the inherent resources that the Creator gave this country, is still very far from the ideal of justice,'' the pope said before noting the vast contrast between the rich few and the poor majority. He said foreign creditors were not the only cause of Mexico's economic problems. The pontiff said that by taking too big a share of the country's resources, the very wealthy accumulated a ``wealth that is a generator of poverty'' for others. John Paul asked business leaders in overwhelmingly Roman Catholic Mexico to create more jobs, pay proper salaries and protect the environment. He said the economic interests of capitalism often ``fomented the consumer culture'' of consumerism and materialism. Those same interests also sometimes instigated ``campaigns against natality,'' he said _ a reference to those who support artificial means of lowering the birthrate. Gen. Agustin Vallejo Alvarez meanwhile said he had no evidence to substantiate Mexican press reports that Japanese Red Army terrorists were stalking the pope. ``That's journalistic rumor,'' said Vallejo, commander of the 10th military region headquartered in Durango. ``We don't have any special alert.'' At the prison, John Paul urged prisoners not to lose hope because ``Christ never loses hope in his creatures.'' ``The worst prison would be a closed and hardened heart,'' he said. He broke schedule to wade into a crowded prison yard as a convict chorus sang Beethoven's ``Ode to Joy.'' He was supposed to greet one prisoner _ a man who killed his wife. But John Paul ordered a gate opened and strolled into the yard, greeting and blessing prisoners for 20 minutes.

DOC.HEAD: Quake Jolts Western Australia
DOC.TEXT: An earthquake registering 4.5 on the Richter scale rocked parts of Western Australia state on Wednesday, scientists said. There were no immediate reports of damage or injuries. The Bureau of Mineral Resources said the earthquake's epicenter was 110 miles northeast of the state capital of Perth, between the towns of Miling and Ballidu. A quake of magnitude 4 can cause moderate damage in populated areas; a quake of magnitude 5 can cause considerable damage. Residents of the farming community of Cadoux, 124 miles north of Perth, said buildings shook and there was a loud rumbling noise. The quake struck at about 2.45 a.m. (12:45 p.m. EDT Tuesday). On Dec. 28, 1989, a quake measuring 5.5 killed 12 people and caused widespread damage in the northern coastal city of Newcastle.

DOC.HEAD: 12 Die in Rebel Attack
DOC.TEXT: Rebels attacked a police headquarters to try to seize arms for a guerrilla campaign, and 12 people were killed, President Ali Saibou said Tuesday. He said six rebels, three security force members and three civilians died in the attack, which occurred Monday at Tchintabaraden, 642 miles northeast of Niamey. The rebels seized six weapons before security forces put down the assault and arrested several attackers, Saibou said. Among those arrested was Mohamed Adullahi, former minister of public and semi-public corporations. The rebels claimed membership in the Revolutionary Movement for the Liberation of Niger, an organization the government says is backed by Libya. Saibou told deputies in the national assembly the rebels planned to use the weapons for attacks on government facilities, including the uranium mining center at Arlit, the main foreign-exchange earner for the impoverished Sahel nation. Arlit is about 240 miles northeast of Tchintabaraden.

DOC.HEAD: Vietnamese Refugee Sentenced in Drowning of Two Illegal Aliens
DOC.TEXT: A Vietnamese refugee was sentenced Tuesday to 21 months in prison for negligence in the drownings of two Malaysian women he was attempting to smuggle across the Niagara River into the United States. Ba Minh Hoang, 28, of Niagara Falls, Ontario, was transporting the women across the river aboard a flimsy raft in December 1988 when it capsized in icy, turbulent water. Hoang swam to shore but Vasugee Krighan, 27, and Fong Yew Cheah, 38, drowned. Both women were illegal immigrants. Hoang pleaded guilty in April to two charges of criminal negligence in the deaths and to charges of conspiracy to violate U.S. immigration laws. He was sentenced Tuesday by provincial court Judge Harry Edmondstone to 21 months for each charge of criminal negligence, and 12 months for conspiracy. The sentences are to be served concurrently. Hoang was paid for his part in the smuggling operation, but the amount was not disclosed in court. Government attorney Barry Hill said Hoang recklessly endangered the lives of the immigrants by crossing the river aboard a three-person, $60 raft that was ``more suitable for a backyard swimming pool'' than the currents and whirlpools of the lower Niagara River. Defense Attorney Larry O'Brien argued that his client's motive was a ``belief he was helping refugees better their lives.''

DOC.HEAD: Bulgarian Killed in Accident with Drunken Turkish Official
DOC.TEXT: A Bulgarian was struck and killed by a Turkish embassy official driving under the influence of alcohol, the state news agency BTA reported Tuesday. According to the report, Hussein Ozatai, an employee of the Turkish Consulate General in the southern city of Plovdiv, struck a pedestrian with his car after he left a wedding party in the nearby village of Ustina. Leven Dimitrov, 29, was killed in the accident, BTA said. Ozatai suffered a fractured leg and facial wounds, the news agency reported. BTA said Ozatai was driving under the influence of alcohol, but gave no further details.

DOC.HEAD: One Dead in Fire Aboard Destroyer; Another Dies in Separate Navy Mishap
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to clarify location, circumstances of accident.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NK1, LaserColor WX8, LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: The guided-missile destroyer USS Conyngham limped back to port under tow Tuesday after a boiler fire spread to its nerve center, killing the ship's operation officer and injuring 12 others, officials said. In a second fatal Navy accident Tuesday, a crew member aboard an air-cushioned landing vessel off the East Coast was killed when a propeller malfunctioned. It was the latest accident since a series of problems forced a worldwide Navy stand-down last fall. The fire on the 27-year-old Conyngham started around 5:30 a.m. while it was on routine operations about 100 miles southeast of Norfolk, where it is based, said Lt. Cmdr. Carrie Hartshorne, a spokeswoman for the U.S. Atlantic Fleet.
