LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: ``Let's talk about love,'' Robert Plant says on the opening track of his newest album. And so he does. ``Manic Nirvana'' is full of reflections on love: physical love, fantasy love, love gone sour. But don't expect the usual, or the serious, from this rock veteran. He's always been known as the master of capricious naughtiness and musical wackiness, but his solo efforts since the breakup of Led Zeppelin in 1980 have been relatively tame. No more. On ``Manic Nirvana,'' Plant returns to playfully sexual lyrics liberally sprinkled with wit and innuendo, and blended with abundant puns. In ``Big Love,'' he juxtaposes a romantic encounter with being at ``15,000 and holding'' on an airplane. He imagines a relationship with a magazine model in the frustrated ``I Cried.'' And in what is probably his most accessible song to date, ``Hurting Kind (I've Got My Eyes on You),'' Plant moans over his love just like old times. The album also contains the first acoustic song of his solo career, ``Liars Dance,'' a quiet but terse commentary on greed and religion. And as always, Plant rejoices in keeping his audience guessing. In his remake of the 1961 Kenny Dino song, ``Your Ma Said You Cried in Your Sleep Last Night,'' he slips in the first two verses of the Zeppelin classic ``Black Dog'' _ just to keep you on your toes. ``(The music) must change and it must give me the variety and the humor and the pomp and the mock splendor and all that sort of thing, depending upon the mood that I'm in,'' Plant said in an interview. The constant changing makes his music difficult to categorize _ and he likes it that way. But he teasingly called it ``angst-pomp.'' ``Part of the reason that I change it so much is to be quirky and to maintain the quirk,'' he said. ``It certainly doesn't help me sell more records. In fact, if it does anything at all, it diminishes the chance, because I'm not playing the natural, straight-down-the-line, middle-of-the-road game.'' That sense of humor has helped Plant to make himself less serious. ``There are parts of my personality that need a lot of tender loving care and attention from myself to myself,'' he said, ``and there are other parts that really are very flippant and have to be a bit derisive. ``I'm serious because I want to make this music sound exactly as it does now, but at the same time, I can't be too serious about it because there are so many holes in it and there's such folly in a rock n' roll singer's ego.'' It seems that Plant can now accept the strutting, bare-chested attitude of his youth and temper it with the cleverness and imagination of maturity. But despite his 42 years, he is by no means a prude. He's called his new album ``thunder and lightning condensed in a condom.'' In other words, it's lusty. But it gets its sexiness from Plant's fantasies and double entendre, rather than blatant vulgarity. In ``Big Love,'' he talks of a bathroom rendezvous aboard an airplane. ``I just felt that it was fair game because it's something that everybody dreams of happening, even if you have the most straight-laced, moralistic point of view,'' he said. However, he said he's not out to exploit or degrade women. ``You have to be careful not to take it as if I'm heralding male dominance and it's only for my benefit. Everybody would benefit from those sort of impromptu meetings.'' Plant wistfully spoke of his ``complete incapacity to have a nice, calm love affair.'' He quoted from his song ``She Said,'' which he said describes him: ``So I say, `Give me fresh horses, let me ride the wild beat. Women in their houses, I can't deal with their heat.''' ``I like the seduction,'' he said. ``I like the kind of intrigue of relationships and I don't like what they do to me _ or what I do to them.'' Part of Plant's new musical freedom has come from his band, formed before the release of ``Now and Zen.'' Guitarist Doug Boyle, bassist Charlie Jones, keyboardist Phil Johnstone and drummer Chris Blackwell are roughly 20 years younger than their leader. But Plant said his outlook keeps him young. ``I think my attitude is my Fountain of Youth, with or without a band, because I feel kind of timeless,'' he said. ``I know I'm getting older, but I don't think that's affecting my state of mind. I surround myself with young guys because they're keen and they're excited and their contribution to everything is very wholehearted. That marriage of enthusiasm and lack of cynicism and lack of worldly over-wisdom _ it's perfect for me.'' As Plant's personality is a combination of adult wisdom and youthful energy, so are his heroes. He is a devotee of early bluesmen Howlin' Wolf and Gene Vincent, but said he admired anyone ``who could swing their hips and make me wonder what that meant.'' He also praised Robert Smith of The Cure. Of the wide variety of his heroes, he quipped: ``Some of them are dead, some of them are tired, and some of them are young.'' Plant's 1990 tour kicks off in Europe on May 1 and should be in the States shortly after. ``I'm very lucky,'' he said. ``I have a particularly strong live following and I haven't had huge Top 40 hits, but I've got a pretty big, interested, live following, which is great _ it's kind of greater than if I'd had Top 40 hits and nothing else.''

Books and Authors: Food an Important Legacy of the 1960s
DOC.TEXT: What's on the dinner table in the 1990s may represent one of the most tangible legacies of the 1960s, even for those who never sprouted a bean. The rebellion by health food ``nuts'' against ``plastic'' food was part of a bigger effort to live better that included the civil rights, environmental and women's movements, Warren J. Belasco argues in ``Appetite for Change: How the Counterculture Took on the Food Industry, 1966-1988,'' published by Pantheon Books. In his preface, including the story of his discovery of alternative ways of eating, Belasco connects the dinner table to the political changes of the 1960s. ``Indeed, I've found that rather than just being silly or perverse _ as our parents and skeptical peers probably thought _ we were cooking up something quite serious, ambitious, and yes, radical: an alternative food system with its own ideology, staples and supply lines, a countercuisine.'' Food, he said, often is ignored by analysts of our history and culture. Belasco, in fact, began his research intending to write about how the mainstream co-opted counterculture efforts in rock 'n' roll, clothing and food. ``The food just became too big.'' The New Left argued over and over that the personal was political, and Belasco argues, nothing is more personal than food. ``And what could be more political than challenging agribusiness, America's largest and most evironmentally troublesome industry ...? ``I really do think that food is one of the most substantial parts of our lives, central to our health and our pleasure,'' he said in a telephone interview from the University of Maryland, where he is an American studies professor. Belasco presents an engaging, and copiously foot-noted, tale that connects food giveaways in the Haight-Ashbury of the mid-1960s to the chocolate-covered granola bars that pass for healthy kids' food today. He adds spice to his theories by liberally quoting many underground food columnists of the 1960s. ``Appetite for Change'' is not just fun, though it is that; it forces readers to consider what's in their pantries and why. Business figured out pretty quickly that the ``countercuisine'' could be profitable. And today, the profusion of so-called health and ``lite'' foods is ironic evidence of success. Of course, the legacy also exists in food cooperatives, concern over health, organic farms and other alternative enterprises. But the countercuisine has not turned us into a nation of healthy, socially conscious eaters, and Belasco tries to explain why ``the supermarket is an additive minefield, processors are consolidating rapidly, the farm belt is a disaster area, pesticides are out of control, and we reek with contradictions like everyone else.'' The reasons are complicated, the fault of the ``ecofreaks'' as well as the food industry. There were plenty of conflicts: vegetarians vs. meat-eaters, white bread vs. whole-grain brown, convenience vs. homemade, natural vs. processed, ethnic dishes vs. ``WASP'' food. Belasco also criticizes the press and the response in the '70s to public concerns about the food supply by a government that ``was itself a bundle of contraditions, inconsistencies and vacillations.'' And there were disputes within the counterculture over the role of food, communes and cooperatives and ``hip capitalists.'' ``It may now be hard to see revoluntionary significance in the eating of unhulled rice and curried carrots or granola and yogurt. In 1969-70, however, dietary change was one of the more substantial household reforms,'' Belasco writes. Twenty years later, Americans are again being coaxed to make changes that start at home _ consume green, recycle, conserve. ``It's good that there is all this news, but I'm kind of skeptical as to how deep it is as far as Earth Day,'' Belasco said in the interview. ``I had very mixed feelings about that as a really meaningful set of activities on that day.'' ``Green'' sounds today a lot like ``natural'' did 20 years ago _ hard to define and therefore open to fraud. And real change is slow, he noted. ``The problem is the public is not going to see immediate gains,'' he said. ``People like me, I'm a believer, and I'm in there for the long pull.'' Today's news seems all too familiar. ``A lot of this is deja vu to me _ we went through this 20 years ago. And I think a lot of it got co-opted,'' he said. ``Beyond defining the content of food, natural was a liberated state of mind, a symbol of opposition to mass production, efficiency, rationalization, limits.'' At the other end of the spectrum: ``Mass-produced, processed food encouraged alientation from nature, society, one's own body. Unfortunately, most consumers seemed to collaborate in their own alientation.'' But, he said, he is a bit more optimistic today than even two years ago when he finished his book with the less-than enthusiastic plea that ``since the odds against us were always steep, I suppose there's no reason to lose heart now.''

Nashville Sound: Melvin Sloan Dancers Have Fun
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The rules are simple for the Grand Ole Opry's Melvin Sloan Dancers. ``Rule No. 1 is to have fun. Rule 2 and 3 is the same rule,'' says Sloan. The energetic, colorful eight-person square dance troupe is celebrating its 10th year on the live country music show. The group, possibly the best known square dance act in the world, also has appeared on the TV shows ``Hee Haw,'' the now-defunct ``Dolly Parton Show'' and other programs. The 50-year-old Sloan says his troupe dances a different style than amateur square dance clubs around the country. His group dances to his spontaneous ``calls'' during the routine. Nearly all the local square dancers use set patterns, he says. ``Our style is self taught,'' he said in an interview. ``No one teaches you how to do this. It's kind of like playing music by ear. Ours is dancing from the heart. We dance like we feel. You express yourself by moving your feet.'' Sloan's brother, Ralph, directed his own Opry square dance group from 1952 until his death in 1980. Melvin then took over the group to maintain the tradition of a Sloan-led Opry dance troupe. He had never danced before, but he learned quickly. ``I had jumped into a lake of water and I didn't know how to swim,'' he recalled about his first dance steps. ``There was confusion. There were times we'd dance and then go to the dressing room and cry.'' He eventually mastered the art by studying patterns that other group members had drawn for him on paper. He spent hours in front of a mirror in his loft, perfecting the dance steps and his coordination. He finally picked up where his brother left off, and the group continued its reputation as one of the Opry's most popular acts. ``There's nothing that puts electricity in a crowd like a loud banjo and some good dancing,'' Sloan said. The troupe ranges in age from mid-20s to 50 and is recruited from square dance groups in Tennessee. No one else in the country dances exactly the style done in Middle Tennessee, he said. ``I tell my dancers that if you can't give me 100 percent, you don't need to go to the stage. We are always received well,'' Sloan said. They perform every other weekend on the Opry, a fabled show that has been presented weekly since 1925. A million people see the production in person every year and millions more listen on the radio. Thirty minutes of the three-hour show is carried live each Saturday night on cable TV's The Nashville Network. The Sloan dancers can tell while standing behind the curtain just before show time whether the crowd will be responsive or quiet. ``If you hear a lot of laughter and everything sounds alive, when the curtain goes up, you can feel it. It's a feeling of energy,'' Sloan said. His group, and his brother's before it, boast of never having missed a scheduled Opry performance in 38 years. But Melvin Sloan's troupe barely made it to a show about three years ago during an ice storm. ``We rushed in to the Opry House and didn't have time to change our clothes,'' he recalled. ``We ran out on the stage and danced in our street clothes to keep the streak going.'' Sloan designs their costumes. Each of the four men's attire has a belt and buckle, shirt, necktie, hanky and white pants and white shoes. These are coordinated with the women's dress, apron or pinafore and sash, hosiery and matching ties for the shoes, and pantaloons. The group also performs at various Nashville conventions. And in 1983, at the request of then President Ronald Reagan, they performed at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington. Despite the tradition and the acclaim, the group is not perfect. ``Sometimes we make a mistake,'' Sloan said. ``But it makes me feel good when someone tells us it looks like we enjoy our dancing so much. We are as proud of our dancing as any singer is of his singing.''

Warfield receives final curtain call this month for his performance as a professor of voice and oratorio at the University of Illinois School of Music, a position he's held since 1974. He has also been chairman of the voice program since 1983. He retires in August. Warfield taught such opera stars as Erie Mills and Jerry Hadley. To salute him for a lifetime of achievement, the university will hold a three-day symposium in Warfield's honor, April 29 through May 1, topped off with a gala concert May 1. The university also is establishing an endowment in h scholarships and fellowships for outstanding voice majors, with special considis name to funderation given to minority students.

In the Groove: Record Reviews
DOC.TEXT:
``Deep'' (RCA-BMG) _ Peter Murphy
The ``deep'' of former Bauhaus singer Peter Murphy's fourth solo project could refer to his unfathomable lyrics, but Murphy has said the title reflects both how he feels about his work _ deeply _ and his perception of the music, which he calls ``deep rock.'' It sounds more like doomsday disco. Murphy's old outfit, a post-punk British band with artistic pretensions, was among the first to mix infectious dance grooves with brooding, introspective lyrics. The style lives on in this recording and in records by The Cure, The The and others favored by masses of black-garbed club hoppers. ``Cuts You Up,'' a single from ``Deep,'' is a hit in dance clubs and on college radio, and its hook is undeniable. But it is difficult to imagine the self-absorbed Murphy finding a broader audience with songs this obtuse. _ By David Dishneau, Associated Press Writer.

``Ace of Harps'' (Alligator) _ Charlie Musselwhite
Charlie Musselwhite sings like his vocal chords are on a leash. But his singing is no reason to listen to ``Ace of Harps,'' his debut with Chicago's Alligator records. A master of the blues harmonica, his playing knows no bounds. He can play down. He can play dirty. He can even play pretty. Whenever he blows, you hear a tradition born by Little Walter, who sparked the explosion of urban blues out of Chicago in the 1950s. Mississippi-born Musselwhite and the late Paul Butterfield built off that tradition in the 1960s and Musselwhite carries it on today. It's gritty and hard driving and powered by no-nonsense blowing that says the man with the harp is in charge. For Musselwhite's definition, listen to ``Leaving Your Town'' or ``Hangin On.'' Just to show he learned his blues lessons well, Musselwhite sings ``My Road Lies in Darkness'' accompanied only by his own playing on acoustic guitar. It's the cut most suited to his deep drawl. A man with lesser convictions would not ring true, but Musselwhite proves he hears the calling on his 14th solo album as strong as he did on his first. Behind Musselwhite on ``Ace of Harps,'' stand Andrew Jones Jr. on guitar, Artis Joyce on bass and Tommy Hill on drums. Joyce and Hill are solid while staying out of the way and Jones punctuates Musselwhite's blowing with some well-placed solos. What Musselwhite chooses to sing on this record is less important than how he approaches the material as a whole, since the fare is pretty standard. But the moment he lights into ``The Blues Overtook Me'' to start things off you believe him, and being overtaken yourself is an easy next step. _ By James Reindl, Associated Press Writer.

DOC.TEXT: Double-digit mortgage rates and rising prices dampened existing home sales in many parts of the United States in the first three months of 1990, according to the National Association of Realtors. The trade group said Tuesday that sales slipped 1.6 percent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.81 million units during the January-March period, down from 3.87 million units during the fourth quarter. Sales totaled 3.90 million during the first quarter of 1989.

Federal regulators have agreed to cut prices on hard-to-sell real estate the government is inheriting from bankrupt savings and loans. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the administration endorsed stepping up sales, but withheld comment on the specifics of the plan. The Resolution Trust Corp. voted Tuesday to permit regulators to cut a property's price by 15 percent if it had not sold in six months _ four months for a single-family home. A further reduction of 5 percent is allowed after another three months.

Visa U.S.A. Inc. and Mastercard International have agreed to abandon a national debit card venture to settle charges by 14 states that they schemed to monopolize the emerging market. But the giant credit card associations _ the world's largest with a combined 370 million cardholders worldwide _ denied the allegations and said Tuesday they agreed to the settlement partly to avoid a lengthy legal battle. Both said they would continue developing separate debit card systems.

Lockheed Corp. will move its aeronautics division from Burbank to Marietta, Ga., in an effort to cut costs in the face of a likely decline in defense spending, the company said Tuesday. The decision by the company's board will end plane-building operations at the site that date back to 1928. Burbank is where ``Rosie the Riveter'' cranked out 30,000 warplanes in World War II and the ``Skunk Works'' designed America's most secret aircraft.

A jury has decided the Dallas Times Herald was not harmed unfairly by the loss of 26 comics and features last fall to its larger rival, The Dallas Morning News. The jury voted 10-2 in declining to award damages to the Times Herald, which contended that the Morning News and its parent, A.H. Belo Corp., violated anti-trust laws by taking over the features in a move to drive the Times Herald out of business. The Times Herald had asked for $33 million in actual damages and what its attorneys termed significant punitive damages. The $33 million would have been tripled if the Times Herald lawsuit had been successful.

House Democratic leaders are urging President Bush not to veto a proposal guaranteeing unpaid leave to workers with family emergencies, but the White House reaffirmed its opposition to the bill. Supporters said Tuesday they believe they have enough votes to win passage in the House but are short of the two-thirds necessary to override a veto.

The Bush administration says it will introduce legislation this week to strip the Commodity Futures Trading Commission of control over stock-index futures. Tuesday's announcement marks a victory for the Securities and Exchange Commission, which regulates the nation's stock markets, in a turf battle with the rival CFTC, which oversees U.S. futures markets. Treasury Undersecretary Robert Glauber told a Senate panel the administration wants the SEC to have authority over all stock-related financial products.

Rain and sodden fields are hampering many farmers as they try to plant corn and other crops this spring, reports the government's Joint Agricultural Weather Facility. Nationally, corn planting was reported 50 percent complete, trailing normal progress by three percentage points. Cotton planting was 39 percent completed, down five points from the usual pace for this time, the government said Tuesday. But corn producers in Iowa, Nebraska and Ohio were able to make up for earlier delays, planting about one-third of their acreage during the week of April 30-May 6.

In a long-planned change of command, J. Richard Munro is stepping down as co-chairman and co-chief executive of Time Warner Inc., the media and entertainment behemoth he helped create. Munro became chief executive at Time Inc. in 1980, and has shared the chairman and chief executive posts with Warner Communications Inc. boss Steven J. Ross since Time bought a controlling interest in Warner and changed its name last year. Succeeding Munro today as co-chief executive will be Time president Nicholas J. Nicholas Jr., 50.

Stock prices jumped Tuesday in a late rally sparked by the outcome of the first phase of a record-sized auction of government debt securities. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks rose 11.94 to 2,733.56. Bond prices rose. The dollar closed mixed. Cocoa futures prices declined sharply; frozen orange juice futures surged; livestock and pork futures declined; grain and soybean prices retreated and precious metals declined.

DOC.HEAD: Lockheed Plane-Building Headquarters Expected to Move to Georgia
DOC.TEXT: Lockheed Corp. said it will phase out all operations at the site where ``Rosie the Riveter'' cranked out 30,000 warplanes in World War II and the ``Skunk Works'' designed America's most secret aircraft. The nation's sixth largest military contractor said the changes would help it adjust to a likely decline in defense spending. ``We will take advantage of this situation to streamline our aircraft operations and enhance profitability,'' said Chairman Donald Tellep. Lockheed, which has built planes in Burbank since 1928, said Tuesday it will move its aerospace division to Marietta, Ga., outside Atlanta. The move to Georgia, where Lockheed already builds and services cargo planes at a government-owned facility, will cut costs substantially, Tellep said. The Skunk Works research unit, where spy planes and the stealth fighter were developed, will become a separate subsidiary and gradually move from the 320-acre Burbank site to Palmdale, in the desert 50 miles north of Los Angeles. Corporate headquarters will remain in Calabasas, Calif. The moves mean more bad news for the aerospace industry in California. State Rep. George Miller said last week the state could lost 200,000 defense-related jobs by 1995. McDonnell Douglas Corp.'s Douglas Aircraft is eliminating 3,000 jobs, most of them in Long Beach. Lockheed said recently it would lay off 2,000 workers in Burbank, Palmdale and Santa Clarita, along with 750 in Marietta. Lockheed spokesman Ron Meder said the company would finish moving all operations out of Burbank by the mid-1990s, ``and then everything will have been sold or will be for sale.'' Lockheed's profits plummeted from $624 million in 1988 to $2 million in 1989 last year, and the company faces tough times as easing world tensions pressure the government to slash defense spending. The company recently won a proxy battle for control waged by Texas investor Harold Simmons, who owns 19 percent of Lockheed's stock and claimed the company was mismanaged. Simmons did force the company to allow big shareholders more participation, however. Tellep said Lockheed would continue to develop its new P-7 submarine-hunting plane in California but will build it in Georgia. Lockheed also will build the Advanced Tactical Fighter in Georgia if it wins the competition for one of the last major aerospace defense contracts in this century. A Lockheed-led team is competing with one led by Northrop Corp., and a decision is expected by the middle of next year. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney recently called for the ATF to go into production in 1996, two years later than previously planned. Lockheed said delays also were likely on the P-7. Securities analysts said the moves may help Lockheed curry support for its ATF bid from Sen. Sam Nunn, the powerful Georgia Democrat who heads the Senate Armed Services Committee. ``He's certainly somebody you'd like to have on your side,'' said Paul H. Nesbit of Prudential Bache Research in New York. ``They have that huge facility down there that Sam Nunn has virtually insisted that the Air Force continue to keep open with the hope in mind there would be work.'' Lockheed Aeronautical Systems Co. was formed in 1987, when plane-building operations in California and Georgia merged under one management. The division has come on hard times of late, with four major military plane programs ended or about to end: the C-5 cargo plane, the P-3 antisubmarine patrol plane, the TR-1 high-altitude reconnaisance plane and the F-117A stealth fighter. Employment at the Marietta plant has fallen from 20,000 workers two years ago to about 9,000. Lockheed officials said the shift of the aerospace division wouldn't lead to any immediate surge in employment in Marietta because no new aircraft production is scheduled until the mid-1990s. Lockheed's operations in Burbank date back to 1928. It produced 30,000 fighters and bombers there during World War II and later built the Constellation and L-1011 passengers planes. The Skunk Works designed secret aircraft such as the U-2 and SR-71 spy planes and the stealth fighter. Corporate headquarters were moved from Burbank to Calabasas five years ago, and Lockheed recently put 225 of its 320 acres in Burbank up for sale. Lockheed has a number of other operations throughout the country including its missiles and space division in Sunnyvale in Northern California, which is thriving.

DOC.HEAD: Visa, Mastercard Drop Debit Card Venture In Suit Settlement
DOC.TEXT: Fourteen states claimed victory in their effort to stop Visa and Mastercard from launching a national debit card, and one state official hinted the vastly larger credit card market could be next on the states' antitrust hit list. Visa U.S.A. Inc. and Mastercard International agreed to settle charges brought by the states in U.S. District Court in Manhattan last June by agreeing to abandon their joint ``Entree'' debit card network, the state attorneys general announced Tuesday. Each company promised to develop separate debit card systems eventually. A point-of-sale debit card is presented at stores like a credit card, but the money is deducted automatically from the cardholder's account and transferred to the merchant. The antitrust suit claimed Entree had an unfair advantage over smaller, regional competitors because virtually every major U.S. bank already was a Visa or Mastercard member. The credit card associations are the world's largest with a combined 370 million cardholders. Visa and Mastercard also have gained control of the nation's two largest automatic teller machine networks _ Cirrus System Inc. of Downers Grove, Ill., and Plus System Inc. of Denver, both of which had been formulating their own plans for national debit card networks since the early 1980s. Visa also took over the Interlink Network, based in San Mateo, Calif., the nation's largest regional debit card network. ``There would have been no competitive forces at work,'' Robert Abrams, the New York attorney general who led the states' action, told a news conference. ``The agreement doesn't prevent the concept from going forward. It prevents a monopoly.'' David Brancoli, a spokesman for Visa, disagreed: ``We feel the program would have been competitive and we would have prevailed in the courts.'' He said Entree was abandoned partly because some banks had begun to lose interest in it in the face of what could have been a lengthy court battle. The other states involved in the suit were: Arizona, California, Connecticut, Louisiana, Maryland, Massachusetts, Minnesota, Tennessee, Texas, Utah, Washington, West Virginia and Wisconsin. At the end of 1989 there were 183.9 million debit cards in circulation nationwide, according to Bankcard Holders of America, a consumer group based in Herndon, Va. But not all those cards operate ``on-line'' as Entree would have, by electronically accessing a comsumer's bank account the same way as an automatic teller machine. Visa and Mastercard began developing Entree in 1986 and had signed up about 200 banks to participate, according to Richard Woods, a spokesman for Mastercard. Two of those banks, Bank One of Columbus, Ohio, and U.S. National Bank of Oregon, already had issued around 100,000 cards, although none has been used, he said. Under terms of the settlement signed Tuesday by U.S. District Judge Pierre N. Laval in Manhattan, Visa and Mastercard will abandon Entree and notify bank participants it will be terminated by Oct. 1. In exchange, the states dropped efforts to compel Visa and Mastercard to divest Cirrus, Plus and Interlink. ``The speedy resolution of this complex lawsuit is the first important step in establishing a more competitive environment in the nation's electornic payment systems,'' Abrams said. He said the states agreed to set up a task force to investigate competition in that field, particularly with credit cards. ``Although there are approximmatly 20,000 financial institutions offering plastic debit, credit and ATM cards, the interest rates and other fees charged ... is disturbingly high, uniform and rigid,'' said Abrams. Abrams said Visa and Mastercard had been engaged in a ``creeping merger'' that already had resulted in largely uniform pricing in the credit card industry. Average credit card rates, which are set by banks, have hovered around 19 percent in recent years despite fluctuations in other interest rates. David Robertson, a vice president for the Nilson Report, a bank industry newsletter published in Santa Monica, Calif., predicted states eventually will challenge the ``duality'' of the credit-card industry, which allows financial institutions to be members of both Visa and Mastercard. ``The competition is done with mirrors,'' said Robertson. ``How can you be a member of both'' and remain competitive.

DOC.HEAD: Nicholas Succeeds Munro as Co-CEO of Time Warner
DOC.TEXT: The guard is changing at the top of Time Warner Inc. The company's president, Nicholas J. Nicholas Jr., succeeds J. Richard Munro today as co-chief executive of the media and entertainment giant. The top-level changes had been widely expected, and the 50-year-old Nicholas said no major changes are expected because he and Munro have worked together so closely for years. ``This represents continuity, not change,'' Nicholas said. The 59-year-old Munro announced he was stepping down at the first annual meeting of Time Warner shareholders since Time Inc. completed its acquisition of Warner Communications Inc. earlier this year. Munro had been chief executive at Time since 1980 and chairman since 1986. He shared both titles with Warner boss Steven J. Ross since Time bought a controlling interest in Warner and changed its name last year. A onetime Sports Illustrated publisher, Munro had said he wanted to serve only 10 years as chief executive, and the company spelled out succession plans when the Warner deal was first announced in March 1989. Munro's contract at Time Warner entitled him to deferred compensation of nearly $4.3 million if he retired from his posts on or before this May 31. Nicholas, 50, has been with Time since 1964 and president since 1986. ``The future belongs to him and to Steve and to the remarkable people at Time Warner. I wish you all godspeed,'' Munro told shareholders and others who filled the 1,150-seat Ziegfeld Theater for Tuesday's 2{-hour meeting. Ross, 62, becomes the company's sole chairman with Munro's retirement. Plans are for him to share the chief executive's post for four more years, after which he is expected to leave that job entirely to Nicholas. Time spurned a $12.2 billion buyout offer from Paramount Communications Inc. last summer and proceeded with a $14 billion purchase of Warner. The deal, completed in January, created a world leader in magazines, books, films, recorded music, TV production and cable TV systems. Time never allowed shareholders to vote on the Paramount offer, but there were few complaints expressed Tuesday about Time's tactics. Shareholders rejected a proposal, which was opposed by management, calling on Time Warner to either redeem or submit to a shareholder vote a key anti-takeover defense known as a poison pill. William Steiner, who presented the resolution, said Time management had cost its shareholders about $5 billion by rejecting Paramount's $200-a-share offer without allowing a vote. About 43 percent of the shares voted in favor of the proposal and 57.8 percent against, the company said. In trading Tuesday on the New York Stock Exchange, Time Warner stock fell 50 cents a share to $94. Ross said uncertainty about congressional efforts to impose more regulations on the cable industry had cut the value of Time Warner stock by $2.5 billion to $3 billion. Time Warner is the nation's second biggest cable TV system operator. One shareholder asked Ross to explain why he deserved his lucrative benefits package, under which he is entitled to deferred compensation of about $122 million. Ross said the package mainly reflected stock bonuses and stock appreciation rights he was granted in 1987 at Warner, and noted the company he founded had grown at a remarkable pace in recent years. Munro, who will stay on as a Time Warner director and chairman of its executive committee, joined the Time magazine circulation department in 1957. He became president and chief executive of Time Inc. in 1980, and took on the title of chairman in 1986, passing the president's job to Nicholas. Munro defended the decision to combine with Warner rather than take the Paramount offer, saying the new company offered a potential ``long-term return on investments that would far outstrip any single short-term gain the sale or breakup of Time might bring.'' Time Warner lost $256 million on revenue of $10.8 billion last year, mainly because of costs associated with its purchase of a majority stake in Warner. Nicholas said a top priority is reducing the company's $10.8 billion debt.

DOC.HEAD: LIN Restructures Purchase of Metromedia's New York Cellular Stake
DOC.TEXT: LIN Broadcasting Corp. has amended its $1.9 billion offer for Metromedia Co.'s stake in the New York City cellular telephone franchise to a combination of cash and stock instead of an all-cash deal. The new deal announced Tuesday will ease the debt burden on LIN, and indirectly on parent McCaw Cellular Communications Inc., as it takes control of a system in a premiere market. McCaw took on a heavy debt in March when it paid $3.4 billion to boost its stake in LIN to 52 percent. The new deal ``increases LIN's financial flexibility as we move ahead with the development of the nationwide seamless cellular network,'' said Craig O. McCaw, chairman and chief executive of both LIN and McCaw Cellular. In a related transaction, LIN said Tuesday it had agreed to give Metromedia control of the Philadelphia cellular franchise by selling a fraction of its interest in that system to Metromedia for $15.5 million. Metromedia, based in Secaucus, N.J., has interests in telecommunications and other activities and is headed by billionaire John Kluge. There had been speculation LIN was having trouble raising the cash needed to buy Metromedia's stake in the New York franchise, Metro One. It agreed to buy the interest two months before agreeing to be acquired by the Kirkland, Wash.-based McCaw. LIN said Metromedia has agreed to accept $1.05 billion in cash and $850 million in preferred stock rather than the $1.9 billion in cash originally offered for Metromedia's 46.3 percent interest in the New York system. LIN already owns a 45 percent of Metro One. Metromedia will be given preferred stock in a new LIN subsidiary, LCH Cellular Inc. The new unit will own all of LIN's cellular businesses; LIN's specialty publishing operation called GuestInformant, which produces city guides for hotel rooms; and one of LIN's seven TV stations, WOTV, which serves the Grand Rapids-Kalamazoo-Battle Creek area in Michigan. The preferred stock will provide dividends to Metromedia and will entitle Metromedia to representation on the LCH Cellular board. In a separate deal disclosed Tuesday, LIN said it had agreed to buy another 1.7 percent stake in the Metro One franchise from other investors for $60 million. That purchase, combined with the Metromedia deal, would boost LIN's stake to 93 percent of the New York franchise. In the transaction involving the Philadelphia Metrophone franchise, LIN agreed to sell a 1.01 percent stake in that system to Metromedia for $15.5 million at the same time that Metromedia gets the preferred stock in the New York deal. That would cut LIN's 51 percent stake in the franchise to just under 50 percent, while boosting Metromedia's 49 percent stake to over 50 percent. The transactions are expected to close in the third quarter of the year and are subject to several conditions including regulatory approvals and approval by LIN's independent directors, the company said. If the conditions are not met, LIN said it will proceed with completion of the purchase of Metromedia's New York interests for cash.

DOC.HEAD: Landmark Dallas Office Complex Sold
DOC.TEXT: The Southland Center, once Dallas's premier office address, has been sold to a Swedish investor in the largest deal in the city's central business district since the real estate market collapsed in the mid-1980s. Lars-Erik Magnusson, chief executive of Larmag Investments Group of Amsterdam, said Tuesday he had paid about $60 million for the three-building downtown complex and would spend another $130 million to renovate them. Magnusson made the purchase in partnership with KTI Associates, another investment firm. ``I think Dallas has had its worst years behind it,'' Magnusson said by telephone from his home in The Netherlands. ``I've been looking at Dallas for a couple of years, but last year I felt it was too early to go in. This year I feel much more comfortable.'' The largest building, the 42-story Southland Tower, was the tallest in Dallas when it was completed in 1959 by Southland Financial Corp. Its companion 31-story Skyway Tower was finished in 1981. The office buildings have about 1 million square feet of leasable space, but are only 30 percent occupied. The 508-room, 29-story Sheraton Dallas Hotel completes the complex. The collapse of the local real estate market in the 1980s left many skyscrapers almost vacant and sent rental rates plummeting. Boosters welcomed the deal as the latest indication of a recovery, but some said the deal's success depends on the refurbishing. Magnusson said he planned to replace the turquoise-tile and florescent-light facade derided by locals, as well as remove asbestos. ``The `recladding' could dramatically increase the appeal of that building, if they can do all that work, and can get acceptance by the public as a new project rather than just a rehashing of the old project,'' said Bob Edge, executive vice president of Cushman & Wakefield of Texas Inc. real estate firm. But Edge said, ``They're going to have do one heck a job of retrofitting that building to get that kind of acceptance.'' Magnusson, whose personal worth has been estimated at about $200 million, said he planned to begin work by the end of the year with completion during 1992. ``I think that the lease market in Dallas will be tighter in the next 18 months and that gives me just the time I need to renovate,'' he said. ``I'm sure I can deliver top class buildings.'' The purchase ``is another piece of the recovery,'' said Larry Fonts, president of the Central Dallas Association, a downtown business group. ``It is a big deal.'' Magnusson, who has invested more than $2 billion in Europe, is a relative newcomer to U.S. real estate, paying $630 million last year for three trophy properties in New York and Chicago. The center once was the headquarters for Southland Life Insurance Co., later a subsidiary of Southland Financial, an insurance company owned by Dallas' Carpenter family. The life insurance company was sold in 1984, and the office complex followed in 1988 in a deal with Ashton Development Corp., a partnership owned by Saudi Arabian investors and New York investor Ian Kean.

DOC.HEAD: Son of Washington Real Estate Magnate Accused in Insider Trading Scheme
DOC.TEXT: The son of a Washington real estate magnate will fight charges of illegally passing confidential information about one of his father's deals to a friend, according to the son's attorney. In a civil complaint filed Tuesday at federal court in Chicago, the Securities and Exchange Commission accused B. Francis Saul III of violating the Insider Trading Act of 1984. The SEC also charged Saul's friend, Peter David Garvy. Both men are 28 and Chicago residents. ``This kid is totally innocent. He's taken a lie detector test and passed it 100 percent,'' said Saul's attorney, George Rogers. ``We intend to fight it immediately as soon as we can get to trial and we expect to win.'' The complaint concerns transactions involving companies owned by Saul's father, B. Francis Saul II of Chevy Chase, Md. In 1988, the SEC alleged, Saul told Garvy, a former school roomate, about a proposed tender offer one his father's companies, Westminster Investing Corp., had made for another Saul concern, the B.F. Saul Real Estate Investment Trust. According to the complaint, Garvy bought 5,500 shares in the investment trust before the tender offer was made public. The complaint also charged that Garvy told his father, Eugene, 70, of Hinsdale, Ill., and a friend, Betsy Perk, 29, of Chicago, about the pending deal and they purchased shares in the Saul trust. The complaint does not accuse the elder Saul, Garvy's father or Ms. Perk of any wrongdoing. Rogers, the younger Saul's lawyer, said he was surprised the SEC was bringing the case despite a federal appeals court decision in New York last week that overturned an insider trading case in which a broker received merger information from a client whose family owned the company in question. ``Sometimes people have to be told twice. No one's ever accused the government of being smart,'' said Robert Stephenson, Garvy's attorney in Chicago. He said his client also denied the charges and would seek a quick trial. The SEC charged that Garvy, his father and Ms. Perk made a total of $61,000 in profits using the information supplied by the younger Saul. The SEC is seeking from both Garvy and the younger Saul, who was not accused of trading for himself, a total of three times the total illegal profits, or $183,000, in penalties.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Wants SEC Control Over Stock Index Futures
DOC.TEXT: After months of hinting at its position, the Bush administration is siding with the Securities and Exchange Commission in its jurisdictional dispute with futures regulators. Treasury Undersecretary Robert Glauber told a Senate panel Tuesday that the administration will introduce legislation to strip the Commodity Futures Trading Commission of control over stock-index futures and hand it to the SEC. The announcement marks a victory for the SEC, which regulates the nation's stock markets, in a turf battle with the rival CFTC, which oversees futures markets. The dispute centers on which agency should oversee financial products that have elements of both a security and a futures contract. These so-called hybrid products include stock-index futures. In testimony before the Senate Agriculture Committee, which oversees the CFTC, Glauber said the administration wants the SEC to have authority over all stock-related products, including stock-index futures and stock-index options. Sen. Patrick Leahy, the committee chairman, said he would ask the leadership to bring the matter to the Senate floor for action. He did so after berating both the SEC and CFTC for their increasingly combative rhetoric and complaining that the measure might delay much-needed futures market reform. Reaction from the futures exchanges was swift and predictable. In Chicago, Thomas R. Donovan, chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade, said the proposal ``would solve a perceived problem only to create a very real one by placing futures markets under two regulators.'' The proposal ``is clearly just the first step of creeping regulatory imperialism,'' he added in a lengthy statement released by the CBOT. ``Such a move could serve to endanger our nation's Number One status in the world in financial services,'' said Leo Melamed, chairman of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange's executive committee. ``That is a risk that Congress ought not take,'' he said in a statement. John Damgard, president of the Futures Industry Association, who sat in on the hearing, said: ``There'll be no jurisdictional change this year. But it sure mucks up the reauthorization scene, which I think everybody will agree is unfortunate.'' In his opening remarks, Leahy complained the dispute has held up passage of a bill that adds several market reform measures to the CFTC's reauthorization legislation. ``Congress remains blocked from enacting the tough reforms we all agreed are needed,'' the Vermont Democrat said. Leahy also said the committee ``should consider responsible, appropriate solutions _ possibly even the ultimate merger of the SEC and CFTC if this is shown to be justified and feasible.'' CFTC Chairman Wendy Gramm told the committee a change in jurisdiction could cripple her agency. ``Splitting off stock index or financial futures from the CFTC would result in the loss of some of our most experienced personnel which could damage agency morale and threaten our ability to oversee the remaining markets within our jursidiction,'' she said. In addition to Glauber and Gramm, Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan and SEC Chairman Richard Breeden also testified before the committee. The four witnesses sit on the White House Working Group on Financial Markets, which was set up in the wake of the 1987 stock market crash to handle intermarket issues.

DOC.HEAD: Employees Disrupt Shareholders Meeting
DOC.TEXT: Pan American Corp. Chairman Thomas Plaskett says the company is still looking for partners as it comes off one of the worst years in its 62-year history. Pan Am, which failed in a bid last year to buy Northwest Airlines, wants to strengthen its route network and has talked to nearly every other major carrier about some form of combination ranging from joint marketing to full-scale mergers, Plaskett said. ``We are looking at every conceivable idea _ but as for now, we don't have an agreement with anyone,'' Plaskett said during Tuesday's annual shareholders' meeting. In a meeting repeatedly disrupted by protesting Teamster union employees, Plaskett said Pan Am would begin reducing losses this year, but he cautioned that the carrier was on a long, slow route to recovery. Although Plaskett said the company needs capital, company officials said there are no plans to sell Pan Am's Northeast shuttle service, as Eastern Airlines sold its Northeast shuttle last year to New York developer Donald Trump. Pan Am has not made a profit since 1980. Pan American World Airways, its major subsidiary, posted a $437.1 million net loss in 1989, compared to $118.3 million in losses in 1988. Pan Am Corp. lost $190 million the first quarter of this year. Hundreds of Pan Am's nearly 5,000 Teamsters-represented employees demonstrated outside the Hotel Inter-Continental, then jammed into the shareholders' meeting. Most employees hold shares because of past stock-wage programs. Plaskett was interrupted repeatedly as he opened his annual report, including when he discussed the financial losses resulting from the December 1988 terrorist bombing of Pan Am's Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, which killed all 259 on board and 11 people on the ground. ``I find it incomprehensible that a tragedy like this would engender jeers and guffaws,'' Plaskett snapped. The Teamsters, representing reservations, ticket, computer and cargo agents, have been working under company-imposed conditions for two years since federal mediation failed. Starting wages for most jobs are under $6 an hour and some are at 1978 levels, the union said. Jack Barmon, chief steward of Teamsters Local 769, said the union hasn't struck because it fears members would never get their jobs back. Tuesday marked the beginning of sporadic work stoppages, he said. Pan Am spokeswoman Pamela Hanlon said a small number of employees failed to report to work on time Tuesday, but their duties were covered by management personnel with no effect on operations. She said the rowdy protests were ``basically what we expected because of the big presence of employees in Miami.'' Plaskett said Pan Am is concentrating on improving and marketing its customer service reputation, increasing business to Europe, including Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, and expanding its Pan Am Express as a feeder service. In Miami, he said, Pan Am is up to 60 departures daily from 45 last year, making Pan Am the leading carrier out of the city. It aims to have 150 to 180 daily flights here by 1995, along with 13,000 employees compared to 6,900 now. Pan Am is hoping to capitalize on Miami's growth and the woes of Miami-based Eastern Airlines. Eastern still is struggling to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization and is basing its future on its Atlanta hub. Eastern is down to 48 daily Miami departures from 110 when its union workers walked out March 4, 1989. By mid-summer, Eastern's South American routes will be taken over by American Airlines.

DOC.HEAD: More Students Take German, Thanks to Fall of Berlin Wall
DOC.TEXT: Once shunned by foreign-language students, German is making a comeback at some schools thanks to the fall of the Berlin Wall and the move to reunifying the two Germanys, educators say. Though German still takes a backseat to Spanish and French at most high schools and colleges, students are becoming increasingly aware of its value as a possible career tool, said Helmut Ziesle, president of the northern Illinois chapter of the American Association of Teachers of German and a professor at suburban Wheaton College. There's been a 30 percent increase this year in the number of Wheaton students majoring in German, he said. ``Once Germany's united, its economic role will become more important,'' Ziesle said in a telephone interview Tuesday. ``The more we are aware here how important that is, the more interest we stimulate in the study of German, I think it will help both countries tremendously,'' he said. ``Most Germans know English, but relativley few Americans know German.'' At south suburban Homewood-Flossmoor High School, the expected enrollment in first-year German will be 19 next year, up from 12 this year, said Principal Charles Smith. The Illinois Math and Science Academy in Aurora will add a second section of first-year German next year, said teacher John Stark. And the Chicago public school system's German language summer camp in suburban Lake Forest is filled up with 20 students, said David Oliver, coordinator of the Department of Language and Cultural Education for the Chicago Board of Education. ``It's way over what we expected,'' he said. ``Last year we had a problem getting more than eight students.'' ``I think it's based on what's taking place in Germany,'' Oliver said. ``I think there's a whole new spirit.'' Before World War I, German was the most popular foreign language in American schools. Both world wars, and especially Nazi Germany, helped change that, Ziesle said. So did the growth in the number of Hispanic immigrants in this country, which helped give Spanish top-billing, said Sherry Parriott, president of the Southern Illinois chapter of the German teachers association. In 1985, the most recent statistics available, about 4 million high school and college students were taking Spanish, about 1.5 million were taking French and about 500,000 German, said Helene Zimmer-Loew, executive director of the association. The Cherry Hill, N.J.-based group has about 6,500 members, mostly high school and college teachers. ``The news I've heard from most colleges and universities is that there's been a greater request for German courses,'' Ms. Zimmer-Loew said.

DOC.HEAD: Sales Flat, Employment Down For Black Enterprise Industrial 100 In 1989
With PM-Black Companies-List
DOC.TEXT: America's black-owned businesses slumped notably last year and must get ``leaner, stronger, better'' to cope with big debt burdens and a less favorable stance by the government, Black Enterprise magazine reported. Hit by the sluggish economy, the nation's biggest black-owned businesses saw employment fall sharply and sales decline last year, the magazine said Tuesday. In its annual tally of the biggest black-owned U.S. businesses, the magazine said the coming years posed even more hurdles because of cutbacks in areas such as defense spending and what it deemed weakening government commitments to affirmative action and minority aid programs. ``Black entrepreneurs will have to rethink their strategic focus and restructure their organizations if they are to keep their competitive edge and reap profits from the ensuing chaos,'' said Earl G. Graves, editor and publisher. ``In other words, black business is going to have to get leaner, stronger, better.'' Among the 100 biggest industrial and service companies, employment fell by 10.4 percent while sales dropped 3.8 percent to $4.46 billion, the magazine stated. For the 100 biggest black-owned auto dealerships, which are listed separately, sales rose by 8.4 percent to $2.33 billion but total staff dropped 1.3 percent, reflecting the slowdown in the nation's auto industry. Nineteen of the biggest companies from 1988 _ two-thirds of them auto dealerhips _ sought bankruptcy court protection from creditors during the year. Retaining the top spot among industrial and service companies was TLC Beatrice International Holdings Co., the foods processor and distributor. The New York-based holding company acquired the international food businesses of the former Beatrice Cos. in a debt-financed $985 million buyout in 1987. TLC Beatrice's gross sales of $1.51 billion accounted for about a third of the total sales of the BE 100 biggest industrial and service companies. But like many of the other companies, TLC Beatrice suffered from weak conditions in the economy and financial markets. A planned public offering of 35 percent of the company, which would have made TLC Beatrice the first black-owned company on the New York Stock Exchange, was withdrawn in December due to a sagging stock market and a weak reception by investors. ``In short, BE 100s companies, like much of American industry, are paying for the excesses of the 1980s,'' the magazine stated. ``Debt-ridden and immurred in cyclical industries, many BE 100s companies realize that the flush times are over _ or at least, stalled.'' ``Not only will black businesses have to confront an economy chugging at a much slower pace, but they must profit as national, state and local government agencies begin to ``reregulate'' sagging industries and develop an increasingly laissez faire attitude about affirmative action and minority set-asides,'' the magazine said. Johnson Publishing Co. Inc. of Chicago, the publisher, broadcaster and maker of cosmetics and hair-care products, retained second place on the list with $241.3 million in revenue. J. Bruce Llewellyn's Philadelphia Coca-Cola Bottling Co. Inc., the soft- drink bottler, kept third place with $240 million in sales. H.J. Russell & Co. of Atlanta, involved in construction, property management and food and beverages, held fourth place, although its revenue of $132.9 million was down 16.8 percent from the previous year. Ranked fifth again was Gordy Co., the former Motown Industries Inc., with sales of $100 million. Computer and office supply companies accounted for 18 of the biggest 100 industrial and service businesses, followed by 17 manufacturing companies, 16 food and beverage companies and 10 media companies. California led all states with 23 of the companies belonging to one or the other of the two top-100 lists. Michigan had 22, followed by New York with 19, Illinois with 17, Ohio with 13 and Texas with 11.

DOC.HEAD: Government Launches National Search For Computer Hackers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf pvs, Search warrants ..., to list all 13 cities. A version moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Secret Service is conducting a coast-to-coast investigation into the unauthorized use of credit-card numbers and long-distance dialing codes as well as illegal entry into computer systems by hackers, according to sources. Search warrants were obtained by the Secret Service to conduct searches Tuesday in 13 cities: Phoenix, Ariz., Chicago, Cincinnati, Detroit, Los Angeles, Miami, Newark, N.J., New York, Pittsburgh, Richmond, Va., Plano, Texas; San Diego and San Jose, Calif. The investigation is being supervised by Stephen McNamee, the U.S. attorney in Phoenix, and Bob Corbin, the Arizona attorney general. The two officials scheduled a news conference today in Phoenix to discuss the searches, the Secret Service said. Secret Service spokesman Richard Adams declined to discuss details of the case. The investigation in Phoenix is also focusing on incidents in which computer hackers allegedly changed computerized records at hospitals and police 911-emergency lines, according to one source. Up to 150 Secret Service agents participated in the searches Tuesday, according to one source.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Says Ford Didn't Intentionally Infringe on Inventor's Patent Rights
DOC.TEXT: A federal jury has found that Ford Motor Co. didn't intentionally infringe on an inventor's patent rights to his intermittent windshield wiper. However, the partial verdict decided on Tuesday still means Robert W. Kearns could collect a considerable amount of money, said Cincinnati patent lawyer Jim Hayes. ``It does not alleviate the jury's initial ruling but it does mean that he will collect less,'' Hayes said. The U.S. District Court panel adjourned after releasing its partial verdict in the claims by Kearns, and was scheduled to begin a sixth day of deliberations today to decide how much money the inventor should receive. The same jury on Jan. 29 ruled that Ford had violated the patent held by Kearns, a former Wayne State University professor who now lives in Gaithersburg, Md. Kearns claims in his 12-year-old suit against Ford that he installed a set of his wipers on a 1962 Ford and took it to the automaker. He said he believed that Ford would buy his system since engineers questioned him at length about it. Kearns, 62, also is suing General Motors Corp., Chrysler Corp., Honda Motor Co. Ltd. and a dozen other automakers and auto-related companies. The case against Ford was the first to go to trial. After the jury's January decision, Judge Avern Cohn issued an order forbidding Kearns or Ford officials from talking about the case.

DOC.HEAD: French, British Aerospace Firms To Study New Supersonic Plane
DOC.TEXT: British Aerospace and Aerospatiale of France said Wednesday they will conduct a five-year study to decide whether to develop a new supersonic airliner to replace their jointly produced Concorde. A final decision on whether to proceed with a $10 billion production program would be made in 1995, Aerospatiale President Henri Martre told a news conference. He said the feasibility study would cost about $34 million and focus on such issues as market potential, technical factors and environmental protection. Martre said the British and French companies would welcome cooperation with other industrial powers, including the United States, Soviet Union, West Germany and Japan. British Airways and Air France together operate 13 Concordes on trans-Atlantic routes. These planes are due for retirement within 15 to 20 years, and the new planes, if developed, would be ready by about 2005. The new generation of supersonic transport would, according to aviation experts, be capable of carrying about 225 passengers over distances of up to 7,500 miles at two and a half times the speed of sound.

DOC.HEAD: Central Bank Says Falling Land Prices Could Cause Problems For Economy
DOC.TEXT: Japan, with some of the most expensive real estate in the world, could suffer economic problems if land prices fall as history indicates they might, the Bank of Japan said Wednesday. ``Experiences abroad suggest that it is important to forestall any turbulence which might arise from a sudden change in land prices, in order to maintain a safe and sound financial system,'' the central bank said in a report. Land prices in Tokyo jumped 23.8 percent in 1987 and 65.3 percent in 1988 before the increase slowed to less than 2 percent last year, according to the National Land Agency. Nationwide, land prices soared 17 percent in 1989 after a 21.7 rise in 1988 as speculative inflation spread to other Japanese cities. The most expensive commercial property in the world, in central Tokyo's Marunouchi and Ginza business districts, was valued at $23,700 a square foot, the agency said. The Bank of Japan said history shows that it is wrong to assume land prices will keep climbing and never decline. This assumption among corporate and individual investors is driving economic decisions and poses a risk to the economy, it said. The bank called for legal and tax reforms to end incentives for property speculation and encourage more efficient land use. Meanwhile, it said, financial institutions should be monitored closely to ensure that a drop in land prices doesn't undermine the value of the currency. The scarcity of land is one basic factor behind the high prices. ``But more fundamentally, institutional factors such as the tax and legal systems seem to work to push up land prices by inhibiting the more efficient utilization of land,'' the Bank of Japan said. It said cases in the United States and Britain show that when land prices climb steeply over a short period, they may decline, harming financial institutions such as savings and loan firms involved in property lending. A sudden decline in land prices could be triggered by tighter monetary policy, which raises interest rates, as well as changes in the economy and legal and tax systems, the bank said. Rising prices in other areas have led the bank to raise its official discount rate four times in the past year, to its current 5.25 percent from a historic low of 2.5 percent. The rate is what commercial banks pay to borrow from the central bank.

DOC.HEAD: Southwest, Pilots Union Agree to Five-Year Contract
DOC.TEXT: Southwest Airlines has signed a five-year contract with its pilots that calls for no wage increase the first year and guaranteed 3 percent hikes during the four succeeding years. In additiion, the 950 unionized pilots could receive up to 3 percent more in pay increases in the last three years of the pact, depending on the airline's profits, said Jim Parker, general counsel for Southwest Airlines. The contract, which will be made retroactive to September 1989, runs through Aug. 31, 1994.

DOC.HEAD: SmithKline Beecham Posts 42 Percent Quarterly Profit Jump
DOC.TEXT: SmithKline Beecham PLC, the newly merged health, household products and pharmaceuticals company, said Wednesday its first quarter profit jumped 42 percent because of the sale of certain businesses. SmithKline said that during the three months ended March 31 it netted $371 million, or 18 cents a share, compared with earnings of $261 million, or 20 cents, a year ago. Sales rose 19 percent to $2.15 billion from $1.8 billion. The results were the first the company reported on a quarterly basis since the merger of SmithKline Beckman Corp. and Beecham PLC in July 1989. Year-earlier figures were made available as if the merger had taken place at the beginning of 1989. SmithKline Beecham attributed the higher quarterly income largely to aset sales. It sold branded businesses such as Ambrosia, Bovril and Marmite food products as well as the Yardley-Lentheric cosmetics, raising around $493 million. The company said that it reduced its debt by $455 million during the first quarter. Its total debt stands at $2.5 billion, down from $4 billion a year ago. SmithKline Beecham Chairman Henry Wendt said that ``interest expense will decline significantly during the year, and the balance sheet will improve as we generate a high level of cash from operations and aggressively pursue debt reduction.'' The pound figures were converted at a rate of $1.65, which was provided by the company.

DOC.HEAD: American Brands Defeats Anti-Tobacco Proposal
DOC.TEXT: American Brands Inc.'s shareholders have defeated a proposal to get rid of the company's tobacco businesses, but the resolution received enough votes to be raised again next year. Nearly 4 percent of the stockholders at Tuesday's annual meeting supported the resolution, which asked American Brands to stop producing and marketing tobacco by the year 2000. ``I'm encouraged. We'll submit it again next year,'' said Jeanne Pinard, a Massachusetts teacher who introduced the proposal. American Brands makes several brands of cigarettes, including Carlton, Lucky Strike, Pall Mall, Tareyton and Malibu. It also sells alcoholic beverages, life insurance, office products, golf supplies, hardware and housewares. In urging voters to defeat the resolution, Chairman William J. Alley said tobacco products represented an important segment of the company's business and contribute a significant portion of the American Brand's revenue. ``Smoking is a matter of choice for each individual,'' he said. Alley was bullish about the company's prospects for 1990. Last year's revenue fell slightly to $11.9 billion, but income increased 9 percent to $630.8 million. First quarter income rose 13 percent to $195 million.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Stops Publication After 76 Years
DOC.TEXT: The Clearwater Sun has stopped the presses after 76 years of publication. ``We were unable to make an effective business,'' Bruce E. Coury, publisher of Clearwater Newspapers Inc., said in a statement Tuesday. Last summer, the newspaper switched from daily publication to a tabloid-size weekly focusing exclusively on news in Clearwater, a central Gulf Coast city also covered by two nearby major dailies _ the St. Petersburg Times and The Tampa Tribune. Last Friday's edition was the last ever, Coury said. Circulation exceeded 50,000 in 1980, but fell to about 25,000 by 1987, and later dipped below 15,000. The newspaper was operated by the Hearst Corp.

DOC.HEAD: Harvill To Become Publisher of The Tampa Tribune
DOC.TEXT: H. Doyle Harvill, vice president and executive editor of the Tampa Tribune, will become publisher of the newspaper and chairman of the Tribune Co. on July 1, the newspaper announced Wednesday. He succeeds Richard F. Pittman, 67, president and publisher of the Tribune since 1978, who is retiring after 44 years with the newspaper. Harvill, 60, spent much of his journalism career in Tampa, serving as a copy editor, reporter, city editor and then managing editor of the Tampa Times, which ceased daily publication in 1982. He left Tampa in 1974 for an executive position at Media General Inc. headquarters in Richmond, Va. In 1976, Harvill became executive editor of The Greenville (S.C.) News and Piedmont, flagship newspapers of Multimedia Inc. He later was named a vice president of that company, and in 1982, became publisher and president of the Montgomery (Ala.) Advertiser and Alabama Journal. He returned to Tampa in 1986 as vice president and executive editor of the Tribune.

DOC.HEAD: Uncertainty Over Soviet Wheat Bid Sends Futures Lower
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures were mostly lower in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade. DOC.HEAD: Volkswagen Reports 5.5 Percent Rise in First Quarter Profit
DOC.TEXT: Volkswagen AG, West Germany's largest automaker, reported Wednesday that its first quarter profit rose 5.5 percent over last year and that 1989 income grew by a record 33 percent. Earnings for the first three months of 1990 totaled $191 million, compared with $181 million last year. Sales were up 7 percent to $10.3 billion worldwide. Volkswagen also disclosed its total net income for 1989 jumped by a record 33 percent to $609 million from $475 million in 1988. Sales for 1989 rose 10 percent to $39.6 billion $36 billion. It was the first time the company disclosed actual financial data for 1989. Chairman Karl Hahn had indicated earlier, though, that net income had risen by more than 30 percent last year. Hahn, buoyed by record sales from last year, also announced Tuesday that Volkswagen was considering expanding in Eastern Europe, just as it plans to grow in East Germany. ``It would undoubtedly be a mistake if we _ in a Europe with nearly 500 million people _ looked only at East Germany with its 16 million people,'' Hahn told a news conference. Hahn said Volkswagen was conducting talks in Hungary, Bulgaria and Czechoslovakia, but he did not elaborate. Volkswagen already is arranging joint production with the East German carmaker IFA-Kombinat, and is shooting for an annual output of 250,000 units after 1994, Hahn said.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Vintner Hopes French Respect Will Help Kick `Cowboy' Image
Laserphoto
DOC.TEXT: Shedding nicknames like ``Chateau de Bubba'' and ``Cowboy Cabernet,'' a West Texas winery has proven beyond a sip of sauvignon that wine from the South Plains can get some respect _ even from the French. This month, three labels from Llano Estacado Winery's award-winning stock have begun appearing in 350 restaurants in France. ``We know (Llano wines) are going to be a success,'' said Jean-Michel Maumont of Selected Distributors and Vintners in Cognac, France. ``At first, it will be curiosity. But, after tasting this wine, they will realize its quality.'' Maumont is importing red, blush and white wines from Llano for restaurants SDV already supplies with the makings of Southwestern cuisine, from Tecate, Lone Star and Carta Blanca beers to pinto beans, picante sauce and taco shells. The French importer and Llano say they hope to capitalize on a European craze for Tex-Mex cuisine. Maumont sought out Llano after the winery won a gold medal at the International Wine and Spirit Competition in London last October. The export deal is a coup for a winery that still touts its best-selling blush wine as the perfect companion to chicken fried steak. Kicking a cowboy image has been tough for the winery, says John Lowey, Llano president and chief executive officer. The operation started in 1976. It began commercial production in 1983 and grew despite the economic downturn that stalled the growth of some other Texas wineries. Lowey said West Texas has an ideal environment for grape growing, with a 3,200-foot elevation and regular daily temperature swings of 30 degrees. ``In grapevine physiology that causes the wine grapes to build sugar as the cooler temperatures help them retain acid,'' he said. ``A good sugar-acid balance is the secret to a strong vintage.'' But, he said, ``When we first started we couldn't give a bottle of wine away here in Lubbock. ``We couldn't beg our way onto a wine list in 1982 and 1983. It was very difficult to establish any credibility at all.'' Llano's big break came at the 1986 San Francisco Fair Exposition and National Wine Competition, where it snatched a double gold medal, the highest honor, for its 1984 chardonnay. ``It was like winning the Kentucky Derby,'' Lowey said. Still, U.S. publications dubbed Llano products ``Cactus Blanc'' and ``Chateau de Bubba.'' Lowey is happy such stories _ and names _ have not circulated in Europe. ``I think we have much more highly developed skepticism in the United States than in France,'' he said. ``In Europe, we are judged on our merits.'' ``Most Frenchmen don't know that wine is made in Texas,'' Maumont said in a telephone interview from SDV headquarters. Llano produces ``a very good wine,'' he said. ``I found other Texas wines that disappointed me greatly. It's certainly one of the best wines of Texas.'' Maumont contends Llano's cabernet sauvignon, the winery's trademark, will satisfy the most discriminating French palates. ``Its style is a little different,'' he said. ``The (Texas) bordeaux has a more complex aroma. It has a taste that is quite extraordinary.'' French customers will get to try three Llano wines: a 1987 cabernet sauvignon, 1989 red and 1989 blush. Llano, which sells 95 percent of its wine in Texas, recently completed another transatlantic deal to stock 300 to 400 cases of cabernet and chardonnay in a chain of wine boutiques throughout the United Kingdom. International Distiller and Vinter's Hunter and Oliver wine shops will carry the Llano stock within a few months, Lowey said. Llano's success at home and abroad has been helped by its relatively low prices. Llano's 14 labels range from $5 to $25 for the top-of-the-line sauvignon. That allows European dealers to cover their shipping costs and still make a profit, Lowey said. He doesn't know how much his wines will cost in France, but said they'll be expensive. Llano's French debut _ a May 21 tasting at the American embassy in Paris _ expands a connection between the Lone Star state and the French wine industry that began almost 100 years ago. In the 1890s, the disease phylloxera, which kills the grapevine's root, was decimating French vineyards. Texas horticulturist T.V. Munson developed a disease-resistant rootstock and sent it to France. Munson was credited with saving the French wine industry and officially recognized by the French government. ``There is a real knowledge that we owe Texas greatly for this help,'' Maumont said.

DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar fell against other major currencies in Europe on Wednesday, hit initially by a rush of Japanese selling and later by general bearishness over the American currency's prospects. Gold prices ended the day narrowly lower. Foreign exchange dealers linked early European pressure on the dollar to continued Japanese interest in selling dollars for Swiss francs. Dealers said some technical selling also was kicked off when the dollar moved below the important support levels of 1.655 West German marks and 157 Japanese yen. ``The sentiment is anti-dollar at the moment,'' said Laudy Bahl, head corporate dealer for the Bank of Tokyo in London. She said the Japanese selling, and later, broader-based selling when the U.S. markets opened, were exerting significant pressure on the dollar. A dealer at a large European bank in Frankfurt cited the possibility of a weakening U.S. economy and the potential for interest rate cuts there as a factor in the dollar's decline. Analysts have pointed to the April U.S. employment report, released Friday, which showed lower job growth that month than economists anticipated.
