DOC.HEAD: Receives $20 Million from United Arab Emirates
DOC.TEXT: Jordan announced Wednesday that it had received a $20 million grant from the United Arab Emirates and said more Arab aid was expected to help overcome a financial crisis. Jordan has relied on oil-rich Arab states as its primary financial donor. A shortfall of previously pledged Arab aid to Jordan has led to a decline in foreign currency reserves. The country's foreign debt totaled $8.3 billion at the end of 1988. As a result of the debt burden, Jordan in November 1988 introduced an economic adjustment program and sought international creditors' help to reschedule its debts. Central Bank Governor Mohammad Said Nabulsi said Wednesday he was unhappy with an initial draft agreement with creditors in London for finalizing a $580 million rescheduling package. He said the bank's foreign currency reserves totaled $390 million, including the new aid received, up from a $200 million deficit last year. Reserves hit bottom around April 1989, when the country sustained four days of rioting sparked by economic problems. Nabulsi said the latest total does not include additional Arab Central Banks deposits totaling $100 million considered as second line reserves for the next five years. Nabulsi said the expected Arab aid will not exceed $400 million. He said that finalizing the $580 million rescheduling package with the London Club, a committee of six bank creditors, was expected later this month. Jordan's total debt to the group is $1.1 billion, he said. Nablusi said that by the end of 1990, remittances from Jordanian expatriates were expected to increase to $800 million, compared to $650 million in 1989. Jordan, with a population of 3.1 million, also depends on an estimated 350,000 Jordanians working in the oil-rich Gulf countries who bring millions of dollars home. In 1987, remittances totaled $1 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Walton Opens Visitor Center Displaying Wal-Mart History
DOC.TEXT: Sporting his traditional Wal-Mart cap and a red, white and blue employee badge bearing the name ``Sam,'' the founder of the Wal-Mart discount chain on Wednesday reopened the 5&10 store that started it all. Sam Walton held court from a flatbed trailer stage in a steady drizzle to formally open the Wal-Mart Visitor Center in the same building on the downtown square where Walton first opened for business on May 9, 1950. ``I bird-hunt in the rain,'' Walton said when offered an umbrella. ``I don't need that thing.'' Aided by displays and audio-video presentations, the center chronicles the rise of the fast-growing chain, now the nation's second-largest discount retailer after K mart Corp., from its beginnings as a small rural shop. The first Wal-Mart Discount City opened in 1962. The window displays date back to the store's opening, with Simplicity patterns and Johnson's Glo-Coat, a box of Dreft and some Ivory Snow. Inside, an electronic map details the company's current 1,500-plus store chain. Also on display is the hula skirt Sam Walton donned for his ``dance on Wall Street,'' which he performed after the company met his challenge to reach a record 8 percent pre-tax profit in 1984. The ceremony, which attracted about 400 people and included a keynote address by Gov. Bill Clinton, lasted less than 45 minutes after Walton admonished master of ceremonies Don Soderquist, Wal-Mart's chief operating officer, to hurry things up. ``We've always been lucky about rain _ it hardly ever rains at any other function we've every planned, but today of all days ... How can you trim this thing down?'' Walton asked. Most of the speakers were Walton family members or Wal-Mart associates who concentrated on the company's history. Sam Walton said Wal-Mart's growth was beyond anything he expected when he opened his five-and-dime. ``What 40 years have brought us, we never could have dreamed,'' he said, noting that he purchased the five-and-dime for $16,000 when it was doing $32,000 annually in sales. ``Helen and I were out of debt _ we'd made a little money in Newport (the site of his first retail store), and we were out of debt for about six months'' when the expansions that grew into Wal-Mart began. He told of taking his wife and four children on scouting trips to potential store sites, when ``the kids would start chanting, ``Dad, no more store looking.'' The expansion could never have occurred, he said, if his Bentonville store had not been profitable.

DOC.HEAD: Board Elects Whitmore Chairman
DOC.TEXT: Eastman Kodak Co. directors on Wednesday elected company president Kay R. Whitmore to succeed Colby H. Chandler as chairman and chief executive officer when Chandler retires May 31. Kodak had designated Whitmore, 57, as its next chairman last December. Whitmore has been president of the photography giant since 1983 and will continue to hold that post. At the company's annual meeting in Orlando, Fla., Chandler forecast an improving financial picture following a restructuring last year to turn around sagging profits. The restructuring cut worldwide employment 5 percent, streamlined Kodak subsidiaries and division and significantly reduced inventories. ``As 1990 unfolds, and our gains from restructuring take hold, we look forward to higher sales, better earnings and improved cash flows, especially in the latter part of the year,'' he said. Kodak in the first quarter reported a 6 percent drop in earnings and a smaller decline in sales. Income for the quarter ending March 31 was $199 million, or 61 cents per hare, compared to $212 million, or 65 cents per share, in the first quarter of 1989. Sales fell 2 percent to $4.1 percent from $4.2 billion a year earlier. Whitmore said the company is working to improve the quality of traditional film products, while pursuing hybrid technologies that combine film and electronic photography. He said Kodak soon plans to test market a kind of video telegram that will allow customers to send ``high resolution, color images of the family anywhere in the world along with a specialized message to Grandma and Grandpa in a matter of seconds.'' William F. Fowble, vice president of photographic products, told shareholders that Kodak expects revenue from Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union to increase by more than 20 percent annually. He said the company has a successful joint venture in Hungary, and is negotiating joint ventures in the Soviet Union.

Feltes noted that export sales from the United States remain weak, while Brazilian exports on a week-to-week basis are strong. ``I think we have a market that is looking at factors not immediately apparent,'' he said. The strength of soybean futures spilled over into the corn market, which also received a boost from continued strong export business. Feltes said the strength shown by the livestock market also provided a boost to corn prices. Wheat futures were relatively weak, with trading light in anticipation of the release Thursday of the U.S Ariculture Department crop report estimating the winter wheat crop. Feltes said the failure of a bid by the Soviet Union to purchase 550,000 metric tons of wheat under an export bonus program had little effect on wheat prices. He said traders expect the sale to be approved eventually. DOC.HEAD: Fastest Growing Segment of Retail Market a $25 Billion Industry
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Members-only warehouse clubs, introduced more than a decade ago to allow buyers to purchase office, food and household goods in bulk, have emerged as the retail industry's fastest growing sector. Sales at the estimated 600 clubs nationwide, which target small businesses, churches and non-profit groups with the lure of wholesale purchases previously available only to large companies, are projected to reach $25 billion this year, a ten-fold increase over 1984. ``It took about five years for people to realize the concept was viable,'' said Arthur Markowitz, senior editor of the trade publication Discount Store News, which has monitored the growth of clubs. ``It's a discount store for businessmen.'' For an annual fee of about $25, club members are offered goods ranging from peanut butter to fax machines, in large buildings that look more like construction warehouses than retail outlets. The draw of the no-frills clubs, industry officials say, is that small businesses can save by buying goods at near wholesale prices. For that reason, the glitter of regular department store chains is unneeded and unwanted. ``Our member is a very intelligent consumer,'' said John F. Geisse, founder and chief executive of Indianapolis-based Wholesale Club, which operates 24 warehouses in the Midwest. ``You'd better have the right item at the right time, the best price and make sure it's presented properly.'' Finding the right way to present the clubs to the target consumer was a matter of fine-tuning, particularly in the Midwest where Geisse was working. ``It was rather rough in the early years,'' he said. ``We opened West Allis (in suburban Milwaukee) and had a fabulous grand opening, but people didn't come back. I don't think we did our homework well. This was only our third unit.'' That was in 1984 when industry sales nationwide were about $2.4 billion for 79 warehouses, according to Discount Store News. Geisse said defining the products for small businesses was the key to overcoming three profitless years and opening 21 new warehouses since 1984. Discount Store News estimates the warehouse clubs are the fastest growing sector of the retail industry with annual sales increases ranging from 140 percent to 26 percent over the last five years. Sales advances in other areas of retailing have been much more modest. Stephen Mandel, a securities analyst with New York-based investment bank Goldman, Sachs and Co., agreed with the warehouse clubs' emerging prominence in the retail industry. He said small business owners, churches and non-profit organizations attacted by prices typically 9 percent over manufacturer's cost are fueling the growth. What makes the warehouse clubs stand out even more is the trouble that other parts of the retail business have been facing recently because of large debts, rapid expansion and overly optimistic forecasts of aggressive spending by consumers, who now seem to be holding back because of economic uncertainty. Some of the swankest department stores, such as Bloomingdale's and Jordan Marsh, now operate under bankruptcy-court protection because of parent company financial crises. Even a few big discounters have sought bankruptcy refuge, most notably the Ames Department Stores Inc. chain last month. Unlike discount stores, which offer about 50,000 items, warehouse clubs sell only about 4,000 items specific to small business needs at near wholesale prices, Markowitz said. Also unlike other retailers that operate on profit margins of more than 20 percent, membership warehouse clubs operate on a 10 percent profit margin because they offer a limited assortment of fast turning items, Markowitz said. The clubs carry staple items and basic office supplies like sugar and copier paper on a regular basis, but beyond that, members don't know what they might find on any given visit. ``The whole concept of buying is different,'' said Cathy Roper, community relations manager for the PACE warehouse chain based in Aurora, Colo. ``We're able to negotiate some bulk-type deals with our vendors unlike a retailer that will get the same items again and again.'' The clubs combine wholesale and retail by buying items for business use in bulk and carrying a few fast-turning consumer items for their customers' personal use, like dress shirts and electronics, Markowitz said. If an item moves slowly, the club won't carry it again, he said. ``That's the only thing that matters to them _ if it sells,'' he said. ``Since they're not locked into anything, they can go into wherever they can sell merchandise.'' The clubs also keep costs low by avoiding members whose checks might not always clear and by refusing to accept credit cards. ``If there's a margin of only 10 percent, they can't afford to pay two or three percent of that to Visa or Mastercard,'' Markowitz said. The clubs were introduced in the United States in 1976 when the Price Co. opened its first Price Club in San Diego. The company now has 48 warehouses nationwide, said Giles Bateman, vice chairman. Price Co.'s founder, Sol Price, got the idea for the warehouses from huge ``cash-and-carry'' stores popular in Europe, Markowitz said. The Price Club began expanding rapidly after the first unit, but other companies didn't seize the market for several years, Markowitz said. PACE entered the industry in 1982 and now has 54 stores in 15 states, Ms. Roper said, adding the company's expansion has not slowed. Discount Store News projects continued growth for the entire industry. Markowitz said states in the Northeast hold extraordinary potential. ``In California, in the Los Angeles market, you have about 30 stores,'' he said. But in the 10-12-state Northeast region, ``in the entire market, they only have about 30 stores. There's still a lot of growth because there's still a lot of areas where there aren't many of them.''

DOC.HEAD: Ten-Year Notes at Year's Peak Yield
DOC.TEXT: Yields on 10-year Treasury notes rose in Wednesday's auction to the highest level in a year as the government's record $30.5 billion cleared its second hurdle. The average yield was 8.88 percent, up from 8.59 percent at the last auction on Feb. 7. It was the highest rate since 10-year notes averaged 9.18 percent on May 10, 1989. The notes will carry a coupon interest rate of 8~ percent with each $10,000 in face value selling for $9,996.70. A total of $10 billion in notes was sold out of bids totaling $30 billion. The refunding winds up on Thursday with the auction of $10 billion in 30-year bonds. It began Tuesday with the sale of $10.57 billion in three-year notes with an average yield of 8.74 percent, up from 8.43 percent at the last three-year auction on Feb. 6 and the highest since such notes averaged 9.12 percent last May 9. Bids totaled $37.3 billion. This quarter's refunding is $500 million larger than the last two. In announcing this week's auctions, Treasury Undersecretary Robert Glauber said $18.1 billion would be used to refund privately held notes maturing on May 15 and about $12.4 billion would be added to cash. Part of the new funds will be used to finance the savings and loan bailout. The notes and bonds are sold regularly during the large debt auctions held four times a year to replenish the government's coffers. The Treasury sold $8.4 billion in three-month bills and $8.4 billion in six-month bills at its weekly bill auction on Monday.
Stock prices pulled back slightly today, pausing after more than a week of steady gains. Shortly before the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down 1.80 at 2,731.76.

DOC.HEAD: Nicaragua Sends First Exports to U.S. Since Trade Ban Imposed
DOC.TEXT: Nicaragua has resumed exports to the United States following former President Reagan's 1985 trade embargo, sending a shipload of sugar from the port of Corinto. Reagan imposed the embargo as a measure against the Marxist Sandinista government. President Bush lifted it after American-backed Violetta Chamorro de Barrios won the presidency in February elections. Nicaragua shipped 18,000 metric tons of sugar on Tuesday, part of the 54,328 metric tons Nicaragua can sell to the United States this year at a preferred price above the world market. During the embargo Nicaragua sold most of its sugar, a major export crop, to Soviet bloc nations. Despite tense diplomatic relations, the United States remained the biggest buyer of Nicaraguan goods until the embargo was imposed. The U.S. embassy, which announced the shipment, said the Bush administration is considering ``a series of steps to reduce barriers and tariffs and open the market to Nicaraguan exports.'' Other exports include cotton, tobacco, beef and seafood. Mrs. Chamorro took over a virtually bankrupt country and is awaiting congressional approval of $300 million in emergency economic aid.

DOC.HEAD: Creditors Seek Involuntary Bankruptcy for Drexel Subsidiary
DOC.TEXT: A group of Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc. creditors asked a federal judge Wednesday to place a commodities trading subsidiary into bankruptcy court because it is not paying more than $500 million in debts. The move by several large foreign central banks and other creditors would toss Drexel Burnham Lambert Trading Corp.into involuntary Chapter 7 liquidation proceedings, removing the company from control of its parent. Drexel said in a statement it would not challenge the petition but would exercise the right to convert it to a Chapter 11 case, which allows a company to reorganize its assets and business under protection from creditors. The petition was filed in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan, where the parent of the Wall Street firm sought protection from creditors on Feb. 13 after a cash crunch and continued problems from its 1989 securities fraud guilty plea. Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the brokerage subsidiary, is liquidating its assets outside of bankruptcy court. Creditors were said to be considering whether to place the firm in involuntary liquidation, where its actions would be controlled by the court. The bankruptcy petition filing by the commodities subsidiary was made by creditors Banco de Portugal, the National Bank of Yugoslavia, Nissho Iwai Corp., a Japanese trading concern, and Ultramar Energy Ltd., an oil trading company in Tarrytown, a New York suburb. The commodities subsidiary owes those and several dozen other creditors between $500 million and $550 million, said Barry Dichter, an attorney for Banco de Portugal. DBL Trading's largest asset is a $645 million claim against the parent company for money that was funneled to the parent before it filed for Chapter 11 protection under the U.S. Bankruptcy Code, Dichter said. Drexel said the commodities trading subsidiary has estimated net liabilities of $505 million, while its claim against the parent company is about $558 million. ``DBL Trading indicated that the amounts recoverable from Group represent the balance of loans and advances made to DBL Group in line with similar transactions dating back over a number of years,'' the statement said. The commodities subsidiary, based in Fort Lee, N.J., traded in oil, precious metals and foreign exchange. It has ceased operations. Attorneys said it had resolved its trading positions except for several involving the future delivery of gold from foreign mining companies. ``The creditors believe that their future is tied to exercising control over the matter,'' Dichter said. ``Basically it was a rudderless ship on which we were all passengers and we wanted to steer the vessel.'' He said DBL Trading's employees, including senior officers, had left the subsidiary and the parent company was controlling its destiny, which he called ``much like having the fox to guard the chicken coop.'' ``We had no confidence the claim would be actively pursued for the benefit of Trading's creditors,'' Dichter said. ``We feared the claim would be dealt with for Group's benefit.'' The hundreds of millions of dollars owed by Drexel to the subsidiary involves precious metals such as gold and platinum that were leased from central banks of various governments, a common trading practice. The metals then were used in other transactions that generated cash for the commodities trading subsidiary. That money then was ``upstreamed'' into the parent company, which was short on cash. Under the filing, Dichter said, the subsidiary's creditors would retain an independent consultant to examine the relationship between the subsidiary and parent and make recommendations on how it should resolve its liabilities. Drexel still would control the company with oversight by creditors and U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Howard C. Buschman III. In a Chapter 7 case, a trustee is appointed who must collect and liquidate all property of the debtor's estate and investigate any claims made by creditors. Lawyers said Nissho Iwai is owed about $160 million, Portugal's central bank $95 million to $120 million, Yugoslavia's central bank about $70 million and Ultramar Energy $11 million.

DOC.HEAD: Supply Concerns Lift Crude, Gasoline Prices Sharply
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil and gasoline prices rallied Wednesday as several news developments raised the possibility that supplies of both fuels could be tighter in the near future. The June contract for delivery of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude, rose 71 cents a 42-gallon barrel, closing at $18.99 on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The market moved higher on reports that Saudi Arabia was exploring ways of cutting its oil production, said Andrew Lebow, an analyst with E.D.&F. Man International Futures Inc. The prospect of reduced output by the largest member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries raised hopes that the glut of oil on world markets _ which has depressed the price of crude this year _ might abate. A job action by oil workers and a gas leak in the North Sea raised further concerns about the near-term supply of crude, Lebow said. Unleaded regular gasoline for June delivery advanced 1.49 cents a gallon to 63.97 cents on the Nymex. Supply concerns also dominated trading in gasoline as a pipeline in the Gulf of Mexico remained shut, analysts said.
