DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Cuts Fares In Half For Weekday Travel Next Two Weeks
DOC.TEXT: Greyhound Lines Inc., the target of a lengthy, often-violent strike, said Wednesday it was cutting its weekday fares in half for two weeks beginning May 14 in an effort to lure back riders. ``This is a business that is based on trial, and then high repeat usage,'' said Ralph Borland, Greyhound marketing vice president. ``We want to induce them to ride and to see that the bus line is unencumbered.'' While the promotion could mean less cash in the short term, ``We're in this for the long term,'' Borland said. Greyhound bus drivers walked out March 2 in a dispute over wages and job security, but the company immediately began replacing them with new drivers and crossovers. The strike has been marked by violence, with buses in a number of locations hit by gunfire. Greyhound Chairman Fred G. Currey said Monday that the company, which operates the only nationwide bus system, now has enough drivers to run at or near pre-strike levels. Currey said Greyhound is serving markets which provided 98 percent of its revenue last year, although ridership and revenue hovered around 70 percent of year-ago levels _ not quite enough to meet expenses. Greyhound is offering half-price tickets for travel Monday through Thursday in the two weeks beginning May 14. The company also is offering Mother's Day fares of $1 for travel of up to 500 miles on Sunday to mothers 18 or older. Borland said he had no projections of the fare cut's impact on ridership. Analysts have expressed doubts Greyhound has enough cash to operate for the long term, but company spokesman George Gravley said, ``We have the capacity here to run things in a reasonable way.'' The strike has cost Greyhound more than it anticipated and helped give the company $55.8 million in first quarter losses. In a move to preserve operating funds, Greyhound last week said it would not make a $9.75 million interest payment due Tuesday and had not made about $5 million in lease payments due in April. Although the missed payments open the door for creditors to take action to force the company into bankruptcy, Currey says he believes they will give him time to rebuild the company. Reclaiming passengers is a key to that recovery. ``The typical Greyhound passenger rides several times a year,'' Gravley said. ``If they take one trip, they generally take a lot of trips. Our job is to get them to take that first trip, and then treat 'em right.''

DOC.HEAD: Tight Supplies Boost Energy Futures
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices surged Wednesday on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid concerns that gasoline and crude oil inventories would be tight in the near term. On other markets, grains and soybeans were mostly higher, precious metals futures gained slightly; copper prices advanced and livestock and pork prices gained. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 1 cent to 71 cents higher with the contract for June delivery at $18.99 a barrel; heating oil was 11 cents lower to 6 cents higher with June at 51.34 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 0.20 cent to 1.49 cents higher with June at 63.97 cents a gallon. Gasoline futures advanced on good cash buying on the Gulf Coast, said Jerry Samuels, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. in New York. Prices also were boosted by American Petroleum Institute figures that showed a drawdown of nearly 1 million barrels of unleaded gasoline. The figures indicated the drop of gasoline stocks had a particularly large impact on the Gulf Coast region, where prices are higher than those on the mercantile exchange. The institute also reported a drop in gasoline output by U.S. refineries. Samuels attributed the decline to maintenance work at the refineries. Crude oil futures also rose on supply concerns, as labor problems and a gas leak in the North Sea raised the possibility of reduced output there, and as Saudi Arabia was reportedly seeking ways to curb its production. Fears of tight supplies and high open interest in contracts about to expire sent copper futures soaring on New York's Commodity Exchange. Adding to the surge was increased labor tension in Peru and New Guinea. In Peru, where a labor dispute at the Southern Peru Copper Corp. was recently settled, workers at the Centromin mines are threatening to strike as are workers at the Oktedi mines in New Guinea. Meanwhile, labor talks were under way at several North American copper mines. Copper was 4 cents to 5.35 cents higher with May at $1.244 a pound. Precious metals futures were higher on the Comex as the value of the dollar fell in relation to foreign currencies. Gold had difficulty getting on the plus side in early trading on rumors the Soviet Union sold bullion to cover costs of recent grain purchases, said Jim Steel, an analyst with Refco Inc. in New York. But the decline in the dollar was too strong for the precious metals market to ignore, he said. Gold was $1.70 to $1.90 higher with May at $371.90 a troy ounce; silver was 3.4 cents to 3.9 cents higher with May at $5.028 a troy ounce. Grain and soybean futures were mostly higher on the Chicago Board of Trade as a surge of buying by professional funds boosted soybeans. ``The strength of soybeans was surprising in that no new features presented themselves to the market,'' said Rich Feltes, an analyst with Refco Inc. Feltes noted that export sales from the United States remained weak, while Brazilian exports on a week-to-week basis were strong. The strength of soybean futures spilled over into the corn market, which also received a boost from continued strong export business. Feltes said the strength shown by the livestock market also provided a boost to corn prices. Wheat futures were relatively weak, with trading light in anticipation of the release Thursday of the U.S Ariculture Department crop report estimating the size winter wheat crop. Wheat was { cent lower to 2 cents higher with May at $3.79{ a bushel; corn was 1 cent to 3} cents higher with May at $2.90 a bushel; oats were 1 cent to 2\ cents lower with May at $1.65 a bushel; soybeans were 13 cents to 14 cents higher with May at $6.46} a bushel. Livestock and pork futures were mostly higher on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle futures were supported by firmness in the cash market and the perception that Tuesday's selloff was overdone. Live hogs were boosted by higher pork product prices, but pork bellies were hurt by the belief that futures were overbought. Live cattle were .15 cent to .83 cent higher with June at 74.75 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent lower to .58 cent higher with May at 84.52 cents a pound; live hogs were .40 cent to .85 cent higher with June at 64.42 a pound; frozen pork bellies were .45 cent lower to 1.38 cents higher with May at 67.95 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Ad Agency Offers Guarantees on its Work
DOC.TEXT: In what is believed to be the first broad offer of its kind, one of the nation's biggest advertising agencies said Wednesday it would give clients a chance to get a guarantee on its work. Executives from DDB Needham Worldwide said the guarantee means the agency would get bonuses for work that produces results that exceed expectations and make rebates for ads that fall short. The precise terms would vary from account to account, but agency executives said the performance plan could increase or decrease an advertiser's bill by as much as 30 percent. The plan comes as advertisers are questioning the value of paying the standard rate that has prevailed in the ad business for decades without regard to performance. An ad agency traditionally gets a 15-percent cut of what an advertiser spends on print space or commercial air time. ``There is a lot of pressure from clients for agencies to go on the line and be accountable for what their advertising does for the client's business,'' said Arthur Anderson, a principal in Morgan Anderson & Co., an adviser to advertisers. William Weilbacher, an advertising consultant, said his latest survey for the Association of National Advertisers indicated only about a third of companies contacted last year said they pay the standard 15 percent rate for advertising, down from about 50 percent in a 1983 survey. The proposal also comes as marketers are spending a greater portion of their budgets on activities such as package design, sales promotion and direct mailing rather than on conventional advertising, to the dismay of ad agencies who are paid on the basis of what is spent for media placements. DDB Needham was the 10th largest advertising agency based on worldwide billings with nearly $4.1 billion in 1989, according to the trade journal Advertising Age. It produces ads for Volkswagen and Audi cars, Michelob beer, Clairol hair products, Ralston Purina pet foods, Michelin tires and Ore-Ida potatoes. Keith L. Reinhard, chairman and chief executive, told a group of media representatives that the agency has been working on the program for more than three years. He said it should inspire ``new heights of original thought and surprising execution'' because the goals are clearer and workers will have new incentives. The plan works like this: The agency and the advertiser decide on precise objectives, such as increasing the number of customers coming into stores by a certain percentage or increasing consumer awareness of a brand. The client agrees to spend a certain amount on behalf of the brand, to integrate all of the brand's marketing efforts with the main advertising message and to maintian the quality, price and distribution of the product. At the end of an agreed timeframe, the results would be tallied and the agency would either have to pay a rebate if results came up short or would get a bonus if the results meet or exceed the target. The agency would share two-thirds of any bonus with employees who produced the improved results. Reinhard said the program has been tested with different clients, who he declined to identify, and would be made available first to the agency's U.S. and Canadian clients. He said two have already said they plan to use the program. The agency has 65 major national advertisers. ``We feel confident that we have both the tools and the talent in hand to support this kind of guarantee,'' he said. Several DDB Needham clients such as Ralston Purina Corp., Anheuser-Busch Inc. and Volkswagen-Audi were asked for their reactions to the proposal but declined to comment. Industry analysts were divided on the potential impact of the plan for the industry in general. They said many agencies are already working for some clients under compensation plans that give them bonuses for good work. Leslie Winthrop, the domestic president of The Advertising Agency Register, which matches advertisers and agencies, said it was ``a very courageous thing to do'' for DDB Needham to make the plan available to all clients. She said other agencies would probably ``sit back and wait to see how it will work.'' But Weilbacher said DDB Needham's plan is a threat to other agencies. ``I don't see how an agency cannot respond to this gauntlet that has been thrown down,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Drops as Fear of Softer U.S. Economy Grows
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell sharply Wednesday against most other major currencies as the foreign exchange market grew increasingly concerned about indications that the U.S. economy is softening. Gold prices rose. Traders and currency analysts said the strength of the West German mark and the Swiss franc accounted for much of the dollar's losses, although the dollar also fell sharply against the Japanese yen. The dollar traded at 1.4020 Swiss francs late Wednesday in New York, down sharply from 1.4310 francs late Tuesday. In London, the dollar fell to 1.4039 Swiss francs from 1.4332 late Tuesday. The Swiss franc is being viewed as a safe haven for investors because many other major currencies appear troubled by domestic concerns, said Brian Guidera, a currency trader for Swiss Bank Corp. in New York. ``It's being seen to be the only logical alternative to the uncertainty elsewhere in the world,'' he said. ``As far as high-yielding currencies go, it's seen as stable.'' Traders also said the Swiss franc is boosted by that nation's relatively high interest rates. The dollar was viewed as the currency of choice until Friday, when government figures showed employment growth in April was far lower than economists expected, traders said. That report altered the belief that the U.S. economy was expanding and that higher interest rates would result. Higher domestic interest rates increase the relative attractiveness of returns on a nation's currency. The West German mark also showed renewed strength Wednesday. The dollar was trading at 1.6365 marks in New York late in the day, down from 1.6575 marks late Tuesday. The dollar fell in London to 1.6375 marks from 1.6580 marks late Tuesday. William Harrington, an international economist with the Wefa Group in Bala Cynwyd, Pa., said the mark has benefited from the recent belief that the union of the currencies of West and East Germany will go more smoothly than originally forecast. The dollar also fell sharply against the Japanese yen. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 157.03 yen, down 1.02 yen from Tuesday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted lower at 156.40 yen, and in New York the dollar fell to 156.50 yen in late trading from 157.63 yen late Tuesday. The British pound rose to $1.6785 in London from $1.6697 late Tuesday. In New York, sterling fetched $1.6785, up from $1.6705 late Tuesday. Other late dollar rates in New York compared with late Tuesday levels included: 1.1660 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1639; 5.5100 French francs, up from 5.5685; and 1,203.25 Italian lire, up from 1,216.00. Other dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Tuesday, included: 5.5010 French francs, down from 5.5710; 1.8470 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8635; 1,203.00 Italian lire, down from 1,216.00; and 1.1660 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1630 Gold prices rose. Gold bullion for immediate delivery on the New York Commodity Exchange rose $1.90 a troy ounce to $371.90. Republic National Bank in New York also quoted bullion at $371.90 a troy ounce as of 4 p.m. EDT, up $2 from late Tuesday. Gold traded at $370.75 per troy ounce in London late Wednesday, up from $369.75 late Tuesday. In Zurich, gold traded at $370.75, up from $369.00 bid late Tuesday. Earlier, gold in Hong Kong dropped $2.49 an ounce to close at $370.93. Silver bullion for immediate delivery rose to $5.028 an ounce on New York's Comex, up from $4.989 late Tuesday. Earlier in London, silver traded at a bid of $5.02 a troy ounce, up from $5.01 late Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Finish Lower; 10-Year Note Auction Rated Success
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices fell Wednesday despite the completion of another well-received round in the Treasury's three-part quarterly refunding auction. The Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond finished down 13-32 point, or $4 per $1,000 face amount, while its yield, which rises when prices fall, rose to 8.86 percent from 8.82 percent late Tuesday. Prices moved generally lower in advance of the announcement of the results of the Treasury's auction of $10 billion in 10-year notes. Kevin Flanagan, a money market economist for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said prices were depressed by weakness in the dollar and worries that demand for the 10-year notes was weak. But the auction results, announced late in the session, turned out better than expected as investors grabbed the 10-year notes at yields of 8.88 percent, the highest level since a similar auction averaged 9.18 percent May 10, 1989. Flanagan said $30 billion in bids were received for the $10 billion in notes, reflecting exceptionally strong demand for the issues. That also was reflected in the amount of non-competitive bids, which amounted to $659 million and the highest level since August 1985. Non-competitive bids often are submitted by individuals or small accounts who are content to buy securities at whatever the average yield turns out to be. The refunding auctions began Tuesday with the sale of $10.57 billion in three-year notes with an average yield of 8.74 percent, the highest since such notes averaged 9.12 percent last May 9. Market watchers say the strong demand for three-year and 10-year notes may not necessarily spill over into Thursday's scheduled auction of $10 billion in 30-year bonds. That sale will complete the refunding auction. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, prices of short-term governments fell by 1-16 point, intermediate maturities fell [ point to 7-32 point, and long-term issues lost as much as 7-16 point, according to Telerate Inc., the financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Hutton Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, fell 1.98 to 1,138.66. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds fell 1-32 point to 89 29-32. The average yield to maturity was unchanged at 7.65 percent, the same as late Tuesday. Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 7.99 percent as the discount lost 4 basis points to 7.74 percent. Yields on six-month bills fell to 8.18 percent as the discount fell 3 basis points to 7.76 percent. Yields on one-year bills fell to 8.36 percent as the discount lost 1 basis point to 7.77 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 8 3-16 percent, unchanged from late Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: USX Art Fetches $2.5 Million So Far
DOC.NOTE: Eds: `della Cioppa' in 12th graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: USX Corp. has fetched $2.5 million in an auction of 15 works of art, in a sale that art analysts say runs counter to a corporate trend of buying expensive art. The steel and energy giant has decided to sell a total of 64 works from its 100-piece collection because they can ``fetch a price,'' said USX spokesman Bill Keslar. Buyers this week snatched up the 15 contemporary pieces for $750,000 more than the pre-auction estimate. ``The market is strong for art work,'' Keslar said. ``This was a privately held collection, and it is like any other asset of a corporation.'' A Morris Louis contemporary painting, ``Beta Zeta,'' and a Frank Stella painting ``Concentric Squares'' each sold for $462,000, about $100,000 more than their pre-auction estimates. Joan Mitchell's ``Belle Bete,'' which sold for $385,000, was estimated to be worth up to $250,000. Jules Olitski's ``Strips Heresy'' sold for $352,000, more than double its estimated value. Most of the buyers were European, Asian and American collectors, said Jay Cantor, director of museum and corporate services at Christie's. Impressionist and modern works will be auctioned May 15-16, and American selections will be sold May 22-23 at Christie's in New York. A selection of European post-war abstract art will be sold at Christie's in London on June 28. Most companies that buy fine art do so to enhance the working environment, said Cantor. ``No company has embarked on an art program primarily as an investment,'' said Beatrix Medinger, manager principle of VIART Corp. in New York, which helps companies create collections. ``In the last 10 years, there's been an astronomical increase in the number of corporations who have worked at putting art collections together.'' Chase Manhattan Corp. started the trend in 1959. The bank's 13,000-piece collection is spread among 350 locations worldwide, said Margaret della Cioppa, manager of Chase Manhattan's art program. The bank has several pieces from famous artists, including a Picasso painting. None of the collection has been sold, Ms. della Cioppa said. ``They (companies) don't think of it as an investment,'' she said. ``I think it's more to do with their image than buying and selling. ...If it were to be considered an investment, it would be a good investment because the art market is up.'' Some companies have opened their collections to the public, but others keep them behind closed doors. At USX, some museums offered to exhibit the company's collection but executives turned them down, said Leon Arkus, former director of The Carnegie Museum of Art. Arkus led the committee that selected the USX collection more than 20 years ago. ``It's got to do with the attitude of a corporation who sees only dollar signs and doesn't see beneath it all,'' Arkus said. ``Why USX kept that collection secret, heaven knows.'' Keslar, however, said the company is not under any obligation to keep the collection in its headquarters city. Also, USX wouldn't have received tax breaks by donating the collection, Keslar said. The profits from the sale will be returned to the company's general funds, he said. Corporate art collecting is extremely popular, but the incentive to donate works to non-profit institutions diminished in 1986 when U.S. lawmakers removed tax breaks, Cantor said.

DOC.HEAD: Retailers Get More Time to File Reorganization Plan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds 2 grafs on judge ruling against landlord of flagship Bloomie's store
DOC.TEXT: Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. on Wednesday obtained a four-month extension in which to file their plan to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization. Lawyers for the retailing units of Campeau Corp. told U.S. Bankruptcy Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr. they might need even longer than the newly approved deadline of Sept. 12 because the case is so complex. Federated and Allied have more than 200,000 creditors, about 100,000 employees and operate 260 stores in 28 states. The judge also approved a settlement Federated negotiated with the Internal Revenue Service in a dispute over how taxes on inventory movement and size in 1981-83. Under the agreement, Federated will receive a $23 million refund from the IRS, but will adopt IRS tax computing methods over a 10-year period _ starting with the 1983 tax year _ that could increase Federated's taxes by $14 million during that time. Federated lawyer Rick Cieri said the settlement increases the value of Federated for creditors, provides additional money for its operations and saves the cost of continued litigation. Aug approved the settlement over the objection of New York-based Citibank, which wanted to know whether Federated's parent company, Federated Stores Inc., would claim any of the $23 million refund. Robert Seppelt, vice president of taxes for Federated Department Stores, said FSI has no claim to the $23 million. None of the Federated or Allied creditors objected to the extension Aug granted. Without it, Federated and Allied would have had to file the plan by Sunday, four months after the companies filed their Chapter 11 petitions Jan. 15. The petitions listed $7.7 billion in debts, most accumulated when Toronto-based Campeau bought both companies in leveraged deals in 1986 and 1988. In another matter Wednesday, Aug ruled against B. Bros. Realty Limited Partnership, landlord of Bloomingdale's posh flagship store in Manhattan. The partnership had claimed the lease for the store which runs through 2006 had become invalid because it was transferred from Federated to Bloomingdale's. The landlord wanted the store vacated by May 17. But the judge angrily rejected the claim, determining that the store was continuing to operate normally and paying the rent promptly. He further ordered the landlord to pay Federated's defense costs in the matter, accusing the partnership's owners of ``vexatious conduct and harassment.'' Carol Sanger, Federated spokeswoman, said the defense costs hadn't been determined.

DOC.HEAD: American Brands Defeats Anti-Tobacco Proposal
DOC.TEXT: Shareholders of American Brands Inc., which makes Carlton, Lucky Strike, Pall Mall, Tareyton and other cigarettes, rejected a proposal to dump the company's tobacco businesses. But the resolution, which asked the company to stop producing and marketing tobacco by the year 2000, received enough votes to be raised again at next year's meeting. Nearly 4 percent of stockholders backed the resolution. In addition to making cigarettes, American Brands sells liquor, life insurance, office products, golf supplies, hardware and housewares. ``I'm encouraged. We'll submit it again next year,'' said Jeanne Pinard, a Massachusetts teacher who introduced the proposal. American Brands Chairman William J. Alley told the meeting in New York on Tuesday that tobacco products represent an important segment of the company's business, and earnings have been a significant source of revenues. ``Smoking is a matter of choice for each individual,'' he said, answering a question. Alley refused to comment on tobacco-related health risks because of pending litigation. He said the company is involved in 41 of the 67 pending cases against the tobacco industry. He criticized the government for trying to impose new restrictions on the industry, such as bans on tobacco advertisements.

DOC.HEAD: FCC Chairman Says Control Possible If Bell's Make Equipment
DOC.TEXT: The government's top telephone regulator said Wednesday he can safely control the huge regional Bell telephone companies if they are allowed to design and manufacture telephone equipment. But Bell rivals and consumer groups told a Senate hearing they were concerned Bell companies could drive out competition and subsidize new business ventures with their monopoly local telephone earnings. A bill by Sen. Ernest F. Hollings, D-S.C., would lift manufacturing restrictions imposed on the seven regional Bell companies by a court ruling that ended an American Telephone & Telegraph Co. antitrust suit in 1984. The Hollings bill would allow the Bells to design, develop and make telecommunications equipment, including network and customer premises equipment. It also has provisions requiring that such activities take place in the United States and assuring against cross-subsidies. The FCC's admitted inability to fully monitor the business practices of AT&T led to the federal consent decree in which AT&T in 1984 spun off the regional Bells. But FCC Chairman Alfred Sikes told the Senate Commerce, Science and Transportation subcommittee on communications that the FCC, with an increased budget and new price regulatory scheme, was prepared to monitor Bell manufacturing activities. ``Existing, pending and proposed FCC and state regulatory safeguards will be adequate to safeguard the interests of telephone ratepayers and potential Bell company manufacturing competitors,'' Sikes said. Sikes said the FCC also is aided now by Bell competitors eager to blow the whistle on any Bell missteps. But Gene Kimmelman, legislative director of the Consumer Federation of America, said lifting the manufacturing restrictions could mean ``substantial local rate increases and diminished competition in return for theoretical, vaguely articulated benefits.'' Albert Kramer, general counsel of the North American Telecommunications Association, said his group of equipment manufacturers and distributors opposes the bill because it would not improve competitiveness. Hollings said he was not sure when he would try to advance the bill. A similar version is pending in the House of Representatives. Previous efforts to free the Bells from restrictions have not advanced in Congress. But the Bells have launched a multimillion-dollar campaign this year to try to swing public and congressional opinion to their side.

DOC.HEAD: Mistrial in Wiper Patent Suit Against Ford; New Jury To Be Picked
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge declared a mistrial Wednesday after a jury failed to agree on how much money to award an inventor whose patent for an intermittent windshield wiper was violated by Ford Motor Co. U.S. District Judge Avern Cohn's decision came after six days of deliberations. The jury decided on Jan. 29 that Ford had infringed on the patent held by Robert W. Kearns, but ruled Tuesday that the infringement was not intentional, limiting the amount he could be awarded. Tuesday's ruling meant Kearns only could be awarded compensatory damages and not punitive damages, Court Executive John Mayer said. The jury of five women and three men was dismissed by the judge, who will oversee a new damages trial with new jurors. ``We are disappointed the jury was unable to reach a verdict in damages,'' Ford spokesman Tom Foote said. ``However, we are pleased that the jury recognized that Ford didn't intentionally infringe the Kearns patents.'' Foote said Ford already has asked the judge to overrule the jury's finding that Kearns' patents were valid. ``We expect the court to hold a hearing on that motion in the near future,'' he said. Kearns said the delay was a disappointment. ``They stole more than my invention, they stole a business opportunity,'' he said. ``They stole what makes America great.'' After the jury's January decision, Cohn issued an order forbidding Kearns or Ford officials from talking about the case. Kearns, 62, of Gaithersburg, Md., claimed in his 12-year-old suit that he installed a set of his intermittent wipers on a 1962 Ford and took it to the automaker. He said he believed Ford would buy his invention since engineers questioned him at length about it. The former Wayne State University professor also is suing General Motors Corp., Chrysler Corp., Honda Motor Co. Ltd. and a dozen other automakers and auto-related companies. The case against Ford was the first to go to trial.

DOC.HEAD: Tisch Concedes Prime-Time TV Problems, But Promises Improvement
DOC.TEXT: CBS Inc. boss Laurence A. Tisch conceded Wednesday that the television network's prime-time ratings are a disaster, but said there will be improvement with next fall's schedule. During a raucous shareholder's meeting, the CBS president and chief executive also called for regulators to free the three major TV networks to share in the financial rewards from reruns of programs sold in syndication. CBS, third in prime time ratings for three consecutive seasons, had its worst prime-time record in the 30-week season that ended in April. CBS averaged a 12.2 rating, a 4 percent drop from 1988-89. Each ratings point represents 921,000 households and by some estimates is worth $100 million in advertising revenue over a year's time. Tisch has insisted for the past two years that he is intent on having the network regain leadership in prime time. But some shareholders said during the 2{-hour meeting that they saw little evidence of progress. One shareholder complained that members of the CBS board other than CBS founder William Paley and former CBS news anchor Walter Cronkite have no background in broadcasting. Another said CBS programming puts her to sleep. Tisch said the board members are knowledgable and pointed out that CBS is first in daytime and sports ratings, adding ``we are not a total disaster.'' The company committed itself over the past year to spend more than $3.5 billion for the rights to broadcast the major league baseball playoffs, professional football, the NCAA basketball tournament and two Winter Olympics. The network hopes those high-profile events will help draw viewers to its prime-time lineup. ``We are a total disaster only in prime time,'' Tisch said, adding that he was confident that was being corrected. He said ``you will see progress in September'' with the new fall schedule drawn up by Jeff Sagansky, new president of CBS Entertainment. Sagansky was hired late last year to succeed Kim LeMasters, who held the job for two seasons. Nonetheless, Tisch said CBS will suffer ``some effect'' from the Federal Communications Commission's one-year waiver that allows Fox Broadcasting Co. to offer its 129 affiliates up to 18{ hours of programming a week. The waiver lets Fox expand beyond the 15 hours the FCC considers the threshold for defining a network, a mantle Fox doesn't want to wear. Had the waiver been refused, Fox would have had to scale back its plans to expand programming this fall or withdraw from the luucrative program syndication business from which CBS, NBC and ABC now are barred by FCC rules. ``Unlike the television networks, the major studios and cable companies freely participate in ownership of both programs and delivery systems,'' Tisch said. He said foreign companies have also benefited from these restrictions on the networks by buying American studios. ``If the '90s are to be a decade of robust, healthy competition among all industry forces, the handcuffs must come off the three American broadcast networks,'' he said.

President Bush and congressional leaders announced plans for emergency budget talks to cut up to $100 billion from a rapidly worsening federal deficit. Tax increases as well as spending cuts will be on the negotiating table. ``Severe action'' is needed to avoid the huge automatic cuts that would be triggered throughout federal programs if deficit-reduction targets are not met next fall, presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Wednesday. Negotiators for the House, Senate and White House will meet for the first time next Tuesday at the White House, said Fitzwater.

Savings and loan financier Charles H. Keating Jr. defended the five senators who stood up for him in his battle against federal regulators. ``I would rate their performance pretty darn high,'' Keating said at a National Press Club luncheon Wednesday. The senators, now the target of a Senate Ethics Committee investigation, met with thrift regulators in March 1987 on behalf of Keating and his Lincoln Savings and Loan Association. ``There's something wrong with the system and, from my perspective, that's what the senators were trying to call attention to,'' Keating said, adding that ``they should be congratulated.''

An international fund should not be created to help poor nations curb their use of ozone-depleting chemicals, the Bush administration said. ``The United States agrees that financial assistance should be made available to help developing countries phase out production of CFCs (chloroflurocarbons),'' White House deputy press secretary Roman Popadiuk said in a statement Wednesday. ``However, we believe it is more sensible to use existing institutions and existing financial mechanisms already established by the World Bank,'' Popadiuk said. But a World Bank spokesman said the institution has insufficient resources to handle the project.

In what is believed to be the first broad offer of its kind, one of the nation's biggest advertising agencies said it would give clients a chance to get a guarantee on its work. Executives from DDB Needham Worldwide said Wednesday the guarantee means the agency would get bonuses for work that produces results that exceed expectations and make rebates for ads that fall short. Agency executives said the plan could increase or decrease an advertiser's bill by as much as 30 percent.

A group of Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc. creditors asked a federal judge to place a commodities trading subsidiary into bankruptcy court because it is not paying more than $500 million in debts. Wednesday's move by several large foreign central banks and other creditors would toss Drexel Burnham Lambert Trading Corp.into involuntary Chapter 7 liquidation proceedings, removing the company from control of its parent. Drexel said it would not challenge the petition but would exercise the right to convert it to a Chapter 11 case, which allows a company to reorganize its assets and business under protection from creditors.

A federal judge declared a mistrial after a jury failed to agree on how much money to award an inventor whose patent for an intermittent windshield wiper was violated by Ford Motor Co. U.S. District Judge Avern Cohn's decision Wednesday came after six days of deliberations. The jury decided on Jan. 29 that Ford had infringed on the patent held by Robert W. Kearns, but ruled Tuesday that the infringement was not intentional, limiting the amount he could be awarded.

Yields on 10-year Treasury notes rose at the latest auction to the highest level in a year as the government's record $30.5 billion cleared its second hurdle. The average yield at Wednesday's sale was 8.88 percent, up from 8.59 percent at the last auction on Feb. 7. It was the highest rate since 10-year notes averaged 9.18 percent on May 10, 1989. A total of $10 billion in notes was sold out of bids totaling $30 billion.

The recording industry unveiled a uniform warning label with explicit lyrics and expressed hope that an improved voluntary system will halt campaigns in some states for mandatory labeling. The black-and-white stickers _ reading ``PARENTAL ADVISORY _ EXPLICIT LYRICS'' _ will appear on the lower right-hand corner of the front of albums that might be objectionable because of lyrics dealing with sex, violence, suicide, drug abuse, bigotry or satanic worship. The stickers were unveiled Wednesday.

Members of Congress urged the Bush administration Wednesday to drop its opposition to forgiving debts owed by Poland and other Eastern European countries. The United States and other Western nations should write off at least a portion of the debt to help the ailing economies of countries emerging from four decades of communist rule, lawmakers said.

The stock market drifted through a mixed session Wednesday. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials slipped 0.68 to 2,732.88, while advancing issues slightly outnumbered declines. Bond prices fell despite another well-received round in the Treasury's three-part quarterly refunding auction. The dollar fell sharply and gold rose. Energy futures surged amid concerns that gasoline and crude oil inventories would be tight in the near term. Grains and soybeans were mostly higher, precious metals futures gained slightly; copper advanced and livestock and pork gained.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Congress to Convene Emergency Deficit-Cutting Summit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 24th graf pvs `Senate Minority ...' with 1 graf to UPDATE with Dole appointments.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and congressional leaders announced plans Wednesday for emergency budget talks to cut up to $100 billion from a rapidly worsening federal deficit. Tax increases as well as spending cuts will be on the negotiating table. ``Severe action'' is needed to avoid the huge automatic cuts that would be triggered throughout federal programs if deficit-reduction targets are not met next fall, said presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. ``The leadership in the House and the Senate ... has accepted the president's invitation'' to a budget summit with no preconditions, declared House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash. Negotiators for the House, Senate and White House will meet for the first time next Tuesday at the White House, said Fitzwater. Bush will chair the first session. After that, he ``will be involved as necessary,'' Fitzwater said. The spokesman blamed increasing interest rates, lower revenues to the Treasury from a sluggish economy and a higher-than-expected cost of the savings and loan bailout for the widening deficit gap. Internal administration estimates suggest that the government will miss deficit-reduction targets next fall by up to $100 billion, Fitzwater said. ``While the numbers aren't clear, it does seem clear to the legislative leaders as well as the administration that severe action needs to be taken to reduce the deficit and keep the economy on a sound track,'' he said in announcing the budget talks. Although a ``no new taxes'' pledge was a central part of Bush's 1988 campaign, deteriorating economic conditions now make massive spending cuts likely next fall in the absence of major deficit-cutting action, administration officials say. Neither White House officials nor congressional leaders would predict whether tax increases might be included in an ultimate compromise _ or what kind or size they might be if included. However, there seemed a growing feeling on all sides that deficit reductions of the magnitude now being discussed could not be achieved through budget cuts alone. No timetables or deadlines were set, but House Minority Leader Bob Michel, R-Ill., said he hoped for ``some real significant progress'' before Congress' Fourth of July recess. ``No decisions have been made other than to begin discussions next week on what we hope will be a good faith effort to deal with a very serious national problem,'' Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said. Seriousness was more evident than optimism. Senate Republican leader Bob Dole of Kansas said in a Senate speech, ``I think we're prepared to succeed, but we may not succeed.'' He said coming up with a long-elusive bipartisan budget agreement was ``like putting Humpty-Dumpty together again.'' Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., the chairman of the tax-drafting House Ways and Means Committee, pointed to political differences among the negotiators and said, ``I don't think we're going to be able to come up with anything out of this group.'' The budget summit _ proposed by Bush earlier in the week _ was annunced after top congressional leaders met with the president for about an hour. Foley named House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., an outspoken critic of Bush administration policies, as leader of the House negotiating team. ``I expect that we're going to proceed in good faith with these discussions and we're not going to attempt to politicize them on either side,'' Foley said. Some Democrats have voiced concerns that the administration may be trying to trap them into advocating election-year tax increases, but Foley said: ``I trust the White House until I have reason not to. And I have no reason not to.'' Foley said other House Democratic negotiators are Rep. William H. Gray III, D-Pa., the assistant majority leader, as well as Reps. Rostenkowski of Illinois, Jamie Whitten of Mississippi and Leon Panetta of California, the Democratic chairmen of the Ways and Means, Appropriations and Budget committees, respectively. Michel of Illinois named Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the assistant minority leader, and the ranking Republicans on those same three tax-writing and finance committees, Bill Archer of Texas, Silvio O. Conte of Massachusetts, and Bill Frenzel of Minnesota. Mitchell said Sen. Wyche Fowler, D-Ga., would be his personal representative to the talks, along with Sens. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, and James Sasser, D-Tenn., the chairmen of Appropriations, Finance and Budget respectively. Senate Minority Leader Dole named Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas, as his representative, with Sens. Mark O. Hatfield, R-Ore., Bob Packwood, R-Ore., and Pete V. Domenici, R-N.M., also of Appropriations, Finance and Budget. The White House announced that, in addition to Bush, who will sit in on the talks from time to time, its negotiators would be Budget Director Richard Darman, Chief of Staff John Sununu and Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady. Fitzwater said repeated use of the ``no preconditions'' term ``indicates and symbolizes an attitude and a spirit of achieving an end result that is good government void of the normal political posturing, politics and perceptions.'' The administration hopes any compromise would cover several years, address some of the president's proposals for overhauling the congressional budget process and not undermine economic growth. ``The wrong kind of tax measures could adversely effect economic growth,'' said Budget Director Richard Darman. Despite repeated efforts by Congress and the administration to reduce the deficit over the past decade, this year's shortfall may rise to nearly $200 billion. The Gramm-Rudman budget balancing law calls for a $100 billion deficit this year and for a $64 billion in fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1.

DOC.HEAD: Building Materials Company President Elected Chairman
DOC.TEXT: Eugene B. Connolly, president and chief executive of USG Corp., will succeed Robert J. Day as chairman of the building-materials maker, the company said Wednesday. Day will continue as chairman until his retirement on May 31. USG's directors elected Anthony J. Falvo Jr., currently executive vice president and chief operating officer, as president. Connolly will retain the chief executive post. Falvo will remain chief operating officer. Connolly, 58, began his career with United States Gypsum Co., now a USG subsidiary, in 1958 as a sales representative. He moved up through the ranks holding key management positions in a number of subsidiary companies. Connolly has served as president and chief executive of United States Gypsum, USG Interiors Inc. and DAP Inc. USG is a Fortune 500 company headquartered in Chicago. Its subsidiaries include United States Gypsum, USG Interiors, DAP, L&W Supply Corp. and CGC Inc.

DOC.HEAD: HBJ Terminates Sale Talks
DOC.TEXT: The textbook publishing and insurance concern Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. said Wednesday it has terminated discussions on selling some of its assets and public debt. Former U.S. Sen. Eugene McCarthy, who has served for a decade on HBJ's board, has previously said the company was holding talks with The Thomson Corp., a Canadian company that owns newspapers, other publishing interests and a travel business. Harcourt, which has been struggling under a huge debt incurred in avoiding a takeover in 1987, acknowledged last month that it was in talks but did not identify who it was talking to or what was being discussed. Thomson offered no comment on the reports. On Wednesday, Harcourt said the talks had involved acquisition of ``certain limited assets of HBJ by a third party and the purchase of some or all of HBJ's existing public debt at a discount'' from book value. HBJ incurred a $2 billion debt through a recapitalization that it undertook as it resisted a hostile 1987 takeover bid by British publisher Robert Maxwell. Last year, Harcourt sold its theme parks business for about $1.1 billion _ below what some analysts expected the company would get _ in an effort to reduce debt. But Moody's Investors Service, the credit rating agency, lowered the company's debt rating in February and said the company's cash flow from publishing and insurance ``will provide only narrow coverage'' of anticipated interest payments and capital expenses coming due shortly. Within three years, Harcourt is to start paying hundreds of millions of dollars more in annual dividends and interest to bondholders. Moody's said those obligations will ``likely necessitate further asset sales and-or debt restructuring.''

DOC.HEAD: Unisys Reorganizes Mainframe Operation
DOC.TEXT: Unisys Corp. said it has combined its mainframe and open-system operations into one department and named Cyril Yansouni president of the unit and executive vice president of the computer company. ``Our mainframes and open systems are becoming increasingly interdependent as we create in the 1990s the seamless cooperative network computing environment that will provide total solutions users want,'' James A. Unruh, Unisys president and chief executive officer, said Wednesday. ``Uniting our mainframe and open-systems product units under one organization ... will further enhance our ability to continue to develop state-of-the-art mainframes, add open attributes to them and transfer mainframe functionally to our open-systems products,'' Unruh said. Unisys also announced that all Blue Bell-based marketing operations _ United States Information Systems, Pacific Asia Americas Division and Corporate Marketing _ would report to Reto Braun, who was named an executive vice president of the corporation. ``The result will be a more efficient, coordinated and focused approach to providing computer users with total solutions that enhance current investments and capitalize on the advantages of open cooperative network computing,'' Unruh said. Yansouni had been president of the company's network computing group and a corporate senior vice president. Braun had been president of Pacific Asia Americas Division, a position he retains, and a corporate senior vice president.

DOC.HEAD: Cost Of Living Increased 11.4 Percent In April; Smallest Increase In Five
DOC.TEXT: The cost of living increased by 11.4 percent in April, sharply down from the previous month's 95.5 percent leap, the Economy Ministry announced. The April figure was the lowest monthly cost-of-living increase since last November's 6.5 percent. It left inflation over the previous 12 months at 16,903.2 percent, and 251.8 percent for the year to date. Officials on Wednesday attributed the sharp April decline to a severe anti-inflationary adjustment to economic policy put into effect by the 10-month-old government of President Carlos Menem. Planning Secretary Moises Ikonicoff said the April decline ``confirmed a tendency toward stabilization initiated in the second half of March'' and predicted the May inflation rate would be even lower than April's. Carlos Carballo, undersecretary of economy, said the April decline in inflation indicated that ``public finances are under control.'' A return to hyperinflation experienced from December through March ``is little short of impossible,'' he added. The cost of living rose 40.1 percent in December, 79.2 percent in January, and 61.6 percent in February. The 12-month inflation figure hit a high of 20,266 percent in March. In its recent policy adjustment, the government sharply reduced the money supply, halting the practice of printing money to finance deficit spending by public companies and other government entities. Earlier, Economy Minister Antonio Ernan Gonzalez removed exchange controls, allowing the local currency to float against the dollar, and sharply increased public utility rates and fuel prices. Menem, a 59-year-old lawyer and former provincial governor, has pledged to spur economic growth by balancing the budget, selling money-losing state companies, deregulating monopolies, ending subsidies, lowering trade barriers, reforming the tax code and eliminating corruption. Economic policy has been criticized by organized labor, which charges that real wages have fallen 50 percent below the average for the 1980s and claims that privatization will lead to loss of jobs and benefits as well as national patrimony.

DOC.HEAD: Entertainment Weekly Buys 7 Days Name, Subscriber File
DOC.TEXT: Time Warner Inc.'s Entertainment Weekly magazine said it has purchased the name and subscription file of 7 Days magazine, the New York arts and entertainment weekly that folded recently. Terms of the deal were not disclosed Wednesday. Publisher Michael Klingensmith said 7 Days' 20,000 subscribers would be offered the chance to receive Entertainment Weekly to fulfill the remaining portion of the subscriptions. If they decline, he said they would get refunds. In addition, Klingensmith said the 7 Days name and trademark might be used in connection with regional or metropolitian editions being considered for Entertainment Weekly. ``The 7 Days trademark is well established and we had tremendous respect for the magazine editorially,'' he said. ``It's a name which we feel has many possible applications for Entertainment Weekly, both in the New York market and elsewhere.'' Entertainment Weekly was launched in February and offers reviews and stories on movies, music, television, books and home video. It has a circulation of 600,000 nationally. 7 Days reported on the New York arts and entertainment scene for two years before it was closed earlier this year because of difficulties attracting advertising in what has been a very soft market.

DOC.HEAD: Arco Chemical Plans To Spend Billions to Increase Capacity
DOC.TEXT: Arco Chemical said Wednesday it would invest about $2.5 billion over the next five years to increase capacity to make propylene oxide. ``Today, we are moving forward with our plans to add about 1 billion pounds of propylene oxide capacity by 1994, for a total of 4 billion pounds,'' Harold A. Sorgenti, president and chief executive officer, said at the company's annual meeting. The expansion will include building a new plant in Channelview, Texas, completing a joint venture in South Korea and expanding the company's facility at Fos-sur-mer, France, he said. Propylene oxide is used in the manufacture of products including seat cushions, pet foods, antifreeze and perfume. Since 1985, Arco Chemical has increased sales from $1.6 billion to $2.7 billion, improved net income from $89 million to $405 million and expanded foreign operations, Sorgenti said. Foreign sales now account for 44 percent of revenues, he said. Sorgenti said Arco is sensitive to public concern about the environment. He told stockholders the company had adopted 10 performance-based principles developed by the Chemical Manufacturers Association and joined with other manufacturers to form a national company to recycle polystyrene plastics. Arco intends to reduce air emissions at the company's plants by 85 percent, he said, and reduce other waste generated by nearly 40 percent from 1986 levels by the end of 1992. Sorgenti said the company expects continued strong growth in demand for MTBE, an octane-enhancer for gasoline that also helps reduce auto emissions.

DOC.HEAD: Government Says It's `A Case About Fraud'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `Pollack began ...' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with later statements, defense to state its case Thursday; picks up 8th graf pvs, `Pollack devoted ...'
DOC.TEXT: The government's prosecution of three commodity traders is simply ``a case about fraud,'' a federal prosecutor said Wednesday at the first trial resulting from an FBI probe at the world's largest futures exchanges. Assistant U.S. Attorney Mark Pollack cautioned the jury in opening remarks at the U.S. District Court trial not to be distracted by the unfamiliar rules and intricate mechanics of futures trading. ``These are not complicated crimes,'' Pollack said. ``These are simple crimes that occurred in a complex setting.'' ``Stripped to its barest essentials, the evidence will demonstrate that this is a case about fraud,'' he said. Defendants Robert D. Mosky, Danny L. Scheck and David Zatz are accused of defrauding public customers as they traded Swiss franc futures at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. They are the first to go on trial of 47 traders and a clerk indicted last year after an unprecedented FBI sting operation at the Merc and the Chicago Board of Trade _ the world's two largest commodity futures exchanges. Defense lawyers were to make their opening statements Thursday morning, followed by the first prosecution witness, an official of the federal Commodity Futures Trading Commission. The CFTC regulates futures trading. Pollack began his opening statement after 12 jurors and five alternates were chosen in a morning session before U.S. District Judge Ann C. Williams. The three defendants were ``motivated by greed, pure and simple,'' he said. ``A thief who plies his trade in the guise of a bright trading jacket and uses a deck of customer orders is no less a thief than a common cat burglar,'' the prosecutor said. Pollack devoted much of his statement to explaining the basics of futures trading. Educating the jury could prove a daunting task in the trial, expected to last about six weeks. The prosecutor also told jurors they would hear conversations about illegal trading, secretly recorded by FBI agent Randall Jannett, who posed as a corrupt trader. Among the recorded comments the jury will hear, Pollack said, is a statement Mosky allegedly made to Jannett that ``good things happen to those who help out.'' Pollack said Mosky made the remark after Jannett agreed to a trade that deprived a customer of ``a profit opportunity.'' ``That phrase ... captures the essence of what this case is all about,'' Pollack said. ``I'll help you, you help me, we'll each make money at the expense of the unwitting customer.'' Mosky faces charges of racketeering conspiracy, 28 counts of mail or wire fraud and 51 counts of violating federal futures-trading rules. If convicted on all counts, he could be sentenced to 415 years in prison and fined $12.4 million. Zatz and Scheck are charged with more than a dozen counts each of mail or wire fraud and trading violations. They face maxiumum sentences of 70 years and 90 years in prison and fines of $2.1 million and $3 million, respectively. Sixteen of those indicted have pleaded guilty to reduced charges in return for their cooperation. The government's case hinges on the testimony of two traders who worked with the defendants and have pleaded guilty to fraud charges, and on the observations and tape-recorded evidence gathered by Jannett. A Swiss franc future is a contract to buy or sell a specified amount of the currency at a future date at a price agreed upon in advance. Banks and multinational businesses trade currency futures as insurance against foreign exchange losses. Futures contracts also are traded by speculators seeking to profit from the constantly changing prices.

DOC.HEAD: Film Producer Grimaldi Sues Pathe, Time Warner Over MGM-UA Deal
DOC.TEXT: Producer Alberto Grimaldi sued Time Warner Inc., MGM-UA Communications Co. and Pathe Communications Corp. Wednesday, claiming the three companies have entered into a fraudulent movie distribution deal. The class-action suit, filed in New York Federal Court, maintains that Pathe's acquisition of MGM-UA and Pathe's subsequent distribution deal with Time Warner will deny Grimaldi fees generated by his more 23 films in the MGM-UA library. Grimaldi is the producer of ``For a Few Dollars More,'' ``The Good, the Bad and the Ugly'' and ``Last Tango in Paris,'' among other films. He claims the deal would leave MGM-UA with insufficient funds to compensate profit participants of the films in the studio's library. Pathe launched its $1.27 billion acquisition of MGM-UA in March. In April, Pathe announced that Time Warner would provide $650 million to help finance the acquisition. In exchange, Time Warner, parent company of Warner Bros., received distribution rights to future and current Pathe and United Artists films. Warner Bros. also is named as a defendant in the suit. Grimaldi, an Italian citizen, believes Time Warner will receive an excessive share _ up to 75 percent _ of the net receipts generated by the exploitation of the MGM-UA library. In his suit, he asks that Pathe's deal with Time Warner either be rescinded or modified and asks for damages of not less than $50,000. Grimaldi said in an interview that he is hopeful other filmmakers with films in the MGM-UA library will join him in the suit. Grimaldi said he had asked Pathe to return his films to him but the studio declined. ``I don't object to Pathe buying MGM-UA as long as MGM-UA remains a healthy company,'' he said. The lawsuit alleges breach of contract, interference with contractual relations, racketeering and violations of the Debtor and Creditor Law. Theodore J. Cohen, Pathe's executive vice president and general counsel, said, ``Pathe has the intention of creating a strong, unified and viable company that will honor the obligations of all its constituents. Time Warner's involvement will serve to strengthen the enterprise.'' A telephone call to Time Warner's offices in New York was not answered and a phone message left with MGM-UA was not returned immediately.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney General Intervenes in Newspaper Dispute
DOC.TEXT: The state of Florida moved Wednesday to join the St. Petersburg Times in a legal battle over stock dividends with a shareholder group led by Texas billionaire Robert M. Bass. Attorney General Bob Butterworth filed a motion to intervene in U.S. District Court in Tampa, saying he wanted to help fend off an ``attack by profiteers.'' His action fulfilled a promise in March to join the Times in the case. The Bass group, known as the Poynter-Jamison Ventures Limited Partnership, filed suit in February against the Times Publishing Co. and the Poynter Institute, a non-profit journalism school that uses Times stock dividends to support its operations. The Bass group owns 40 percent of the company's voting stock but receives only 5.7 percent of its dividends. The Poynter Institute owns a majority of the voting stock and receives 83 percent of the dividends by virtue of its control of most of the company's preferred stock. The Bass group wants to change the stock structure to get a better return on its investment. Times Publishing defends the stock arrangement as beneficial to the journalistic standards of the newspaper and the health of Poynter Institute. ``The relief sought by the Ventures partners would significantly diminish the future resources of the Poynter Institute,'' Butterworth said. ``The Attorney General has determined that it is important to Florida public policy to protect such arrangements from attack by profiteers.'' Also, Butterworth said, he wanted to send a message ``to reassure those persons who desire to give money to charities that their request and wishes will be honored by the state of Florida, and that the state will not permit charitable bequests to be usurped by outside speculators and interlopers.'' The Bass group includes relatives of the late Nelson Poynter, who founded the Institute and set up the unusual stock arrangement.

DOC.HEAD: National Intergroup Says Earnings Up 26 Percent
DOC.TEXT: National Intergroup Inc. said its fiscal fourth-quarter earnings increased 26 percent, in part because of the sale of aluminum assets. National Intergroup, which owns steel, drug-distribution and retail interests, said Tuesday it earned $3.4 million, or 9 cents a share, on sales of $752.8 million in the three months ending March 31. That was up from earnings of $2.7 million, or 6 cents a share, on sales of $663.8 million in the year-earlier period. National Intergroup said it made $7.1 million in the latest quarter from sales of aluminum assets, including the discontinued National Aluminum interest. The company is in the process of selling its metals business to concentrate on wholesale distribution, primarily of pharmaceuticals. It agreed two weeks ago to sell a 40 percent stake in National Steel Corp. to NKK Corp. of Japan for $294 million. In the fiscal year ending March 31, National Intergroup said it earned $55.7 million, or $2.31 a share, compared with a loss of $15.7 million, or 98 cents a share, in the preceding year. Sales rose to $2.8 billion from $2.3 billion.
